webTitle: Food sellers face beefed up EU regulations on hygiene

fields.headline: Food sellers face beefed up EU regulations on hygiene
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: Britain's 520,000 food outlets, from supermarkets to the smallest sandwich bar or burger van, will have to prove they know basic hygiene rules under a tougher food safety regime demanded by the European commission.
fields.body:
Britain's 520,000 food outlets, from supermarkets to the smallest sandwich bar or burger van, will have to prove they know basic hygiene rules under a tougher food safety regime demanded by the European commission.

New businesses will face extra bills of between £200 and £1,000 to gain a licence to trade while existing operators will be also checked to ensure they meet the standards before being formally registered by local environmental health officers.

The government's food standards agency, which is already introducing compulsory licensing for 12,000 butchers this autumn, will draw up plans to spread the system throughout the food industry under a shake up of EU rules demanded by health and consumer protection commissioner David Byrne.

The new regime may not be enforced until 2004 but Britain's food regulators welcomed its main proposals, which include extra duties on even the smallest retailers to check for bacterial contamination, and maintain proper freezing and cooking equipment.

The requirements seem certain to provoke strong reactions from the food industry who fought off extra levies to help fund inspection procedures when the agency was being established.

But the meat industry will welcome other rule changes which will reduce the need for vets to be present during slaughter in abattoirs and allow trained meat inspectors to be there instead. This should cut costs.

Mr Byrne brushed aside suggestions he was adding red tape to the food business and insisted individual member states would be given some flexibility on the way they introduced new rules. "We have learned our lesson from the food crises of the 90s... Food operators large and small will find this simplified and transparent set of rules easier to apply.

"They give them greater responsibility for making sure food is safe, while leaving them more freedom and flexibility in deciding how to achieve that in their own premises."

Outlets and owners would face penalties of up to £5,000 or imprisonment if they neglected their responsibilities.

fields.headline: Waco inquiry clears FBI
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration has been exonerated for its handling of the ending of the 1993 siege at Waco for the second time in a week, but the emphatic findings are unlikely to satisfy conspiracy theorists.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration has been exonerated for its handling of the ending of the 1993 siege at Waco for the second time in a week, but the emphatic findings are unlikely to satisfy conspiracy theorists.

The inquiry by special counsel John Danforth, a former Republican senator from Missouri who has been mentioned as a possible presidential running mate for George W Bush, concludes "with 100% certainty" that the federal government and FBI agents were innocent of wrongdoing in the 51-day siege and the subsequent fire, in which at least 80 members of the Branch Davidian cult died.

The Danforth inquiry preliminary findings come exactly one week after a Texas jury dismissed allegations by relatives of the dead Davidians that the government was responsible.

Mr Danforth declared that FBI agents did not start the fire. He also found that government agents did not shoot at the blazing building, as Davidian supporters allege, did not misuse the armed forces in ending the siege, and did not engage in a cover-up.

He acknowledged that some justice department and FBI employees had failed to disclose the fact that teargas canisters had been fired near the Davidian compound - a fact which only came to light last year, and which prompted the attorney general, Janet Reno, to set up the this latest inquiry.

Yesterday's findings - coming on top of last week's jury ruling - are a victory for Ms Reno, who has been vilified by rightwingers and Republican politicians for her handling of the siege.

fields.headline: Chief constable attacks jail system
fields.trailText: A senior police officer last night strongly criticised the prison service for freeing a double killer who later murdered a teenage prostitute.
fields.body:
A senior police officer last night strongly criticised the prison service for freeing a double killer who later murdered a teenage prostitute.

In a savage attack on the role of the prison authorities, the West Midlands chief constable, Edward Crew, called for an urgent review after Paul Brumfitt was released after serving 15 years of a life jail term for killing two men.

Brumfitt, 44, was yesterday jailed for life at Birmingham crown court for murdering a 19-year-old prostitute, Marcella Davis, whose body he dismembered and burnt, and for raping another prostitute following his release from prison in 1994.

In a statement released after the verdicts, Mr Crew said: "Apart from the massive cost of police investigations, it seems inconceivable that a man who has previously been convicted for a litany of offences since 1968, including two counts of manslaughter and wounding for which he re ceived three life sentences, can still be allowed to wander around the streets."

Brumfitt, a landscape gardener, of Dudley, west Midlands, was caught after detectives called in forensic experts, anthropologists and archaeologists to try to identify tiny shards of skeleton found in the embers of a fire at his yard in Wolverhampton. It was not known how Miss Davis died.

The prison service said yesterday it was conducting a wide-ranging review into parole board procedures.

webTitle: Prescott takes a swipe at Blair's pollster

fields.headline: Prescott takes a swipe at Blair's pollster
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: John Prescott took a swipe at Tony Blair's circle of advisers yesterday when he criticised the prime minister's polling guru whose leaked memos have embarrassed Downing Street.
fields.body:
John Prescott took a swipe at Tony Blair's circle of advisers yesterday when he criticised the prime minister's polling guru whose leaked memos have embarrassed Downing Street.

Speaking after the prime minister rallied to the defence of Philip Gould, Mr Prescott said he never bothered to take any notice of the pollster.

Asked on the Today programme whether he agreed with Mr Gould's remark in his most recently leaked memo that the New Labour "brand" had been contaminated, the deputy prime minister laughed before replying: "No."

Showing his disdain for Mr Gould, who is loathed by virtually everyone in the Labour party outside the Blair inner circle, Mr Prescott added: "All that glitters isn't Gould. I am not a great fan of that kind of talk."

Mr Prescott's criticism of Mr Gould came less than 24 hours after the prime minister mounted a strong defence of his pollster, who has warned that "something has gone seriously wrong" with New Labour.

Speaking on his way to the G8 summit in Japan, Mr Blair said: "For goodness sake, he's an adviser. People write notes that are designed to challenge - and quite right too. There is froth and there is reality and in the end the froth will be blown away."

However, Mr Prescott's remarks show that ministers outside the immediate Blair circle are hoping that Downing Street's embarrassment over the leaks will undermine the position of Mr Gould. Mr Prescott's thoughts were echoed on Thursday, in rather more diplomatic terms, by Gordon Brown, who dismissed the Gould memos as "ephemeral things".

Insisting that he would never adopt Mr Gould's language and refer to New Labour as a brand, the chancellor told the Today programme: "People do not expect us to spend our time reading memos like this. I am not going to be diverted by short term memos. I have not read this memo and I do not understand all of these terms."

His remarks show how Mr Prescott and Mr Brown hope that Mr Gould has been weakened by the series of embarrassing leaks. Mr Gould, who boasts of visiting Downing Street three times a day, epitomises for non-Blairites what Mr Prescott referred to as the "beautiful people" who hover around the prime minister.

One Labour source, who is close to a senior minister, said that Mr Gould had become a liability for the party. "Gould's focus groups have become something of a joke in the party," the source said.

"Professional pollsters are critical of his style because he intervenes in focus group meetings and argues on behalf of the government. That defeats the entire purpose of focus groups which is to listen to what people say."

fields.headline: Railtrack fined over death
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack was fined £200,000 yesterday for a blunder that killed a passenger whose head was struck by scaffolding as he leaned out of a train window.
fields.body:
Railtrack was fined £200,000 yesterday for a blunder that killed a passenger whose head was struck by scaffolding as he leaned out of a train window.

The fine, imposed by Judge David Martineau at Blackfriars crown court in London, was the highest levied against Railtrack for a health and safety offence. The judge said the incident followed "a total failure" by Railtrack and BCM Construction, a scaffolding company, to follow standards laid down half a century ago.

The scaffolding was not the requisite minimum of 22in from the side of the train, the clearance between passing carriages and the pole on which David Brown struck his head.

The court heard that Mr Brown, 35, from Weavering Street, near Maidstone, Kent, was killed after he leaned out of the window at Denmark Hill, south London, and was hit by the scaffolding.

webTitle: Renegade ups ante in secrets war

fields.headline: Renegade ups ante in secrets war
fields.standfirst:
Former MI5 officer says he is coming home after latest embarrassing defeat for ministers
Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Yesterday's judgment is the latest in a string of defeats for government lawyers in their increasingly desperate attempt to silence the MI5 renegade, David Shayler, and other whistleblowers from the security and intelligence agencies. More embarrassments will follow.
fields.body:
Yesterday's judgment is the latest in a string of defeats for government lawyers in their increasingly desperate attempt to silence the MI5 renegade, David Shayler, and other whistleblowers from the security and intelligence agencies. More embarrassments will follow.

The decision by one of his colleagues, Jestyn Thirkell-White, to speak out in today's Guardian is a warning to the agencies that their former employees are no longer prepared to keep mum.

But Shayler remains the immediate cause of their serious concern. After obtaining an assurance from his lawyer that the crown prosecution service will not oppose bail, he told the Guardian last night he intends to return to Britain before the end of August.

Neither MI5 nor MI6 are relishing the prospect of a high profile criminal trial where the allegations of a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy, and other items of the agencies' dirty linen will be exposed in court.

If appeal court judges are prepared to stand up for exposing allegations of misdeeds by the agencies in the way Lord Justice Judge did yesterday, what will be the attitude of an Old Bailey jury?

There are serious doubts within the government and MI5 about the wisdom of a trial. Any prosecution under the Official Secrets Act requires the consent of the attorney general, Lord Williams. Yet a decision not to prosecute Shayler would be tantamount to saying that the act is null and void.

Though government lawyers privately believe the act is incompatible with the Human Rights Act, which comes into force on October 2, they are not prepared to say so publicly and certainly do not want the Shayler case to kill it off.

Shayler yesterday upped the ante by sending letters to every MP in which he says he is returning to Britain "because I am a patriot not a traitor". He adds: "I believe in my country and its long tradition of parliamentary democracy and respect for the law. In this vein, I shall be submitting my evidence of the MI6-funded plot to assassinate Colonel Gadafy of Libya to the Intelligence and Security Committee, hopefully in person so I can also be examined on it. I have nothing to hide."

He added: "With my presence once again on British soil ... it will be increasingly difficult to ignore these issues ... I am returning to instigate open and informed debate, which cannot take place while I remain in France."

A trial will prompt memories that Tony Blair and Jack Straw, the home secretary, among others now in government, opposed the Official Secrets Act when they were on the opposition front bench when the statute passed through the Commons in 1989.

It will come in the wake of the government's failure to extradite Shayler from Paris after a French judge dismissed the move as politically-inspired. It will also follow a UN report calling for sweeping reforms of the security services and an end to gagging orders on whistleblowers who expose wrongdoing in MI5 and MI6. In words echoing those of the judges yesterday, the author of the UN report noted that the secrets act "is used to stifle legitimate debate and to penalise writers and journalists who refuse to reveal their sources".

Covert surveillance

The government faces the prospect of further embarrassment when Nigel Wylde, a former senior army officer, appears at the Old Bailey on November 20. He is a holder of the Queen's Gallantry Medal for defusing unexploded bombs in Northern Ireland.

He has been charged under the Official Secrets Act for passing information to the journalist, Tony Geraghty, about covert surveillance systems used by the army. In his book, The Irish War - which is still on sale in bookshops - Geraghty describes how the army's systems "provide total cover of a largely innocent population". Wylde's trial is likely to take place before Shayler's.

Lord Justice Judge yesterday went out of the way to emphasise the fundamental rights established through the centuries by English common law. However his point was addressed as much to the issue of self-incrimination as to freedom of expression.

Yesterday's judgment may herald a more liberal approach by the courts. It may also herald a more benevolent attitude towards former members of the security and intelligence agencies who blow the whistle.

What is certain is that the Wylde case is likely to provide the first concrete test of whether Britain's draconian secrets laws breach the Human Rights Act. The Ministry of Defence will be hard put to convince a jury that the disclosures damaged national security.

Meanwhile, the MoD is preventing the Sunday Times from disclosing allegations made by a former member of the Force Research Unit, an undercover army intelligence unit in Northern Ireland.

This week, Liam Clarke, the newspaper's Northern Ireland editor, was summoned for questioning by MoD police. The whistleblower has also been silenced. His house was burgled and the manuscript of a book he has written was stolen.

His allegations relate to the involvement of the FRU and one of its informants - Brian Nelson, a former member of the Ulster Defence Association jailed for conspiracy to commit murder - in supplying information to a loyalist paramilitary group.

At the last count, the MoD had obtained nine injunctions against former soldiers.

The ministry's concern about more unwelcome disclosures about the activities of the SAS and other special forces lies behind their fierce opposition to the publication of the memoirs of the former head of MI5, Dame Stella Rimington.

Though her book will in no way damage national security the MoD and MI6 argue it would be a dangerous precedent that would be used by other former members of the secret world. The concerns of MI6 may have led Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, to call on Dame Stella during a recent Commons debate "to think again" even though Jack Straw is responsible for MI5.

Liberals in Whitehall - and there are some - argue that time, and now the law, is on their side.

But not, it seems, until the government experiences some embarrassing secrets trials.

fields.headline: Bred in the bone
fields.standfirst:
Why freedom of speech is ingrained in English law
Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Lord Justice Judge delivered a ringing endorsement of press freedom - a principle, he said, which was deeply ingrained in English law. Indeed, he suggested lawyers who repeatedly referred to the European convention on human rights - incorporated in English law on October 2 by the human rights act - did not appreciate that the principles were already enshrined in English common law.
fields.body:
Lord Justice Judge delivered a ringing endorsement of press freedom - a principle, he said, which was deeply ingrained in English law. Indeed, he suggested lawyers who repeatedly referred to the European convention on human rights - incorporated in English law on October 2 by the human rights act - did not appreciate that the principles were already enshrined in English common law.

Freedom of speech and protection against self-incrimination were principles "bred in the bone of the common law and indeed, in some instances at any rate, the folk understanding of the community as a whole," he said.

The prospect of the police entering the premises of the Guardian and the Observer, reminded him of a passage written by the constitutional authority, Albert Dicey. "As a matter of general principle," observed Dicey, "with us individual rights are the basis not the result of the law of the constitution".

The judge referred to a case in 1765 - Entick v Carrington - when the king's "messengers" broke into a home of a resident of Stepney, east London, on a warrant from a secretary of state. "No man can set his foot upon my ground without my licence," said the then chief justice, Lord Camden. "Papers are the owner's goods and chattels... where private papers are removed and carried away, the secret nature of those goods will be an aggravation of the trespass... Where is the written law that gives any magistrate such a power? I can safely answer, there is none; and therefore it is too much for us without such authority to pronounce a practice legal, which would be subversive of all the comforts of society".

The judge yesterday referred to a peroration made about the same time by Pitt the Elder. "The poorest man may in his cottage bid defiance to all the forces of the crown," said Pitt. "It may be frail - its roof may shake - the wind may blow through it - the storm may enter - the rain may enter - but the king of England cannot enter - all his force dares not cross the threshold of the ruined tenement."

The words of Lord Camden and Pitt, continued the judge yesterday, were encapsulated in the phrase that "an Englishman's home is his castle".

Those principles, said the judge, were clearly understood in this country while an absolute monarch, still reigned in France. "If the Bourbon monarch, Louis XV, had heard of such language used by a prominent politician and former first minister [Pitt] the speaker's best hope would have been for the king to have assumed he was joking. But even that would not have prevented some fawning minion from despatching a lettre de cachet to ensure that he was locked up, indefinitely, and without trial.

"It is hardly surprising therefore that Voltaire, having twice been imprisoned in the Bastille, and eventually forced to live in exile, and notwithstanding what we can now appreciate were its great defects then, so greatly admired our constitution".

The judge moved to a more recent case, in 1981, when Mr Justice Watkins told the high court: "I am concerned with the fundamental freedom which this country has prided itself on maintaining, and for which much blood has been spilt over the centuries, namely freedom of speech".

The two principles reflected in the cases he cited were interlinked, said Lord Justice Judge. "Premises are not to be entered by the forces of authority or the state to deter or diminish, inhibit or stifle the exercise of an individual's right to free speech or the press of its freedom to investigate and inform...".

He added: "Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services or for public authorities should not be suppressed".

"If the Bourbon monarch, Louis XV, had heard of such language used by a prominent politician and former first minister [Pitt] the speaker's best hope would have been for the king to have assumed he was joking. But even that would not have prevented some fawning minion from despatching a lettre de cachet to ensure that he was locked up, indefinitely, and without trial. "It is hardly surprising therefore that Voltaire, having twice been imprisoned in the Bastille, and eventually forced to live in exile, and notwithstanding what we can now appreciate were its great defects then, so greatly admired our constitution". The judge moved to a more recent case, in 1981, when Mr Justice Watkins told the high court: "I am concerned with the fundamental freedom which this country has prided itself on maintaining, and for which much blood has been spilt over the centuries, namely freedom of speech". The two principles reflected in the cases he cited were interlinked, said Lord Justice Judge. "Premises are not to be entered by the forces of authority or the state to deter or diminish, inhibit or stifle the exercise of an individual's right to free speech or the press of its freedom to investigate and inform...". He added: "Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services or for public authorities should not be suppressed".

webTitle: Comment: Our rail system is a disgrace

fields.headline: Oh, Mr Prescott
fields.standfirst:
Our rail system is a disgrace. And throwing billions at it won't make a difference

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Our rail system is a disgrace. And throwing billions at it won't make a difference
fields.body:
John Prescott, the Lorenzo the Magnificent or the fat controller Sir Topham Hat (I nearly said Mussolini) of the railways, has promised a £60bn investment in the nation's tracks and trains. Spending will rise by more than 50% in real terms over the next 10 years. Passenger traffic will rise 50%, freight by 80%. There will be 6,000 new trains _ and money for safety, money for subsidy, money for Crossrail, money for the rich, money for the poor, money for speeding new trains faster than fairies, faster than witches along smooth welded tracks between hedges and ditches. Certainly faster than the last two Virgin "expresses" from Manchester Piccadilly that had me in Euston a long while after a London & North Western Railway express hauled by a Webb compound would have more than a century ago.

Much slower than a Jag, or two, guzzling gas down the M6. Perhaps the trains of the Prescott renaissance will even be as smart as those racing routinely across much of the rest of Europe today, running well and often on time.

Maybe. Like the rest of us who rely on but no longer like our degraded mainline railways and their sad, poorly designed, garishly painted trains, I can't help wondering who will be spending these riches on our behalf. Not Railtrack, surely. Which of us trusts this accident prone instrument of Thatcherite transport policy?

The Tories despised Britain's railways so much that not only did they privatise them in a manner no other national railway has followed, but they also gave serious consideration to Sir David Serpell's report of 1982 which recommended the railways be pruned to a "profitable core" of just 3,000 miles. The rest could be roads for ton-up plus, armour-plated ministerial limos for all the government cared.

There had been 18,000 miles of main-line railways in 1962, before Richard Beeching's infamous report for Sir Alec Douglas-Home's government that saw rural branch lines uprooted and a total of 7,500 miles of track abandoned. A half-cock "modernisation plan", implemented haphazardly from 1955 had meanwhile seen no great increase in speed or reliability, or at least not nearly great enough to counteract the effectiveness of new motorways and inter-city jets. The country's railways were not in a particularly good state at the time of the Beeching report, but nor had they been since the beginning of the first world war. Whether privately or publicly run, they were chronically underfunded and, with a few notable bursts of electrical energy (the Southern Railway under Sir Herbert Walker), stolid, old-fashioned and in constant danger of being undermined not by the exploitation of coal seams beneath the hammering wheels of their coal- powered trains, but by cars and planes.

Our recently privatised train operating companies are a very mixed bag. Would you trust billions of pounds of money from the public purse to companies that would get short shrift in Thomas the Tank Engine's fictional Isle of Sodor and shorter shrift still in Japan where the railways have been privatised fairly successfully? Probably not. So, who can we trust if not in Railtrack or the train companies? Stewart Francis, chairman of the Rail Passengers Council, says: "We need the right management, the right train companies, and the right regulation." Of course, of course. But who will ensure that you, I and Mr Francis gets these things? Sir Alastair Morton, perhaps, of Eurotunnel fame, and his Strategic Rail Authority (aka British Railways Board), but this has too little power, influence or money to keep our unruly pirate railways in check. And how can Sir Alastair convince us that the new breed of railway management is more genuinely interested in running railways than in talking US-management talk, inventing imaginative "remuneration packages" and handsome "retirement packages" for itself and patronising the rest of us by calling us "customers" and nurturing an annoying faux airline culture? Thomas has fewer troubles with his recalcitrant trucks than Sir Alastair may yet have with train companies more interested in the desires of shareholders than the needs of passengers.

It might be better if the railways were renationalised and one responsible, publicly accountable body was entrusted to spend the Prescott billions on improving trains and services. Our record, however, public or private, has been rather dismal over the past 80 years. Escaping nationalisation in the first world war, the railways were grouped into the "big four" (Great Western, Southern, London Midland & Scottish and London & North Eastern) and regulated as far as charging went by the Railway Rates Tribunal. Despite some glamorous escapades in terms of 100mph art deco steam streamliners and the Southern's steady electrification, the big four were hard pressed to turn a profit. They managed 2-3% on preference shares and then not every year. With the decline of heavy industry in the north-east, the LNER ("the Late and Never Early") failed to pay dividends between the wars. Its directors, despite braying "no to nationalisation" in public were secretly relieved when the state took control on January 1 1948.

Immediately before the creation of British Railways and its apocryphal sandwiches, the wartime coalition government considered a Railtrack-plus-the-big four type operation, but plumped for full nationalisation instead. Did this help? To an extent. Up until 1953 the heavily used railways made a profit, but modernisation, although sincere, was slow in coming.

The railways were hidebound and many of their best managers had refused to be nationalised. Even though labour was slowly raising its value, the railways relied on much technology based on the crude exploitation of skilled labour. Men were expected to perform grimy jobs that elsewhere, in the United States and Europe, had been mechanised.

Even so, by the time Mrs Thatcher did her worst, British Rail was turning itself, lock, stock and air-brake compressor, into a modern, commercially driven network, with strategically marketed sectors such as Inter-City turning a profit. The Railways Act of 1993, however, did for the railways and all thoughts of an integrated national transport network. A concupiscent drive for private gain among a new generation of directors and shareholders and a disturbing decline in the status, training and morale of staff - when were engine drivers last working-class heroes? - saw our railways reach a nadir, via Southall (September 1997) and Paddington (October 1999). Then John Prescott, with an eye on the next general election, announced his £60bn hand out. There are many of us who wouldn't trust a British train company to get us anywhere on time in any style in these islands. Oh, Mr Prescott, what shall we do?

fields.headline: Papers win Shayler MI5 case
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: The appeal court yesterday roundly dismissed attempts by the police and state prosecutors to order the Guardian and the Observer to hand over any information they may possess relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, including a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.
fields.body:
The appeal court yesterday roundly dismissed attempts by the police and state prosecutors to order the Guardian and the Observer to hand over any information they may possess relating to the former MI5 officer, David Shayler, including a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

In a ringing defence of press freedom and the newspapers' right to publish allegations by whistleblowers, Lord Justice Judge told the court: "Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services or for public authorities, should not be suppressed".

Otherwise, he said "legitimate inquiry and discussion" and the "safety valve of effective investigative journalism" would be "discouraged, perhaps stifled".

He pointed to what he called the alarming allegation that MI6 was involved in a failed plot to kill the Libyan leader in 1996 which led to the deaths of innocent bystanders, an allegation described by Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, as "pure fantasy".

If true, the judge said, it was difficult to overestimate its enormity. If false, the allegations were inevitably damaging. Yet their refutation was also a matter of public importance.

"Unless there are compelling reasons of national security, the public is entitled to know the facts and, as the eyes and ears of the public, journalists are entitled to investigate and report the facts..." said the judge.

The two principles of freedom of speech and the right of protection against self-incrimination, the judge said, were "bred in the bone of the common law", let alone established in the European convention on human rights.

"Premises are not to be entered into by the forces of authority or the state to deter or diminish, inhibit or stifle the exercise of an individual's right to free speech or the press of its freedom to investigate and inform," said the judge.

He criticised the failure of the police special branch to explain convincingly why they needed an emailed letter sent to the Guardian in February and any notes in the possession of Martin Bright, an Observer journalist, relating to Mr Shayler's allegations about the Gadafy plot.

Disclosure orders should be made only when there was "compelling evidence" in the public interest.

He also pointed to the prosecution's failure to give an undertaking that journalists on the newspapers, notably Mr Bright, would not be prosecuted under the Official Secrets Act if they handed over any material.

The judge was supported by Mr Justice Gibbs though the third member of the court, Mr Justice Maurice Kay, ruled against the newspapers.

Initially, all three judges said the Observer newspaper should provide the police with any copy of a letter Mr Shayler sent to Jack Straw, the home secretary, last year giving details about the Libyan plot. They dropped that demand when the newspaper said it would sign an affidavit saying it was not in its possession.

In a statement after the judgment, the newspapers said: "This is a judgment with profound implications for press freedom and shows that the Guardian and Observer were fully justified in fighting this case."

John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer and director of Liberty, the civil liberties group, said: "The court has taken a very important step to protect freedom of expression. I hope that government and law enforcement agencies take note."

Maurice Frankel, director of the freedom of information campaign, said: "The government wants weak rights for citizens but tough powers for the state. Labour politicians have spent most of their working lives promising to protect press freedom. They should not have allowed this application against the newspapers to have been made."

The Crown Prosecution Service is deciding whether to appeal to the House of Lords against yesterday's ruling.

Mr Shayler, speaking from Paris last night, said the judgment was long overdue. He said the government had given no indication that they intended to investigate his evidence.

fields.headline: Dome may need another bail-out
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The beleaguered Millennium Dome is expected to earn less than half of its forecast income, it was revealed yesterday, prompting fears that more National Lottery funding will be needed to bail out the attraction.
fields.body:
The beleaguered Millennium Dome is expected to earn less than half of its forecast income, it was revealed yesterday, prompting fears that more National Lottery funding will be needed to bail out the attraction.

The dome has raised only £85m in commercial income so far this year - less than half a predicted income revenue of £194m - because total spending by visitors is now expected to be less than half what was originally forecast.

The revelation was made in the third annual report of the company which runs the Greenwich site, the New Millennium Experience Company. It blamed the financial difficulties on the strong pound and "negative media coverage".

The report predicted that without a change in circumstances the dome was likely to need extra funding to remain open until the end of the year.

The warning came despite the award of £29m from the National Lottery in May, which came on top of the £496m of lottery funds already committed to the dome.

A source at the Millennium Commission - in charge of handing out lottery cash - said that it would be "politically difficult" for any further funds to be made available, but refused to rule out the possibility.

A spokesman for the NMEC said: "It is not our intention to ask for further money. At this stage we are confident we will achieve visitor targets, make the necessary cuts and get £30m from the legacy sale."

The NMEC's 74-page report revealed that the dome's total income over this year is now estimated to be £761m, with another £3m set aside to promote and market the attraction.

The significant reduction in the estimates of commercial income reflect the halving of the paying visitor target from 12m to 6m.

The accounts indicate that the original £399m of lottery money received by NMEC had now risen to a net figure of £525m, including the additional grants of £60m in February and £29m in May.

The company report, which covers the last nine months of 1999, also revealed details of the pay deals of senior staff. Jennie Page, the former chief executive, received severance pay of £178,983 - more than her annual £150,000 salary - when she was ousted in February, while the operations director, Ken Robinson, who resigned his £184,000 post in the same month, received a pay-off worth £147,025.

webTitle: Welsh assembly's debates utterly boring, says Morgan

fields.headline: Welsh assembly's debates utterly boring, says Morgan
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Wales
fields.trailText: The Welsh assembly has struggled to make its mark since last year's grand opening ceremony in Cardiff - and now we know why.
fields.body:
The Welsh assembly has struggled to make its mark since last year's grand opening ceremony in Cardiff - and now we know why.

Rhodri Morgan, Wales's first secretary, admitted yesterday that the assembly is so boring that viewing its proceedings is like "watching paint dry".

The outspoken Mr Morgan, who has devoted his career to fighting for devolution in Wales, blamed the calibre of assembly members and the limited powers of the new body for its dreary debates.

"Performance of the assembly has not been as punchy or as focused or as strong or as interesting for the people outside as I would have liked," Mr Morgan said in an interview with BBC News 24's One to One programme.

"The kind of secondary legislation that we have powers over, that we debate on a typical Tuesday or Wednesday afternoon, is like watching paint dry."

Mr Morgan's remarks will come as a surprise to Labour leaders, who have been impressed by his handling of the assembly after he replaced the Blair favourite Alun Michael as first secretary earlier this year. But the assembly has failed to make the same sort of mark as the Scottish parliament.

Mr Morgan puts this down to the limited powers devolved to Wales, which is an assembly rather than a parliament.

Devolution also never won the same support in Wales as it did in Scotland. The referendum in Wales was won on the votes of the final constituency. Only a quarter of the population voted for the assembly.

Mr Morgan also struck a seri ous note, when he warned that Britain's failure to join the euro risked deterring inward investors. "I think we would all say, 'This is one of those decisions where everybody wants to go to heaven, but nobody wants to die first'," Mr Morgan said. "So you say, in 10 years' time everybody thinks we will be in the euro, realistically."

webTitle: Second MI5 officer attacks security service

fields.headline: Second MI5 officer attacks security service
fields.standfirst:
Second MI5 officer joins attack on service

Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: A second MI5 officer, Jestyn Thirkell-White, has decided to speak out to the Guardian in the wake of attempts on behalf of MI5 to harass the press.
fields.body:
A second MI5 officer, Jestyn Thirkell-White, has decided to speak out to the Guardian in the wake of attempts on behalf of MI5 to harass the press.

He backs many of the allegations of mismanagement made by his former colleague, the renegade MI5 officer David Shayler.

"I think it is totally wrong that there has been no serious investigation into Shayler's allegations," he says. "Instead, the government has harassed his friends. I thought the arrest of his student supporter Julie Anne Davies, and another of his friends for so-called money laundering - he was never charged - was unjust and outrageous. It was totally disproportionate to the alleged offence. MI5 and special branch were acting like the very police state they are supposed to be protecting us from."

Mr Thirkell-White, who resigned from MI5 in 1996 and now works as a banker, says: "I do not accept Jack Straw's statements that Shayler's revelations have in any way damaged national security." This included Mr Shayler's claim that the sister overseas espionage organisation, MI6, had colluded in an assassination plot by opponents of Col Gadafy in Libya, and that Libyan intelligence officers had been active in London.

Mr Thirkell-White also agrees that the organisation has been in desperate need of reform and modernisation.

"When David went public, I expected an independent inquiry, because the allegations were serious enough to warrant proper investigation: instead, MI5 appointed a former deputy director, John Alpass, who was a friend and colleague of MI5 chief Steven Lander, to conduct a broad review of all three intelligence organisations - MI5, MI6 and GCQ. That was quite wrong."

Mr Thirkell-White and Mr Shayler served together in T Branch (anti-terrorism), where Mr Thirkell-White was trying to block flows of arms and money to the IRA from Eastern Europe and the US.

He backs up one of Mr Shayler's most seemingly bizarre allegations - that MI5 officers wasted vital hours in the search for IRA bombers dickering about the wording of warrants, because of bureaucratic "turf wars" with the police special branch.

MI5 had successfully seized control of anti-IRA operations from the police in the early 1990s, while searching for a new role at the end of the cold war.

"The endless redrafting was nothing to do with protecting people's civil liberties. MI5 were desperate to keep their new role and en sure the special branch could not regain that role. They were desperate to ensure the special branch could not point to any procedural mistake."

Mr Thirkell-White joined MI5 from Cambridge alongside Mr Shayler in 1991. Like him, he was startled to discover the archaic nature of the organisation. Officers still wrote out reports in longhand, for a secretary to draft and then retype after laborious corrections. "It was appallingly inefficient."

"A lot of officers were asked to write endless briefings, just to generate work. It was too hierarchical, and too many layers of management."

I thought the arrest of his student supporter Julie Anne Davies, and another of his friends for so-called money laundering - he was never charged - was unjust and outrageous. It was totally disproportionate to the alleged offence. MI5 and special branch were acting like the very police state they are supposed to be protecting us from." Mr Thirkell-White, who resigned from MI5 in 1996 and now works as a banker, says: "I do not accept Jack Straw's statements that Shayler's revelations have in any way damaged national security." This included Mr Shayler's claim that the sister overseas espionage organisation, MI6, had colluded in an assassination plot by opponents of Col Gadafy in Libya, and that Libyan intelligence officers had been active in London. Mr Thirkell-White also agrees that the organisation has been in desperate need of reform and modernisation. "When David went public, I expected an independent inquiry, because the allegations were serious enough to warrant proper investigation: instead, MI5 appointed a former deputy director, John Alpass, who was a friend and colleague of MI5 chief Steven Lander, to conduct a broad review of all three intelligence organisations - MI5, MI6 and GCQ. That was quite wrong." Mr Thirkell-White and Mr Shayler served together in T Branch (anti-terrorism), where Mr Thirkell-White was trying to block flows of arms and money to the IRA from Eastern Europe and the US. He backs up one of Mr Shayler's most seemingly bizarre allegations - that MI5 officers wasted vital hours in the search for IRA bombers dickering about the wording of warrants, because of bureaucratic "turf wars" with the police special branch. MI5 had successfully seized control of anti-IRA operations from the police in the early 1990s, while searching for a new role at the end of the cold war. "The endless redrafting was nothing to do with protecting people's civil liberties. MI5 were desperate to keep their new role and en sure the special branch could not regain that role. They were desperate to ensure the special branch could not point to any procedural mistake." Mr Thirkell-White joined MI5 from Cambridge alongside Mr Shayler in 1991. Like him, he was startled to discover the archaic nature of the organisation. Officers still wrote out reports in longhand, for a secretary to draft and then retype after laborious corrections. "It was appallingly inefficient." "A lot of officers were asked to write endless briefings, just to generate work. It was too hierarchical, and too many layers of management."

fields.headline: Israelis hint at shared Jerusalem
fields.standfirst:
Rightwing outrage greets Camp David compromise plan

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli ministers abandoned the sacred shibboleth of Jerusalem as the "undivided and eternal capital of the Jewish people" in a first tentative attempt to soften up their public for a compromise with the Palestinians on the most explosive topic at the Camp David summit in the US.
fields.body:
Israeli ministers abandoned the sacred shibboleth of Jerusalem as the "undivided and eternal capital of the Jewish people" in a first tentative attempt to soften up their public for a compromise with the Palestinians on the most explosive topic at the Camp David summit in the US.

In interviews, Rabbi Michael Melchior, a cabinet minister and part of Ehud Barak's public relations team at the summit, said the Israeli prime minister was considering a US formula for sharing sovereignty with the Palestinians in parts of Arab East Jerusalem, an nexed by the Jewish state after the 1967 war.

"We're talking about a US proposal which accepts the Israeli sovereignty over all of Jerusalem as an undivided city and has some signs of joint sovereignty, expanded self- administration, of some of the Arab Muslim quarters in the outskirts of Jerusalem," Mr Melchior told BBC television.

A senior Palestinian official spelled out more clearly than ever before last night that the Palestinians were ready to recognise Israeli sovereignty over West Jerusalem.

Hassan Abdel-Rahman, the PLO representative in Washington, said: "Our position remains _ that we recognise Is raeli full sovereignty over West Jerusalem in return for full Palestinian sovereignty over East Jerusalem."

That Mr Barak would even dare to consider such an idea represents the crumbling of a taboo. At the US presidential retreat this week, he became the first Israeli leader ever to discuss the city's future with the Palestinians - "an act from which there can be no return", the historian and former deputy mayor of the city, Meron Benvenisti, wrote in Ha'aretz newspaper.

Mr Melchior's statement - speedily denied by a member of the negotiating team at Camp David - follows a now familiar pattern in seven years of peace talks of deliberate leaks from Israeli politicians meant to gauge domestic public opinion to possible comprises.

In the scant details that emerged yesterday, the US formula appears virtually identical to proposals on sharing the city quietly put forward by liberal Israeli academics.

Although Israeli and Palestinian cartographers and academics have been quietly discussing ways of sharing the city for some time, in public, at least, Israeli politicians cling to the mantra that Jewish sovereignty over the entire city is an immutable fact.

"This is a kind of a breakthrough on Israel's systematic policies on the city," said Manuel Hassassian of Bethlehem university, who has been advising Palestinian representatives. "For Palestinians, such statements are encouraging."

But the statements caused immediate outrage among rightwing Israelis, who accuse Mr Barak of plotting to forsake the city they see as a biblical birthright.

It is unclear how a polarised Israeli public would greet an agreement that involved giving up land within city limits. Despite the collapse of Mr Barak's coalition on the eve of the summit, he soldiered on, claiming Israelis were with him.

But opinion polls in two Israeli newspapers yesterday suggest support for Mr Barak, and a negotiated peace, appears to be eroding. In a survey in Yediot Ahronot, 70% of those polled opposed the return of any part of east Jerusalem to the Palestinians.

However, a poll in the Ma'ariv newspaper found that even though the public was uneasy about Mr Barak's leadership, and the prospects of a lasting peace with the Palestinians, when push came to shove, some 45% would still vote in favour of a peace agreement in a referendum.

The US proposal hinges on expanding the limits of Jerusalem to take in Jewish settlements in the West Bank while offering the Palestinians control over municipal services in neighbourhoods in the north of the city.

It would stave off the most contentious questions about the city's future - control over the holy relics of Islam, Christianity and Judaism, within the old city walls - until a permanent settlement is reached.

However, Palestinians would be offered a passage to the al-Aqsa mosque - the third holiest Muslim shrine - perhaps via an underground tunnel beneath the Mount of Olives.

fields.headline: Virgin team highlights NHS shambles
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: A devastating report on squalor in hospitals and shambolic management paved the way yesterday for Tony Blair's announcement next week of the most fundamental reform of the NHS since its foundation in 1948.
fields.body:
A devastating report on squalor in hospitals and shambolic management paved the way yesterday for Tony Blair's announcement next week of the most fundamental reform of the NHS since its foundation in 1948.

Consultants from Richard Branson's Virgin group - called in to advise ministers on how to make hospitals more consumer friendly - blamed an over-centralised NHS bureaucracy for dirty wards, chaotic booking arrangements and general lack of consideration for patients.

"Within the service there is the impression of management by cascading paper, of ideas being passed down from above. The dead hand of bureaucracy seems to stifle imagination and flair and obscure responsibility," the Virgin team said in a confidential report to Alan Milburn, the health secretary.

After spending 26 days visiting nine hospitals, GP surgeries and minor injuries clinics, the Virgin managers said they found corridors strewn with cigarette ends, wards where nobody knew who was in charge and indifferent staff and managers who looked after their own interests better than those of patients.

They visited one NHS hospital where the chairman's office was as large as the casualty department - and better decorated.

The consultants observed: "As a matter of course, the patient is required to fit into the system rather than the other way around."

Although there was no evi dence of a deliberate leak from government, disclosure of the leaked report in yesterday's London Evening Standard served as a useful warm-up act before the prime minister launches his national plan for health on Thursday.

The plan will be more cautious about cutting hospital waiting times than ministers hoped when they started the review in March, but a lot more radical than they expected in redefining the relationship between NHS doctors, managers and the state. "We are putting right the bits that went wrong during the compromises made to set up the NHS in 1948," a source said.

Heads of the medical profession have been told to expect a shake-up of hospital doctors' conditions of employment, including annual appraisals, job plans, merit awards, performance payments and possible restrictions on private practice. At private meetings over the last few days ministers have told doctors' representatives that they would pursue the reforms "gently, but relentlessly".

Leaders of the big three royal colleges and British Medical Association are expected to support the aims of the national plan, but subsequent negotiation of the detail may be more tense.

Ministers will ignore some of the Virgin team's recom mendations. For example Virgin wanted patients to be examined quickly by a doctor on arrival at an accident and emergency department, but the national plan will divert non-critical patients to nurse-led minor injury clinics. The tone of the government's document is also likely to be more sympathetic than Virgin to the problems faced by hospital managers trying to put the patient first.

But the Department of Health said Mr Milburn was "taking the report extremely seriously" and its "criticisms of dirty and scruffy hospitals are expected to be targeted for action in the plan".

Other problems identified included:

Staff communicating with patients inefficiently, using letters rather than phone or email to book appointments;

Too much money being spent on bureaucracy, with one administrator employed for every two clinical staff;

Low staff morale, with workers more used to being criticised than praised.

But Stephen Thornton, the chief executive of the NHS Confederation, said: "I challenge the Virgin team to show me what they describe as a suffocating bureaucracy. Where on earth do they get ridiculous figures that imply there is one administrator to every two clinical staff?"

Of all NHS staff, only 3% were managers, compared to 44% nurses, 8% doctors, 17% clerical, he said, asking: "I wonder how many back-up staff it takes Virgin to get one pilot into the air?"

But he accepted that standards of cleaning had declined after years of cost cutting.

webTitle: Blair accused of waste as cost of running No 10 rises to £10.4m a year

fields.headline: Blair accused of waste as cost of running No 10 rises to £10.4m a year
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has admitted that Downing Street's running costs have risen by 50% since he took office, prompting Tory and Liberal Democrat claims that the prime minister is squandering taxpayers' money.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has admitted that Downing Street's running costs have risen by 50% since he took office, prompting Tory and Liberal Democrat claims that the prime minister is squandering taxpayers' money.

In a written parliamentary answer issued yesterday, the prime minister blamed an increase in the "administrative burdens" of his office for the increase in costs.

Mr Blair said that in his first year in Downing Street, his office cost £6.9m to run. The figure has since risen to £10.4m a year.

The prime minister defended the rise, saying that Downing Street had to take on extra staff after an 84% increase in letters sent to his office.

In the past year, Mr Blair has received 500,000 "items of correspondence", compared with 25,000 five years ago.

"Before coming to office the government clearly set out its aim to have a strong strategic centre of government," Mr Blair said. "Since May 1997 some of the administrative burdens of my office have greatly increased."

However, the Tories and Liberal Democrats rounded on the prime minister. Norman Baker, Liberal Democrat MP for Lewes, who tabled the question to the prime minister, said: "It seems the costs of Downing Street are spiralling out of control. No doubt the prime minister needs this extra bank of spin doctors to explain why pensioners only received a 75p rise."

Mr Baker added that the increased costs were symptomatic of the government's weaknesses. "Tony Blair should shave down No 10 and show some humility. This is New Labour, new megalomania."

Andrew Lansley, the Tory cabinet office spokesman, said that the government was costing more and delivering less. "Tony Blair has obviously been forced to pump yet more taxpayers' money into dealing with the rising tide of dissatisfaction with his government's failure to deliver on its promises and its obsession with spin over substance," he said.

webTitle: Not a crumb from G7 table

fields.headline: Not a crumb from G7 table
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The world's seven richest industrialised nations yesterday failed to agree any new proposals to breathe life into their flagging plans to relieve the third world's debt burden.
fields.body:
The world's seven richest industrialised nations yesterday failed to agree any new proposals to breathe life into their flagging plans to relieve the third world's debt burden.

Despite efforts by Tony Blair to persuade his fellow G7 leaders to do more to respond to campaigners around the globe calling for a fairer deal for developing nations, they settled for restating the intention to implement an agreement reached last year in Cologne.

Revealing the frustration felt by the premier at his failure to reinvigorate the initiative, Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said: "He does feel that we could and should have made further progress but no-one should underestimate the progress already made."

Mr Blair, who has received 250,000 postcards and emails from drop-the-debt campaigners in three months, chaired the discussion of the subject at the G7's annual summit on the Japanese island of Okinawa.

But Britain's enthusiasm to respond to public opinion by granting faster, deeper and broader debt relief was not shared by his counterparts, Bill Clinton, of the United States, Japan's Yoshiro Mori, Germany's Gerhard Schröder, France's Jacques Chirac, Canada's Jean Chretien and Italy's Giuliano Amato.

At the end of their talks, the G7 issued a statement saying they would work together to ensure the targets set last year were met, giving due consid eration to economic reform in the eligible countries.

Acknowledging that the debt relief process had been hindered by frustrating bureaucratic delays, Mr Campbell conceded that the best that could now be hoped for was a strong message of political commitment to make faster progress in the final summit communique to be issued on Sunday.

During the rest of the summit, Mr Blair will also push for the establishment of a high-level group of politicians to persuade warring countries in Africa to put down their arms in exchange for debt relief.

Ann Pettifor, director of Jubilee 2000, the global coalition of charities which has led the campaign for debt relief, said: "This summit offered the chance to go further and write off all the unpayable debts of the poorest countries - a genuine new start. The world's leaders have blown it.

"While we welcome the encouragement given to poor countries to end war, we believe that the G7 could play a more decisive role in conflict countries, by ending arms sales to these regimes. Debt cancellation must not be held hostage to the international arms trade."

Henry Northover, policy analyst with the UK aid agency Cafod, added: "This summit is a £500m blowout for the world's most powerful men and nothing new for the world's poor."

The Birmingham summit two years ago cost £6.5m.

Tonight the G7 leaders, plus Russia's Vladimir Putin, at tending his first summit, are due to sit down to a gala banquet with lobster, caviar and duck on the menu at Shurijo Castle, a 15th century palace.

Ms Pettifor said: "This reminds me of Marie Antoinette dining at her table and when the poor of Paris banged on her door she said let them eat cake."

Under the agreement reached at Cologne last year, the G7 committed themselves to cancelling debts worth $100bn and said they expected 24 of the eligible 41 countries to begin receiving some form of debt service relief by the end of this year. So far nine have begun to receive debt relief. Jubilee 2000 estimates that less than $12bn of the $100bn total has been cancelled and that most of that was already in the pipeline before Cologne. The campaign group says the 41 countries identified as possible recipients of debt relief currently have debt of $212bn.

fields.headline: Carry on sunbathing
fields.standfirst:
Summer hols get off to a sultry start

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The inexhaustible optimism of the British sun worshipper received a boost yesterday as forecasters predicted a sweltering start to the peak holiday season.
fields.body:
The inexhaustible optimism of the British sun worshipper received a boost yesterday as forecasters predicted a sweltering start to the peak holiday season.

But already some of the country's biggest resorts and attractions showed signs of straining under the weight of so much hope.

Met Office forecasters predicted a hot, sunny weekend as schools in England and Wales break up for the summer. The best of the weather will be centred on Wales and south-west England, where temperatures are expected to peak today at 26C (77F) before cooling tomorrow.

In Surrey, thousands of children and parents were evacuated yesterday from Thorpe Park as two boat rides and a neighbouring building went up in flames.

Smoke and flames could be seen from the M3 as the fire took hold, and there were initial fears that a number of visitors had gone missing in the chaos. A hundred firefighters tackled the blaze. By 5pm the emergency services confirmed it was under control and everyone had been accounted for.

The sunshine is expected to boost already record-breaking crowds at the Open golf championship at St Andrews, where police yesterday sought to play down newspaper reports suggesting they might have to cordon off the town and ban spectators if numbers climbed higher.

Airports were expecting a busy weekend, with Heathrow predicting a throughput of 630,000 travellers today and tomorrow.

But Channel tunnel users face a summer of delays as members of Aslef, the train drivers' union, prepared to vote on an overtime ban in a battle over recognition.

Meanwhile in Blackpool, public transport ground to a halt as bus and tram drivers went on strike for a second day in a dispute over pay.

webTitle: Leader: A court comes to the rescue of free speech.

fields.headline: Justice done
fields.standfirst:
A court comes to the rescue of free speech

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: A court comes to the rescue of free speech.
fields.body:
David Shayler may be an honourable whistle blower or he may be an excitable fantasist. If his story is true, then it deserves to be told. If it is untrue, then he deserves to be exposed. Either way, it is essential that the former MI5 officer's allegations about the conduct of the security services are openly and frankly investigated. Since parliament and government show no appetite for doing so, it has been left to the media to do the job. A number of reporters have diligently done their best to investigate his claims.

So far so good. But everything changed in February this year when the police began threatening moves against two newspapers - the Guardian and the Observer - after we published material relating to Mr Shayler. The police did not claim that either newspaper had in any way threatened national security. But they did demand that we hand over a number of emails, notes and documents and suggested that the Observer's reporter, Martin Bright, might himself face prosecution under the Official Secrets Act. We refused to comply.

Yesterday the court of appeal backed the newspapers in overturning the original decision by an Old Bailey judge, Judge Martin Stephens QC, to order the material to be handed over. Lord Justice Judge's leading judgment is as robust a statement of the rights and duties of a free press as has been heard in an English court room. He stated from the outset that if Shayler's allegations were true it was difficult to overstate their enormity. The public had a right to know the facts: newspapers had an entitlement to investigate them. The police's attempts to purloin the newspapers' material "would have had a devastating and stifling effect on the proper investigation... Virtually any journalist who made contact with him, and any newspaper publishing an article based on discussions with Shayler, would have been at risk of a similar application." It was vital that "inconvenient or embarrassing revelations - whether for the security services or for public authorities - should not be suppressed."

Perhaps it is asking too much of our politicians to understand the value of true freedom of speech, or how it needs protection. On yesterday's form Lord Justice Judge certainly appears to have a more sophisticated appreciation of the issues than, say, Jack Straw. An entertaining detour in his judgment saw him argue that we don't need Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Right to tell us about free speech: "it is bred in the bone of the common law". True or not, an English court came to the rescue of free speech yesterday. For that, thanks.

webTitle: Hague orders gag on Thatcher to stop her stealing Tory show

fields.headline: Hague orders gag on Thatcher to stop her stealing Tory show
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague is to gag Margaret Thatcher at this year's Tory conference after the former prime minister upstaged the entire party leadership at last year's annual gathering.
fields.body:
William Hague is to gag Margaret Thatcher at this year's Tory conference after the former prime minister upstaged the entire party leadership at last year's annual gathering.

Amid fears that television pictures of Lady Thatcher on the conference circuit will repel potential Tory voters, Mr Hague's office has asked her to take a back seat in Bournemouth in October.

"It is well under control," a Tory leadership source said after discussions with her allies about the conference. "We recognise that we have to put on television those people that will be ministers and not those from the past. A great deal of effort has been expended to ensure that."

The former prime minister came close to hijacking last year's conference in Blackpool. Leadership sources say they cannot afford to have this year's conference dominated by coverage of Tory splits provoked by the former prime minister at what is likely to be the last conference before the election.

Lady Thatcher distracted attention from the main conference last year with her high profile support for the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet at a fringe rally.

The former prime minister also irritated the leadership when she declared - in her first speech at a Tory conference since her downfall - that all of Britain's problems in her lifetime had "come from mainland Europe". After her provocative remarks - at the party's Scottish night - she was mobbed by party activists who ignored Mr Hague.

Lady Thatcher's behaviour at last year's conference was condemned by John Major who said that "harking back to the 1980s" was a turn-off for voters. "There are no votes in yesterday and many to be lost if the Ghost of Government Past appears to lead the party by the nose," he wrote in the Spectator.

Leadership sources, who know that Mr Hague cannot afford to fall foul of Lady Thatcher, insist that he still admires the former prime minister. But one source pointed out that whatever Lady Thatcher says is always interpreted in an unhelpful way.

But most activists who attend conference have never forgiven the parliamentary party for abandoning the former prime minister in such a brutal fashion in 1990.

At last year's conference, shadow cabinet ministers were able to win easy cheers by praising Lady Thatcher and pointedly ignoring John Major. Francis Maude, then the shadow chancellor, lavished praise on her handling of the economy. A spokesman for Lady Thatcher said last night: "We haven't got our minds round it yet but I am sure Lady Thatcher will be going. She goes every year."

Lady Thatcher is likely to want to talk about her latest book, to be published next year, about leadership in the age of spin.

webTitle: Leaders: Politicians should be wary of the fast lane.

fields.headline: A fair cop
fields.standfirst: Politicians should be wary of the fast lane
fields.trailText: Politicians should be wary of the fast lane.
fields.body:
It is difficult to guess who was more shocked - the police officer who stopped the speeding car on the M5 only to find the home secretary inside; or Jack Straw, who would have immediately known just how much media attention his speeding car was going to make.

The list of speeding motorists covers all classes: politicians (John Prescott - 85mph on the M62), sports people (Lester Piggott, Ian Botham), performers (Terry Wogan, Rowan Atkinson), and royalty (Princess Ann). Jack Straw wasn't actually driving the car, but he has been unequivocal in his belief in the need for "zero tolerance" towards speeding motorists. He backed a senior police officer's call last year for the prosecution of drivers exceeding the limit by a mere 1mph. Mr Straw's car is alleged to have been travelling at over 100mph.

Avon and Somerset police have yet to decide whether they will be taking any further action. But they do not have any choice. Of course they have discretion, but imagine the political fuss if they dropped the case. True, John Redwood rushed in to suggest the special branch officer driving the car should not be prosecuted. But there will be plenty of other Tories rightly shouting "foul" if there is no prosecution. Mr Straw wasn't even travelling on government business, but was late for a meeting of the Labour party's national policy forum in Exeter. This is hard luck on the officer involved, but it will at least reinforce the readiness of other Whitehall drivers to remember the rules of the road. They have a right - indeed a duty - to remind ministers, even home secretaries, of the law. Road safety campaigners are right to point to the unnecessary injuries and deaths caused by speeding drivers. But policing only succeeds with public cooperation. That is why police were right to apply a narrow buffer zone, above the limit, in which motorists weren't prosecuted. Jack Straw was wrong to oppose it. Perhaps he will have learned this lesson.

webTitle: Key Republicans pushing for Bush-McCain ticket

fields.headline: Key Republicans pushing for Bush-McCain ticket
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Washington is abuzz with speculation that this year's Republican presidential hopeful, George W Bush, may be about to bury the hatchet and choose Senator John McCain as his running mate, perhaps as early as this weekend.
fields.body:
Washington is abuzz with speculation that this year's Republican presidential hopeful, George W Bush, may be about to bury the hatchet and choose Senator John McCain as his running mate, perhaps as early as this weekend.

Mr McCain is among a number of senior Republicans who have been asked to remain available for phone calls from Mr Bush this weekend, as the Texas governor prepares to announce who will accompany him to the Republican convention in Philadelphia on July 31.

Whether he is willing to take a chance on Mr McCain remains a closely guarded secret, but that has done nothing to dampen the sudden surge of speculation that he may pull a spectacular surprise.

Mr McCain appeared to rule himself out as a running mate after Mr Bush defeated him in the frequently bitter primary struggle in March. When they finally met in private in Pittsburgh two months ago, Mr McCain repeated that he did not wish to be considered, and Mr Bush has said that he takes his former rival at his word.

But Mr McCain appears to have done a spectacular about-face in recent days, and his supporters are making an 11th-hour lobbying effort to have his name added to the ticket - a step that would undoubtedly alarm conservative Republicans, to say nothing of the Democratic challenger, Al Gore.

The speculation seems to have been triggered by a phone call on Tuesday to Mr McCain from Governor Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, himself a leading candidate for the job. He urged Mr McCain to take the number-two position on the Republican ticket if it was offered.

He made it clear that he was not speaking on Mr Bush's behalf.

"You know me, Tommy. If the governor asked me, you know I would serve. I would prefer not to, but I'll serve," the Associated Press reported Mr McCain was reported as saying.

"If Bush were to make a case, he would do it, but he prefers not to be asked," a McCain adviser told the Washington Post.

Reports of that conversation were quickly followed by the news that Congressman Tom Davis of Virginia, leader of the Republican effort to keep control of the house in November's elections, was circulating a petition in support of drafting Mr McCain.

He sees the Arizona senator as a trump card in the battle for swing voters.

Campaign officials have hinted several times this week that Mr Bush may announce his choice on Monday, a week before the convention, to maximise the media coverage.

fields.headline: Fireman douses election fever
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Douglas Couvertier's campaign for office has none of the affable vacuity of George W Bush's race for the White House, nor the rancour of Hillary Clinton's attempt to assume a New York Senate seat.
fields.body:
Douglas Couvertier's campaign for office has none of the affable vacuity of George W Bush's race for the White House, nor the rancour of Hillary Clinton's attempt to assume a New York Senate seat.

But he does have something that makes him stand out from the common herd of candidates: he is asking the electorate to vote for someone else.

"I would really appreciate if people didn't vote for me," said the 54-year-old who is standing for a council seat in Southwest Ranches, Florida.

Mr Couvertier, a Miami-Dade fire department chief, did not realise when he embarked on his political career that the county prohibits employees from holding elected office. And the supervisor of elections has refused to remove him from Tuesday's ballot because 64 postal voters have already chosen him.

Now Mr Couvertier says that he will have to resign the seat immediately if he wins because he does not want to damage his pension entitlement with only three years to go before retirement. He had hoped to play a part in shaping the town's future.

"I really believe in this area," he said. "I've lived here for over 20 years and I love it here. I thought it was important for my town for me to get involved."

It seemed as though many in the settlement of 7,000 agreed, making him a frontrunner in the poll. "I stood a real good chance of being elected," he said. "People have been telling me 'you're in, you're going to win'. I am trying to stop this snowball. My fear is I still stand a real good chance of being elected."

webTitle: Baffled US may aid Kim's space dream

fields.headline: Baffled US may aid Kim's space dream
fields.trailText: US officials said yesterday that Washington was puzzled but ready, in principle, to assist North Korea in developing its own space programme if Pyongyang gave up its efforts to develop long-range missiles.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Washington and Mark Atkinson in Okinawa
fields.body:
US officials said yesterday that Washington was puzzled but ready, in principle, to assist North Korea in developing its own space programme if Pyongyang gave up its efforts to develop long-range missiles.

North Korea's communist regime, slowly beginning to come out of its isolation, has not previously been known for its aspirations to space travel.

But its "Dear Leader", Kim Jong-il, has made his desire for space technology a condition for giving up tests of his country's experimental missiles.

The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, who visited Pyongyang last week, was reported to have put the North Korean plan to his US counterpart, Bill Clinton at a 75-minute meeting yesterday before the Okinawa G8 economic summit.

North Korea's missile programme is cited by Washington as a key reason for its proposed US national missile defence system (NMD), elements of which would be based in Alaska. In Asia and in Europe the idea is controversial.

In a separate bilateral meeting in Okinawa,Tony Blair last night urged Mr Putin to pressure rogue states like North Korea to adopt more conventional norms, as a way of discouraging the Americans from pressing ahead with the defence grid.

If Mr Putin could bring North Korea to heel, there might be less political pressure on Washington to bolster US defences, Mr Blair told the Russian leader.

Senior British government officials said North Korea's proposal to trade its missile programme for space technology was a positive development which warranted careful consideration by Nato.

This response echoed Washington's uncertain welcome. "It's not entirely clear what is in Kim Jong-il's mind with regard to this possible trade-off," a senior American official who attended the meeting said.

The official was quoted as saying the US was willing to explore the idea if Pyongyang abandoned its missile programme entirely and if the help it sought on space exploration was in the form of aid for North Korea to launch its satellites using rockets built and fired by other states.

The US would provide the country no assistance to make or launch its own rockets, he added.

North Korea shocked everyone when it test-fired a ballistic missile over Japan in 1998.

Pyongyang said the rocket it launched was a space shot aimed at putting a satellite in orbit, but the claim was greeted with ridicule.

In agreeing to discuss Kim Jong-il's bizarre offer, Washington risked handing ammunition to Moscow and other opponents of NMD, whose proponents say is designed to protect the US from missile attacks by "rogue states" - North Korea being the most frequently cited example. China believes the proposed system is really aimed at it.

NMD is opposed by Russia, China and some US allies in Europe, including France and Germany, on the grounds that it violates the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty, and is therefore destabilising.

The US argument has been that "rogue states" cannot be contained by the principles of mutual deterrence, of which the 1972 treaty is a central pillar. If the threat posed by the North Koreans - who could be capable of launching a missile attack by 2005, according to US intelligence - appears to be receding, one of the premises underpinning the NMD scheme would vanish.

However, proponents of the $60bn (£40bn) anti-missile defence shield maintain that Iran and Iraq could pose a ballistic missile threat within the next few years and say they are also concerned that there may be an accidental nuclear missile launch by an established power like Russia, whose defence system is crumbling.

Mr Clinton is under congressional pressure to give development of the anti-missile shield a green light by November to allow completion of the first phase by 2005, but two out of three tests of the system over the past year have failed, putting the timetable in doubt.
