webTitle: Pardon for drug smuggler jailed in Thailand

fields.headline: Pardon for drug smuggler jailed in Thailand
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Sandra Gregory, the former teacher who has spent seven and a half years in prison after she was caught smuggling heroin, was freed yesterday after a show of clemency by the king of Thailand.
fields.body:
Sandra Gregory, the former teacher who has spent seven and a half years in prison after she was caught smuggling heroin, was freed yesterday after a show of clemency by the king of Thailand.

She was released from Cookham Wood prison in Kent, where she has spent the last nine months of her sentence, after she was pardoned by King Bhumibol Adulyadej.

Gregory, of Sowerby Bridge, West Yorkshire, was jailed in 1993 after she admitted smuggling 86.9 grammes of heroin which she had hidden in her body in a condom. She claimed she had only agreed to be a drugs mule because she was short of cash and was desperate to get home.

She was arrested by Thai authorities with her travelling companion Robert Lock as they checked in for a flight to Japan.

At their trial, Gregory was sentenced to 25 years in prison - later reduced to 22 years - and Lock walked free.

When she was released from prison yesterday afternoon she said: "It is absolutely marvellous. I was not expecting it at all and am humbled by it. I have learned an awful lot in the past seven and a half years. It has given me empathy with other people. I think more than anybody I would like to thank my parents for everything they have done. They have been great." She said she accepted full responsibility for her actions. "I was guilty of breaking the law in Thailand and I take full responsibility for what I have done," she said. "I still think Thailand is a marvellous country. I have been smiling for 24 hours, but it's hard to make plans."

She could not go back to teaching because she had a criminal record. She would like to work in drug rehabilitation.

Her parents, Doreen and Stan, from Aberdeenshire, have conducted a campaign to secure her release. They appealed to the government and the king of Thailand for clemency. Their appeal was supported by church leaders in Scotland and by politicians.

They claim that their daughter, who is now 35, had been the longest serving woman prisoner in Britain apart from serial killers Rosemary West and Myra Hindley.

She had spent four and a half years in the notorious Lar Yao women's prison - sometimes dubbed the Bangkok Hilton - before being returned to Britain under a prisoner exchange treaty in 1997.

Her mother said the worst moment came when Sandra was transferred to the maximum security wing at Durham prison in 1998. Sandra wrote to her parents saying she was in a cell "like a gerbil cage" and that she was frightened. She had portrayed the system as being like slow torture. "Being kept alive to suffer slowly," she wrote. "Killed from the inside out."

Gregory was transferred to last autumn to Cookham Wood, where she began an Open University degree course. She would not have been eligible for parole until December 2003.

Yesterday her parents were jubilant. Her mother was outside the prison gates. She said: "The whole prison is rejoicing. We were completely stunned when we heard the news. It is the first time in eight years that I have been able to smile."

They were phoned at home by the Foreign Office on Thursday evening.

Malcolm Bruce, their local MP, said: "Stan and Doreen have fought a wonderful campaign. The dignified way in which they have conducted themselves has been crucial in mobilising cross-party support."

James MacKay, an elder of the Church of Scotland, who campaigned for Sandra's release, said: "It is terrible that the government has done so little to help."

A spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said it had not supported the application for a royal pardon, which would only have been endorsed on compelling or compassionate grounds.

I have learned an awful lot in the past seven and a half years. It has given me empathy with other people. I think more than anybody I would like to thank my parents for everything they have done. They have been great." She said she accepted full responsibility for her actions. "I was guilty of breaking the law in Thailand and I take full responsibility for what I have done," she said. "I still think Thailand is a marvellous country. I have been smiling for 24 hours, but it's hard to make plans." She could not go back to teaching because she had a criminal record. She would like to work in drug rehabilitation. Her parents, Doreen and Stan, from Aberdeenshire, have conducted a campaign to secure her release. They appealed to the government and the king of Thailand for clemency. Their appeal was supported by church leaders in Scotland and by politicians. They claim that their daughter, who is now 35, had been the longest serving woman prisoner in Britain apart from serial killers Rosemary West and Myra Hindley. She had spent four and a half years in the notorious Lar Yao women's prison - sometimes dubbed the Bangkok Hilton - before being returned to Britain under a prisoner exchange treaty in 1997. Her mother said the worst moment came when Sandra was transferred to the maximum security wing at Durham prison in 1998. Sandra wrote to her parents saying she was in a cell "like a gerbil cage" and that she was frightened. She had portrayed the system as being like slow torture. "Being kept alive to suffer slowly," she wrote. "Killed from the inside out." Gregory was transferred to last autumn to Cookham Wood, where she began an Open University degree course. She would not have been eligible for parole until December 2003. Yesterday her parents were jubilant. Her mother was outside the prison gates. She said: "The whole prison is rejoicing. We were completely stunned when we heard the news. It is the first time in eight years that I have been able to smile." They were phoned at home by the Foreign Office on Thursday evening. Malcolm Bruce, their local MP, said: "Stan and Doreen have fought a wonderful campaign. The dignified way in which they have conducted themselves has been crucial in mobilising cross-party support." James MacKay, an elder of the Church of Scotland, who campaigned for Sandra's release, said: "It is terrible that the government has done so little to help." A spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said it had not supported the application for a royal pardon, which would only have been endorsed on compelling or compassionate grounds.

fields.headline: Washington will miss greenhouse target
fields.trailText: The United States is unable to meet the legally binding greenhouse gas reduction target it accepted at the Kyoto climate conference in 1998, Washington admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
The United States is unable to meet the legally binding greenhouse gas reduction target it accepted at the Kyoto climate conference in 1998, Washington admitted yesterday.

Unless Europe gives way and allows the US unlimited rights to trade internationally in so-called "carbon credits", it will not fulfil "a large fraction" of its obligations, the under-secretary for global affairs, Frank Loy, said.

Countries can offset domestic carbon emissions by planting forests, buying credits from countries which have fallen below their own limits, or by helping to build clean power stations in polluting countries. But others want to limit America's ability to buy its way out of its domestic obligations.

Mr Loy said the booming US economy of the 1990s had pushed up carbon dioxide emissions by 12% on 1990 levels. To achieve the reduction of 7% on 1990 levels by 2010, as promised at Kyoto, it would have to get emissions 30% below the projected level.

"We have not got a snow ball's hell of doing this unless we use market mechanisms like carbon trading with other countries. The earth does not care where the carbon dioxide comes from. If we get more carbon cuts for each dollar in Kenya or China then the earth benefits more.

"There is only a certain amount of money available for climate change and we have to make the most of it."

Mr Loy said he believed it would be "tough" to get agreement on how to implement the cuts agreed in Kyoto at this year's climate change convention meeting in the Hague, but the US was determined to do so. He was asking Europe and the developing world to reconsider their demand for limits on the US.

Europe wants to limit Washington's ability to buy notional carbon savings from countries such as Russia to 50% of its total required savings, otherwise it believes the US will be let off the hook. The US produces 25% of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.

Tony Juniper of Friends of the Earth said: "The US is doing tricks with arithmetic rather than deal with some of the fundamental problems of profligate use of fossil fuels."

Until now, Congress has been unwilling to support the Kyoto protocol, because of fears it might hit the gas-guzzling lifestyle of the US people.

Big business joined together to form a climate change coalition to successfully lobby against the protocol.But the coalition has fallen apart. Ford, Boeing, BP Amoco and other big companies had pulled out, Mr Loy said. All four US presidential candidates now acknowledged that the science of climate change was convincing and the US people wanted action.

"All this adds up to a complete change in attitude in the last two or three years. I am sure if we get what we want in the Hague, the US will be able to ratify the protocol and deliver a 7% cut in emissions," he said.

Mr Loy added that the US believed in the legally binding nature of the Kyoto protocol and wanted penalties if the US or other countries did not meet the target they agreed to.

Mr Loy's comments coincided with more evidence of the dangers of global warming. Nasa, the US space agency, warned that the warming climate is eroding more than 50bn tonnes of water a year from the Greenland ice sheet, increasing the risk of coastal flooding around the world.

Eleven cubic miles of ice is disappearing annually, enough to raise sea levels around the globe by 0.13mm a year.

"We see a significant trend. When we can go back after five years and see 10 metres of glacier gone, there is some thing happening," said William Krabill, head of Nasa's ice sheet measurement project.

The melting of Greenland ice and the calving of icebergs from Greenland glaciers is responsible for about 7% of the annual rise in global sea level. Measurements suggest that over the past century the sea level has risen about 23cm, enough to cause some low-lying areas that were once high and dry to be awash at high tide or during storms.

The trend could get worse, said Mr Krabill, if the Greenland ice sheet continued to melt.

fields.headline: Memorial to civil rights revolution
fields.trailText: Campaigners came a step closer to winning their fight to create a museum on the site of one of the best-known protests against segregation in the American South this week, after a long-running battle for funding.
fields.body:
Campaigners came a step closer to winning their fight to create a museum on the site of one of the best-known protests against segregation in the American South this week, after a long-running battle for funding.

On February 1 1960 four black students from the local university walked into Woolworths in Greensboro, North Carolina, bought an item each, and then sat at the food counter reserved for whites and politely asked for coffee. They were refused service.

It was supposed to be a one-off local protest, but within a fortnight it had sparked a series of copycat sit-ins which changed the strategy of the civil rights movement and challenged segregation across the US: an event as significant as Rosa Parks's refusal to move to the back of the bus in Montgomery, Alabama, five years earlier.

The Woolworths on February 1 1960 Street - renamed to commemorate the day the young men made their stand - was closed seven years ago but it still houses part of the "white counter". In 1993, civic leaders offered to buy it to turn it into an international civil rights centre and museum. They were given generous terms by the Woolworth corporation and opened it as a museum.

They then asked architects to draw up ambitious plans for a three-level cultural centre which would incorporate an exhibition hall with the counter as its centrepiece.

The cost - $10.5m - was the only stumbling block, but it has proved near insurmountable. At least $5.5m is needed just to renovate the elegant art deco building.

So far $2.1m has been raised, most of it from local, mainly black, charitable foundations.

The North Carolina state government refused funding for the scheme when approached in 1998.

But on Tuesday there was a breakthrough when the city council provisionally agreed to ask Greensboro voters if the museum should be granted $3.5m of public money so that it can finish the renovations.

If the referendum question is incorporated on the ballot paper and then passed in the November elections, work could begin almost immediately and the new history centre could be open within two years.

McArthur Davis, general manager of the museum, said yesterday: "The bricks and mortar is the hardest part to get the money for. We could probably raise the money for the rest of the museum in about 18 months if we get that."

The organisers have also managed to get the support of their local congressman, Mel Watt, as well as John Lewis and Maxine Waters, two prominent campaigners in the House of Representatives.

They are petitioning the federal government in Washington for $3.5m more in funding but there is unlikely to be any decision on that before next April.

The civil rights movement remains a divisive issue in the south and Mr Davies is cautious about the prospects for success after the group's seven-year battle for funds.

"I am not a politician," he said. "I would not like to say why the money has not been forthcoming.

"But we do not think there is any logic behind it."

webTitle: The act that gave the struggle new life

fields.headline: The act that gave the struggle new life
fields.trailText: The Franklin McCain was one of the four black teenagers who sparked a wave of sit-ins and protests when he sat at the "white counter" of the Greensboro Woolworths on February 1 1960. Here he describes what happened and why he did it:
fields.body:
The Franklin McCain was one of the four black teenagers who sparked a wave of sit-ins and protests when he sat at the "white counter" of the Greensboro Woolworths on February 1 1960. Here he describes what happened and why he did it:

On the day that I sat at that counter I had the most tremendous feeling of elation and celebration. I felt that in this life nothing else mattered. I felt like one of those wise men who sits cross-legged and cross-armed and has reached a natural high.

Nothing else has ever come close. Not the birth of my first son nor my marriage. And it was a cruel hoax, because people go through their whole lives and they don't get that to happen to them.

And here it was being visited on me as a 17-year-old. It was wonderful but it was sad also, because I know that I will never have that again. I'm just sorry it was when I was 17.

It was the most intense peace within myself and my surroundings. I had no tensions and no concerns. If there's a heaven, I got there for a few minutes. I just felt that you can't touch me. You can't hurt me.

I was brought up with a major myth. I was told that if I worked hard, believed in the constitution, the 10 commandments and the bill of rights, and got a good education, I would be successful. For a long time, I held it against my parents and my grandparents as well. I felt they had lied to me and I felt suicidal. I felt that if that is what this life was all about then it wasn't worth it. There seemed no prospect for dignity or respect as a young black man.

So we decided to do something.

When we sat down, and the waitress refused to take our orders, there was a policeman behind us slapping his night-stick on his hand. I thought, I guess this is it. But then it occurred to me the policeman really didn't know what he was doing, and I must say I was relieved.

Some way through, an old white lady, who must have been 75 or 85, came over and put her hands on my shoulders and said: "Boys I am so proud of you. You should have done this 10 years ago."

That is exactly the sort of person you didn't expect to hear anything from.

Then there was the black help in the Woolworths kitchen who told me to get up and leave, saying "You are not supposed to be here". At that time the whites did the serving and the blacks did the washing and helping out. It was only 15 or 20 years later that I learnt to forgive them and understand them. I was threatening their livelihood. And it was around that time I realised that my parents weren't naive in the cruel lie that they had told me. They lied to me be cause they loved me.

This is an edited extract from No Place Like Home, A Black Briton's Journey Through the American South, by Gary Younge, published by Picador at £16.

fields.headline: Clinton woos unhappy Battleship Okinawa
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton tried to win over the people of Okinawa yesterday by a direct address to the island, which houses the biggest concentration of American firepower outside the United States.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton tried to win over the people of Okinawa yesterday by a direct address to the island, which houses the biggest concentration of American firepower outside the United States.

Arriving on Japan's southernmost island for the summit of the G8 group of leading industrial states and Russia, Mr Clinton spoke a day after 27,000 peace campaigners formed a chain around Okinawa's largest US base.

It was the biggest protest against the American military presence on the island since 1995, a reminder to Mr Clinton - the first US president to visit Okinawa in more than 40 years - of the feeling of many residents that Okinawa's share is disproportionate to that of the rest of Japan.

There are 26,000 US troops in Okinawa, more than half American personnel in Japan, though it comprises only 1% of the country's landmass.

Many of the bases were taken by American forces after the 1945 battle of Okinawa, the bloodiest confrontation of the second world war in the Pacific.

Speaking at a memorial to the 200,000 who died in the battle, Mr Clinton said the presence of US troops on the island was playing a vital part in ensuring stability and peace in Asia.

He recognised, however, that local people - whose island is considered an unsinkable battleship by Washington - did not ask to play such a role.

"I have tried to understand your concerns," he said. "We are going to keep doing what we can to reduce our footprint on the island."

His opponents said this vague promise merely reaffirmed the 1996 Japan-US agreement to consolidate some bases.

In four years, little has been done about it, partly because the islanders cannot agree.

"This is a huge disappointment," said Seicchi Sakugawa, whose family home was torn down to make way for the Kadena airbase. "He used nice words, but what he said was that Okinawans will have to go on living with the burden of the bases for years to come."

But not everyone is against the bases. Landowners receive generous rents and many shops and bars depend on business from the troops.

But the resentment resurfaced in June when a US marine broke into the bedroom of a 14-year-old Okinawa girl and tried to molest her. The military authorities were also embarrassed by a hit-and-run incident involving an airman from Kadena earlier this month.

These crimes revived memories of the rape five years ago of a girl of 12. That sparked protests by 80,000 people.

The military authorities have introduced a midnight curfew and restricted flights to try to ease the tension, but political and economic factors have given fresh momentum to the movement against the bases.

The Tokyo government pays a contribution for the US bases which underpin its security, the Japanese armed forces having been restricted since the war. And Tokyo shares Washington's concern about China. But to Okinawans these are not the paramount concern.

"Japan is in recession, so it cannot afford to keep the bases," said Kiyomi Tsujimoto, a social democratic MP. "And now that relations between North and South Korea have improved, we must ask whether we really need such a strong military presence."

Mr Clinton has not endeared himself to his Japanese hosts by arriving late and hinting that he will fly home early - in both cases because he is hoping to salvage some sort of agreement from the Palestinian-Israeli peace talks at Camp David. The G8 summit was supposed to be the islanders' reward for putting up with the US troop presence.

"These are empty gestures," said Kiyoko Miyagi, a resident. "The only good thing that has come out of this summit is that the world has a chance to see what wars and occupation have done to our beautiful and peace-loving island."

webTitle: Sun, surf and suits all round

fields.headline: Sun, surf and suits all round
fields.trailText: With its azure seas, golden sands and tropical vegetation, Okinawa was seen by Japan as a place the G8 summit would help publicise as a holiday paradise.
fields.body:
With its azure seas, golden sands and tropical vegetation, Okinawa was seen by Japan as a place the G8 summit would help publicise as a holiday paradise.

But thanks to an unwritten dress code, the leaders of the world's richest states spent much of their first day on the sweltering island looking more like stressed-out executives than chilled-out tourists.

"We proposed adopting casual attire," said one G8 source. "The organisers said that was fine as long as we wore a suit and tie. We got the message."

Having spent £800m on lavish entertainment, gourmet cuisine and a huge security force, Japan probably felt its taxpayers had to see that this was a working event, not a party.

But the leaders - all from cooler climes - have looked rather incongruous as well as uncomfortable wandering among the palm trees in dark jackets.

After an hour in the afternoon sun with his tie knotted and his jacket fastened yesterday, President Clinton was red and sweating.

But the G8 leaders were not the only ones missing out on the holiday action.

Coastal resorts near the summit venue in Nago - usually bustling with tourists now - were more like ghost towns, save for 22,000 policeman drafted in to beef up security.

The authorities have also banned fishing and diving in many areas, while frigates and frogmen keep a watch at sea.

"It's all a bit stiff," said Kazuhiko Shiro, who works at a local car-hire company. "You'd never believe this was a tourist spot."

fields.headline: Gatwick officer jailed
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Gatwick immigration officer Guy Emmett was yesterday jailed for eight years for his part in a conspiracy to allow illegal immigrants to stay in Britain.
fields.body:
Gatwick immigration officer Guy Emmett was yesterday jailed for eight years for his part in a conspiracy to allow illegal immigrants to stay in Britain.

Old Bailey judge Timothy Pontius told Emmett that his greed had led him "without regret or shame" to betray his employers.

Emmett, 35, of Purley, Surrey, was earlier this week convicted of conspiracy to defraud the home secretary, and conspiracy to allow illegal immigrants to remain in Britain. He was yesterday sentenced to eight years and six years jail, to run concurrently.

Christian Jideofo, 42, a lawyer, of New Barnet, Hertfordshire, was jailed for a total of six and a half years after being convicted of the same offences.

fields.headline: Leniency plea for Straw's driver
fields.trailText: The Police Federation yesterday called for leniency in dealing with the special branch officer who was caught speeding while driving the home secretary, Jack Straw, to a Labour party engagement.
fields.body:
The Police Federation yesterday called for leniency in dealing with the special branch officer who was caught speeding while driving the home secretary, Jack Straw, to a Labour party engagement.

The police have not decided whether to charge the unnamed officer, who was caught driving at 103mph on the M5 earlier this month, but the police union said it should be considered as a special case.

Avon and Somerset police pulled over Mr Straw's car, believed to be a private top of the range Vauxhall Omega rather than his ministerial Jaguar, near Taunton at 8.55am on Sunday July 9. After a brief conversation with the driver, and seeing Mr Straw in the back, police allowed them to continue to Labour's national policy forum in Exeter.

Any driver caught travelling at more than 100mph is liable to be banned and fined up to £800.

Avon and Somerset police are investigating the incident. But the Metropolitan Police Federation chairman, Glen Smyth, said it would be unfair to blame the special branch driver.

"Not many of us are put in a such a difficult position, where we are driving such a high profile and powerful figure. The home secretary has played a bit of a political price for this, but it is the driver who faces much more serious consequences."

A Downing Street spokesman said the incident was a matter for the police.

But John Redwood, head of the Conservatives' parliamentary campaigns unit, said: "It is disgraceful that the home secretary, who told us we were criminals if we did 31mph in a 30mph limit and would be prosecuted, has not yet apologised for speeding at 103mph. Anyone going to a morning meeting in the back of a car would have realised the car was speeding. A sensible home secretary would have asked the driver to slow down. We don't just want the driver to be prosecuted, we want the home secretary to apologise."

webTitle: Migrants with skills may be welcomed

fields.headline: Migrants with skills may be welcomed
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Home office ministers are studying a Canadian scheme which would enable more economic migrants with professional and specialist skills to work in Britain as part of a possible shake-up of the immigration laws.
fields.body:
Home office ministers are studying a Canadian scheme which would enable more economic migrants with professional and specialist skills to work in Britain as part of a possible shake-up of the immigration laws.

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, said in a speech in Paris yesterday that the government believed it was time to start a debate on finding ways to meet "legitimate desires to migrate" to Britain and called for an "imaginative rethink" of existing immigration rules so migration could meet economic and social needs.

She wanted to see "innovators with good ideas to take the economy forward" and add to national wealth, as well skilled specialists come to Britain.

It is thought that ministers are more inclined to an extension of the current overseas workers scheme which enables some specialists in shortage occupations to work in Britain rather than a major relaxation of the 1971 Immigration Act which effectively bans primary immigration.

The Home Office is believed to be looking at a limited version of the Canadian scheme under which 200,000 migrants will enter Canada this year.

Mrs Roche's speech, which was to have been delivered by Mr Straw, marked a sharp departure in tone for government ministers who, while they have stressed the positive benefits of immigration to Britain, have tended to concetrate rather more on the abusive claims of some asylum seekers and the criminal gangs who operate behind them.

Mrs Roche made clear yesterday that she believed the two issues of asylum and immigration had to be treated differently and separately. The government's approach to dealing with skilled workers who could benefit the economy could not be dictated by the need to clampdown on the racketeers who smuggled illegal migrants into the country.

"Our thinking on these issues is now developing," she said. "It is clear throughout the centuries immigrants have had a very positive impact on the societies they join. I welcome the debate and will want to play a full part in it."

The Canadian scheme enables professionals and skilled workers to get a permanent resident visa in Canada even if they do not have a job offer from a prospective employer. To qualify, a potential migrant has to have a minimum of 70 points based on occupation, education and training, experience, age and knowledge of English and French. For example, those who are between 21 and 44 get a maximum of 10 points but those under 18 or over 48 get zero for age. A university degree ranks as 16 points, a validated job offer 10 points, personal suitability based on an interview up to 10 points, five points for a relative in Canada and so on.

Ministers believe this is fairer than the green card system operated in the US. Occupations which attract the most points in Canada include computer programmers, physiotherapists and sous-chefs.

Immigration welfare groups welcomed what they saw as the "first faint stirrings" of signs that the government may at last be putting the asylum issue into the sensible context of the pressures faced by economic migrants.

But Mrs Roche reinterated the government's plans to redefine the Geneva convention on refugees, including the possibility of imposing quotas on refugees from high-risk areas.

fields.headline: Passenger guilty of endangering flight
fields.trailText: A passenger involved in fighting on board a packed holiday jet travelling to Jamaica was found guilty yesterday of endangering the flight.
fields.body:
A passenger involved in fighting on board a packed holiday jet travelling to Jamaica was found guilty yesterday of endangering the flight.

Patrick Connors, 36, of Lewisham, south-east London, was convicted at Hove crown court of endangering the safety of the Airtours flight to Montego Bay on January 31 last year. He was also found guilty of affray on board the jet.

The jury reached its verdict on Connors after deliberating for seven hours.

Francis Coyle, 40, also of Lewisham, was found not guilty of endangering the aircraft but was later found guilty of affray on board the flight.

After delivering the verdicts to the court the foreman of the jury said that pre-flight safety announcements should include a "warning about it being an offence to be drunk on an aircraft".

Judge Austin Izzard-Davies remanded both men in custody for sentencing on August 11.

After the hearing, Detective Constable Rod Bird, who led the inquiry into the incident, said: "We treat every case of so-called air rage very seriously. It is a message to everyone who would even consider getting into an aggressive manner on board an aircraft."

He added: "The comments of the jury, I think, are very sensible. A warning such as this would only take a few seconds to give."

Debra Saddler, spokeswoman for Airtours, said: "Airtours' policy on unruly passengers remains the same as any other airline. Airtours will not accept any behaviour that puts either passengers or crew at risk."

The verdicts ended a three-week trial. On Thursday, a single mother of four, Elizabeth O'Driscoll, also of Lewisham, was cleared of being drunk on board the plane. She claimed she slept through the fracas involving Coyle and Connors and only drank three and a half cans of lager.

The prosecution claimed Colye joined with Connors in trying to fight with a Jamaican passenger.

fields.headline: Curb on dentists after deaths
fields.standfirst: General anaesthetics banned from use in dental surgeries
fields.trailText: General anaesthetics are to be banned from use in dental surgeries following the deaths of eight patients, five of them children, in the past four years.
fields.body:
General anaesthetics are to be banned from use in dental surgeries following the deaths of eight patients, five of them children, in the past four years.

Liam Donaldson, the government's chief medical officer, announced the step yesterday because a succession of expert reports and guidelines has not stopped the death toll. From January 2002, any patients who genuinely need a general anaesthetic for dental work, such as some children with special needs, will have to be admitted to hospital.

"We are bringing to an end general anaesthetics in the dentist's chair which have been responsible for a small number of tragic deaths, many involving children," Professor Donaldson said.

The decision follows a review of the evidence, that he chaired jointly with the chief dental officer, Robin Wild.

The report recommends that alternative methods of pain and anxiety control should be used to further reduce the use of general anaesthetics.

Although the General Dental Council says that only a qualified anaesthetist should administer a general anaesthetic, dentists are still permitted by law to do the job themselves.

Inquiries after recent deaths have criticised the basic standard of care provided, such as the assessment of the patient's fitness and the monitoring of their heart beat and blood pressure while they are unconscious. There have also been delays in starting resuscitation and getting the patient to hospital when things have gone wrong.

In March this year, a dentist and an anaesthetist were charged with manslaughter following the death of five-year-old Karla Selley in Lancashire.

The girl, who was having a tooth removed under general anaesthetic, developed breathing difficulties. She was dead on arrival at hospital.

Last November, Bradley Legge, also five, died in a dentist's chair in Portsmouth after suffering a heart attack while under general anaesthetic for the removal of two teeth.

The most recent paper on the subject in the British Dental Journal a year ago estimated that out of about 70,000 general anaesthetics given in a year, only 7,000 were needed. "A lot of general anaesthetics are done in general dental practices because the patients want it," Mr Wild said.

The numbers had already dropped from about 300,000 a year following guidelines discouraging the procedure, issued in 1998 by the General Dental Council. Many patients were happy to opt for sedation or other pain relief instead if the risks involved in general anaesthetics were explained to them.

"I had a practice in the 1960s which gave general anaesthetics. When I looked at the hazards I decided to stop giving general anaesthetics and for the next five years I never had the need to give one," Mr Wild said.

The ban will not come in for 18 months to give hospitals time to prepare to take dental patients needing general anaesthetics and for dentists to change their procedures.

In the meantime, Prof Donaldson said, higher standards would be enforced in dental practices giving general anaesthetics, including inspections. The review also wants higher standards of conscious sedation - where the patient is given intravenous drugs or a mixture of gas and air. The report says such patients must never be allowed to slip into an unconscious state.

The General Dental Council is at one with the government over the changes, but while the British Dental Association agrees that general anaesthetics in dental surgeries must go, they are unhappy about measures being taken to deal with those who need them.

John Renshaw, chairman of its executive board, said that 90% of current general anaesthetics were necessary. "There is a significant group of patients who can't or will not access treatment - they are seriously nervous and their ability to accept treatment is limited. Dentists who offer pain and anxiety services for these people need support."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Railtrack was fined £200,000 yesterday at Blackfriars crown court, following the death of a passenger who leaned out of a train window and struck a scaffolding pole placed too near the track.
fields.body:
Railtrack fined over death

Railtrack was fined £200,000 yesterday at Blackfriars crown court, following the death of a passenger who leaned out of a train window and struck a scaffolding pole placed too near the track.

Businessman David Brown, 35, died instantly just outside Denmark Hill station, south London, last December. Railtrack had admitted breaching the Health and Safety At Work Act.

Blair's new green adviser

Former Friends of the Earth director Jonathon Porritt, 50, has been made an environmental adviser to Tony Blair. Mr Porritt, now director of Forum for the Future, is to chair the new sustainable development commission, which will examine ways of boosting economic growth without causing pollution.

Ex-patient's £1m gift

A former heart patient, who is not being named, has donated £1m in gratitude to North Hampshire hospital, in Basingstoke.

Father accused of killing girl, 12

Phillip Hall, of Whitelye, south Wales, appeared at Newport magistrates court yesterday, charged with murdering his daughter Emma, 12, by stabbing her with a kitchen knife as she lay in bed on Tuesday. He was remanded in custody for a week.

Eye rides suspended

Rides on the London Eye were suspended yesterday for safety checks, after one of the 16 drive mechanisms which propel the giant wheel failed on Thursday evening.

webTitle: Every day is election day, politicians are told

fields.headline: Every day is election day, politicians are told
fields.standfirst: The thoughts of Clinton guru who inspired PM's adviser
fields.trailText: The advice given to Tony Blair by Philip Gould, the prime minister's chief pollster, is based on the work of the controversial US political consultant Dick Morris, who in his latest work suggests that modern political leadership is no longer about ideology but substance.
fields.body:
The advice given to Tony Blair by Philip Gould, the prime minister's chief pollster, is based on the work of the controversial US political consultant Dick Morris, who in his latest work suggests that modern political leadership is no longer about ideology but substance.

In an echo of the Downing Street denunciation of the media obsession with spin, Morris claims modern electorates want substance rather than scandal.

He also claims that incumbent politicians must campaign full time, in part to overcome the inertia of full time civil servants. "Every day is election day in modern America," he says.

The spread of the internet, he claims in his other leading theory, will introduce an era of direct democracy, ending representative democracy in which we rely on congressmen or MPs to represent our interests.

Mr Gould refers warmly to The New Prince, the latest book by Morris, the former political consultant to Bill Clinton, in his leaked memo to Mr Blair. The New Prince was published in the US in June to mixed reviews, with some describing it as the bible of Clintonism.

Others claim Morris "is the man who has done as much as anyone in the 1990s to increase cynicism in the political process and encourage politicians to play to our worst fears and instincts."

Morris derides civil servants: "The permanent bureaucracy of the executive branch of a democratic government is dedicated to a single mission: to change nothing. Left or right matters little. They are neither liberal nor conservative. They are in favour of things as they are."

Morris, who is widely credited with turning the Clinton presidency around by taking him to the right after his first two disastrous years, quit after being caught with a prostitute.

His latest book is designed to reinject idealism into politics. He says the modern politician's task is "to stay positive; to focus on the issues; to rise above party; and to lead through ideas ... Our candidates and office holders need to change their tactics, their focus, and their strategies - not in the interest of better government, but in order to succeed in their chosen line of work."

Fewer people are voting, he says, but the ones who do are better informed.

He also thinks Americans are sick of scandal, which is why the Republicans could not impeach Bill Clinton over his affair with Monica Lewinsky. He argues that politicians have constantly to take the public temperature to govern effectively.

In echoes of the Downing Street approach, Morris argues that "a politician needs a permanent campaign to keep a permanent majority." He defines political leadership as maintaining "sufficient forward momentum to control events and steer public policy without losing public support. The fundamental choice facing leaders is their character projection.

"The most basic decision a modern politician must make is whether to be aggressive or conciliatory."

He calls the electorate pragmatic idealists and says polling is the key to finding the right issue.

He also advances a form of modern representative democracy already picked up by Mr Gould: "The fundamental paradigm that dominates our politics is the shift from representational (Madisonian) to direct (Jeffersonian) democracy. Voters want to run the show directly and are impatient with all forms of intermediaries between their opinions and public policy.

"This basic shift stems from a profusion of information on the one hand, and a determined distrust of institutions and politicians on the other."

The development of 24-hour news and more media outlets is also making it more difficult to govern. "With this level of information has come a certitude about political opinions. Where once voters were inclined to subordinate their own views to those of wiser heads, they now feel capable of analysing public-policy issues themselves.

"In the 1960s, it was common to hear people say that their leaders had access to more information, that it was wrong to judge them without knowing all the facts. Now, we would laugh at anyone who said that on television."

"As the electorate has become more opinionated and self-confident, its distrust of politicians, parties, and all institutions has become more profound". As a result every institution suffers from scandals and voters trust no-one but themselves.

One byproduct of this shift in power from politicians to voters is the decline of ideology. Voters want to think for themselves and will not buy the prefabricated, predictable opinions of left or right.

Men of affairs who respond to each new situation with practical, specific ideas unfettered by ideological constructs increasingly dominate our political process. The new independent voters do not care about party labels.

Morris says pollsters should never twist their findings. "The candidate's not interested in what the pollster thinks, he wants to know what the voters think."

webTitle: 'Confused' old master draws a veil over financial affairs

fields.headline: 'Confused' old master draws a veil over financial affairs
fields.standfirst: Haughey returns to the witness box as judicial inquiry tries to find out whether the wealthy ex-premier was paid for favours
fields.trailText: Haughey returns to the witness box as judicial inquiry tries to find out whether the wealthy ex-premier was paid for favours
fields.body:
Times are difficult, and his power and striking mistress are gone. But Charles J Haughey is still fabulously wealthy, so he was in little need of the smattering of coppers tossed at his chauffer-driven limousine as he arrived for his latest humiliation yesterday.

Oyster Eyes used to inspire strong emotion. He was a much cherished three-times taoiseach, an old rogue all the more lovable because he enjoyed nothing more than putting it up to the British, particularly over Northern Ireland and the Falkland Islands. But when his money-grasping activities were first exposed, the Irish felt sorely cheated, and thousands turned up to boo him.

That was three years ago, when Mr Haughey, now 74, eventually admitted accepting a £1.3m payment from cocaine-scrambled supermarkets boss Ben Dunne, and it has proved to be a tiny tip. So inured are the Irish these days to corruption, only a few dozen turned up at Dublin Castle to see him back for a fresh grilling. They were more interested in gauging his health than in questions of his wealth. He is said to be suffering from prostate cancer, though he is such a wily operative some suspect a Pinochet-style ruse.

Mr Haughey's reluctant concessions in July 1997 came at Mr Justice Brian McCracken's investigations into payments to politicians. The investigation originated in the battle for control of the supermar ket chain after Mr Dunne's 1991 suicide attempt in Florida when cavorting with a prostitute and narcotics, an evening's entertainment which now threatens to alter Irish society forever.

Yesterday's appearance was before Mr Justice Michael Moriarty, appointed after McCracken to look more closely at Mr Haughey's affairs. His inquiry has discovered that benefactors paid him more than £8m between 1979, when he first became taoiseach, to 1996.

It is one of four judicial tribunals under way as the Irish Republic faces up to endemic corruption. They are throwing up examples of outrageous sleaze daily, though taoiseach Bertie Ahern's Fianna Fail-led government has so far avoided implication.

Child abuse

The public inquiries include a massive investigation into child abuse and the supply of contaminated blood to hospitals in the 80s. That episode left 74 people dead.

Mr Haughey was sprightly as he left his Mercedes, supplied with his driver, bodyguard and mobile telephone courtesy of the taxpayer. He has a 50ft ketch, Celtic Mist, which he takes to Innishvickillane, his 170-acre island nine miles off Kerry.

He was on board when word came through last month that his criminal trial for allegedly misleading the McCracken tribunal had been postponed indefinitely because of intemperate comments from deputy premier Mary Harney, a former political foe, who suggested he should go to jail.

Mr Haughey reacted in his usual dry fashion. "Ah, my new VBF" [very best friend], he said. During the next week of evidence, he is to be in the box for two hours a day because of his age and health. Mr Justice Moriarty wants to find if there is a causal link between monies received and favours given.

On the agenda yesterday was Mr Haughey's overdraft with the Allied Irish Bank. He was £1.1m in the red when he ousted Jack Lynch as Fianna Fail leader and became taoiseach in December 1979, but the debt was mysteriously paid off within weeks. Mr Haughey, who owns a Georgian mansion and 250 acres of land in the most expensive area of north Dublin, can also expect to face questioning on his various exotic offshore accounts.

Mr Haughey will also be questioned on whether he spent £150,000 from funds raised to finance a liver transplant in the United States for Brian Lenihan, his now deceased political colleague and friend. He also spent £16,000 on hand-crafted shirts from Paris while mounting an economic austerity package at home.

Overdraft

In the witness box, he adopted a tactic he had used at the McCracken tribunal. He had, he said, handed all his financial affairs over to his accountant Des Traynor since 1960. He mentioned Mr Traynor 17 times. Mr Traynor is dead.

Mr Haughey, minister of finance in the 60s, was asked about his overdraft, which ran in 1974 to almost £300,000. His salary as a member of parliament then was about £5,000. Mr Haughey reduced the AIB overdraft through borrowing £150,000 from the Northern Bank. "It would seem I was borrowing from Peter to pay Paul," he told John Coughlan, counsel to the tribunal.

He pleaded confusion as Mr Coughlan took him through a dozen documents relating to the AIB account, and still he only reached 1975. He wanted to be as helpful as he could, but it was difficult to cope with the complex detail. It was all so long ago.

The documents indicated that the increasingly frustrated AIB decided to take his cheque book away. Mr Haughey's response? To ask for a bigger overdraft.

webTitle: Islam and Black Label hit brewery

fields.headline: Islam and Black Label hit brewery
fields.standfirst: Pakistan's one legal alcohol maker hedges by adding soft drinks to its Gymkhana whisky
fields.trailText: Business has always had its hazards for Minoo Bhandara, selling beer in an Islamic country where alcohol is formally banned. But lately sales at Pakistan's only brewery have fallen badly.
fields.body:
Business has always had its hazards for Minoo Bhandara, selling beer in an Islamic country where alcohol is formally banned. But lately sales at Pakistan's only brewery have fallen badly.

Since military officers seized power in October the few remaining licensed alcohol outlets in the liberal streets of Karachi have been closed.

Now there is just a handful of places left in Pakistan where the Murree brewery's beer and spirits are on sale - though that is not to say Pakistan is dry.

"Of course there have been very many vicissitudes," Mr Bhandara said as he chewed a handful of dried lentils washed down with a Murree pilsner.

"What we make in a year now is a pittance. Most European breweries make this much in a week."

Operating at half capacity, the brewery is producing 2.8m pints of beer a year.

Mr Bhandara sounded oddly nonchalant, but perhaps he could afford to be: Cindy, his company's non-alcoholic beer, remains a best seller.

And although the sale of spirits - brands such as Gymkhana blended malt whisky, Beehive brandy, and Silvertop gin - is down a quarter on last year, drinking continues behind closed doors.

The company was set up in 1861 to brew beer for the British empire's thirsty soldiers. In modern-day Pakistan, 97% of the population is Muslim and officially forbidden alcohol.

But Islamic law is not the only thing driving Mr Bhandara's sales down.

The snob factor can also hit domestic products: the drinks cabinets of the middle classes in Sind and Punjab often hold the preferred tipple of the elite, Johnnie Walker Black Label scotch. It costs £50 on the black market.

"People get worked up at the Friday sermons in the mosques. There is a certain hypocrisy here," Mr Bhandara said.

He is Zoroastrian Parsee, so exempt from the alcohol ban, though most of the workers in the plant are Muslim.

Even the head of state, General Pervez Musharraf, whose official residence sits across the street from the brewery, is known to enjoy a drink or two after a long day at military headquarters.

The general may be a moderate but there is a large and vocal group of Islamic leaders who do not look kindly on the Murree brewery.

Under the 1978-88 rule of General Zia-ul Haq, an observing Muslim, the brewery was briefly shut.

The current corps commander for Sind, Lieutenant-General Muzaffer Usmani, known as a strict Muslim, is thought to be behind the closure of the off-licences. Religious parties are clamouring for a pure Islamic state.

Now the Murree brewery is going into soft drinks. "We live one day at a time, but we are preparing for the day when we might not have alcohol around," Mr Bhandara said.

Nevertheless, he is launching a new blended scotch, a 12-year malt, and Millennium Beer, which packs a powerful 8% alcohol level.

"Pakistanis don't drink beer for the taste," a Muslim worker at the brewery said.

"They drink it to fly like kites."

webTitle: Compensation claim for crop damage upsets Sarah Payne's family

fields.headline: Compensation claim for crop damage upsets Sarah Payne's family
fields.trailText: The owner of a field near to where Sarah Payne went missing over three weeks ago has upset the murdered eight-year-old's relatives by demanding compensation for the damage caused to his crops by police search teams.
fields.body:
The owner of a field near to where Sarah Payne went missing over three weeks ago has upset the murdered eight-year-old's relatives by demanding compensation for the damage caused to his crops by police search teams.

A police source who visited the family yesterday said they had reacted in "disbelief" to the £10,000 claim. The source said they had been in "a particularly low mood".

Detectives from Sussex police are also said to be surprised and angered by the timing and circumstances of the claim, which came as the investigation team were being deluged with more than 2,000 calls a day.

Paul Langmead, of Roundstone farm in Ferring, near Worthing - which is only 150 metres from Sarah's grand parents' home - put in the claim after officers spent two weeks scouring cornfields around the spot where Sarah was last seen playing with her brothers and sister on July 1.

A spokesman for Sussex police said: "We have asked for clarification of the exact nature of the damage." They estimate that about three acres of the farm were affected by their search.

In a statement read out on Mr Langmead's behalf at the gate to Roundstone farm, he said he was very upset at the events of the last three weeks and promised any compensation would be donated to a Sarah Payne fund.

"I, and my farm staff, have been deeply distressed by the tragic disappearance and murder of Sarah," he said. "However, we cannot afford to ignore the fact that, through no fault of the police, many thousands of pounds worth of damage have been done to our crops.

"It was entirely proper that the police should have been notified promptly that a quantified claim would be submitted in due course, so that they, or their insurers, could make their own assessment of the damage."

He added that he felt deep sympathy for the Payne family and hoped that Sarah's murderer would be brought to justice as quickly as possible.

"It goes without saying that I, and my farm staff, will continue to help the police in every possible way during the weeks ahead and any compensation received from Sussex police will be donated to the Sarah Payne Fund," he said.

A spokeswoman for the National Farmers' Union said it was not prepared to back Mr Langmead's claim at this stage. "Unless something unforeseen happens, it is a matter between him and Sussex police," she said.

But one industry expert said: "With harvest only weeks away, damage to crops could not come at a worse time and will hit him hard. There would be no prospect of any recovery before harvest time."

The murder inquiry, which involved up to 150 officers during the initial search for Sarah, has so far cost more than £400,000.

Detectives yesterday said they were continuing intensive searches around the field near Pulborough, West Sussex, where Sarah's body was found on Monday, and the spot four miles away where her shoe was discovered on Thursday.

They were particularly looking for Sarah's other shoe and clothing, including a blue tennis dress.

webTitle: Poorest regions promised increase in funds and power

fields.headline: Poorest regions promised increase in funds and power
fields.trailText: Depressed regions in England were yesterday promised significantly more cash and greater freedom from Whitehall to create more jobs, redevelop derelict land, and improve run down neighbourhoods.
fields.body:
Depressed regions in England were yesterday promised significantly more cash and greater freedom from Whitehall to create more jobs, redevelop derelict land, and improve run down neighbourhoods.

The chancellor and the deputy prime minister told the heads of England's eight new regional development agencies (RDAs) to pursue a more strategic role embracing housing, transport and higher education.

Outlining a 10% inflation-plus increase in agency budgets, Gordon Brown and John Prescott promised RDA chairmen that their organisations would shortly be backed by funding drawn from three departments, principally the deputy prime minister's environment, regions and transport empire.

Ministers last night stressed that giving the RDAs greater influence - by working with councils, universities, transport operators and housing providers - was as important as the extra cash, which will see budgets rise by £500m to £1.7 bn in 2003.

The move comes two weeks after delegates at Labour's National Policy Forum decided that the next Labour government should commit itself to directly-elected regional government in England "where there is demand" - placing the RDAs, effectively business-led quangoes, under democratic control.

John Prescott, who is pressing for a firm commitment on English devolution in Labour's next manifesto - notably a white paper, leading to a bill - said yesterday that the RDAs had emerged from the spending review as the "strategic leaders of economic development and regeneration in the regions".

The deputy prime minister said that extra funds would allow the agencies to "fire on all cylinders".

With an eye on disaffected voters in Labour's heartlands, Gordon Brown said radical new measures were needed to help poorly performing regions by strengthening economies and promoting social renewal.

"We need to attack the cause of poverty - too few jobs and too little economic activity - and empower local people with the skills and confidence they need to build the enterprising businesses that work."

Although the share of new money has to be worked out between the eight RDAs, some ministers will be pressing for northern and midlands regions to get the lion's share of the extra cash in recognition of higher unemployment, often three times above the level of the booming south-east.

Yesterday's meeting is a further indication that Tony Blair's earlier opposition to special aid for depressed regions has been overtaken by events - namely the party's dismal local election performance in its heartlands two months' ago.

Fewer ministers would now trumpet the Prime Minister's claim that disparities within regions - even the booming south-east - are often greater than any north south divide.

A subsequent Cabinet Office report supporting this claim is now regarded by some as an embarrassment.

A recent government-sponsored report from the centre for advanced studies at Cardiff University accused ministers of concealing the north south gulf for "political reasons".

It found that while London and the south-east is performing as well as the world's top 10 competitive nations, such as Singapore and Switzerland, regions such as Yorkshire and Humberside and the north-east could be ranked alongside countries like Hungary and Chile.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, acknowledged the north south divide yesterday, promising £50m from his department for a new regional innovation fund.

webTitle: Car shredder clue to lost woman

fields.headline: Car shredder clue to lost woman
fields.trailText: Detectives searching for a missing woman have discovered fragments of bone or tooth in a scrap yard vehicle shredder, police confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Detectives searching for a missing woman have discovered fragments of bone or tooth in a scrap yard vehicle shredder, police confirmed yesterday.

Officers investigating the disappearance of Zoe Simpson, who was 24 when she vanished from her home in Manchester in October 1996, re-opened their inquiry last April following a tip-off directing them to a scrap metal merchant's in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire. The huge Lindemann shredder, one of only four in the country, swallows cars whole, retaining metal for recycling and depositing the rest as slurry in a tank. It has not been used for two years.

Archaeologists from Manchester university have been helping detectives examine the machine, but police stressed it could be up to four weeks before they could be sure whether fragments found among the debris in the tank are human.

Miss Simpson, who left two children, now 10 and four, moved to Manchester in 1994 to live with her boyfriend, Karl Richardson. He was arrested but released without charge.

Detective Superintendent Andy Tattersall said he believed vital clues may lie with people who had known her in her home town, Macclesfield, in Cheshire. "We are convinced Zoe has been killed. I feel strongly that we are closing in on those responsible."

Miss Simpson disappeared just before she was due to inherit several thousand pounds. The money remains in trust.

fields.headline: Garden of Eden restored
fields.standfirst: Royal Holloway chapel gets a facelift
fields.trailText: The rabbit in the garden of Eden gets no mention in the Bible, but he is the central figure in one of the most extraordinary Victorian chapels, where conservation work is nearing completion.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The rabbit in the garden of Eden gets no mention in the Bible, but he is the central figure in one of the most extraordinary Victorian chapels, where conservation work is nearing completion.

The building was created by Thomas Holloway, a 19th century millionaire, when he established Holloway College, in Egham, Surrey - an eccentric Grade I listed building bristling with towers, turrets and flying buttresses. The chapel is still in daily use by students of Royal Holloway, now part of the University of London.

Most of the chapel's plasterwork is of extremely high quality. The master craftsman died during the work, and the apse was finished by his apprentices. At the centre of the vault, where most chapels would have a cross or a figure of Christ, the Holloway chapel has a white rabbit, sitting up and looking around Eden with a slightly anxious air. His gaze is fixed on the figure of Eve, being created from Adam's rib.

Holloway's 1883 deed of foundation records state that he wanted his ecumenical chapel to inspire "most forcibly in the minds of the students their individual responsibility, and their duty to God". His architect, William Crossland, thought it would remind people of the Sistine Chapel. However, Crossland's death before completion left it open more to ridicule than awe.

A journalist who visited the chapel in the 1890s wrote: Whether he [Adam] objects to Eve's super-abundance of adipose tissue, or whether he demurs at taking for his mate a lady with a canary-coloured wig is not explained; but the father of the human race evidently looks upon the whole affair as a somewhat doubtful joke."

The ceiling was in such poor condition that nets were stretched under it to prevent the figures falling onto the congregation.

The plasterwork has now been put invisibly back into place and the first complete clean since it was built has revealed shimmering real gold leaf.

Architect Peter Riddington, who also restored Windsor Castle after the fire in 1992, said: "Royal Holloway is a pretty wacky place, but the chapel is undoubtedly the wackiest bit of all.

"It is the job that's given me most pleasure of any I have worked on."

Architect Peter Riddington, who also restored Windsor Castle after the fire in 1992, said: "Royal Holloway is a pretty wacky place, but the chapel is undoubtedly the wackiest bit of all. "It is the job that's given me most pleasure of any I have worked on."

The novel is now in development with Granada Films.

Although my heroine is in her twenties, not thirties, (and even younger in the film script) she uses the exclamation OH GOD! frequently and has friends with ludicrous names - Sapphire, Tricky, Giancarlo, Skara, Eloise Tartan, Dick Dinkins and so on.

She has a posh, mad, mother and a fistful of lovers. I don't remember using any lists, but there is a great deal of product placement in the book: 192, Harrods, Prozac, Floyd on Fish and star placement - Ralph Fiennes, Daniel Day-Lewis, Gary Oldman and many more.

When the paperback came out in 1997 (Mandarin), it was reviewed in your paper as being in the same ball park as Gentlemen Prefer Blondes - at that time the only previous reference to the single girl diary genre. Kate Morris
London

fields.headline: Customer relations department
fields.trailText: Last Saturday's article on customer service by Richard Colbey (Sad to say, taking hostages is illegal, July 15) made a number of unfounded and unsubstantiated allegations about the commitment of the Dixons Group to its customers.
fields.body:
Last Saturday's article on customer service by Richard Colbey (Sad to say, taking hostages is illegal, July 15) made a number of unfounded and unsubstantiated allegations about the commitment of the Dixons Group to its customers.

As we repeatedly made clear, Dixons places the highest priority on customer service, as we hope our recent multi-million pound investment in a customer service centre in Sheffield will testify. While we accept that no such service is perfect, objective journalism should differentiate between the particular, and we hope rare, experience where things fall short of our standards and the more typical experience of our millions of satisfied customers. Although we provided detailed responses and refutations of many of the points in the article, little of this appeared in print.

For the record, I would like to make clear the following points. As far as we are aware, after thorough checks, the customer mentioned in the article who resorted to kidnapping her washing machine manufacturer's engi neer had not contacted us either at store level or though the customer services department. We assured Mr Colbey that it is our policy to arrange repairs of goods that are demonstrably faulty while under guarantee and would have done so had we been aware of this case.

Dixons also gave an assurance that there was no policy for its customer services director not to talk to customers. In fact the company has an agreed and understood escalation procedure within its customer services department.

Although Mr Colbey reported his experience in failing to get through to our customer services department the article did not include our explanation that we are currently migrating this department to the new centre in Sheffield, of which the first phase has recently opened. In total the company expects to invest £45m in this facility which, when fully operational, will create some 2,000 jobs. No such operation is foolproof and we regret those infrequent instances where customers may feel let down. In such cases we do all we can to put things right as soon as possible.

Our employees and our training schemes have won awards for customer service (including, among others, the DTI's Consumers First award) which is difficult to reconcile with the allegations carried in the article.

Lastly we are amazed at the absurd suggestion that national retailers value their reputation any less than small retailers. Nothing could be further from the truth. Nor are there any grounds for the claim that small retailers are likely to be cheaper than our stores. Independent price checkers compare our and our competitors' prices on hundreds of products nationwide several times a week in order that we cannot be beaten on price. To be doubly sure we offer a price promise to match any local price.

Perhaps the best advice is for your readers to ignore the cynics and find out for themselves.

Lesley Smith
Group director, Corporate and Public Affairs, Dixons Group plc

fields.headline: Tales of the riverbank
fields.trailText: Our village has been abuzz since the news of specially bred voles being introduced into the wild (Saving the vole: top secret operation under way, July 18) as our village's charitable trust has been waging a war against the voles for the past three years and has probably accounted for a fair number of them.
fields.body:
Our village has been abuzz since the news of specially bred voles being introduced into the wild (Saving the vole: top secret operation under way, July 18) as our village's charitable trust has been waging a war against the voles for the past three years and has probably accounted for a fair number of them.

First, despite environment agency advice, it was only just prevented from digging up the voles' burrows by last minute police action - life is not dull in the sticks you know, it's all excitement here. This was followed by months of rows in the parish council between councillors wanting the law kept, at least on the PC-owned village green, through which the stream runs, and trustees determined to be rid of "'ermin".

For all the last three summers, the stream has been repeatedly, frequently and unnecessarily cleared and foliage close strimmed, including all the lovely wildflowers which used to grow there. This both starved the poor critters and exposed them to predators, and we had been hoping our local wildlife trust would ensure prosecution. Then last month a pest control expert was hired to put poison into the voles' burrows.

A number of us will be sending the trust cuttings of your piece; one wonders if at last somebody somewhere will take action?
Lesley Lovell
Steventon, Oxon
lesleylovell@clara.net

fields.headline: Archbishop says sorry
fields.trailText: Your report (Catholic leader appointed paedophile priest, July 20) and leading article made no reference to the fact that in recent years the bishops of England and Wales established strict pastoral and procedural guidelines to ensure that any allegations of clerical child abuse are dealt with promptly, in conjunction with the statutory authorities, including the police.
fields.body:
I would like to comment on your coverage of my handling of the Michael Hill case. Your report (Catholic leader appointed paedophile priest, July 20) and leading article made no reference to the fact that in recent years the bishops of England and Wales established strict pastoral and procedural guidelines to ensure that any allegations of clerical child abuse are dealt with promptly, in conjunction with the statutory authorities, including the police.

Any further comment by myself concerning the Michael Hill case might seem to be defensive, which is not my reaction to this unhappy affair. My primary concern is for the victims who have been scarred by the abuse of a priest. My heart goes out to all victims of child abuse and in particular to the victims of Michael Hill.

I would like to say how truly sorry I am that these things should have happened. Most Rev Cormac Murphy-O'Connor
Archbishop of Westminster

In 1960, when I was a very new teacher, a 13-year-old girl told me she was being sexually abused by her father. I had no experience of such things but common sense made me persuade her that we should involve the police, and she agreed. Eventually this led to her father's imprisonment.

Apparently in the 1980s a bishop's common sense suggested that such a matter be hushed up. I think the Catholic church needs a leader with more common sense than a 21-year-old PE teacher.
Janet Nightingale
Rowley Regis, West Midlands janet.nightingale@which.net

fields.headline: All meat and no veg
fields.trailText: Here we go again: "vegetarians..." and their "noted qualities of tolerance and humour" (Why is veggie food so bad?' G2, July 21).
fields.body:
Here we go again: "vegetarians..." and their "noted qualities of tolerance and humour" (Why is veggie food so bad?' G2, July 21).

Do me a lemon. Every time my intolerant, humourless veggie friends accompany me to a decently meaty restaurant they get offered this poncy separate menu. Yet when I'm compelled to join them at one of their pulse pavilions I'm never offered a list of meat options. Isn't there something in the European convention about this blatant discrimination?
John Armstrong
London

I would like to assure John-Paul Gower (Letters, July 21) that at all three UK theme parks we have visited, priority was given to our learning-disabled daughter. At Alton Towers, Chessington and Thorpe Park you go to the exit instead of the entrance to the ride, and the staff will let you get on the ride as soon as they can. Also, you quite often get front seats!
Barbara Williams
Sparsholt, Oxon
barham@btinternet.com

Simon Hoggart refers to the "little old ladies" in Somerfields (Diary, Saturday Review, July 15). Why are old ladies always "little", and why don't we read about little old gentleman? There are quite a few in this town.
EM Symonds
Harlow, Essex

Is Wallace Arnold (String 'em all up, I say, July 21) the coach company boss? If so, this may explain his appointment to the Special Sentencing Policy Review (on the assumption that a coach driver knows about as much about sentencing as a taxi driver, and has the same sense of humour). The review needs these qualities more than it needs to be burdened by any liberal tendencies that might want to consider evidence that doesn't come from the gut or a focus group.
Andy Wilson
London
andy.wilson@newscientist.net

fields.headline: More turmoil over leaks
fields.trailText: On the morning after you reported a major, possibly definitive spending review, you give us acres of print about leaks. This froth only "threatens to overshadow the huge increase in public spending" mentioned in passing in your frontpage article (No 10 insider is leak suspect, July 20) because that is what you decide.
fields.body:
On the morning after you reported a major, possibly definitive spending review, you give us acres of print about leaks. This froth only "threatens to overshadow the huge increase in public spending" mentioned in passing in your frontpage article (No 10 insider is leak suspect, July 20) because that is what you decide.

The likes of Philip Gould can "knock the Labour good news out of the headlines" (your leader) because you cannot resist a media-related story. Or is it because you prefer bad news for Labour? You may see yourselves as a cut above the "maliciously hostile Conservative press" (your leader again), but you have a case to answer nonetheless. Margaret Pelling Oxford

Philip Gould says New Labour has been undermined by spin, amongst other things, and he concludes "We need to reinvent the New Labour brand" (Gould's dire warning to Labour, July 20). If they drop the New word, to "get back in touch", what's that, if not spin?
Max Hess
Folkestone, Kent
max@truesocialism.freeserve.co.uk

The PM could save a lot of money by sacking Philip Gould and hiring my husband. At least two months before Mr Gould's leaked memo, my husband told me he thought the government could well lose the next election as its support was not solid but meringue-like. V Crews
Beckenham, Kent

I was most concerned to read (Ministers try to shrug off memo, July 20) that education secretary David Blunkett wants "less memos". Perhaps more grammar lessons might be in order, along with fewer of those troublesome leaks.
William Mills
London

When I was the full-time agent of the city of Leeds Labour party in the early 1960s, a bright young journalist of your paper bounced into my office in Queens Square and offered his services (unpaid) to us. In my view he was one of the best media manipulators in the business. His election address as the Labour candidate for Moortown was one of the best that bears my imprint as the publisher.

Bernard Ingham, for it was he, could teach our col leagues a great deal about the need to "keep your trap shut" and "to put your pen in your pocket", and "switch off the word processor".

The real lesson is that old-style Labour agents might well be better to advise politicians than brilliant young journalists are. But at 83 I am not offering my services; I am too busy painting the garden shed.
Alderman Sir Richard Knowles
Birmingham city council

I felt I had to write to say thank you for your relentless attacks on Tony Blair and New Labour and your daily criticisms of their failures and inadequacies. I write on behalf of my husband and family as well.

I must confess that our daily newspaper is the Telegraph, but the Guardian is available at work and for quite a long time now I have been reading it. I am delighted that you have seen through New Labour. Not only that, you have started to praise William Hague and Michael Portillo

The day you actually advise your readers to vote for the Conservatives will be the day we start buying the Guardian, as well as the Telegraph. Ann Waters
Thornton Heath, Surrey

webTitle: Business: meger between Glaxo and SmithKline

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst: Glaxo/SmithKline merger
fields.trailText: The creation of Britain's new drugs powerhouse has been surprisingly low key, with a mixture of scepticism and indifference greeting the proposed £120bn merger between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham .
fields.body:
The creation of Britain's new drugs powerhouse has been surprisingly low key, with a mixture of scepticism and indifference greeting the proposed £120bn merger between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham .

Shares in the two companies have been treading water since they announced the tie-up in January, but both will make a final effort to sell the deal next week with their last individual results.

Glaxo's Sir Richard Sykes will struggle to deliver a final flourish and is likely to face hard questions on irritable bowel syndrome. The group's new product for the disorder, Lotronex, has been a bit of a flop. Analysts expect revenue from the drug of just £15m, because American doctors see irregular bowels as a nuisance, rather than an illness.

Interim profits should reach about £1.5bn, helped by one-off gains, a strong performance from the asthma treatment Flixotide and good figures from HIV drugs.

The smaller partner in the merger, SmithKline, is likely to be more impressive. Jean-Pierre Garnier will face scrutiny as chief executive for the first time but should report underlying profits growth of about 12%.

The antidepressant Paxil continues to sell well, as does the new diabetes treatment, Avandia.

Drugs shares have suffered this year from anxiety about possible changes to healthcare funding in the United States. A trend towards rationing in the NHS has not helped, although Britain is a relatively small market.

There are long-term doubts about the strength of Glaxo SmithKline's combined research pipeline, and about the effect of the internet - where unauthorised drug sales could affect the big groups' profits.

The shares are unlikely to excite in the short-term, although sheer size will make Glaxo SmithKline a safe haven for longer-term investors.
