fields.body:
At last some real excitement in the London market and it all started when HSBC Securities cut its rating on cable company Telewest Communications to "sell" from "hold".

Dealers claimed HSBC had made the move after a call to a Telewest service line revealed that the roll-out of its digital TV service, a crucial weapon in the battle against BSkyB, had been delayed by three to four months.

As Telewest shares went into reverse, plunging 10%, it soon became clear that something was behind the speculation and by mid-morning Telewest was forced to reveal that it had suspended marketing of the service.

The problem, it said, was the lack of set-top boxes. Supplier Pace Micro Technologies, it seems, has run out of the flash-memory cards, a central component in the boxes, and cannot provide any more because of a general shortage of the cards.

Although Pace described the problem as a "temporary blip", this was little consolation to Telewest, whose shares closed down 23p at 235p. Pace fared better, unchanged at 955p, but bears in the stock believe it could be in for a rocky ride next week. They claim Telewest has cause for financial redress from Pace. A spokesman for Pace refused to comment on the nature of the contract with Telewest.

Meanwhile, the FTSE 100, down 90.6 points at 6,378.4, was busy registering its biggest one-day points fall since May 19 and market heavyweight Vodafone AirTouch was the chief culprit. Its shares fell 11p to 296p, wiping nearly 30 points from the main index. Opinion was divided as to the cause. Some blamed declines on Wall Street, others a warning from Ericsson that component shortages would hit profits in its mobile phone unit.

There were plenty of other things upsetting investors. One was a friendly bid by Anglo American - down 123p to £32.82 - for Australian group North. The bid, which topped an offer from rival Rio Tinto, 18p weaker at £10.60, is an attempt to capture a sizeable position in the world's iron ore export market.

But analysts doubt the deal will create shareholder value. Unlike Rio, Anglo does not have substantial iron ore operations in Australia and will therefore not be able to leverage significant operating synergies, they say. UBS Warburg responded by cutting its rating on Anglo to "hold" from "buy".

Holders of Granada Media shares,29p weaker at 577p, were also fretting after Carlton Communications, off 13p at 802p, and United News & Media, up 14p to 958, scrapped their merger. Granada Media is now likely to launch an offer for United and the City always treats takeovers with suspicion.

On the upside, Kingfisher shares were up 7p to 560p as it found much-needed support from broker Deutsche Bank.

For the best part of the week, shares in Kingfisher have been on a downward trend after a number of brokers trimmed forecasts following pre-closed season meetings with the company. By Thursday they had their hit lowest closing level since May 9.

But Deutsche Bank analyst Rod Whitehead believes the fall has gone too far and has slapped a "buy" recommendation and 750p price target on the owner of the B&Q and Woolworths chains. He claims the downgrades reflect higher than expected spending on its Big W format and not problems with its core DIY business, which by all accounts is roaring ahead.

Kingfisher shareholders should also take heart from rumours that the company's investor relations department has suspended any further broker visits.

Lower down the market, Singer & Friedlander rose 19.5p to 244p as it warned profits would be better than expected. However, QXL fell 6.75p to 85p as stockbroking powerhouse Goldman Sachs downgraded the internet action group and took the red pen to forecasts.

Among small-cap stocks, port owner Powell Duffryn surged 81p to 545p after revealing "approaches that could lead to an offer".

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.body:
Pinochet ruling awaited

Human rights lawyers are cautiously optimistic after a three-day hearing that the Chilean supreme court will confirm a ruling stripping Gen Augusto Pinochet, 84, of immunity from prosecution. The court is due to decide in the next three weeks.

Thousands died and disappeared in Chile between 1973 and 1990. Jonathan Franklin, Santiago

Two indicted for Olympics bribes

Two former executives on the Salt Lake City Olympic committee were indicted on Thursday on fraud and conspiracy charges for allegedly bribing Olympic officials to secure the 2002 winter Games for Utah.

Thomas Welch, 55, and David Johnson, 41, are alleged to have paid more than $1m in cash and bogus contracts. Washington Post

More hostages freed in Jolo

Islamic rebels yesterday freed two Filipino women and three Malaysians held hostage for four months, officials said. They were among dozens of mostly foreign hostages held by Abu Sayyaf rebels on Jolo island, 600 miles south of Manila. Reuters, Jolo

Helicopter crash kills 19

Nineteen airmen were killed yesterday when a helicopter crashed after taking off from a military airfield in northern Russia, the air force said. The 16 paratroopers and three crew were on a training flight in Levashovo, just north of St Petersburg. AP, Levashovo

Mandela backs girl power

The former South African president Nelson Mandela has urged the married women of Burundi to ostracise their husbands if they refuse to sign a peace deal on August 28. He suggested they refuse to talk to their husbands or cook for them. Reuters, Arusha, Tanzania

fields.headline: Food for BAT thoughts
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco, itself the product of a demerger, might have scope for another carve-up.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco, itself the product of a demerger, might have scope for another carve-up.

According to analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the tobacco group should consider spinning off its troubled Brown & Williamson operation in the United States.

The idea is to emulate US rival Philip Morris, which is spinning off part of its Kraft foods unit and buying the food combine Nabisco, although the company insists it is not a prelude to full scale division of its food and tobacco operations.

The Dresdner analysts believe the Kraft spin-off shows US investors still see value in the rump tobacco business, despite the waves of litigation.

They suggest Brown & Williamson could be demerged, with BAT shares worth around 600p. Yesterday they closed down 7.5p at 392.5p. Something BAT chairman Martin Broughton might investigate?

webTitle: Diplomatic row as ship held captive

fields.headline: Diplomatic row as ship held captive
fields.trailText: The fate of the world's biggest tall ship, the 122-metre (400ft) Russian four-master Sedov, was in the hands of a French court yesterday, the innocent victim of a 10-year commercial dispute which has developed into a full-scale diplomatic row between the two countries.
fields.body:
The fate of the world's biggest tall ship, the 122-metre (400ft) Russian four-master Sedov, was in the hands of a French court yesterday, the innocent victim of a 10-year commercial dispute which has developed into a full-scale diplomatic row between the two countries.

The court said yesterday that it would rule on Monday whether the French authorities were legally justified in impounding the sail-training vessel at a tall ships regatta in Brest, Brittany, last week.

The seizure, at the request of a Swiss trading firm, Noga, which claims it is owed $800m (£530m) by the Russian government, has made Moscow furious and dealt a blow to Franco-Russian relations, badly strained by Paris's criticism of the Chechen war.

The duma, the Russian lower house of parliament, censured Paris this week and called for French property in Russia to be confiscated in retaliation for the "unfriendly gestures".

As part of the dispute, French courts have frozen the bank accounts of the Russian diplomatic mission in Paris.

The Sedov - on a summer tour of European ports with its 176-strong Russian crew of sailors, cadets and schoolboys - was allowed out at the weekend for four days, with two French navy officers on board to ensure that it did not try to escape and under court orders to return to Brest before 9.30am yesterday, in time for the hearing.

"This is the first time in maritime history a school ship has been impounded," Michel Quimbert, a lawyer for the ship's owners, the technical university in the northern Russian town of Murmansk, told the court. "It is not right for children to be taken hostage."

The mayor of Moscow, Yuri Luzhkov, has written to the French president, Jacques Chirac, to protest at the treatment of 15 Moscow schoolchildren on the ship. "

They are hostages in a dispute which is none of their making, and their fate is a tragic one," he said.

Mr Quimbert argued in court that the university could not be held responsible for the dispute, and demanded Fr500,000 and DM600,000 (£250,000) in compensation.

But lawyers for Noga - which wants an immediate payment of $63m as an advance on the money it says it is owed for oil-for-food deals it arranged for Russia in the early 1990s - said the state-run university should be liable for the debts.

Twenty of the 100 naval students on board the Sedov attended yesterday's hearing in full uniform, together with the captain, Viktor Mishenev.

"We really do not understand what is going on," said Sergei, a cadet.

"We came along for a big party, and all we have found is bitterness and restrictions."

In recent days the cadets, who were paid just £125 for their three-month tour of ports in France, Germany, Holland and Madeira, have begun asking the long queues of French visitors to the Sedov for a £2 "solidarity contribution".

Others have been selling Russian dolls to earn extra cash.

The Sedov was built in Germany in 1921 and carried nitrates from Chile and cotton from Australia.

It was ceded to Britain as war reparation in 1946 and passed on to the Soviet Union, which renamed it in honour of a leading Russian polar explorer. It passed into the hands of the Murmansk university in 1991.

fields.headline: Skaters brought to heel
fields.trailText: The inline skate has become too popular for its own good in Paris: a Friday-night parade which regularly draws more than 25,000 skaters was called off by the police for the second consecutive week yesterday because of safety fears.
fields.body:
The inline skate has become too popular for its own good in Paris: a Friday-night parade which regularly draws more than 25,000 skaters was called off by the police for the second consecutive week yesterday because of safety fears.

The three-hour, 15-mile blur of outsized sweatshirts and flailing limbs moving at random through the city for the past three years has grown so big that the police can no longer guarantee the safety of the skaters and other road users, and want to confine it to one of four fixed routes.

"It now takes up to half an hour for the Rollerbladers to pass by," said Jean-Claude Terrier, head of the police traffic department, which gives the parade a motorcycle escort.

"That means that for 30 minutes, major road junctions are completely impassable. What's the legal position, for example, if once of the vehicles blocked is an ambulance with a critically ill patient on board?"

Skaters were treated as pedestrians in French traffic law and had no business on the roads. "What we want to do is... keep them to certain predetermined routes," he said.

But the parade organisers are vehemently opposed to the restrictions.

"Rollerblades are about freedom and choice," said Boris Belohlavek, president of Pari-Roller. "Confining us to fixed routes will kill the spirit of the event and encourage wildcat parades - people will just get bored with the official one."

webTitle: Biotech start-up Vernalis set for first drug launch

fields.headline: Biotech start-up Vernalis set for first drug launch
fields.trailText: Vernalis, one of Britain's biotechnology pioneers, yesterday won approval to sell its first product, a pill providing 24-hour relief from migraines.
fields.body:
Vernalis, one of Britain's biotechnology pioneers, yesterday won approval to sell its first product, a pill providing 24-hour relief from migraines.

Medical authorities in France gave the green light for the company to launch the drug, called Migard, later this year.

This will trigger automatic approval in other European Union countries.

Nick Heightman, commercial director of Vernalis, said: "This is a very important milestone for us.

"It shows that at least one of the start-up companies in the British biopharmaceuticals industry has started to deliver," he said.

Vernalis's shares jumped 17.5p to 235p on the news.

The group joins a select club of small-scale drug development companies that have launched a product - among the others is Celltech, which recently joined the FTSE 100.

Analysts believe Migard could snatch 10% of the market for migraine drugs, which is worth about $2bn (£1.3bn) worldwide.

However, Vernalis will get about 17% of the revenue; the rest will go to its marketing and development partners.

Migard works by constricting the blood vessels in the brain, which dilate to cause severe headaches.

Vernalis, formerly Vanguard Medica, says that Migard provides relief for a whole day, in contrast to existing migraine drugs which work for only four to six hours.

The approval comes after a difficult period for Vernalis: regulators in the US rejected Migard, asking for more clinical trials.

The company recently had unsuccessful merger talks with a rival, CeNeS Pharmaceuticals, and its shares have collapsed from a peak of 697p two years ago.

Max Herrmann, an analyst at Charterhouse Securities, said he thought that the City would be likely to remain wary: "Royalties from this should move them into profits but not until 2004. That's too far out for investors."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Swaledale
fields.trailText: The sun has been shining, so, in the words of the old adage, they have been making hay up in Swaledale. This means that the region's press photographers have also been out in the sun, because haymaking in Swaledale is one of those traditional events, like a local agricultural show.
fields.body:
The sun has been shining, so, in the words of the old adage, they have been making hay up in Swaledale. This means that the region's press photographers have also been out in the sun, because haymaking in Swaledale is one of those traditional events, like a local agricultural show.

They still make hay in Swaledale the way my uncles and grandfather did. True, they use machines to bale it, even to turn the drying swaths, but the bales are brick-shaped, capable of being lifted with one hand hooked into the two bands of string. From every hillside comes the "whump, whump" of the baling arms pressing the grass into blocks of winter stock food. All the family turns out, because haymaking is an urgent process. It must be mown, dried just the right amount, baled and stacked as quickly as possible. Wet hay quickly rots, making it fit only for bedding.

The grass must be turned to ensure even drying. Some of the fields are so small and scattered that teams with pitchforks are still used to get the job done. That is when the press photographers turn out, the classic picture being of a plump dales woman turning the hay with a fork, or an elderly husband and wife together, sharing the work.

Swaledale hay meadows are still full of wild flowers. Silage fields may well be having their second cut now and any flowers that are there are hacked into obscurity long before they have any chance to set seed. But haymaking happens at just the right time, so that the mowing actually shakes out the seeds and spreads them across the meadow.

Before the mowing, fields on the outskirts of Muker were blue with wood cranesbill, white with ox-eye daisy and pink with hoary plantain. The drystone walls are hunted for insects by newly fledged families of wrens, while the capstones provide song posts for yellowhammer. Grass verges are blue with meadow cranesbill - why it is wood cranesbill in the meadow and meadow cranesbill outside, I do not know - and any wet area is creamy-white with meadow-sweet.

webTitle: Maison Novelli chef swallows a bitter pill

fields.headline: Maison Novelli chef swallows a bitter pill
fields.trailText: An unusual financial recipe has been served up at Maison Novelli, the Clerkenwell restaurant run by French celebrity chef Jean Christophe Novelli, indicating that the business quietly went into liquidation recently.
fields.body:
An unusual financial recipe has been served up at Maison Novelli, the Clerkenwell restaurant run by French celebrity chef Jean Christophe Novelli, indicating that the business quietly went into liquidation recently.

While diners were still being served food prepared by Mr Novelli last night, ownership is believed to have moved to Jimmy Lahoud, the restaurant financier best known for his backing of Marco Pierre White and his ownership of several famous London restaurants, including Quo Vadis.

According to filings at Companies House, Maison Novelli Limited, which owns Maison Novelli, went into voluntary liquidation last month with debts of more than £200,000 and assets of £13,000.

Its liquidator, Duncan Beat of Morison Stoneham, who was appointed on June 30, said yesterday that the business had been sold to a company called JJ Restaurants, although he was unable to provide details of the owners of this firm.

Mr Beat is working to secure agreements with the remaining creditors, including Bibendum Wines, Customs & Excise, Mr Novelli himself and Christopher Wheeler, a director of the group.

Neither Mr Novelli nor Mr Wheeler would comment yes terday. However, the filings at Companies House show the business was sold for a little over £100,000. Mr Lahoud was not available for comment yesterday, although trade sources said he had agreed to keep Maison Novelli open.

A 25-year veteran of the restaurant sector, Mr Lahoud has backed several of London's top venues, including L'Escargot. He is also said to have sold the Clerkenwell restaurant site to Mr Novelli.

Mr Novelli gained fame when he won a Michelin star in his first year as head chef at the Four Seasons Restaurant, using this as a launch pad for a small chain of restaurants across the capital.

But financial pressures soon forced the sale of all but the Clerkenwell restaurant.

fields.headline: Footnote to Italy's fascist past
fields.trailText: With hindsight, it is obvious that she was embarrassed. The flickering eyes, the shrugging, the raised hands, the mumbled answer: "Early 20s, maybe earlier."
fields.body:
With hindsight, it is obvious that she was embarrassed. The flickering eyes, the shrugging, the raised hands, the mumbled answer: "Early 20s, maybe earlier."

She was the caretaker of my apartment block, had been for decades, so it seemed natural that she should know when it was built.

Like many blocks in Prati, a district near the Vatican, it has a handsome courtyard, marble stairs and yawning windows. Its occupants have a tendency to feel rather grand.

A few months ago some friends dropped by, but Vittorio, an architect, refused to come in. He stayed outside caressing the walls. "Wonderful workmanship. Pure fascist." Or 1932, to be exact.

The design was intended to mimic Rome's imperial grandeur and use as little iron as possible, sparing it for the armed forces, he said.

Had the caretaker lied, or merely been mistaken? In Rome these days it's difficult to tell. For 50 years fascist buildings have been neglected, loathed or mocked.

Pouring concrete among the imperial, renaissance and baroque treasures, modernity had a tough act to follow. That it built largely to glorify Benito Mussolini's takeover in 1922 adds ethical objections to the aesthetic.

But some dissenters are trying to reclaim fascist buildings as beautiful monuments of a daring era. The government's sale of the Foro Italico, a sports complex with colossal marble nude athletes and an obelisk dedicated to Mussolini, has flushed out the period's admirers.

Hold your nose if you must, but architecture that blends the classicism of ancient Rome with 20th-century functionalism and rationalism ought to be appreciated, they say.

What Il Duce intended as a propaganda tool blossomed into a revolutionary movement based on youth and innovation. So cry lonely voices on the political right and in the odd architectural college. They are growing louder.

The prospect of the Foro Italico being turned into venue for entertainment and fast food is making it respectable to salute fascist icons. "Culture cannot be sold!" posters for the once extremist but now mainstream National Alliance party scream. And some leftwingers agree.

Originally called the Foro Mussolini, it encompasses the Casa della Scherma fencing pavilion, the Stadio dei Marmi track stadium, and a 7,600-metre (25,000ft) esplanade of mosaics exalting fascist conquests.

After 30 years of singing its virtues from the University of Rome architecture department, Giorgio Muratore says his colleagues no longer regard him as nuts. Those who dismissed the fencing pavilion, designed by Luigi Moretti, as ugly and fascist were now willing to admit it was beautiful, he said.

Other monumental projects, including railway stations, towns and EUR - a Rome suburb intended as an expo site - could be next on the list for rehabilitation.

Perhaps it's because fascism is no longer seen as viable,but the signs are multiplying. Sit at the corner table of the restaurant in Piazza Agosto and the 30cm lettering on the facing wall becomes visible: Mussolini. He commissioned the square but the sign was defaced for decades and read Musso, donkey. It was recently restored.

Yet it may be too soon for Prof Muratore to yell "Told you so" from his window. Romans are, if not hostile, at least profoundly ambivalent about Il Duce's legacy.

Every weekend the Villa Torlonia park fills up with families, couples and joggers. Dogs and children rummage through the ruined early 19th century villa. A sign says when it was built and the history of the park, but fails to mention that Mussolini lived there. All the locals know any way. The adults never go inside, they don't campaign for its restoration, and they don't brag about its last occupant.

Yet nor do they spray graffiti, dump rubbish or loot it. The villa remains untouched. Out of respect or contempt? It's difficult to tell.

webTitle: Bleak future awaits axed Welsh steelworkers

fields.headline: Bleak future awaits axed Welsh steelworkers
fields.trailText: The axe has been hanging over steelworkers' heads for some time, but confirmation of a fresh round of cutbacks at the enormous Llanwern steelworks in south Wales was no easier to take when the blow finally landed.
fields.body:
The axe has been hanging over steelworkers' heads for some time, but confirmation of a fresh round of cutbacks at the enormous Llanwern steelworks in south Wales was no easier to take when the blow finally landed.

Workers leaving the plant after the morning shift yesterday were grim and depressed following the announcement that 450 jobs are to be lost as part of a cost-cutting drive that will result in the loss of 1,300 jobs throughout the Welsh steel industry.

Adding to the bleak mood is continued uncertainty about the longer term future of Llanwern, where much hinges on a decision by the plant's owners, Corus, on whether to proceed with a multimillion-pound blast furnace investment.

Michael Collins, a 23-year-old cold mill worker, said he did not want to think what would happen if he were among those who had to go. There was not much work to be had in Newport.

"It's pure depression. Everybody is scared," he said. "Nobody knows what is going on."

Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel manufacturer, blamed the cuts on the strength of the pound against the euro.

It said that 400 jobs would go at its Port Talbot works, with a further 300 being shed at Ebbw Vale and at Trostre, near Llanelli. Smaller cuts are being made at other plants in Wales, including the Shotton steelworks on Deeside.

The cutbacks, denounced by opposition leaders in Wales as a devastating blow to the Welsh economy, bring the number of job losses announced since Corus was formed last year by the merger of British Steel and the Dutch firm, Hoogovens, to almost 5,000. All but 680 of the losses have been in the UK. Michael Leahy, leader of the steel union, the ISTC, said the cuts made no economic sense.

He accused the company of "screwing" British steelmakers, whose productivity he defended as being among the highest in the world.

The union is to hold a series of crisis steel summits on Sunday and Monday in order to decide the next steps to save steel jobs in Wales and other steel communities hit by the Corus slimdown.

Llanwern, which once em ployed more than 10,000 people, has seen the loss of 1,000 jobs in recent years. The latest cuts will reduce the workforce to just 2,500 and there are some who fear this may not be the end of the slimdown.

Nick Cragg, the managing director of Corus Strip Products, said the company had to reduce costs and become more efficient in order to secure a viable future.

He said the cutbacks announced yesterday assumed the continuation of the existing plant configuation.

fields.headline: Tomkins offloads RHM for £1.1bn
fields.trailText: Rank Hovis McDougall, the maker of Hovis bread, Bisto gravy and Mr Kipling cakes, was sold yesterday to a private equity group for £1.1bn after long and tortuous negotiations by its owner, the former conglomerate Tomkins.
fields.body:
Rank Hovis McDougall, the maker of Hovis bread, Bisto gravy and Mr Kipling cakes, was sold yesterday to a private equity group for £1.1bn after long and tortuous negotiations by its owner, the former conglomerate Tomkins.

In one the largest transactions of its kind, Doughty Hanson, a venture capital firm, is now expected to fatten up RHM for flotation within the next three to five years.

As a result of the sale, which raised less than the company had hoped, Tomkins will return around £700m to its shareholders. It will be left with its core US-based automotive engineering and construction businesses which are expected to be expanded through acquisition.

Nigel Doughty of Doughty Hanson pledged to build RHM into a leading European food company. "We now intend to build on RHM's stable of long-established brands with market-leading positions by both growing the business organically and making acquisitions to expand in Europe".

The RHM stable already includes McDougalls flour and Cadbury Cakes, and 95% of all British households are estimated to have bought at least one branded product manufactured by RHM.

The deal is one of the largest buyouts arranged by a private company. Doughty Hanson also includes PowderJect Pharmaceuticals which makes needleless injection equipment.

Tomkins shares rose 5p to 217p even though the sale price fell short of the amount hoped for by many investors.

Nick Hyslop, analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said he was not enthusiastic about immediate prospects for the business even though it had shrugged off its conglomerate status.

"It leaves Tomkins with two businesses in the US at a time when it is not a very exciting place to be with economic slowdown on the way."

Tomkins is shedding its conglomerate tag and this disposal comes just three weeks after Greg Hutchings announced he was relinquishing his role as executive chairman of Tomkins while continuing as chief executive. Institutional investors, concerned at a sliding share price and his inability to make a quick sale, had put pressure on Mr Hutchings to end his dual role.

Doughty Hanson will provide £200m from its funds for the transaction with debt financing the balance. It has been talking to Tomkins for nearly a year, over which time the price has been depleted by a slowing in volumes and the cost of opening new facilities.

Sales from Tomkins' food division, of which RHM is by far the largest part, fell from £962.9m for the first half of the fiscal year, to October 1998, to £925.5m 12 months later.

But margins, sales and profits in the core engineering businesses were ahead of expectations in that first half of the financial year on the back of strong US markets.

Various rivals expressed interests in buying parts of RHM, such as the Centuria-branded foods but Tomkins was reluctant to split up the company for fear of being left with the least attractive assets, such as milling and baking.

RHM has some strong brand names with powerful market positions and solid cash flows but they are not considered high-growth.

Tomkins has brought new blood into the business, with David Newlands, former General Electric Company finance director, taking over as chairman.

webTitle: Pentagon's one-sided view of free trade

fields.headline: Pentagon's one-sided view of free trade
fields.standfirst: Notebook Level landing fields needed
fields.trailText: The Yanks are coming. Next week's Farnborough air show will see a greater presence of US aerospace and defence contractors anxious to secure closer links with European counterparts and governments to undermine the foundations of what they fear will be fortress Europe.
fields.body:
The Yanks are coming. Next week's Farnborough air show will see a greater presence of US aerospace and defence contractors anxious to secure closer links with European counterparts and governments to undermine the foundations of what they fear will be fortress Europe.

Days before the biennial bean feast, Jacques Gansler, the Pentagon's under-secretary of defense, said: "Unfortunately, recent large consolidations in Europe, recent European procurement decisions and recent regional advocacy - regarding industrial mergers - demonstrate a fortress Europe model."

Well, he would, wouldn't he? The Pentagon encouraged a spate of US mergers in the 1990s only to discover they stifled competition - and the giant companies ran into financial problems. The DoD now wants to open up its domestic market but only a little - and key contracts are off limits for Europeans.

Meanwhile, the political masters at the Pentagon and state department are urging the European allies to carry a bigger share of the burden of peace keeping and conflict prevention within their borders. And then squeal like Mr Gansler when they order the Meteor missile for Eurofighter against a Raytheon model or opt for the Airbus A400M military transporter - expect France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Belgium and Turkey to follow Britain's lead next week and commit to orders - against Boeing's C17 or Lockheed's C130J.

The Americans still have to learn that it takes two to tango - in step. As John Weston, BAE Systems chief executive, puts it: "We need an industrial structure which helps the transatlantic market ...

"There's an industrial dimension to Nato's development." BAE, with last week's $1.2bn purchase of Lockheed's electronic warfare business, has a strong US foothold that has helped it move from a aircraft maker to a global systems and software company.

Its main European rival, Eads, struggling below its recent float price, wants the Pentagon to give it equal access to the US market, including acquisitions. The Franco-German-Spanish combine is, as CSFB analysts note, overexposed to a likely downturn in the commercial aircraft market and needs to bolster its military business through alliances with US partners - or BAE, despite lingering resentments over its decision to opt for a UK-UK merger (with GEC). None of these conflicts or tensions will be resolved in the bars of Farnborough. For one thing, they need a new White House administration to give the green light for more transatlantic joint ventures, and cross-pond mergers remain a far off vista.

They are inherent in a competitive market rendered more opaque by political friendships and rivalries.

A resurgent Boeing, for instance, will seek to regain ascendancy over Airbus with a series of orders for its stretched 777s and plans to match Airbus's A3XX superjumbo with bigger 747s.

BAE, as Weston admits, cannot yet take on the Americans as prime contractor in their own backyard while the Yanks can and do here. It's up to our US cousins to level the playing-field and allow a few European running-backs on to the pitch.

Inequitable life

Earlier this year, as the dispute with policyholders over guaranteed annuity rates ground on, Equitable Life, the king of the mutual insurers, went into background briefing mode. The press had entirely misunderstood the court case and its financial implications for the society. The much bandied figure of £1.5bn was a chimera put about by over-excited enemies. The true cost would probably be about £50m, at worst £200m. Nothing a great society, with £33bn of assets under its care, could not cope with.

Letters went out to policyholders in February. "I am writing to reassure you ... contrary to many of the reports which appeared in the press, there would be no significant costs imposed on the society if the court of appeal's decision were upheld in the House of Lords. Your society remains, and will continue to re main, financially secure." The letter was signed by managing director Alan Nash.

It is now Equitable's duty to send another letter to policyholders.

One can only guess if such hubris will prevail again. What will surprise many policyholders is that the signature at the bottom will again be Mr Nash's. Despite Equitable's calamitous defeat in the House of Lords, he is to remain at the helm and will steer the company into finding a partner "capable of providing capital support' - read: financial rescue. On the day of the court defeat, and with an ebullience at odds with the unhappy death of the world's oldest mutual society, he said he retained the full support of Equitable's board.

Mr Nash is unlikely to have the full support of Equitable's policyholders. Members will have to vote on a transfer. They should be given the opportunity to put a cross against a motion of no confidence in the board and its directors.

fields.headline: G7 threatens sanctions against launderers
fields.trailText: Countries harbouring money launderers were threatened with sanctions by the world's leading industrialised countries yesterday unless they take tougher action to prevent the proceeds of crime polluting the global financial system.
fields.body:
Countries harbouring money launderers were threatened with sanctions by the world's leading industrialised countries yesterday unless they take tougher action to prevent the proceeds of crime polluting the global financial system.

In a strongly worded statement issued on the first day of their annual summit in Okinawa, Japan, the G7 said they were prepared to take co-ordinated action against those countries and territories which failed to clean up their banking systems.

Some $600bn (£395bn) from drug cartels, mafia barons or other criminal outfits is believed to pass through banks each year - a sum close to the value of the Canadian economy, the world's seventh largest.

"The fight against money laundering is not only a great moral cause but an essential element for a return to more peace and stability in the world," French president Jacques Chirac said yesterday.

The leaders of the G7, later joined by Russia's Vladimir Putin, said they would consider isolating offenders from the international financial system and blocking aid to them if they continued to launder money obtained through illegal activities, including drugs and gun running.

In the G7's sights is a hit list of 15 nations, including Russia, drawn up earlier this summer by the Financial Action Taskforce on Money Laundering, which co-ordinates its activities from the Paris-based Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development.

"There are places that must make corrections, either by annulling laws or passing laws to eliminate money laundering," Mr Chirac said. "If they don't this, naturally we will demand sanctions, up to and including the ending of their operations."

fields.headline: Multi-story structure widens base
fields.standfirst: Brand values Reuters
fields.trailText: Nobody knows why Israel Beer Josaphat chose Reuter as his surname when he was baptised at the age of 29 at St George's Lutheran Chapel, Whitechapel, in 1845. But the decision by Paul Julius Reuter, as he chose to be called, led to the creation of Britain's most valuable brand name, Reuters.
fields.body:
Nobody knows why Israel Beer Josaphat chose Reuter as his surname when he was baptised at the age of 29 at St George's Lutheran Chapel, Whitechapel, in 1845. But the decision by Paul Julius Reuter, as he chose to be called, led to the creation of Britain's most valuable brand name, Reuters.

Interbrand, a specialist consultancy, this week estimated that the Reuters brand is worth £4.9bn, putting it well ahead of other leading British brands such as BP and Shell. However, Reuters ranks only 49th on the world stage where the Coca-Cola name still tops the billing with a value of £48.9bn.

Reuter was born at Cassel, Germany, in 1816, when his father was the acting chief rabbi for the community. His family had religious and business connections and Reuter gained a knowledge of financial affairs while working at a number of banks. He moved to London in 1845, changed his name and religion and got married. He may have chosen Reuter, a relatively common name in Germany, to play down his Jewish origins.

But the change marked the start of his real career. He returned to Germany and became a partner in a Berlin bookshop which he left abruptly - some say with the shop's takings at a book fair - to work as a sub-editor and translator at the Paris news agency run by Charles Havas.

He then branched out on his own in Paris, but the business failed. He returned to Germany, using carrier pigeons to carry stock exchange prices between Aachen and Brussels, exploiting a gap in the telegraph network.

When the gap was filled by new cable a year later, he moved to London and opened an office in the City in 1851. He used the newly opened Calais to Dover submarine cable to transmit stock exchange prices between London and Paris.

His business then widened its scope to provide news for British and mainland European newspapers at a time when few could afford to maintain their own network of foreign correspondents.

Scoops helped to establish Reuters' reputation. It brought the news of President Lincoln's assassination in 1865 to Britain two hours ahead of its rivals but 12 days after the event because of the sea crossing.

Reuters, Havas, and Wolff, the leading British, French and German news agencies, carved up most of the world between them in a secret pact in 1870.

In 1883, a memo, probably written by Reuter's son, Herbert, set out what correspondents were to do. They were to report "fires, explosions, floods, inundations, railway accidents, destructive storms, earthquakes, shipwrecks attended with loss of life, accidents to war vessels and to mail steamers, street riots of a grave character and disturbances arising from strikes; duels between and suicides of persons of note - social or political - and murders of a sensational or atrocious character.

"It is requested that the bare facts be first telegraphed with the utmost promptitude and as soon as possible afterwards a descriptive account, proportionate to the gravity of the incident. Care should, of course, be taken to follow the matter up."

Herbert, who succeeded his father as managing director in 1878, was responsible for some unsuccessful diversifications, including Reuter's Bank. The bank was eventually sold in 1917 to Charles Hatry, the City financier later imprisoned for fraud. Herbert Reuter committed suicide in 1915 after his wife's death, and his own son, Hubert, was killed in Flanders the following year, so ending the founding family's management of the agency.

During the first world war, the number of Reuters shareholders was reduced from 1,200 to two through a Foreign Office and Bank of England-backed deal to prevent the agency from falling into undesirable hands. John Buchan, the politician and author of The Thirty Nine Steps, became the FO's first representative on the Reuters' board.

Julius Reuter had died in Nice in 1899. By then Reuters was a traditional news agency with a worldwide reputation. Technology was to transform the business during the next century, returning it to its roots as a major provider of financial information. It was already using radio to transmit news by 1923 and four years later teleprinters were installed in newspaper offices. The turning point in 1964 was the introduction of a computer-based system to send financial information to market traders throughout the world. This was followed nine years later by a foreign exchange information service.

As computers became smaller and more powerful, Reuters launched a computer-based dealing service. Its profits began to soar on the back of its services to the financial markets. The group was floated in 1984, providing its ultimate shareholders - newspaper groups in Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand - with much needed cash infusions.

A national advertising campaign was undertaken to track down the heirs of the original owners of a handful of Reuters shares, once virtually worthless but now worth millions. The group moved into providing television footage when it bought a controlling stake and eventually full control in Visnews, now renamed Reuters Television. Reuters is now a paid up member of the new economy, with a wide range of computer-based systems and services and one of the biggest private communication networks. It has come a long way from carrier pigeons.

webTitle: Railtrack relents over Christmas mail services

fields.headline: Railtrack relents over Christmas mail services
fields.trailText: Railtrack has reconsidered its decision to close down the rail postal system over Christmas after angry protests from the Post Office.
fields.body:
Railtrack has reconsidered its decision to close down the rail postal system over Christmas after angry protests from the Post Office.

The Post Office confirmed yesterday that Railtrack has agreed to allow 77 per cent of postal trains to operate over the Christmas and New Year period - even though Railtrack is carrying out essential work for the £5.6bn modernisation of the west coast main line between London and Glasgow.

The Post Office said that talks with Railtrack were still continuing to iron out details. But it was pleased that the company had moved substantially from a position of no mail to one "where we will be able to operate some of our trains."

Railtrack has agreed to allow 31 of the Post Office's 40 trains to operate daily over the holiday period from the PO's national rail centre at Willesden, north London, which handles 16m letters a day. The Post Office said that it would send the rest of the mail by road.

John Roberts, chief executive, said that the Post Office had been dismayed at Railtrack's initial plans to close a vital section of the west coast main line - without any consultation.

At the opening of a new mail distribution centre at Bristol, he warned that the continued use of trains to carry letters depended on the industry giving a "speedier and more flexible service."

The Post Office is one of rail's most important customers and Mr Roberts said that the railways had to respond to its customer-focused needs.

The Bristol centre was three years late, almost entirely because of planning delays and disputes between various parts of the railway "over which we have no control". This meant that the PO had been forced to use more road vehicles.

If the railway wanted more business, it would have to improve its performance - otherwise the Post Office might have to use alternative transport. "We want to increase our use of this great form of transport, but this will not, and cannot be at any price."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Anglo trumps Rio's North bid

International mining firm Anglo American launched a friendly A$3.1bn (£1.2bn) cash bid for North yesterday to gain access to the iron ore industry, trumping a hostile move by rival Rio Tinto.

Anglo offered A$4.25 a share, including a five cent dividend from North, well above Rio's A$3.80 a share bid last month.

Anglo also looked to be trying to intimidate its rival bidder, saying it could pay up to A$4.60 per share. Investors in North were clearly warming to the prospect of a bidding war. North shares ended in Australia at A$4.34.

Escort drives into history

The last Ford Escort rolled off the assembly track yesterday. Ford of Europe chairman Nick Scheele brought down the curtain on the car's success story when he drove the 5,202,412th car off the track at the Halewood plant near Liverpool - ending a production run which began in 1968.

"The Ford Escort is a legend in its own lifetime," said Ian McAllister, chairman of Ford of Britain. The next car to be built at the Merseyside plant will be a new Jaguar which goes into production next year. Ford bought Jaguar in 1989.

Richemont beats Gucci

Richemont, the Swiss luxury goods company, yesterday confirmed it had bought the watch business Les Manufactures Horologères for £1.24bn, beating off Gucci and LVMH. Vodafone, which acquired the watchmaker through its takeover of Mannesmann, will receive £1.15bn and the balance will go to Audemars Piguet group, buying out its 40% stake in the Jaeger-LeCoultre subsidiary.

United Utilities spends £500m

United Utilities told the annual meeting it plans to spend £500m over the next five years on an electricity distribution network. The northwest water, electricity and telecoms group, said that present trading was in line with its expectations.

United intends to separate into five business units to deliver more shareholder value. Last year's net profit was £490.2m and total dividend 45.2p.

Virgin Blue faces delay

Richard Branson's Australian start-up airline Virgin Blue said yesterday it was unclear when it would make its maiden flight, after it was unable to meet licence requirements in time for its planned August 3 launch.

The discount carrier said it would reimburse customers who had paid to fly before mid-August, and had temporarily suspended sales.

Ericsson profits soar

LM Ericsson's first-half profits quadrupled as network sales continued to boom, but its shares fell heavily as it warned that component shortages in its mobile phones unit would hit earnings in the third quarter. Pre-tax profit came in at 18.6bn crowns (£1.36bn), beating market forecasts, but included an 8.2bn crown capital gain.

fields.headline: Straight lines
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on...  the need for attribution
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the need for attribution
fields.body:
Last Saturday the editor of the Guardian wrote about changes in the paper's policy towards parliamentary briefings and in particular to the use of anonymous quotes, especially when these are pejorative and seem calculated to damage someone's reputation for political purposes. These juicy quotes are thrown to us like meat to the guard dog, sometimes irresistible but subverting our real purpose to someone else's.

The strapline across the top of the editor's article called his proposals "a Guardian policy to give our readers a fairer deal". If you are reading this column then you probably read his too. In it the editor undertook to codify the new guidelines and to publish them, and that will happen soon.

The paper, in future, he promised, will name the spokesman at official lobby briefings, adopt stricter rules on pejorative quotes and encourage reporters to be as specific as possible about the source of anonymous quotes, when they have to be used, so that the reader has some chance of judging the value of the remarks.

One requirement that is almost certain to figure in the rules now being formulated is that anonymous pejorative quotes, when they are included in stories, will have to be referred to the editor or the editor of the day before any decision is taken to print them. Much of this we have talked over in this column in the past in response to your reactions to what you have seen - not just in the field of politics - as an abuse of anonymity.

We are moving closer to the rules which operate on some papers in the US, such as the New York Times and the Washington Post. Indeed, a journalist from the New York Times came to a meeting in the editor's office last week to discuss the matter with political staff and senior editors.

The editor of the Guardian, in his article, quoted from the extensive guidelines available to journalists on the New York Times. These are readily accessible to the paper's readers and published in book form as The New York Times Manual Of Style And Usage, edited by Allan M Siegal and William G Connolly (Times Books/Random House).

The New York Times, which probably has the strictest code of this kind in the world, says, "Anonymity must not become a cloak for attacks on people..." The Washington Post says, "Every time we ask readers to trust an anonymous source, we are putting our credibility on the line. We should always assume that information provided by confidential informants is weaker than information attributable to real people.

"This means that reporters need to continue looking for on-the-record sources for significant information even if they already have two confidential sources. We must work as hard as we can to minimise the number of attributions to confidential sources throughout the newspaper."

The thrust of the guidelines on both papers, and in the message (shall we call it?) from the editor of the Guardian is: tell the readers as much as possible about the sources of your material. Readers, not unreasonably, want to know where the stuff is coming from, just as they want to know, and are still not always told, where the writer is coming from when that is or may seem to be a factor of possible relevance.

The point was made in the editor's article, and at his meeting, that it is easier for serious newspapers enjoying more or less monopoly positions in the US to apply stringent rules than for British broadsheets buffeted by the fierce winds of competition. That is true.

It has been suggested that the rigour of the US codes has produced "dull" newspapers, the implication appearing to be that if the Guardian adopted a code anywhere near such rigour its sheen, so to speak, would go off. I do not believe that is a serious cause for concern. It confuses presentation with integrity of content.

The guidelines will not eradicate anonymous quotes. Circumstances will remain in which they are useful and unavoidable. The paper will, I am sure, provide opportunities for you to accuse it of lapsing from its stated position.

Many of you will hope, as I know from earlier correspondence on the subject, that the guidelines will extend beyond politics to cover other areas. We have discussed examples in the past - concerning anonymous remarks directed at the appointment of the poet laureate and at the former chairman of the board of the Dome.

It is clear to me that many readers disapprove of their use just as strongly in cases such as these as they do when they occur in our political coverage. When I defended one that I considered justifiable - the remarks about the former chairman of the Dome - I had angry letters from several readers who disagreed with me.

I trust you think the paper is moving in the right direction.

Email: reader@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Rear-Admiral Desmond Callaghan
fields.standfirst: Engineer who presided over the return of the rapid-firing 4.5-inch naval gun
fields.trailText: Rear-Admiral Desmond Callaghan, who has died aged 84, was the prime mover behind the rapid-firing gun that returned triumphantly to favour in the Royal Navy after the Falklands war in 1982, which showed that missiles alone were not a panacea, even in the electronic age.
fields.body:
Rear-Admiral Desmond Callaghan, who has died aged 84, was the prime mover behind the rapid-firing gun that returned triumphantly to favour in the Royal Navy after the Falklands war in 1982, which showed that missiles alone were not a panacea, even in the electronic age.

Only three of the fleet's 34 destroyers and frigates now lack the automatic 114mm (4.5-inch), mark 8 general purpose gun, which can fire 25 shells of 21 kilograms per minute over 22,000 metres. Such is Admiral Callaghan's lasting legacy to the fleet he served as an engineer for a third of a century.

Callaghan went to the Royal Naval College Dartmouth as a cadet before studying for a degree at the Royal Naval Engineering College at Keyham, where he graduated in 1937. His first four years of active service were spent on battleships, including HMS Warspite from September 1939.

It was in this modernised Jutland veteran that he took part in the second battle of Narvik in April 1940, one of the few successes in a botched Allied intervention in Norway. The battleship led a flotilla of small destroyers in a surprise attack on German units, sinking eight enemy fleet destroyers in a fierce action.

Callaghan stayed put when Warspite became the flagship of the Mediterranean Fleet under Sir Andrew Cunningham, Britain's foremost fighting admiral of the war. A period of hectic action followed, including exchanges with the Italian fleet, as well as escorting convoys to besieged Malta. Warspite was also involved in the fighting in north Africa, Greece and Crete in 1941, when defeat in the Balkans was snatched from the jaws of imminent victory in Libya.

By that time, Callaghan had been sent ashore to help maintain the British Army's tanks, overstretched in the forward rush to expel the Italians from north Africa. But after the German General Rommel's arrival in February 1941, the rout was reversed and Callaghan had to help demolish facilities in Benghazi before the advancing Afrika Korps arrived.

Withdrawing to Derna, he seized a local fishing boat, which he renamed HMS Eskimo Nell, thus becoming the first engineer-officer in naval history to command a warship, complete with machine-guns and one light cannon. Fleeing to Mersa Matruh, aided only by a small atlas, he went ashore to phone Cunningham's headquarters at Alexandria, to which he was ordered to sail.

On arrival, he was solemnly piped aboard his old ship for an interview with the commander in chief, who men tioned him in despatches and ordered him to reapply his engineering skills to the Navy. He soon became engineer officer on the destroyer Hereward, which was among the many ships sunk in the disastrous last fight for Crete in May 1941. Callaghan was one of only 40 survivors of a devastating German dive-bomber attack; more than 300 sailors and soldiers aboard died.

Plucked out of the water by an Italian torpedo-boat, Callaghan spent the next four years in captivity. He twice broke out of Italian camps but was recaptured. In 1943, on the Italian surrender, the Germans moved him to a naval camp near Bremen. Like many other prisoners in the dying days of the war in Europe, he was forced to march east, but the British Army freed him and his colleagues during the swift final advance across northern Germany.

Callaghan promptly went back to sea in a Pacific Fleet cruiser, moving to a carrier in 1946 before taking up a post on the training staff at Dartmouth. Raised to commander, he switched from propulsion to ordnance engineering and became Mediterranean fleet ordnance engineer under Lord Mountbatten; he served as commander (E) on the carrier Eagle at Suez in 1956.

Three years later, he was promoted captain and held staff posts in weapons development, becoming a divisional director at the Admiralty establishment at Bath, where he worked on the famous 4.5-inch gun. His last post, before retiring as a rear-admiral with the CB in 1971, was as president of the Ordnance Board. He then became director-general of the National Supervisory Council for Intruder Alarms, a body which he founded and which set national standards in burglar alarms.

He married Patricia Munro Geddes in 1948 and they had one son and two daughters, all of whom survive him.

 Desmond Noble Callaghan, sailor, born November 24 1915; died May 28 2000

His first four years of active service were spent on battleships, including HMS Warspite from September 1939. It was in this modernised Jutland veteran that he took part in the second battle of Narvik in April 1940, one of the few successes in a botched Allied intervention in Norway. The battleship led a flotilla of small destroyers in a surprise attack on German units, sinking eight enemy fleet destroyers in a fierce action. Callaghan stayed put when Warspite became the flagship of the Mediterranean Fleet under Sir Andrew Cunningham, Britain's foremost fighting admiral of the war. A period of hectic action followed, including exchanges with the Italian fleet, as well as escorting convoys to besieged Malta. Warspite was also involved in the fighting in north Africa, Greece and Crete in 1941, when defeat in the Balkans was snatched from the jaws of imminent victory in Libya. By that time, Callaghan had been sent ashore to help maintain the British Army's tanks, overstretched in the forward rush to expel the Italians from north Africa. But after the German General Rommel's arrival in February 1941, the rout was reversed and Callaghan had to help demolish facilities in Benghazi before the advancing Afrika Korps arrived. Withdrawing to Derna, he seized a local fishing boat, which he renamed HMS Eskimo Nell, thus becoming the first engineer-officer in naval history to command a warship, complete with machine-guns and one light cannon. Fleeing to Mersa Matruh, aided only by a small atlas, he went ashore to phone Cunningham's headquarters at Alexandria, to which he was ordered to sail. On arrival, he was solemnly piped aboard his old ship for an interview with the commander in chief, who men tioned him in despatches and ordered him to reapply his engineering skills to the Navy. He soon became engineer officer on the destroyer Hereward, which was among the many ships sunk in the disastrous last fight for Crete in May 1941. Callaghan was one of only 40 survivors of a devastating German dive-bomber attack; more than 300 sailors and soldiers aboard died. Plucked out of the water by an Italian torpedo-boat, Callaghan spent the next four years in captivity. He twice broke out of Italian camps but was recaptured. In 1943, on the Italian surrender, the Germans moved him to a naval camp near Bremen. Like many other prisoners in the dying days of the war in Europe, he was forced to march east, but the British Army freed him and his colleagues during the swift final advance across northern Germany. Callaghan promptly went back to sea in a Pacific Fleet cruiser, moving to a carrier in 1946 before taking up a post on the training staff at Dartmouth. Raised to commander, he switched from propulsion to ordnance engineering and became Mediterranean fleet ordnance engineer under Lord Mountbatten; he served as commander (E) on the carrier Eagle at Suez in 1956. Three years later, he was promoted captain and held staff posts in weapons development, becoming a divisional director at the Admiralty establishment at Bath, where he worked on the famous 4.5-inch gun. His last post, before retiring as a rear-admiral with the CB in 1971, was as president of the Ordnance Board. He then became director-general of the National Supervisory Council for Intruder Alarms, a body which he founded and which set national standards in burglar alarms. He married Patricia Munro Geddes in 1948 and they had one son and two daughters, all of whom survive him.  Desmond Noble Callaghan, sailor, born November 24 1915; died May 28 2000

fields.headline: Freddy Bloom
fields.standfirst: War camp survivor who changed the way we think about the deaf
fields.trailText: Freddy Bloom, who has died aged 86, was a New Yorker who, after a searing three and a half years in Japanese prison camps during the second world war, made her home in London. The mother of a daughter born profoundly deaf, she subsequently devoted her life to the needs of deaf children.
fields.body:
Freddy Bloom, who has died aged 86, was a New Yorker who, after a searing three and a half years in Japanese prison camps during the second world war, made her home in London. The mother of a daughter born profoundly deaf, she subsequently devoted her life to the needs of deaf children.

She was born Elfrieden Wenzel, the only child of Robert, a German consular official, and his wife Emmy, a journalist. She graduated from Barnard College of Columbia University, New York, and took a further degree at Trinity College, Dublin, after her parents moved to Ireland.

Her first marriage was to a medical student who became the medical officer to a regiment of the Indian army. When war broke out, her husband was posted to Malaya where, almost immediately, he contracted pleurisy and died. Freddy found a job as a journalist in Shanghai and, while living there, met Philip Bloom, then a major in the Royal Army Medical Corps.

Nine days after they married, Singapore fell, and Freddy and her husband were interned in different Japanese camps. It was an ordeal from which many failed to emerge and in which a few displayed immense heroism. Freddy was one of the latter; she was indomitable and raised the morale of her fellow prisoners through a camp newsletter, called Pow Wow, which she started.

That was to lead to the most agonising experience of her incarceration. Because of her editorship of the publication, she was suspected by the Japanese of involvement in a spy ring. She was removed from the women's camp for interrogation, and held for five months, from October 1943, in a Singapore prison. There she shared a cell 17 feet by 10 feet with 15 men. All were forced to sit crossed legged throughout the day and at night were permitted to lie down on the floor. There was no furniture and a single lavatory was the only source of water.

Released because of a near-fatal illness, Freddy was returned to the Changi women's camp, where she remained until the Japanese defeat. Despite the unspeakable privations she had endured, Freddy never expressed, nor appeared to harbour, any bitterness towards the Japanese people, and, in 1994, accepted an invitation to visit that country. She regarded it as an occasion for reconciliation and for establishing personal relationships with a number of Japanese.

After their release in 1945, husband and wife, with little but what they stood up in, came to London, where Philip set up a consultancy practice as an obstetrician and, later, a psychiatrist. Freddy, incapable of sitting still, ran the Youth Book Club, a non-profit enterprise to encourage teenagers to read good literature. That occupation was interrupted the following year when her daughter Virginia (Ginny) was born.

Because of the malnutrition Freddy had suffered in the Japanese camp, Ginny was born profoundly deaf. At the time, children in that condition were regularly described as "deaf and dumb", but Freddy was determined to change that concept. It was a decision which transformed her own life and benefited thousands who were born with the disability.

Freddy dedicated herself to teaching Ginny how to speak, and her unstinting devotion of time, effort and patience was rewarded. Ginny is so articulate that it is almost impossible to believe that she cannot hear. Freddy brought her experience and determination to a small society concerned with deaf children which she expanded into the National Deaf Children's Society (NDCS), of which she was chairman until 1965 and vice-president until her death. She devoted herself unstintingly to this organisation - lecturing, broadcasting, advising and editing its magazine. It was entirely through her efforts that the NDCS received national and subsequently international recognition. For her services to deaf children, she was awarded an OBE in 1966.

During her internment, Freddy had both kept her own sanity and preserved a record of events by writing frequent letters to Philip which, however, she could never send. In 1980, these letters of understated horrors and experiences were published under the title of Dear Philip: a diary of captivity, Changi 1942-5. Most of her other published works, like Our Deaf Children (1963), offered help and advice to parents.

Until the very last, Freddy retained her inquiring mind, dauntless spirit and an infectious humour. She never asked for sympathy and one of her constant refrains was: "Who said life has to be fair?" She was at her most relaxed with a cigarette in one hand and a glass in the other. Straightforward and a ready and patient listener, Freddy was one of those spirits who instantly inspired trust and affection. She leaves Ginny, and a son, William, as well as a host of friends whose lives she enriched. Her husband died in 1984.

 Freddy (Elfrieden) Bloom, journalist and author, born February 6 1914; died May 20 2000

fields.headline: Brake hard on motor costs
fields.trailText: Named and shamed: The British built Vauxhall Astra, the Honda Civic and the Land-Rover Discovery have been cited by the European Commission for high costs
fields.body:
Named and shamed: The British built Vauxhall Astra, the Honda Civic and the Land-Rover Discovery have been cited by the European Commission for high costs

While Nissan and Ford are making high volume pronouncements about their price cuts, the running costs of cars have risen by a staggering amount over the past year. In fact, the good news about falling car prices in Britain - an average of 1% year on year according to What Car? - hides bad news.

The EU Competition Commission has just published a report showing the gap between car prices in Britain and the rest of Europe is growing, and not just because of the strong pound, which should bring down prices for vehicles manufactured on the continent.

The EU watchdog cited Volkswagen, Renault, Fiat and Peugeot for overpricing their cars in this country. It found that out of 73 models pre-tax, 65 were more expensive in Britain.

UK-built models are also far more costly and this can not be blamed on shipping costs. Named and shamed models include the Vauxhall Astra, the Land-Rover Discovery, the Range Rover and the Honda Civic.

The cheapest country in Europe for cars is non-Euroland Denmark. A Fiat Bravo, which costs £10,131 before tax in the UK, is just £4,469 there.

But it is the cost of running a car that can really hit a buyer, particularly if you compare this with costs a year ago. Keeping a small car for a year, driving 10,000 miles during that period, costs £1,506 this year, an increase of £123 on last year. For larger cars the increase is even more dramatic: £2,757 against £2,387, a difference of £370.

Petrol has, controversially, shot up in price. The petrol companies blame the price of crude oil - and to be fair, when oil is cheaper, prices do usually come down - but the bulk of the cost is tax. Petrol costs 86p per litre, 73p of which is VAT and other taxes.

So great are the revenues from petrol that ironically, they could scupper the government's economic plans. As headline inflation figures rose to their highest levels in almost two years last month, the statisticians were blaming "a sharp rise in pump prices".

This time last year petrol was just 70p a litre. Now, according to the AA, the average household spends £70 a week on petrol, making it the single biggest item on the family budget, ahead of food and mortgage payments or rent.

Fortunately for most drivers, deputy PM John Prescott has now abandoned plans to introduce motorway tolls, but Londoners may not be so lucky: Mayor Ken Livingstone, pictured left, is still considering plans to charge drivers for bringing their cars into the city centre.

Insurance premiums have typically risen 20% on last year and by nearly £200 over the last six years, while household policies have gone down by £15 in the same period. The AA says drivers can expect their insurance bill to be around £100 higher this year, with the average premium now £561.

George Lowe, AA director of insurance, says: "In 1994 insurers were still making a profit. This drew in new players, each one promising to offer lower premiums. What we are seeing now is the backlash of this price war: insurers withdrawing from unprofitable markets, underwriters joining forces to increase their viability in the market and premiums increasing to compensate for years of loss leading."

Car insurers are now paying out £1.20 in claims and expenses for every £1 they take in premiums, so price rises have been inevitable. One reason is that car accident victims can now claim for more money from insurance companies and "no win no fee" solicitors are encouraging more people to claim.

Worse still for the industry - and hence the driver - the government has ruled that insurers should reimburse the NHS for money spent on treating victims.

The proliferation of internet insurers should push prices down in the future, adds Mr Lowe, but this has yet to take effect. Telephone broker Peoples Choice predicts this will not happen before next year. Car tax has also increased on last year.

But there are some ways to cut the cost of car insurance:

Shop around. Telephone-based insurance broker Peoples Choice claims it saved one customer nearly £500 on the back of just one free call to them.

Keep your car safe. Many insurers discount for secure parking, alarms and immobilisers. An approved immobiliser can cut premiums by 10%.

Protect your no claims bonus. Most car insurance policies allow you to protect your no claims discount, allowing you to make two claims in five years. The benefit of doing this is likely to outweigh the costs.

Increase your excess. Most insurers will cut your premium if you agree to a higher excess. Opt for an excess of £500, and you could, for instance, slash your premium by a quarter.

Insure for a named driver. Insurers can more accurately assess the risk for named drivers rather than just any driver, so better rates are offered. If at a later stage a friend or relative needs to drive your car, they can take out temporary cover for a weekend or longer. By doing this you could save up to 30% on your premium.

Low mileage. It sounds paradoxical to have a car and not drive it, but if your annual mileage is less than 8,000 then you could reduce your premium by 10%.

Car price index, which shows the true prices paid for new and used cars as opposed to the list price, compiled by Alliance & Leicester in conjunction with What Car? is at www.carpriceindex.com Peoples Choice www.peopleschoice.co.uk

fields.headline: In the hair tonight
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
I owe Clare Balding an apology. Only this week, with the start of her new series, Time Out with Balding (talking to sporting personalities about their favourite non-sporty pastimes), did I realise my error. Many of you will, I'm sure, have enjoyed Ramblings with Clare Balding (5 Live).

Me, I scanned the Radio Times and thought I saw mention of Baldings with Clare Rambling. What could it be? Live commentary from atop men's heads? Or reports from a surreal bungalow christened by EF Benson (houses in Mapp and Lucia were always called things like Baldings). But no, ramblings it was. It's the equivalent of calling an art exhibition "doodles", or a film "possible storyboards we're discussing over long lunches".

I've missed other things for equally silly reasons. Take Phil Collins's Big Band Bash (Radio 2). I had assumed it would feature Phil ("In the Air Tonight") Collins and thus naturally gave it full body swerve.

"No," said a friend, "it's another Phil Collins - like Ted Heath the band leader isn't Ted Heath." I tuned in this week. "Get those timbals ready!" the press notes fizzed. I got them ready. My friend was wrong. It was the real, balding Phil Collins. My timbals went straight back in the cupboard. But you always know where you are with divorce.

Thanks to Melissa Benn's exhaustively thorough series Divorce - Right or Privilege? (Radio 4) you'll know even more clearly from now on. It's jam-packed full of chirpy stats: 41% of British marriages will end in divorce; divorce lawyers charge £120 an hour on average, and a Bella magazine survey says 6% of divorces are caused by snoring.

Snoring. These are perky enough facts, and the historical ones are even better (in the Georgian period, a man had the right to beat his wife with anything as long as it was no wider than his thumb). However, Benn's delivery could do with some work: it's stuck at the reading-out end of flat (she referred to "seeming progress", and you can guess what old Madam Mix-Up here thought she said).

This is one of these Radio 4 in-depth wonders that leaves you not sure what to do with all the information you've gleaned. Impress friends? Go on Mastermind? Soothe those heading for the courts? ("Why are you worried about who'll get the cat? Did you know the first women to challenge the divorce laws were foully demonised by the press?! Knew that would make you feel better.")

Better by far to tune into those two happy widows, Irene Spencer and Vera Small in Ladies of Letters.com (Radio 4) - they never make you ask what they're for.

A thin premise for a series, admittedly, the letter-writing duo have discovered email. The joy of these exchanges is the clash of bizarre suburbia meets old ladies behaving very badly, mostly to each other under the guise of friendly letters.

Irene is being stalked by a man who follows her around the supermarket. "I managed to lose him in feminine hygiene," she reports. She doesn't mention if he was balding.

fields.headline: You're my wonder wall
fields.standfirst: Deborah Colker's dancers need a head for heights, says Keith Watson
fields.trailText: Deborah Colker's dancers need a head for heights, says Keith Watson
fields.body:
Asked to name her six favourite dancers, Brazilian choreographer Deborah Colker came up with a list that includes Pele, Michael Jackson and Bruce Lee. On the strength of Mix, the latest show she has brought to London, it's a little surprising that Chris Bonnington didn't make it in there somewhere.

Colker clearly has no hang-up about heights. Last time, in Rota, she had her dancers spinning around like high-fashion hamsters on a giant wheel. Now there's Mix, an eclectic medley of earlier works at the Barbican this week, that climaxes with the cast scampering with the sure-footedness of mountain goats up and down a vertical wall.

Vertigo is not a concept Colker is familiar with. It's exhilarating, breath-taking stuff, the kind of adrenaline rush that you associate with the moments when the line between sport (OK, maybe not British sport) and art disappears and you're left with a moment of sheer physical beauty. That's the kind of dream moment Colker is forever chasing in her dance. And when her performers are nimbly bounding and twisting across the cliff face, their silhouettes picked out against a giant orange sun, she comes mighty close.

Combining the daring of high-divers with the muscular symmetry of gymnasts, Colker's team is up there in Olympic class, going all out for gold. You half expect judges to flash up scores by way of a finale. All these sporting references are no accident. Colker, a psychology graduate, divided her youth in Rio between volleyball (she made the city team, and Brazil are major players in the game) and ballet before turning to contemporary dance at the age of 18.

The ideal of aesthetic athleticism, as embodied in her dancers, is the moving force that steers her work. It's most evident in the floor-bound sections taken from Velox, her second work for her company and one directly inspired by the dynamics of sport.

The primping and preening of athletes (when you're that good, narcissism is par for the course) is worked into a calisthenic routine that comes on like the most stylish aerobics class you've ever seen. With the astute eye of an anatomist, Colker takes delight in deconstructing the mechanics of human physical action to get to the root of how we do the things we do. There are echoes of the pioneering photographic studies of Eadweard Muybridge (the jockstrap replaced by 21st-century fashion sports gear) but this is no academic exercise, for uppermost on Colker's agenda is a keen awareness of the need to entertain.

Nowhere is that more evident than in Passion, a beguilingly bizarre tribute to the love duet that proves Colker is no one-trick pony. Set to an eccentric compilation tape, we skitter nervously from song to song (a few bars of Donna Summer's Love To Love You Baby segues into a snatch of Michael Jackson's Ben; work that one out), occasionally relaxing enough to let a memory play out in full.

The effect is like a fantasy jukebox, the stage and dancers bathed in misty yellow afterglow as the action recalls every stage of the love game, from the pre-match warm-up to the final climactic score, taking in all the nervous fumbling and tackling that goes on in between. Except only in dreams would we be that flexible and sure-footed.
