It's exhilarating, breath-taking stuff, the kind of adrenaline rush that you associate with the moments when the line between sport (OK, maybe not British sport) and art disappears and you're left with a moment of sheer physical beauty. That's the kind of dream moment Colker is forever chasing in her dance. And when her performers are nimbly bounding and twisting across the cliff face, their silhouettes picked out against a giant orange sun, she comes mighty close. Combining the daring of high-divers with the muscular symmetry of gymnasts, Colker's team is up there in Olympic class, going all out for gold. You half expect judges to flash up scores by way of a finale. All these sporting references are no accident. Colker, a psychology graduate, divided her youth in Rio between volleyball (she made the city team, and Brazil are major players in the game) and ballet before turning to contemporary dance at the age of 18. The ideal of aesthetic athleticism, as embodied in her dancers, is the moving force that steers her work. It's most evident in the floor-bound sections taken from Velox, her second work for her company and one directly inspired by the dynamics of sport. The primping and preening of athletes (when you're that good, narcissism is par for the course) is worked into a calisthenic routine that comes on like the most stylish aerobics class you've ever seen. With the astute eye of an anatomist, Colker takes delight in deconstructing the mechanics of human physical action to get to the root of how we do the things we do. There are echoes of the pioneering photographic studies of Eadweard Muybridge (the jockstrap replaced by 21st-century fashion sports gear) but this is no academic exercise, for uppermost on Colker's agenda is a keen awareness of the need to entertain. Nowhere is that more evident than in Passion, a beguilingly bizarre tribute to the love duet that proves Colker is no one-trick pony. Set to an eccentric compilation tape, we skitter nervously from song to song (a few bars of Donna Summer's Love To Love You Baby segues into a snatch of Michael Jackson's Ben; work that one out), occasionally relaxing enough to let a memory play out in full. The effect is like a fantasy jukebox, the stage and dancers bathed in misty yellow afterglow as the action recalls every stage of the love game, from the pre-match warm-up to the final climactic score, taking in all the nervous fumbling and tackling that goes on in between. Except only in dreams would we be that flexible and sure-footed.

fields.headline: A fairer deal for victims
fields.standfirst: The House of Lords has upheld a compensation claim from a 14-year-old who was crushed by a boat. Richard Colbey reports
fields.trailText: It was with some satisfaction that I read of the House of Lords' decision to award compensation to Justin Jolley, who had been crippled by an accident when he was 14, in 1990.
fields.body:
It was with some satisfaction that I read of the House of Lords' decision to award compensation to Justin Jolley, who had been crippled by an accident when he was 14, in 1990.

A boat had been abandoned in the grounds of some flats owned by the London Borough of Sutton. Justin and a friend decided to try to restore the boat, with the aim of taking it to Cornwall to sail and, using a borrowed car jack, propped it up.

After six weeks spent diligently replacing rotten planks, the boat fell off the jack with Justin under it, crushing him and rendering him paraplegic. I wrote in these columns almost exactly two years ago, after the Court of Appeal had ruled he should not receive anything, that the case was a striking illustration of the inequities of our system for compensating accident victims.

The Lords' decision, however, should be a comfort to all parents of adventurous children. It may put pressure on landowners, particularly local authorities, to ensure there are no potential hazards awaiting youngsters, and give those unfortunate few who are injured a much greater chance of being properly compensated.

The judge who first heard the case decided that the council had been negligent in not removing the boat. It was aware that leaving it there presented risks, even put a sticker on it saying "Danger, do not touch this vehicle unless you are the owner. It will be removed after seven days."

The council had then, despite this notice and the request of residents of the flats, failed to move it. The judge also decided that it was foreseeable that children would play with the boat and that an accident could occur, and awarded Mr Jolley more than £600,000.

The Court of Appeal agreed that the council had been negligent, but decided that it was not foreseeable that an accident of this kind could occur. It would, in its view, only have been foreseeable that a child might climb on the boat and be injured falling through a rotting plank. On the basis of the rule that someone who is negligent is only liable for those consequences of their actions they could reasonably be expected to predict, the council escaped liability.

Had the Court of Appeal's judgment been allowed to stand, any owner of land on which a child had been injured could have the courts minutely analyse the accident to see if it were of a predictable kind.

The law lords, particularly Lord Hoffmann, accepted such an approach was not desirable and avoided the simple truth that the council, having recognised that the boat represented a danger, should have moved it. He talked of the ingenuity of children in finding ways of doing mischief to themselves and others.

The likely implication of this decision, once it is absorbed by insurance companies, will be that pressure is placed on landowners to remove things, particularly abandoned vehicles that could prevent a hazard to children.

If a car is abandoned it may be predictable that children will cut themselves on rusty metal playing on it. It is much less likely, but not impossible, that it will burst into flames, causing them more serious injuries.

The outcome of Justin Jolley's sad case will be that in either situation, the landowner will be liable.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: The last word on   Reading
fields.standfirst: How many a man has dated a new era in his life from the reading of a book! -   Henry Thoreau.
fields.trailText: How many a man has dated a new era in his life from the reading of a book! - Henry Thoreau.
fields.body:
According to reports this week, doctors in west Yorkshire are to begin prescribing books instead of medications to patients suffering from depression, stress and anxiety. The patients will be referred to a bibliotherapist - yes, bibliotherapist - who will give patients reading lists suited to their conditions.

Half a million pounds has been allocated for this pilot scheme, whose inspiration is the observation by librarians that borrowers are apt to say on returning books (and I quote): "This book really cheered me up", and "I enjoyed this book because it was about somebody more miserable than me", profundity here vying with charity as the evidential basis for a medical advance.

There are almost too many things to say about this amazing idea. Cynics will ask, "What sort of pass are we in that people need a doctor's prescription to prompt them to read? When did we forget that reading is, for a thousand reasons, one of the chief resources of life? Will doctors turn to prescribing dinner for the peckish and sleep for the tired as the next step in the medicalisation of human existence, or as a response to the supine inability of people to think and act for themselves?"

There is a tincture of justice in these exclamations, but it is not appropriately directed at the NHS in west Yorkshire. It should rather be directed at the failure of our culture to show people what rich deposits of pleasure and usefulness, and what expansion of horizons, are to be found in reading.

An education in reading includes guidance - very easy to give; it takes five minutes (much less if you say, "ask a librarian," which is excellent advice) - on how to find any required book or kind of book. And just a little experience as a reader grants access to the great country where one flies as an eagle over the history, comedy, tragedy and variety of human experience, at every point garnering much, if the reading is attentive, from the abundance on offer.

The key is "attentive." The best thing any education can bequeath is the habit of reflection and questioning. Reading can be a passive affair, an entertainment leaving no impression on the mind beyond a pleasant present distraction. Many books are skilfully written to demand no more, and there is nothing wrong with that. But for anything more, reading has to be an activity, not a passivity.

It is hard to define what makes good books good, because good books come in so many different kinds, but one thing common to most of them is that they make readers think and feel, elevating or disturbing them, and making them see the world a little differently as a result. In short, they elicit the activity in active reading. "We find little in a book but what we put there," Joseph Joubert said, "But in great books, the mind finds room to put many things."

Reading does not automatically make people wiser or better. When it has that effect it is because readers have done the work themselves, quarrying the materials from their response to the printed page. But apart from practical experience of life, which is everyone's chief tutor, scarcely anything compares with books as the mine where that quarrying can begin.

To read is to enter other points of view; it is to be an invisible observer of circumstances which might never be realised in one's own life; it is to meet people and situations exceeding in kind and number the possibilities open to individual experience.

As a result, reading not only promotes self-understanding, it equips one with insights into needs, interests and desires that one might never share but which motivate others, in this way enabling one to understand, and tolerate, and even to sympathise with, other people's aims and concerns. As an extension of how this informs one's behaviour towards others, it is also the basis for civil community and the brotherhood of man.

webTitle: Is there honey still for tea with Jeffrey Archer?

fields.headline: Is there honey still for tea with Jeffrey Archer?
fields.trailText: Wigan gastronomy | Boss women
fields.body:
A guest at Jeffrey Archer's summer party in Grantchester last weekend told me what a sad and desolate affair it has become. The only Tories present were Virginia and Peter Bottomley (I seem to see them at all parties, though for that reason I suppose they could say the same about me), John Gummer, Jonathan Aitken, and the global life president of the World Institute of Thatcherology.

There weren't even any photographers stationed outside the gate this year, though any inside could have got a tremendous shot of Thatcher flanked by Aitken and Archer. She, at least, was always able to overlook troubles with the law when they happened to her friends, which appears not to be true of so many other fair-weather liggers and blaggers.

Clive James, who lives in Cambridge, was the only celebrity to make the trip, and as for the galaxy of other stars who used to cast their benison on the occasion, none of them turned up at all. "Almost everyone I spoke to turned out to be one of Jeffrey's neighbours," says my party-going mole.

 More fascinating letters about Jack Straw's plainly absurd claim that 31.5% of the male population has been convicted of a serious crime by the age of 30. George Moore, writing from North Yorkshire, blames ignorant civil servants getting their hands on the work of statisticians. "At some point our boffin pours forth a stream of data from whatever criminal statistics he has been working with. He produces, from a random sample, a table of probability which gives the now famous 31% figure. In the nature of the exercise and common usage, he writes this up, using the term 'population', meaning the statistical population with which he has been working - light years away from 'the population' per se... and so our hero gets to his feet and the rest is, if not history, at least grist to your column."

Even more significantly, Colin Smith writes from Stourbridge to point out that DJ West and his colleagues at Cambridge have produced many studies of potentially delinquent boys, some of whom they followed from the age of eight. These were all socially disadvantaged, and the dons did some fascinating work on what actually helps a boy from a broken home or a sink estate avoid a life of crime.

"The figure of 30% for criminal records by the age of 30 was the finding for this [especially high at-risk] group. It couldn't be that clever people like Home Office officials and judges have extrapolated this figure from a small and untypical sample to the whole male population? Or could it?"

 My friend Fergus was in France the other day when he began to feel ill. Things got worse until he found it almost impossible to breathe. A local doctor, who sounds like Charles Bovary only less au fait with the latest medical practice, prescribed some drugs, but when these didn't work, had him whisked immediately into intensive care. (His having the correct EU form means that the French government picks up 80% of the bill; his insurance the rest.)

After a few days, they decided he had stabilised, and he's fine now. "I was barely conscious much of the time in the hospital," he said the other day, "but I realised that I was out of intensive care but still in France when the woman came round to my bed with lunch. ' Du vin, monsieur ?' she asked."

 Thanks, too, for all your gastronomic news from Wigan, the Périgord of the North. Several readers have written in about the Wigan kebab, which is three pies on a stick, and Ian Foster claims to correct me over the "Wigan butty". "This is actually called a 'slap barm', he says, "from the noise the pie makes hitting the buttered barm cake." I shall leave local etymologists to sort this out.

Mike Southcott of Preston has sent a clipping from his local paper, the Lancashire Evening Post. It shows the nuptial festivities of Jonathan and Jane Farrimond of Standish, near Wigan, who are glimpsed in front of three tiers of pie-shaped wedding cakes. The groom's mother said that they looked exactly like three meat and potato pies. "We were shocked, but it is typical of them," she added.

We had hoped to bring you this picture, but it has been suggested the rights are being sold for some absurd sum, as if it showed Elvis in Loch Ness, or Prince William snogging Britney Spears. Or perhaps, I would hope, so that the couple's children never have to see the grisly evidence.

 Watching Boss Women on BBC1, the film about the editor of American Vogue, Anna Wintour, it struck me once more that fashion writers are probably the only journalists left who feel it essential to suck up shamelessly to the people they are writing about. The days of lickspittle motoring correspondents ("there are plenty of gee-gees under this bonnet, and they're all British... if I have a complaint, it is that the ash tray is a little small") are long gone. Sports reporters frequently say the rudest things and make the most damaging allegations against club managements. Even some theatre critics have come to realise that their job is not merely to act as boosters for British actors and playwrights.

Yet fashion slavishly reports each bizarre and absurd garment, every upside-down dress, every hat disguised as a dead partridge, as if it were an artistic achievement. Meanwhile, these preening idiots measure their own self-esteem by the seat they are allocated for each catwalk cavalcade. If lobby correspondents in last weekend's film about Alastair Campbell had minced into Downing Street, saying "Do you mind? I think you'll find that's my seat directly in front of Alastair!" we'd never have heard the end of it. Yet the fashion press goes on spending millions of pounds and aeons of time uncritically promoting the industry.

fields.headline: Go west, witches
fields.standfirst: A brassy, jazzy hymn to selfhood, The Witches of Eastwick is a surefire Broadway hit. So why, wonders  Matt Wolf, is it premiering on this side of the Atlantic?
fields.trailText: A brassy, jazzy hymn to selfhood, The Witches of Eastwick is a surefire Broadway hit. So why, wonders Matt Wolf, is it premiering on this side of the Atlantic?
fields.body:
'I've never produced a new show first in America, and I have no intention of ever doing it," Cameron Mackintosh told me back in March at the London press launch of The Witches of Eastwick. His utterly sensible rationale was: "All my friends are here."

Besides, why risk opening an untested show on Broadway - with costs sometimes double those of the West End - where a show can be gone within months? London clearly remains the safer option, not least because the imprimateur of West End success then acts as a show's best advocate for a transfer to New York.

Nonetheless, with Witches at last upon us, I can't help feeling "good show/wrong city", more or less borne out by this week's mixed critical response. If ever a putative London blockbuster seemed ripe for New York - in terms of subject matter, sentiment and score - Witches is it. As an American based in London for many years, here's my advice to this newborn musical: go west, young show.

Why? Begin with the music by relative American unknowns John Dempsey and Dana P Rowe. They fared distinctly poorly with the London press in their previous outing, a Mackintosh-backed run of The Fix, directed by Sam Mendes at the Donmar Warehouse in 1997. Paradoxically, Mackintosh has acknowledged that the dismissive response to The Fix moved him to give the songwriters another chance with Witches. "The fact is," says the producer, "a lot of the British critics don't have an ear." Nor can Londoners necessarily be expected to appreciate an appealingly eclectic score steeped in the Broadway era of Bells Are Ringing and Bye Bye Birdie of some 40 or more years ago.

While too many contemporary composers are writing in a genre that one might best describe as post-Sondheimian drear, Dempsey and Rowe pay homage to an unabashedly jazzy, brassy Broadway of yore: torch songs and anthems, wistful ballads and all-out oompah company numbers. This score's totemic figures would seem to be Frank Loesser, Jerry Herman and Cy Coleman, not the heavily orchestrated faux-operatics of the Lloyd Webber or Alain Boublil/Claude-Michel Schonberg school - the team behind Miss Saigon and Les Misérables - on whom Mackintosh made his millions.

The result, in musical terms, places Witches in opposition to the bulk of West End fare, which tends towards either ponderous Puccini-isms or Abba Euro-pop. (The exception: Maria Friedman's first-act showstopper, Words, Words, Words, which owes a delightfully self-evident debt to the patter songs of Gilbert and Sullivan.) If such a decisively American sound deserves an American hearing, one goes on to question the suitability for the British of the musical's very attitude and tone.

Compare, for starters, some of the other heroines concurrently on offer in the West End - Blood Brothers' hapless Mrs Johnston, for instance, with her doomy fixation on Marilyn Monroe; or the fall-and-rise-and-back-again trajectory of Spend Spend Spend's Viv Nicholson, a tough little lady whom life has clearly not spared.

Against these self-evident English victims, what could seem bolder and more brash than not one American woman but three who learn to live without men and, in the process, love themselves? "I am the music," sings cellist Joanna Riding in the show's exultant final number, Look At Me, with sculptress Lucie Arnaz adding for good measure: "I am a major work of art." Frustrated journalist Maria Friedman, meanwhile, discovers that her much-needed words were "inside me all along".

Before long, the trio have launched into exactly the kind of roof-raising hymn to selfhood on which thrives the Broadway musical as an extension of the American psyche. (The deliciously cynical Chicago sends up this very notion in a lyric like: "I am my own best friend.") "How corny," remarked an English friend, reacting to sentiments that across the Atlantic have assumed the status of gospel. And therein lies the difference in what may well be Witches' appeal. If I were Cameron Mackintosh, I'd shift my expectations for this show westward, where an entire populace exists ready to join the sisterhood.

 Matt Wolf is Variety's London theatre critic

While too many contemporary composers are writing in a genre that one might best describe as post-Sondheimian drear, Dempsey and Rowe pay homage to an unabashedly jazzy, brassy Broadway of yore: torch songs and anthems, wistful ballads and all-out oompah company numbers. This score's totemic figures would seem to be Frank Loesser, Jerry Herman and Cy Coleman, not the heavily orchestrated faux-operatics of the Lloyd Webber or Alain Boublil/Claude-Michel Schonberg school - the team behind Miss Saigon and Les Misérables - on whom Mackintosh made his millions. The result, in musical terms, places Witches in opposition to the bulk of West End fare, which tends towards either ponderous Puccini-isms or Abba Euro-pop. (The exception: Maria Friedman's first-act showstopper, Words, Words, Words, which owes a delightfully self-evident debt to the patter songs of Gilbert and Sullivan.) If such a decisively American sound deserves an American hearing, one goes on to question the suitability for the British of the musical's very attitude and tone. Compare, for starters, some of the other heroines concurrently on offer in the West End - Blood Brothers' hapless Mrs Johnston, for instance, with her doomy fixation on Marilyn Monroe; or the fall-and-rise-and-back-again trajectory of Spend Spend Spend's Viv Nicholson, a tough little lady whom life has clearly not spared. Against these self-evident English victims, what could seem bolder and more brash than not one American woman but three who learn to live without men and, in the process, love themselves? "I am the music," sings cellist Joanna Riding in the show's exultant final number, Look At Me, with sculptress Lucie Arnaz adding for good measure: "I am a major work of art." Frustrated journalist Maria Friedman, meanwhile, discovers that her much-needed words were "inside me all along". Before long, the trio have launched into exactly the kind of roof-raising hymn to selfhood on which thrives the Broadway musical as an extension of the American psyche. (The deliciously cynical Chicago sends up this very notion in a lyric like: "I am my own best friend.") "How corny," remarked an English friend, reacting to sentiments that across the Atlantic have assumed the status of gospel. And therein lies the difference in what may well be Witches' appeal. If I were Cameron Mackintosh, I'd shift my expectations for this show westward, where an entire populace exists ready to join the sisterhood.  Matt Wolf is Variety's London theatre critic

fields.headline: Drum-smashing, T-shirt-ripping soul boy
fields.standfirst: Michael Odell  on D'Angelo, ferocious at last
fields.trailText: Michael Odell on D'Angelo, ferocious at last
fields.body:
New York soul star D'Angelo has been the crown prince of so called "nu soul" since his scorching debut in 1995. But mid-term wobbles have suggested that the shy muso may have alienated core support with new developments in his show, such as getting up and moving about a bit, not to mention borrowing chunks of core R&B policy from Prince.

The last time he played in the UK, D'Angelo pitched most of his performance at his shoes. But right from the opening burst of Devil's Pie, it is clear that things have changed: he strips to his waist and prowls the stage with rangy intent. Add to this a 12-piece band called the Soulfonics, and the old-school soul revue is complete.

It works. Chicken Grease, a fairly tame jam from D'Angelo's new album, is transformed into pure pantomime by a call-and-response routine between our hero and his heroic backing trio. But it is on the bitter tale of bedroom treachery inflicted by a lover and best friend on Shit Damn Motherfucker that D'Angelo departs from the strict choreography. Suddenly he's crowd surfing and having his T-shirt ripped to shreds. Next he is smashing the mike stand to bits. Finally he attacks his drummer's shiny new kit, pitching cymbals and stands to the floor. The song ends with the poignant self-inquisition: "Why am I in handcuffs?" He might have added: "Why am I smashing my band's gear when there's still an hour to go?" But it's worth it. This is the turning point, where D'Angelo is no longer a mannered, rehearsed artiste - but a man touched by voodoo.

By the time we reach D'Angelo's greatest songwriting moment, Untitled, he is ready with a manifesto pledge to his core female vote. Like Prince before him, D'Angelo knows that the role that cunni- lingus plays in the making of R&B icons cannot be overstated. He tells the female contingent that after years of prudence "sucking", "going downtown" and even "smelling" are now on the agenda. The joint erupts. And just like his forebear always did before him, D'Angelo followed it up with a second secret club gig for 150 lucky souls at 3am the next day. Stars in our eyes, indeed.

fields.headline: Drum majors
fields.standfirst: Percussion rules the Proms for Turnage's new work, reports  Andrew Clements
fields.trailText: Percussion rules the Proms for Turnage's new work, reports Andrew Clements
fields.body:
As Mark-Anthony Turnage's career has developed so the influence of jazz, an important ingredient in his music from his earliest scores, has become more and more explicit. The most ambitious and far-reaching of his syntheses of the worlds of classical and jazz has been the evening-long suite Blood on the Floor, first performed in 1997, in which solo, partially improvised roles for saxophone, guitar and percussion were set against a "classical" ensemble. The soloists at the premiere included the great jazz musicians John Scofield and Peter Erskine.

Now in his new double concerto, Fractured Lines, first performed in Wednesday's Prom by the BBC Symphony Orchestra under Andrew Davis, Turnage has defined another role for Erskine. Asked by the BBC to write a percussion concerto for Evelyn Glennie, he decided to pit her classically- based playing against Erskine's jazz instincts.

So the solo roles for the two star percussionists are conceived almost confrontationally - Turnage has talked about the piece as a duel between them. They are positioned on opposite sides of the orchestra at the front of the stage, each surrounded by a distinctive battery of instruments. Glennie plays tuned instruments, especially the marimba, and what Turnage calls "industrial percussion" - metal sheets, scaffolding poles and the like - while Erskine's array is all untuned - a jazz drumkit, and a range of hand drums - though both players have little "cocktail" kits, including snare drums, with which they mark the climax of the single-movement piece with a double cadenza in which neither player emerges totally dominant.

But then Turnage's scheme is much more subtle than a battle to the finish between his protago nists. The orchestra plays a crucial expressive role, with long limbed-instrumental lines woven around the two percussionists in the first half of the work and much denser chordal writing in the second. The relationship between the two soloists, and between them and the orchestra, is constantly reassessed.

Thematically too the piece is tightly knit. Just as Turnage paid homage to Scofield's compositional gifts by using a theme of his as the starting point for both an orchestral work (Silent Cities) and one of the interludes in his opera The Silver Tassie, so Erskine's own music is the starting point for Fractured Lines is a tune of Erskine's called Bass Desires. After an ominous exchange of bass drum strokes between the two soloists, that melody appears in the opening bars of the concerto scattered around the orchestra - hence the title of the work, and it reappears in various guises to anchor the argument, and to form the basis of the long, glowing coda, after Erskine's final valedictory cadenza in some of the most harmonically expressive music Turnage has written to date.

In performance there is a degree of theatricality about these two sparring soloists. Radio 3 listeners will have missed the fascinating contrast in style between Erskine's wonderfully controlled and laid-back authority and Glennie's attention-seeking flamboyance. A glimpse of the score showed that in the cadenzas the two of them are allowed quite a lot of improvisational freedom (Erskine especially), but most of the piece is precisely notated, though some of Glennie's contributions suggested that either changes had been made during rehearsal or she was taking further liberties with what she had been allotted. Doubtless the piece will settle down as it receives further performances; a first encounter suggests that Turnage's music has continued to expand its range and its flexibility, and that he has written a work that confounds expectations of what a double percussion concerto might be, as much as it confirms them.

 The premiere is on BBC1 on August 13.

fields.headline: Aspinall's wild life and times
fields.trailText: Gorilla Academy |
fields.body:
John Aspinall was a strange man. He died in June, after a long battle with cancer, and last night's Gorilla Academy (BBC1) was a not altogether inappropriate tribute.

Normal obituary programmes fly a fairly standard trajectory: tributes from friends and colleagues; the story slotted neatly together with embarrassing episodes diplomatically side-stepped, winding up with a quote from the subject, providing an accurate summation of a life's achievement. Most "obits" of major public figures are prepared months, sometimes years, in advance of the subject's death. It's a peculiar practice, but a necessity if the broadcaster is to be seen to do comprehensive justice to a life.

Gorilla Academy was, as one could tell from the title, a most unconventional obituary. Ostensibly, it was a natural history programme about the return of two male gorillas, Kwa Kwa and Kwam, from Aspinall's animal park to the Gabon in Africa. But Aspinall's cancer hung over the film, his deteriorating condition slowly erasing him from his own story.

By the time Kwa Kwa and Kwam were released back into the wild, Aspinall had died. The film tastefully avoided any cod symbolism to be had from the release of the untamed spirit (normally accompanied by a slow-mo shot of a dove ascending to the heavens). Instead, Aspinall simply faded from view as the film progressed.

His story began in the 50s, when he began to amass a fortune from gambling. Winning £6,000 on a horse, he bought Howletts Animal Park in Kent. There's another Aspinall story, told in last year's fascinating BBC2 series, about a small clique of gamblers in the 60s who went on to control British business in the 80s and 90s. Aspinall was at the heart of this circle.

So there were two Aspinalls at the last count. One was a character from the Persuaders, wearing a smoking jacket in a casino and forging strange, life-long pacts with the major players of the new moneyed establishment. The other was the Greystoke figure of Gorilla Academy. The man who, filmed in a cage with a tiger in 1975, said: "What you are seeing is a mutual transfer of trust and affection. A bond far better than any form of dominance, of which there is none here." Shortly afterwards, the tiger attempted to maul him.

In fact, three keepers died over the years in order to preserve Aspinall's "mutual transfer of trust and affection" at Howletts. His policy of intimate contact with dangerous animals spoke to our deepest Victorian desires: to communicate with our Darwinian cousins; to ennoble the beasts - and, preferably, get them to wear frock coats. Aspinall's zoo-that-wasn't-a-zoo was considered, in his lifetime, the indulgence of an eccentric millionaire. Now, it's being considered a workable model for breeding endangered species. An irony Aspinall could relish even in his own lifetime.

Watching him on the roof of a cage, benignly feeding bananas through the grille just before he died, made one want only to see the whole story - a re-evaluation of a man out of time, our final link with those dark and peculiar desires of the 19th-century explorer.

Friends (C4) continued to be Friends, but appeared, in some cryogenic experiment, to be returning on a loop to past lives of Friends. Ross once more fancies Rachel, and... dur!.. Rachel doesn't know. Monica and Chandler are having arguments about bedroom refurbishment, the flowering of arguments that Ross and Rachel so lovingly nurtured before splitting up (Doh! And then marrying!). Joey remains reassuringly Joey-like: "Wanted. Female Roommate. Non-Smoking. Non-Ugly."

On the internet, there's a digitally enhanced picture of Friends in 30 years' time, spilling out of their communal sofa with obesity, hanging on to the few hairs they have left on their scabby heads. It's a frighteningly accurate reflection of the fact that Friends will never move on, trapped in its cycle of regurgitated gags and old story-lines. By 2020, who knows what it'll look like: an installation by Damien Hirst, perhaps?

fields.headline: Welcome to my nightmare
fields.standfirst: A two-headed child, a guillotine, a rebirth...  Steven Poole  enters the weird world of Alice Cooper
fields.trailText: A two-headed child, a guillotine, a rebirth... Steven Poole enters the weird world of Alice Cooper
fields.body:
The stage sweats under camouflage netting; a backdrop depicts a scorched earth in green and black. Suddenly, to an explosion of lights and sonic grinding, a metal box on a plinth opens to reveal a wild-haired Methuselah consisting only of head and upper torso on a stick. He pleads with us to run for our lives. "I am the only piece of technology left on this dead planet," he thunders with staring eyes. "A lifeless, godless world, run by the sadistic megalomaniac, Alice Cooper!"

As Cooper pounds into the extreme noise riffing of the title track of his new album, Brutal Planet, he still cuts a diabolically attractive, dynamic figure on stage at London's Hammersmith Apollo: wrapped in leathers and chains, stalking the stage like a grizzled old Cerberus. Red chopsticks making devil's horns in his hair, he twirls riding crops and canes like a cartoon majorette from Hades. Under certain lights he resembles Cilla Black dressed for Hallowe'en - but such genuinely alarming moments are few.

Cooper is the unabomber with good tunes, spitting at the stupidity and evil of commercial industrialism, and the show's cathartic comedy of death and destruction is a glorious piece of Day-Glo theatre. During Feel My Frankenstein, Cooper roams the stage finding bloody bits of bodies and feeding them into an upright glass pod, straight out of 60s sci-fi cinema. He is all of 20th-century humanity, embodying the tragic hubris of man the technologist.

The ethics of mercy-killing get a look in too, as Cooper sings Goodbye Little Baby while spearing a two-headed infant on his sabre. For this crime, he is bloodily guillotined. Cooper always has to die for our sins. Halfway through the show, we endure a fabulously, insanely dull drum solo, which really does seem to last the biblical three days and nights. And then, naturally, Cooper is resurrected: reanimated from within his Frankenstein pod, resplendent in white tails over a shredded chain mail T-shirt. No More Mr Nice Guy.

Cooper is the Nietzschean Antichrist of rock: a man beyond shame, beyond useless humility, who glories in his dirty power. "I am a vicious young man," he sneers. Age cannot wither him: the arch wielding of a crutch during I'm Eighteen is mere cunning misdirection. And how his fans love to be abused by this avuncular Beelzebub. "Raise your hands if you're poison!" he commands, and we all do. "Oh, my disobedient children!" he wails, spying a headbanger in a Marilyn Manson T-shirt. The disappointment is righteous: Manson stole Cooper's phantasmagoria but stripped it of all its humour and joie de mourir .

Meanwhile, through it all, Cooper's band pounds out an irresistibly raw, multi-legged spider of hard rock: the twin guitars build churches of harmonic crunch. His greatest hits are all present and freshly forged in Hell's finest rehearsal room: Under My Wheels, Poison, Go to Hell, Billion Dollar Baby, I Wanna Be Elected, and of course the anthem of anthems, School's Out.

Cooper has also been having his traditional woman problems. A masked, writhing S&M dancer gets kicked off her podium; a Carry On nurse is repeatedly shoved into the boot of a wrecked car. But then Cooper gets sensitive, sitting on a stool to sing his feminist ballad, Only Women Bleed. A grinning apologist explained to me that Cooper had gone further than any other male pop artist in dealing with women's issues. "Even Lloyd Cole didn't write a song about menstruation," he shouted through the din, nearly convincingly.

But Alice's best feminist joke comes when he reappears for the encore in a black sleeveless T-shirt with the legend: "Britney Wants Me." He gyrates his hips and then twirls, so we can read the continuation on his back: "Dead." There can be few better recommendations.

webTitle: Bowing before the weight of tradition

fields.headline: Bowing before the weight of tradition
fields.standfirst: As pounds and ounces return,  John Vidal  looks at the highly charged history of measurement
fields.trailText: As pounds and ounces return, John Vidal looks at the highly charged history of measurement
fields.body:
Once upon a time, everything was easy. We had butts, chaldrons, drachms, fathoms, florins, furlongs, gills, grains, groats and guineas. There were kilderkins, lasts, leagues, minims, pecks, poles and perches. Not only them, but rods, sacks, scruples, tods and dozens more units of measurement. Since you ask, two kilderkins made a liquid barrel or a dry coomb, and two barrels made a liquid hogshead or a dry quarter - each being a quarter of a ton.

Goodness knows what they all precisely measured. Units of volume, mass, liquid, money, weight, length and area, of course, but perhaps goats' scrotums, too. Almost every trade had its own measurements. This medieval system lasted for centuries more or less intact, and we must assume that it worked reasonably well. It was essentially local and very sophisticated. Weight and volume, area and length were often directly related to each other.

The medieval European systems of measurements, based on Egyptian, Roman and Babylonian systems, were sublimely anthropometric and empirical. The ancients noted that all the parts of the body were roughly constant. So measurements of lengths were based on fingers, feet, hand's breadths, thumbs and arms. Weights might be measured by handfuls of grain, lengths by a man's stride, area on how much you might cultivate. Because they had a direct relationship with people's bodies or their work, they were easy to remember.

Periodically, however, everything got into a terrible tangle, with people complaining of being ripped off - and kings, parliaments, churchmen and, later, scientists tried to standardise everything. Every hundred years or so they would bang heads together and try to rationalise the systems. Mostly, little or nothing happened.

Then came the French revolution. In 1793, the revolutionaries tried to impose change in every area of life to signal the radical change of regime. Mathematicians, geodecists, engineers and physicists sought a system of measures based on the figure 10, a proposal first made by a French vicar, Gabriel Mouton, in 1670. One of the first things they did was to change the time and the calendar. There were to be 10 months, each of three weeks, each 10 days long. Each day was to have 10 hours. The system was a disaster and was quickly dropped.

In 1795 a system of measures was introduced based on the metre - one 10-millionth of the distance from the north pole to the equator along the imaginary meridian running through Paris. Hence the metric system we enjoy today.

The system's conquest of Europe followed Napoleon's military successes and the "systeme international d'unites", or SI as it is known, is now effectively the global system of weights and measures, more or less accepted by all countries. Only the US, Burma, Liberia and parts of the old British empire are holding out against it.

No one doubts that the metric system is efficient. It works well for science, business and commerce. But that doesn't mean that it is human, desirable or necessary for people not engaged in technological or global endeavour.

This week, Tesco decided to offer its customers goods measured in pounds and ounces as well as kilograms and grams. There's a nice irony in globalising supermarkets, so often accused of monopolising trade and imposing an alien culture on communities and farmers, actively trying to save something threatened. But perhaps the supermarkets have struck an important note with the public.

As the world becomes more homogenous and globalised, there is a real desire, even a need, to celebrate diversity and appreciate that there are many ways of conducting our affairs. Dual systems of religion, law, language, governance and money are perfectly workable and quite rational in their own way. One system, like one anything, tends to be rigid and vulnerable.

Most people in the world speak more than one language fluently. We mostly use dual credit and cash systems of finance. In many African societies people are Muslim, Christian and animist, taking from each belief system what they gauge is the best for themselves.

There are, too, perfectly workable local trading systems in which members of a community or interest group exchange goods among themselves using their own local currencies. This allows them to cut out middlemen and avoid debt, and gives them some control of their own system of exchange. The New Economics Foundation recently proposed a local currency for London. We could have the euro, the pound and the "London" all running in parallel, each useful for different exchanges.

Tesco is so far happy with its experiment, as are the customers - and not just people who grew up before metrification. Any government, whether local, national or international, should learn the lessons of history. People change slowly. They like choice. And to force a rigid system on anyone usually proves hazardous.

fields.headline: Journey's end
fields.standfirst: 'With his traffic-cone hotline, John Major now seems, in his clumsy way, to at least have been trying to address a 'touchstone issue''
fields.trailText: 'With his traffic-cone hotline, John Major now seems, in his clumsy way, to at least have been trying to address a 'touchstone issue'.'
fields.body:
I am not quite sure what a "touchstone issue" is, but in the context of Tony Blair's leaked memo, it appears to mean any issue that threatens the Government's popularity. The Prime Minister singled out crime, immigration, defence and the family as his "touchstone issues", ones requiring urgent, eye-catching initiatives "personally associated" with him.

What these issues have in common, according to Blair, is that they can together determine the Government's image as either strong or weak, soft or assertive, "on your side" or "out of touch with gut British instincts". What they also have in common is that they offer easy opportunities for right-wing posturing, as William Hague has successfully demonstrated. They allow politicians to gather popular support without actually doing anything very much.

This is not true of my personal touchstone issue, which is probably why Blair left it off his list. This is the issue of transport, both public and private, which requires so much immensely expensive action that nobody can bear to face up to it. But the state of the roads and the railways is so dreadful and inflicts so much misery on the travelling public (in other words, on practically everybody) that genuine improvements would be received by the people with pathetic gratitude towards whatever government was responsible.

Ken Livingstone got elected as the first mayor of London because people believed the he really intended to do something to improve the Underground. Since I work at home in Hammersmith, I take the Underground irregularly, perhaps three or four times a week; but I can honestly say that I have not travelled on it once during the past couple of months without there being some problem.

Apart from the painful congestion during rush-hour periods, which I suppose I must regard as normal, I have been made late for several appointments by weird delays, trains stopping between stations for long periods or edging along at a snail's pace without explanation. Even the new Jubilee Line extension signally fails to match up in performance to the glistening, hi-tech appearance of its award-winning stations.

The railways are also getting worse and worse, and it is interesting to note that passengers only get addressed over the Tannoy when things are going according to plan. On the half-hour train ride from Gatwick Airport to Victoria Station the other day, we were allowed hardly a moment to ourselves. When we were not being thanked often and profusely for choosing to travel by the Gatwick Express (in preference to what, I wonder?), we were being told where we were going (which we already knew, since the only stop was to be Victoria) and that the refreshment trolley passing along the corridor in front of us was indeed doing exactly that. On the other hand, if the train had come to an unexpected halt, one can be more or less certain that nobody would have told us why.

One depressing thing about the Gatwick Express, by the way, was that the train's windows were filthy. They were so grey that you could hardly see out to the greyness beyond. There is nothing more demoralising than dirty train windows, especially when you are returning to England from the Mediterranean sun. To keep train windows clean would be a simple demonstration of genuine concern for the welfare and happiness of passengers as opposed to the pretence concern expressed in the endless intrusive blather over the public-address system.

On the roads, things just go from bad to worse. I was among the many who mocked John Major for his "traffic-cone hotline", which was meant to enable drivers to obtain explanations for road or lane closures where no work appeared to be going on. It seemed ridiculous at the time, but now that there are more traffic cones than ever, John Major seems, in his clumsy, unsophisticated way, to at least have been trying to address a touchstone issue.

I feel particularly strongly about this because I live at the moment in a London borough under siege, or at any rate one from which there is no easy escape by road except to the west towards Heathrow Airport, abroad, and freedom. I refer again to the west-London borough of Hammersmith. To the east there is now practically no way out. Two bridges over the railway line between Hammersmith and Kensington have been simultaneously crippled - one closed entirely for several weeks, the other reduced to one very narrow lane. To add to the chaos, several other roads in the immediate neighbourhood have also been closed.

The result is that Hammersmith is effectively sealed off from the metropolis by road, unless you are prepared to wait at least half-an-hour to get out of it. It is obvious to anybody that all these closures need not have taken place at the same time. It is obvious that nobody in authority cares.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Tina Arena
fields.trailText: Tina Arena
fields.body:
Tina Arena, 33, was born Philopina Lidia Arena, and raised in Melbourne, Australia, by Sicilian parents. She first sang in public at six, and by eight was a national TV star. In 1993, she signed to Sony Music. Her debut album, Don't Ask, sold millions worldwide, and made her Australia's biggest-selling female vocalist of all time. She is currently starring as Esmeralda in Notre-Dame de Paris at the Dominion Theatre, London.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
At this point in time, a new personality.

What is your greatest fear?
Being unable to find that new personality.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Joan of Arc - I may not burn for my beliefs, but I've certainly sacrificed.

Which living person do you most admire?
Goldie Hawn - I wish I had her sense of humour right now.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Let's not start.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Sleazy come-ons.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Everything but the kitchen sink.

What is your favourite building?
Hard to say: there are so many to choose from. I'm a big fan of architecture.

What is your favourite journey?
The one I'm on - life.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
Not for me to comment.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Far too broad a question - we could debate this issue for years - and I'm not running for government.

For what cause would you die?
Oh please - not a relevant question in the 21st century.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes, with the right person.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?
My pet pooch Goldie.

Which living person do you most despise and why?
The trick is to never let them know!

What is your greatest regret?
My first marriage.

How do you relax?
What's that?

How often do you have sex?
You guys have got to get a life!

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
More personal time.

How would you like to die?
Painlessly, of course.

How would you like to be remembered?
As making a contribution to friends and family.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Be real.

webTitle: How to write a personal ad

fields.headline: How to write a personal ad
fields.trailText: Abbreviations are very common in personal ads. The only one you really need to know is WLTM, which means the person in question likes a rare kind of country music that is found only on that particular American radio station.
fields.body:
Abbreviations are very common in personal ads. The only one you really need to know is WLTM, which means the person in question likes a rare kind of country music that is found only on that particular American radio station. Getting N/S (non-smoking) confused with S/M (sado-masochist) may make your first date difficult if you want to light up after being thrashed to within an inch of your life.

Be very careful if you decide to meet someone who claims to have a GSOH (great sense of humour). Really, this should be followed by IYTREMPSIF (If You Think Regurgitating Entire Monty Python Sketches Is Funny). Generally, you should steer clear of all abbreviations, as they give the impression that you're a cheapskate trying to cut down on the word count, or that you've been in the dating game so long that you use a desperate kind of shorthand. Besides, if your ad is just a string of letters, it looks like you have the personality of a nappy bag. (If you do, then fair enough.)

Most people are quite coy about personal ads, so try not to identify yourself unwittingly: heir to throne seeks like-minded plant, etc. When describing yourself, try to steer clear of clichés: 'attractive' only means that your face is vaguely symmetrical; 'lively' that you have a pulse; 'fun' that you're not in tears all the time. On the other hand, don't go overboard with the descriptive stuff; 'Picaresque Shavian Sybarite' translates for most people as 'Tosser Of Epic Proportions'.

Look carefully at what people say they want: 'friendship, maybe more' means sex if I fancy you; 'country walks' means sex in haystack; 'romance' means sex after dinner; 'conversation' means sex on the sofa; 'travel' means sex on a ferry; 'laughter' means sex after a joke; 'long evenings in' means sex after sex; 'long-term relationship' means sex after you've met my parents and established a rapport with my four children. Be very, very careful if someone just comes out with it and says that they're after a strenuous physical relationship, as there is a very real danger that they might be a closet rambler.

Once you've sifted through the one reply to your ad, you might want to meet that person in the flesh. Follow these rules: meet in a public place (ie, not your bedroom); tell a friend what you're doing (and they'll tell everyone else); wear something recognisable (not your purple tweed jacket). And finally, if you've advertised in the Guardian, don't say you'll be carrying a rolled-up copy of the Telegraph.

fields.headline: Alive and bubbling
fields.standfirst: Roger Protz looks ahead to next month's Great British Beer Festival, and reveals how you can become one of the judges of Camra's Beer of Britain competition
fields.trailText: Roger Protz looks ahead to next month's Great British Beer Festival, and reveals how you can become one of the judges of Camra's Beer of Britain competition
fields.body:
If you've been feeling mildly bitter about the state of the brewing industry, perk yourself up with a trip to the annual Great British Beer Festival at London Olympia, where you'll be refreshed by the sight of hundreds of cask ales from the country's family-owned regional and smaller craft breweries.

Bass and Whitbread may have thrown in the bar towel and sold their breweries to Interbrew of Belgium, manufacturer of a billion gaseous glasses of Stella Artois; and such revered names as Mansfield, Marston's, Morland and Ruddles may have been swallowed by regional giants Greene King and Wolverhampton & Dudley - but British beer is still alive and bubbling. In fact, I cannot recall a time when so many new ales have come into the nation's bars, all of them ales that have been crafted with great skill and dedication. As well as rich-tasting bitters, porters, summer ales and harvest beers, brewers have kicked aside convention and searched for new aromas and flavours: St Peter's beer, for example, made with lemongrass and ginger, and St Austell's Clouded Yellow, made with the addition of vanilla and maple syrup. And what about the hoppy delights of Yella Belly, Bateman's welcome contribution to the growing ranks of organic beers?

Yes, there will be such delights, and no doubt surprises aplenty, at the Great British Beer Festival, which is being staged by the indefatigable Campaign for Real Ale (Camra) from August 1-5. Some 700 beers will be on show, including some genuine lagers , both dark and pale, from the Czech Republic, Germany and the US, but the belt and braces of this annual beer bonanza will, as ever, be the cask-conditioned ales brewed by those British brewers who are still wedded to such concepts as flavour and character.

Unlike Bass and Whitbread, who first sold their souls to bland lager and "creamflow" keg beers and then sold their birthright to Interbrew, our smaller brewers have kept the faith, and still make distinctive ales that ripen in casks in pub cellars. They don't see themselves as part of an industry in crisis, with real ale disappearing into the abyss. London's two independents, Fuller's and Young's, report a healthy rise in the sales of their beers, as do Brakspear of Henley, Charles Wells of Bedford, and Belhaven in Scotland; Timothy Taylor, meanwhile, whose aromatically hopped Landlord pale ale won the Champion Beer of Britain award at last year's festival, brewed more beer last year than at any time in a history that dates back to 1858, and has just installed new fermenters to cope with demand. And just this month, the Tomos Watkin brewery moved from its cramped premises behind a pub in Llandeilo to smart new buildings in Swansea, from where it can boost dramatically the output of its ripe and succulent ales. There are similar good stories from all over the country.

More than just a forum for our best brews, however, the festival destroys all the clichés about real ale. It's not peopled solely by men with vast girths and bird's-nest beards: 40% of visitors are women, and many ale drinkers, of both sexes, are young. There will be ales, lagers, ciders and perries to suit all tastes and age groups, and the music at lunchtime and evening will cater for rockers and classicists alike. Royalists can sup at a special bar with beers brewed to mark the Queen Mother's 100th birthday, while republicans can raise a glass of Tom Paine at the Harvey of Lewes stand.

The festival kicks off with the annual Champion Beer of Britain competition to find the finest milds, bitters, strong bitters and speciality beers. Once again, the Guardian has joined forces with Camra in sponsoring the bottle-conditioned beer awards, and we need volunteer readers to join the panel of judges. The tasting is at 12 noon on July 31, at Olympia. Volunteers should write to Matthew Fort, Food & Drink Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER with a day-time telephone number (or email: weekend@ theguardian.com).

 Full details of the festival on www.gbbf.org.

And just this month, the Tomos Watkin brewery moved from its cramped premises behind a pub in Llandeilo to smart new buildings in Swansea, from where it can boost dramatically the output of its ripe and succulent ales. There are similar good stories from all over the country. More than just a forum for our best brews, however, the festival destroys all the clichés about real ale. It's not peopled solely by men with vast girths and bird's-nest beards: 40% of visitors are women, and many ale drinkers, of both sexes, are young. There will be ales, lagers, ciders and perries to suit all tastes and age groups, and the music at lunchtime and evening will cater for rockers and classicists alike. Royalists can sup at a special bar with beers brewed to mark the Queen Mother's 100th birthday, while republicans can raise a glass of Tom Paine at the Harvey of Lewes stand. The festival kicks off with the annual Champion Beer of Britain competition to find the finest milds, bitters, strong bitters and speciality beers. Once again, the Guardian has joined forces with Camra in sponsoring the bottle-conditioned beer awards, and we need volunteer readers to join the panel of judges. The tasting is at 12 noon on July 31, at Olympia. Volunteers should write to Matthew Fort, Food & Drink Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER with a day-time telephone number (or email: weekend@ theguardian.com).  Full details of the festival on www.gbbf.org.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Marinades, part II
fields.trailText: Marinades, part II
fields.body:
The subject
Uses and abuses of marinades, those versatile donors of flavour, lubrication and tenderness to all manner of food.

The basics
A marinade needs three things: oil for lubrication and bulk, acid for flavour and tenderising power, and flavourings for - guess! Oil: neutral or extra -virgin olive. Acid: wine or vinegar or lemon/lime juice. Flavourings: you name 'em.

The details
Certain ingredients were born to marinate. The Knowledge's Famous Five: all alliums (especially garlic and shallots), ginger, herbes de Provence, coriander seed, soy sauce. The Knowledge's All-Purpose Marinade (old family recipe): equal parts soy sauce, oil and red-wine vinegar with a couple of chopped cloves of garlic. A full day's soak (refrigerated, naturally) will work maximal wonders. If your marinade contains vegetables and aromatics, cooking it briefly (then cooling before the meat goes in) will develop the flavours marvellously. The marinade pool should be shallow, one half to two thirds the depth of the food. Turn the food, don't soak it. And don't forget to towel it off: draining excess marinade makes for better browning. Odd marinating-man-out 1: 'dry' marinades (ie, herb and spice mixes rubbed into the meat). Some people don't consider these marinades, but they're being pedantic. Odd-man-out 2: vegetables, which are marinated after cooking (such as champignons à la Grécque, leeks in vinaigrette, grilled or roasted veg in extra-virgin olive oil and sherry vinegar). If you want a summer meal worth killing for (but not worth killing animals for), this trinity will answer your prayers.

Where to buy
N/A.

The easy way out
Aka the eastern way out: the only bottled marinade the Knowledge buys is Kikkoman Teriyaki Marinade, which is really just glorified soy sauce.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck and J Sainsbury plc get a rush of blood to the head.
fields.body:
The winner of the competition set in this column some weeks ago- in which readers were invited to identify a particularly exquisite wine quotation - is Ms Joanna Brown of London SW18. She was the first to point the finger at Sybille Bedford's novel, A Compass Error, first published in 1968 but recently reissued by Penguin (18 points out of 20, £6.99), with a fascinating new introduction by the author herself.

Only two other readers nailed it, Mr John Guest of Derby and Ms Helen Holmes of Togston, Northumberland. Incorrect guesses at authorship included Sylvia Townsend Warner, Molly Keane, Sebastian Faulkes, Antonia Fraser, Jane Gardam, DH Lawrence and, most fantastic of all in my view, John Fante. Ms Brown wins lunch at Le Gavroche. Ms Holmes and Mr Guest win copies of the next Superplonk wine guide. I apologise to readers who may find this kind of competitive indulgence a wildly discursive bore, otiose to my duty to find remarkable wines at unremarkable prices, but I do get these rushes of blood to the head now and then.

As does J Sainsbury plc. This retailer's latest artery-quickening brood includes half-a-dozen terrific South African wines knocked down in price until July 29. Kumala Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, on offer at £3.59) is nutty and restrained, and has an elegant, Italian, fish wine feel to it. The own-label, non-vintage South African Chardonnay (15 points, normally £3.99, but buy three and you pay £10) is rather demure and restrained, but is hugely sippable and a great summer party wine. South African Reserve Selection Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, on offer at £4.39) is warm and comforting, being, like a favourite cardigan, richly textured and thickly knitted.

On the red side at JS, Spice Route Andrew's Hope Cabernet Merlot 1999 (16.5 points, on offer at £4.99) has a great opening of spice and leather, then it turns more petit chteau and dry, and then it goes full-frontal rich and ripe with integrated tannins on the final flourish. The non-vintage, own-label South African Cabernet Sauvignon (15.5 points, on offer at £3.49) is utterly unpretentious and deliciously mellow. It makes few demands on the intellect, true, but as a slab of fruit it is marvellously quaffable. Winds Of Change Pinotage Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16 points, on offer at £3.99) has elegance, dryness and a savoury biscuit quality to its texture. It throws in a quietly thrilling climax of spicy plums and berries.

Last at Sainsbury, there is La Chasse du Pape 'Reserve Barrique' Côtes du Rhône 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99). This is not a 'special offer' price, but it could advertise itself as such for it is a marvellous bargain offering stunning ripeness, earthy plum fruit with undertones of blackcurrants, and lively tannins. The same wine is also at Safeway, but it is the 1999 vintage and this rates the same and costs the same and just about tastes the same, except that, being that bit older and from a different vintage, there is more weight on the tannins but it is still a marvellously solid, textured wine of great class and sensory impact.

Safeway has three further worthy reds. Mont Tauch Barrel-Matured Merlot Vin de Pays du Torgan 1998 (17 points, £7.99) is magnificent, and available at selected branches. It has superb tobacco undertones to the leather, and plummy spiciness; my tasting notes, only a trifle extravagantly, include the rider 'Is this the Pétrus of the Midi?' This refers to an obscene Bordeaux artefact, employing the same grape, that asks a hundred times more money. The extraordinary complexity and beautifully textured richness of the Mont Tauch represent far better value.

Cono Sur Reserva Merlot 1999 (16.5 points, £6.49), from Chile, also puts to shame many a stratospherically higher-priced Bordeaux. It is not chilly or austere, but warm, friendly, rounded and a huge, fun-filled, quaffing wine. Likewise Domaine Chris Limouzi Corbières 1998 (16.5 points, £5.49), which has exceptionally soft and beautifully textured tobacco and blackberry fruit. I drank a bottle with Ms Bedford s book for company and enjoyed myself thoroughly. I heartily recommend the marriage, though be warned that the wine is just arriving at selected Safeway branches (01622 712926 for details) as you read this.

fields.headline: Get fresh
fields.standfirst: Purple patch
fields.trailText: Purple patch
fields.body:
This vibrant juice has a wonderfully concentrated and complex flavour. The potentially over-the-top sweetness of beetroot is cut by the clean bitterness of pink grapefruit. It's a juice for when you've had too much coffee, and want to bring your tastebuds back to life. Beetroot is an excellent source of folic acid and good for iron, too, so purple patch is a brilliant combination for anyone who needs to get these nutrients - pregnant women, say, or vegetarians who aren't too hot at a balanced diet. Pink grapefruit tastes less acid than other citrus fruits, but has all the benefits of anti-carcinogenic, immune-system-boosting vitamin C (the latter also improves the absorption of the folic acid and iron from the beetroot).

In a juice machine, pulverise: one large raw beetroot, peeled; the flesh of a pink grapefruit, peeled. If you haven't got a juicer, juice the grapefruit in a lemon squeezer, chop the beetroot small and give it a whizz in a blender. Sieve the pulp over a bowl and collect the juice. Mix together. Makes two small glasses.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: rude awakening
fields.standfirst: 'Not without misgivings, enter chat room under the code name Harry'
fields.trailText: 'Not without misgivings, enter chat room under the code name Harry'
fields.body:
'Dulcie? Arrre you thinking of going on holiday this summerrr, dearrr ?"

Aunt wants trip to Scotland. Has been dropping subtle hints for weeks about the Highlands and how she longs to see a man in a kilt once more before she dies. Kilts evidently Caledonian form of HRT. "I'm thinking of Umbria, Auntie," I retort firmly. "But Gordon might fancy a little trip north. I want to show Harriet some Renaissance art before she starts going off on holidays with her friends."

Harriet already wants to go off with her friends - to the Reading Festival. Can Perugino's frescoes compete with the Foo Fighters? Surely she is too young to go to a pop festival? "Don't worry, Mum. Emma's going, an' Gabby an' Shelley 'n' Tris 'n' Wills." Am fleetingly reassured, though know my misgivings will loom up again later. My baby! If the sun shines she'll be baked, if it rains she'll be drowned, she'll be robbed or raped, or at the very least have to queue for an E. coli-infested loo.

But these are remote anxieties. A more immediate concern is what we are going to have for supper. The treadmill of catering. But wait! I have discovered the possibility of on-line shopping. Run to computer and introduce myself to Iceland and Waitrose. Torn between Iceland's offer, Belchers 800g Bar-B-Q Rib 'n' Wing Combo, and Waitrose's Blackened Pastrami Salmon With Rocket And Grilled Lemon, though the latter sounds more like a defence policy than a tempting delicacy. Aunt looms up behind me. "Iceland!" she exclaims. "I thought you said you werrre thinking of Umbrrria, dearrr ?"

"I am, Auntie," I hurl my cursor towards Go airlines and summon up prices of flights to Rome. "You can do anything on the internet these days. It's marvellous. You really should get to grips with it. There's lots about Scotland on it, you know."

"Mum!" Harriet arrives, fresh from phone. "Emma can't come! She can't afford it! And Gabby's parents are taking her on holiday then! But Tris 'n' Wills are still okay, and Wills says he's got a tent like big enough for all of us." Wait! He? Realise belatedly that Wills, and probably also Tris, possesses testicles. "I'm not sure if a girl as young as you..."

"It's todally, like, safe, Mum! There's loads of police and first aid and everything. Log on to the Reading Festival website - you'll see."

Obey, though uneasily aware of Aunt still hovering. Reading website opens with artwork of young couple sprawling in underwear. Young man invites me, through speech bubble, to "Click on my pants to enter the site". Aunt tuts audibly.

"It's great, see Mum, innit? Everyone there's, like, into music, yeah? Not, like, football hooligans."

"What is a chat rrroom?" enquires Aunt peering at screen. "I like the sound of that. I quite like a chat. Can we trrry it, dearrr?"

Not without misgivings, enter chat room under code name Harry. Someone called Biggun enquires, "Any sexy ladies out there?" Not sure if Aunt glimpsed this enquiry in the split-second it took me to get rid of image. "Oh, we've lost it," I cry in mock-dismay. "Chat rooms are a waste of time, anyway," adds Harriet nervously. "Just, like, weirdos an' stuff."

"I tell you what, though, Auntie," I persist, aware that if she could only become an aged internet-addicted anorak, many of our problems would be solved, "I can even do my banking on-line. Look." Hope she will glimpse, and pity, my overdraft, and perhaps offer a little something towards Umbria, especially as I've been looking after her every need since way back last autumn. Key in request for personal banking, but to my horror receive instead highly explicit pornographic images. For a moment am paralysed. Check typing. Yes, I asked for banking with a "b". Harriet dives on to mouse and censors image before Aunt is halfway through her first gasp.

"Just a medical page," I soothe, as urbanely as possible. "To do with prostate cancer checks, I think."

"And brrreast cancer, too, I think, dearrr," ponders Aunt, who potters off and locks herself in the bathroom. Probably to inspect her imposing bosom, but who knows? I am not my aunt's keeper. I have other fish to fry - Rack-Grilled Chilli-Lime Squid with Asian Herb And Peanut Salad to be exact.

fields.headline: Perfect picnics
fields.standfirst: The tastiest food, best paraphernalia, top locations, fabulous fashions... Weekend's picnickers' guide, introduced by Charlotte Abrahams
fields.trailText: The tastiest food, best paraphernalia, top locations, fabulous fashions... Weekend's picnickers' guide, introduced by Charlotte Abrahams.
fields.body:
It's Sunday morning and the sun is shining, so you decide to have a picnic. Your head fills with romantic thoughts of sun-dappled meadows and babbling brooks, but when you get there the car park is jammed and the kids are fractious. So, you park up on a verge and set off in search of a decent spot. You settle for a patch of grass between two other families. You eat, the bugs eat - then the weather breaks and there's a stampede back to the car.

So why do we do it? It's all to do with bloody-mindedness, says Georgina Battiscombe in her book, English Picnics: "A picnic is the Englishman's grand gesture, his final defiance flung in the face of fate. No climate in the world is less propitious to picnics... yet with a recklessness that is almost sublime [we] rush out of doors to eat a meal at every possible and impossible occasion." She has a point, but I think it has more do with the fact that we are a nation of incurable optimists. We may live in a country where the difference between summer and winter is that the former gives us more opportunity to see grey skies, but we simply won't accept it. Summer (we know, we've been abroad) means long, hot days and lazing with friends in a grassy dell. Deep down, we know that the dell will be overcrowded or that rain will stop play, but that is irrelevant: the pleasure is in the anticipation.

So what goes into a perfect picnic? According to Johnny Roxsburgh of chic catering company the Admiral Crichton, the main requirements are "the right people, a beautiful location, running water, linen napkins, decent glasses, no children, no dogs and absolutely no nettles". For the children in Swallows And Amazons, meanwhile, perfection is scrambled eggs cooked on a camp fire and eaten out of the "common dish" with not a grown-up in sight. Which just goes to show that the ideal picnic, like the fantasy it is, is a personal thing.

One point that people agree on is that a picnic should be a feast. It's the fresh air that does it. Being outdoors seems to free us from inhibitions, and the vast spread on the ground makes everyone stuff themselves.

For some, such as Drusilla Beyfus, author of Modern Manners, picnics have strict rules: "You should aim for effortless brilliance. Picnics should be sybaritic. Proper plates and glasses are important. Plastic is acceptable if there are children, but it really is very pleasant to eat off proper plates and have linen napkins."

So much for the spontaneous picnic of a loaf and fresh fruit. But that, wonderful though it is, is a foreign thing, for a climate where the sun shines in summer. The British picnic must be planned, because the planning may be as far as we get. It also needs to be rather grand, because if the weather does allow us our day in the sun, then we should make it one to remember.
