As once trusted drugs begin to fail, it is gaining ground. Jerome Burne investigates the fight to conquer a disease that has afflicted man for centuries.
fields.body:
Dr Jo Lines leans his bare white arm lightly on the fine net that forms the roof and walls of the cage. Within seconds, about 20 of the creatures inside have latched on to him and were sucking his blood.

"Try it," urges Lines, senior lecturer in vector biology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. "It's only a bit uncomfortable." Lines is obligingly providing a blood meal for a cluster of female mosquitoes of the variety Anopheles, the one that carries the parasite Plasmodium falciparum , which is responsible for malaria.

These particular specimens, living in their cage in a hot, low-ceilinged cellar under Gower Street in central London, are certified malaria-free; but it was their infected cousins that last month slid their needle-sharp probosces through the skin of British troops stationed in Sierra Leone, allowing the parasite lurking in their salivary glands to slip into the soldiers' bloodstream and induce the potentially lethal fever of malaria.

Every year, 500 million people in tropical countries develop malaria; one million of them, mostly children under the age of five, die as a result. In some areas, P. falciparum 's resistance to multiple drugs is growing so fast that even if you can afford treatment, it may not work. But, just because the number of cases in this country is still comparatively few, we would do well not to be complacent. Malaria has shrugged off everything our modern medical arsenal can throw at it, and, after a brief retreat just after the second world war, is on the march again.

More than 2,000 travellers return from infested areas to the UK every year infected with malaria, and the number is rising. The disease, which may well have infected the dinosaurs, kills more people worldwide than Aids. The people who arrive home are the lucky ones: get to the doctor in time, and fast, effective treatment is available. Without a course of drugs, however, you can feel as though a mild flu is coming on at midday and be dead from inflammation of the brain by midnight.

A plausible scenario, sketched for me by Dr Lines, suggests that it would take a rise in our average minimum temperature of only a few tenths of a degree - quite possible, given global warming - for malaria-carrying mosquitoes to be once again capable of infecting people in the south of England. Lines has been tending mosquitoes for more than 20 years - not that you can become too attached to your subjects, seeing as they live only for about two weeks - yet he is still affected by the saliva they inject when they "bite". "If I flare up immediately," he says, "that means I won't have trouble later." He removes his arm and gazes calmly at his unmarked skin. "I'll be itching like hell tonight."

So, why do some people get attacked by every mozzie in the neighbourhood while others can sleep through the night unmarked? "We know they are attracted to moisture, carbon dioxide, lactic acid and warmth," he says, "but we don't know why some people are much more attractive than others."

References to malaria-type fevers date back to the ancient Greeks - the historian Herodotus mentions that fishermen used to sleep under their nets for protection. Treatments up until the 19th century were drastic and largely ineffective. Purging and bleeding were used for malaria, as for almost everything else. More specific and imaginative remedies included: eating live spiders on a pat of butter; embracing a bald-headed Brahmin widow at dawn; and placing a copy of the fourth book of the Iliad under the patient's head.

The first recorded western use of the one really effective remedy - the bark of the cinchona tree, first found in what is now Equador - is around 1630. Experts now generally agree that the deadly form of malaria, carried by the Anopheles mosquito, was actually brought to the Americas by the slave trade, another gift from the west, along with smallpox. Traditional healers probably tried the bark because it was effective against other fevers. French chemists extracted quinine, the active alkaloid in cinchona, in 1820.

For a long time, cinchona bark was associated with the Jesuits and regarded with suspicion. Oliver Cromwell, who died of malaria, might have been saved by the new treatment, but his doctors did not dare prescribe the Popish Powder. For more than 200 years, debate raged over how effective it was, many doctors continuing to recommend bleeding, purging and worse. The 18th-century British surgeon, James Lind - better known for his advocacy of lemons to combat scurvy - also supported the use of bark for sailors, and made up a recipe of bark, orange peel and alcohol that cut malaria cases in the navy.

Despite the effectiveness of quinine, during Victorian times more than 30% of hospital beds in the British colonies were filled with malaria cases, and malaria was still killing hundreds of thousands in Europe alone at the beginning of the last century. More than 100,000 British soldiers, and the same number of Germans, contracted malaria in the Balkans between 1916 and 1917. It was not eradicated from Rome until as recently as the 30s, when Mussolini drained the Pontine Marshes.

Despite the fact that the disease has been a menace to man for so long, there is still a lot that the experts don't know about malaria. What they do know is remarkable enough. Malaria, or rather P. falciparum , which infects both humans and mosquitoes, is such a fearsome adversary partly because of its protean life-cycle, which makes it seem like some mythical beast. The "thing" in the movie Alien shocked audiences when it burst out of its original pod in one form and then destroyed poor John Hurt's stomach when incarnated in another. This Plasmodium goes through no fewer than five such transformations in its brief life.

You'll first encounter it during what's known as the sporozoite stage, when you are bitten by an infected mosquito and the parasite is injected into your bloodstream, along with the insect's saliva. There may be only a half-a-dozen individual parasites in your blood at this stage. Like special-forces troops, these parasites then have to evade not only your immune system, but must also rendezvous at your liver, where they hole up, the first stage of their mission completed.

For about 10 days, you remain quite unaware that anything is happening. But the sporozoites are engaged in a frenzy of activity. Not only are they changing into their next stage, but each member of the original team is multiplying by a factor of 10,000. Then, just short of 10 days - the time it takes your second line of immune defence, the T-cells, fully to mount a counter attack - they burst from the liver and back into the bloodstream. But now they have become what are known as the merozoites: within minutes, each one invades a red blood cell and, once inside, begins to break down the iron-rich molecule of haemoglobin inside for food while starting to multiply yet again. This is when you start to notice that something is wrong.

A classic sign of malaria is a fever that comes on every two or three days. That's how long it takes for each merozoite to multiply up to 20 times. So, by this point, even if only a single sporozoite had successfully made it to your liver in the first stage of infection, some 200,000 merozoites would now be infecting your blood cells and taking a chemical wrecking ball to their insides. Merozoites have a voracious appetite: in just a few hours, they can suck as much as a quarter of a pound of haemoglobin out of the red blood cells of an infected human. This is why those who are chronically infected with malaria suffer from anaemia, with all the associated lethargy and vulnerability to infection.

Normally, when red blood cells are infected, it is the job of the spleen to spot that something is wrong and destroy them. But the merozoites have evolved a cunning plan to prevent this. They make the blood cells grow little protrusions so they become stuck in narrow blood vessels and capillaries, especially in the brain. That way, they never get to the spleen. Instead, lodged in some arterial backwater, they wait, brood pouches for Plasmodium , while enzymes leach out their iron. Then the merozoites breach the walls of the blood cells and pour out, leaving the cells' dying hulks behind.

The damaging effect of malaria is due partly to a lack of oxygen. The clustering of cells stuck in the capillaries has an effect similar to that of the blocked blood vessels caused by a stroke, and the amount of oxygen reaching the brain drops off. The latest scientific thinking, however, is that some other as yet poorly-understood metabolic changes also take place, and that these are responsible for many of the symptoms - the reasoning behind this assumption is that a stroke causes irreversible brain damage, but someone who is sinking into a malarial coma can walk out of hospital within a few hours of taking drugs that target the merozoites.

P. falciparum has not by any means finished its quick-change routine at this stage. So far, it has been operating by basic cell division, much like a bacterium or virus. Now it is ready for sex. Merozoites in a few of the infected blood vessels, instead of churning out copies of themselves, divide into a male and a female version, known as gametocytes.

Once again, just how they decide to change is not clear. We know, however, that they indulge in some fancy footwork over sex ratios: to begin with, there are significantly more males than females; later on, the proportion evens up. Actually, the term male and female is a bit of a loose description - the females are essentially large eggs, while the males are not much more than sperm.

The stage is now set for the final part of the cycle - the Plasmodium 's mission is accomplished, and it is time to ship out. Your bloodstream is by now packed with millions - if not billions - of infected cells, some of which contain the crucial gametocytes, the ones that are going to start the whole cycle all over again. If you live in a mosquito- infested area, you are likely to be bitten regularly, so when the next female mosquito sucks the blood from you that she needs to fertilise her eggs, some of the red corpuscles she ingests will contain gametocytes.

Once the gametocytes are inside the mosquito's stomach, which is slightly cooler than their previous surroundings, they immediately recognise that they have successfully transferred and proceed to fuse to form zygotes. If you've only been infected by one set of sporozoites, then the mating of the gametocytes won't create any genetic variation, but if, as is more than likely in the Tropics, your original infection stemmed from the sporozoites of dozens or more mosquitoes, then this is where genes can be swapped and a resistance to drugs passed on. The zygotes then start dividing and produce - yes, you've guessed it - a new batch of sporozoites. We are nearly back at the beginning again. Relentlessly, these newly-hatched sporozoites will make their way through the dark tunnels of the mosquito's body and into the insect's salivary glands, where they will sit awaiting the next mission.

The Plasmodium 's complicated life-cycle is both the key to its success and the root of its vulnerability. Some researchers are confident that the huge range of targets which this variety of manifestations offers means they will soon be able to deliver a knock-out blow. All the sophisticated techniques of modern molecular medicine are being pressed into service. Hit it with antibodies when it first arrives, jack up the T-cell response to mount an attack in the liver, tinker with the proteins it needs to bore its way into the blood cells, prevent production of the enzymes used to break up the haemoglobin, disrupt the sex ratio so only male or only female gametes are produced: variations on each of these methods are currently being researched in laboratories around the world.

"Malaria is a preventable disease," argues Professor Adrian Hill, of the Institute of Molecular Medicine, Oxford. "It's a scandal that millions die from it every year. Money is at the root of the problem. The people who suffer most from malaria have little or no money." Hill is currently attempting to develop a vaccine, and that takes money. "The total budget worldwide for research on a malaria vaccine is about $20 million," he explains. "Compare that with $40 million for an Aids vaccine, and many times that for specific western diseases. A proper budget of $500 million a year could produce a really effective vaccine within a few years."

Hill's vaccine approach is probably the most advanced in the world. It uses a combination of fragments from the parasite's DNA, which identify the proteins it exhibits at the liver stage, and a more traditional vaccine that was originally used against smallpox. "DNA vaccines were the next big thing about five years ago," he says. "They work brilliantly in mice, but they've been disappointing in humans. But combining them with a viral vaccine seems to boost their effect, and the early trials are looking good."

Others in the field are not so sure that such vaccines are going to be the answer. Professor Eleanor Riley, an immunologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, is considerably more cautious. "There are enormous problems with getting the immune system to fight off malaria," she explains. "We still don't really know which immune responses are important. I wouldn't expect to see an effective vaccine for 10 or 15 years, if then. So far, there hasn't been a single useful vaccine against any human parasitic disease."

In fact, that last statement is not entirely true. There is a way that you could be vaccinated against malaria today that would give you protection for about six months with no need to take any drugs or preventatives. The only problem is that it is a technique that no one, except the most dedicated researcher, would be prepared to use - all you have to do is irradiate a large number of mosquitoes that are infected with P. falciparum by bombarding them with X-rays, then do a large-scale version of Dr Line's trick for real and put your arm in their cage and allow at least 1,000 of them to bite you.

One of the few people in the world who does expose himself to this particular form of torture is Dr Stephen Hoffman, of the US Naval Medical Research Institute, who has devoted years to the fight against the disease. His experience provides a cautionary tale for those who believe a vaccination is around the corner. More than 20 years ago, he was among the researchers who were jubilant to discover exactly why volunteers treated in this way became immune.

Microscopic studies revealed that the sporozoites in their blood had lost their protective protein coat, which is why they were no longer able to infect their host. The road suddenly seemed open to create a vaccine. Isolate the protein (which was dubbed circumsporozoite, or CS), inject it and wait while the body created antibodies, because sporozoites without CS cannot invade the liver.

It worked very well in mice, but 13 years ago the first highly-publicised trials with humans were a disaster. Seven of the eight vaccinated volunteers developed the disease when they were infected. CS still hasn't delivered a viable vaccine, although new versions are currently being tested. Similar high hopes were placed in a vaccine called SPf66, developed by a Colombian researcher, Dr Manuel Elkin Patarroyo, and based on a synthetic peptide that targets the blood stage. A few years ago, it, too, was hyped as the next big thing, and some reports claimed that ethnocentric western scientists were ignoring its potential. But it, too, has not lived up to its early promise: clinical trials in Africa and south-east Asia have shown little or no protective effect.

But amid all this talk of yet more hi-tech molecular fixes, it is easy to forget that in this century malaria has been successfully eradicated from large areas of the world, largely as a by-product of prosperity. Drainage to reclaim agricultural land and the move to live in solid houses with glassed windows had the incidental effect of both reducing the mosquito population and keeping them away from people. The last cases of malaria in Britain were recorded in the 50s on the Isle of Sheppey. Until the 30s, malaria was endemic in large areas of the US, where hundreds of thousands of people were infected every year. Since then, however, rising living standards have almost completely banished it. (Last year, the death of just three people in New York from a mosquito-born virus called St Louis encephalitis triggered off a major public health scare.) Malaria is, more than anything, a disease of poverty.

"Humans are the only host for falciparum malaria," says Riley. "Theoretically, if everyone in the world with malaria could be treated with effective drugs and then kept from being bitten again, it would die out." This is, of course, impossible, but it is the principle that lies behind most eradication programmes: drain the marshy areas where the Anopheles mosquito likes to breed, detect early anyone who has been infected, treat them with drugs and then keep them from being re-infected. "One of the most effective means of prevention is very simple and very low-tech," says Riley. "It is a bed net dipped in insecticide. If they were properly used in Africa, you could reduce childhood mortality by up to 40% for a cost of less than $15 dollars a head." This low-tech approach relies on using different techniques for different situations and cultures: "Nets work in Africa, because the mosquitoes there feed at night. But in South America, they are not so effective, because the mosquitoes bite before people go to bed."

Within the past 15 years, cases of malaria have been dramatically cut in the Hunan province in China - from nearly a million in 1985 to 68,500 by 1993 - without the introduction of any new wonder vaccines but through a combination of better drainage, insecticide-treated nets and the rapid treatment of cases with drugs and traditional medicines, such as Qinghaosu, or sweet wormwood. Of course, results such as that assume a well-established and funded public health service, which is rarely available in most of Africa.

But such pedestrian solutions tend not to grab the headlines. Far more exciting are the technological fixes, such as the proposal, reported earlier this year, to treat malaria patients in large trucks, where they would be exposed to oscillating magnetic fields. Professor Henry Lai, of the bioengineering department at the University of Washington, believes that the electromagnetic approach might succeed where chemicals have been failing. The key to this radical approach is that the remains of haemoglobin molecules, attacked by merozoites and bound into long stacks like "tiny magnetic bars", would be destabilised. He has found that the merozoite count was significantly reduced when blood samples were put into weak oscillating magnetic fields. The theory is that these fields cause the stacks to spin, damaging or even killing the parasites.

Last month, however, it was fluorescent green mosquitoes that were being heralded as the key to "eliminating this deadly disease": researchers at Imperial College, London, reported that they had succeeded, for the first time, in genetically engineering a mosquito - they were green because the test gene the researchers inserted was one that causes fluorescence, to make the insect easier to spot when the experiment had worked. The idea is to create swarms of transgenic mosquitoes that have been engineered for sterility or resistance to P. falciparum , and then release them into the wild, where they can wreak havoc on the indigenous mosquitoes' ability to procreate or pass on their resistance. But the success of any such project depends on the very basic evolutionary principle that, if these transgenic mosquitoes are successfully to pass on their modified genes, they must either out-compete their rivals in the wild or be irresistibly sexually attractive. Such traits are a lot harder to insert than a bright green colouring.

In fact, an evolutionary approach is the key to perhaps the most radical approach to malaria control of all. What both hi- and low-tech methods have in common is that they all involve waging war on P.falciparum . It is a pest, a parasite, to be fought, defeated, eradicated, disabled. But suppose you could cultivate it so that it became milder? Instead of regarding P. falciparum as some implacable enemy, how about treating it like another creature to be domesticated, such as sheep or horses? Sounds ridiculous?

"Imagine that you are a rhinovirus, the sort that causes colds," says Professor Paul Ewald, a biologist at Amherst College, Massachusetts. "You want to infect people, but you want them to be able to move about and infect other people. So you are successful if you stay relatively mild. But if you are transmitted by an insect, say a mosquito, then it doesn't matter if your host is moving about or not. That's why diseases such as yellow fever and sleeping sickness are so much more virulent than others. The most successful infectious agents are those that replicate rapidly and get passed on fast."

The essence of Ewald's idea is that if you can create conditions that make transmission harder, then the strains of the disease that are most successful will be the milder ones, which allow the host to move about and survive longer. One study that supports his view involves cholera, an infection carried via faeces in water - the more contaminated the water (ie, the easier it is for the cholera to be passed on), the more virulent the strains should be. Ewald's research in South America showed just that: heavily contaminated water in Guatemala was linked with a particularly vicious strain of cholera, while in Chile, where the water is much purer, the cholera is far milder. "The most preventative form of medicine," he says, "is when you change the organism so that it doesn't make you sick."

Applying this approach to malaria, Ewald suggests that the key would be effective mosquito-proofing of houses. "If the really sick, infected people are kept somewhere they can't be bitten, then the ones who are walking about will be the ones with a milder version," he explains. "The selection pressures on P. falciparum will be to evolve into a milder strain." An evolutionary approach, he suggests, would also indicate that if you were developing a vaccine it should allow a mild version to persist so that people could build up natural immunity.

Ewald's ideas are hardly mainstream yet, but he does have some supporters. "If he is right, it may be that the application of an evolutionary theory to public health could save millions of lives," says Professor Joseph Schall of the University of Vermont. "If we are able to manipulate the evolutionary trajectory of our friends - domestic animals and crops - why can we not do the same with our enemies such as cholera and malaria?"

The widespread incidence of the gene for sickle-cell anaemia in certain African populations where malaria is endemic shows that evolution in the human host is important as well. If you inherit one copy of this sickle-cell anaemia gene, it will modify your blood in such a way that merozoites find it more difficult to break down the haemoglobin; you would not be fully immune to malaria, but you will be less badly infected by the parasite. At a price: if you inherit two copies of the gene, one from each parent, you develop sickle-cell anaemia, a horrible disease that usually kills you in childhood. Yet the evolutionary trade-off between the risk of a lethal blood disease and partial protection against malaria turns out to be so beneficial that in some parts of Africa 25% of the population now has the sickle-cell gene.

Medical historians estimate that P. falciparum has been using humans as a host ever since we developed agriculture, which gathered enough of us in one place to act as a reservoir. So, the history of malaria is essentially a mini-history of medicine. A hundred years ago, P. falciparum was treatable with a South American herbal medicine and vigorous public-health programmes. Today, with its genome nearly sequenced, we know infinitely more about its inner workings, but there are still areas of the world where all that is keeping it in check are public-health programmes and traditional herbs. P. falciparum is a parasite and a killer, but is also a powerful antidote to medical hubris

The war on malaria

Could malaria return to Britain? We already have Anopheles mosquitoes in this country, but they are not infected with malaria. According to Dr Ron Behrens of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, for malaria to become a risk here, 'first, you need some local anophelines to become infected by biting people who have come to the UK with malaria in their blood. What happens next depends on the temperature, which is why global warming could become a factor.'

The warmer it is, the quicker the parasite develops. 'What's important is the minimum temperature,' says Behrens, 'but a small increase can have a big impact: a 0.2C increase in areas that were almost free of infection has increased the incidences of malaria from 1% to 5%.'

There are increasing numbers of infected people in the UK; some do not even realise it and so have not sought treatment. If one of them was bitten in a hot summer, however, the cycle could start: 'Malaria is so dangerous because you have to act fast,' says Behrens. 'If you haven't been away and get infected, no one is going to suspect malaria. You may think you just have flu, and then find yourself in a coma within hours.'

Why the drugs don't work

A few years ago, almost no new drugs against malaria were in the pipeline because the pharmaceutical companies did not consider it a profitable-enough disease - although it affects millions worldwide, few can afford the pills. Recently, several large-scale projects have encouraged partnerships between research institutes and drug companies; these include The Malaria Vaccine Initiative (MVI), sponsored to the tune of $50 million by Bill Gates, and the WHO's Medicines for Malaria Venture (MMV). The latest thinking appeals to industry and government self-interest by arguing that malaria holds up economic development.

Resistance to the drugs is growing. The Thai-Cambodian border, for instance, is a region of enormous upheaval, where gem miners in search of rubies and emeralds try drug after drug in an attempt to stay on their feet long enough to make their fortune. The result has been the emergence of a strain of malaria that is resistant to all the registered anti-malaria drugs bar Artemisia, the traditional Chinese remedy based on sweet wormwood.

In other areas, resistance is growing to some older drugs such as chloroquine and proguanil (discovered in the early 40s and sold here under the trade name Paludrine), although other combinations, such as Malarone (a combination of proguanil and atovaquone), are still effective. Quinine and its derivatives work by poisoning P. falciparum in its own waste, by preventing it from getting rid of one of the by-products of breaking-down haemoglobin. Artemisinin seems to work by increasing the action of damaging free radicals that attack the parasite.

The gene in P. falciparum that has mutated to resist one anti-malarial drug also resists others of similar chemical structure. 'It's disturbing,' say researchers, 'that a mutation in just one gene can trash three or four drugs at once.'

Advice for travellers

If you are French and travelling to a malaria-infested area, you will be given Savarine which contains the familiar combination of chloroquine and proguanil, but in higher doses than are given here, and is taken daily rather than weekly. Some experts claim that this gives more constant protection. Savarine is hard to obtain in the UK.

Mefloquine, also known as Lariam, was developed in the 80s and is based on quinine. It is more expensive than chloroquine and proguanil, but is more convenient, because you don't have to take it as often. Resistance to it is much less widespread than to chloroquine, but there are worries over side-effects, which may occasionally include psychotic symptoms.

Malarone, one of the new combination drugs and even more expensive, is currently licensed only for treatment, but some experts consider it a very effective prophylactic. Relatively convenient to take. Trials are underway.

The herbal treatment, Qinghaosu, also known as sweet wormwood, has been used in China for 2,500 years to treat fevers. Artemesinin, the active ingredient, was isolated by Chinese scientists in 1972, and has since proved to be effective against strains that are resistant to other drugs. It is sometimes used as a treatment in the UK.
fields.bodyText: Dr Jo Lines leans his bare white arm lightly on the fine net that forms the roof and walls of the cage. Within seconds, about 20 of the creatures inside have latched on to him and were sucking his blood. "Try it," urges Lines, senior lecturer in vector biology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. "It's only a bit uncomfortable." Lines is obligingly providing a blood meal for a cluster of female mosquitoes of the variety Anopheles, the one that carries the parasite Plasmodium falciparum , which is responsible for malaria. These particular specimens, living in their cage in a hot, low-ceilinged cellar under Gower Street in central London, are certified malaria-free; but it was their infected cousins that last month slid their needle-sharp probosces through the skin of British troops stationed in Sierra Leone, allowing the parasite lurking in their salivary glands to slip into the soldiers' bloodstream and induce the potentially lethal fever of malaria. Every year, 500 million people in tropical countries develop malaria; one million of them, mostly children under the age of five, die as a result. In some areas, P. falciparum 's resistance to multiple drugs is growing so fast that even if you can afford treatment, it may not work. But, just because the number of cases in this country is still comparatively few, we would do well not to be complacent. Malaria has shrugged off everything our modern medical arsenal can throw at it, and, after a brief retreat just after the second world war, is on the march again. More than 2,000 travellers return from infested areas to the UK every year infected with malaria, and the number is rising. The disease, which may well have infected the dinosaurs, kills more people worldwide than Aids. The people who arrive home are the lucky ones: get to the doctor in time, and fast, effective treatment is available. Without a course of drugs, however, you can feel as though a mild flu is coming on at midday and be dead from inflammation of the brain by midnight. A plausible scenario, sketched for me by Dr Lines, suggests that it would take a rise in our average minimum temperature of only a few tenths of a degree - quite possible, given global warming - for malaria-carrying mosquitoes to be once again capable of infecting people in the south of England. Lines has been tending mosquitoes for more than 20 years - not that you can become too attached to your subjects, seeing as they live only for about two weeks - yet he is still affected by the saliva they inject when they "bite". "If I flare up immediately," he says, "that means I won't have trouble later." He removes his arm and gazes calmly at his unmarked skin. "I'll be itching like hell tonight." So, why do some people get attacked by every mozzie in the neighbourhood while others can sleep through the night unmarked? "We know they are attracted to moisture, carbon dioxide, lactic acid and warmth," he says, "but we don't know why some people are much more attractive than others." References to malaria-type fevers date back to the ancient Greeks - the historian Herodotus mentions that fishermen used to sleep under their nets for protection. Treatments up until the 19th century were drastic and largely ineffective. Purging and bleeding were used for malaria, as for almost everything else. More specific and imaginative remedies included: eating live spiders on a pat of butter; embracing a bald-headed Brahmin widow at dawn; and placing a copy of the fourth book of the Iliad under the patient's head. The first recorded western use of the one really effective remedy - the bark of the cinchona tree, first found in what is now Equador - is around 1630. Experts now generally agree that the deadly form of malaria, carried by the Anopheles mosquito, was actually brought to the Americas by the slave trade, another gift from the west, along with smallpox. Traditional healers probably tried the bark because it was effective against other fevers. French chemists extracted quinine, the active alkaloid in cinchona, in 1820. For a long time, cinchona bark was associated with the Jesuits and regarded with suspicion. Oliver Cromwell, who died of malaria, might have been saved by the new treatment, but his doctors did not dare prescribe the Popish Powder. For more than 200 years, debate raged over how effective it was, many doctors continuing to recommend bleeding, purging and worse. The 18th-century British surgeon, James Lind - better known for his advocacy of lemons to combat scurvy - also supported the use of bark for sailors, and made up a recipe of bark, orange peel and alcohol that cut malaria cases in the navy. Despite the effectiveness of quinine, during Victorian times more than 30% of hospital beds in the British colonies were filled with malaria cases, and malaria was still killing hundreds of thousands in Europe alone at the beginning of the last century. More than 100,000 British soldiers, and the same number of Germans, contracted malaria in the Balkans between 1916 and 1917. It was not eradicated from Rome until as recently as the 30s, when Mussolini drained the Pontine Marshes. Despite the fact that the disease has been a menace to man for so long, there is still a lot that the experts don't know about malaria. What they do know is remarkable enough. Malaria, or rather P. falciparum , which infects both humans and mosquitoes, is such a fearsome adversary partly because of its protean life-cycle, which makes it seem like some mythical beast. The "thing" in the movie Alien shocked audiences when it burst out of its original pod in one form and then destroyed poor John Hurt's stomach when incarnated in another. This Plasmodium goes through no fewer than five such transformations in its brief life. You'll first encounter it during what's known as the sporozoite stage, when you are bitten by an infected mosquito and the parasite is injected into your bloodstream, along with the insect's saliva. There may be only a half-a-dozen individual parasites in your blood at this stage. Like special-forces troops, these parasites then have to evade not only your immune system, but must also rendezvous at your liver, where they hole up, the first stage of their mission completed. For about 10 days, you remain quite unaware that anything is happening. But the sporozoites are engaged in a frenzy of activity. Not only are they changing into their next stage, but each member of the original team is multiplying by a factor of 10,000. Then, just short of 10 days - the time it takes your second line of immune defence, the T-cells, fully to mount a counter attack - they burst from the liver and back into the bloodstream. But now they have become what are known as the merozoites: within minutes, each one invades a red blood cell and, once inside, begins to break down the iron-rich molecule of haemoglobin inside for food while starting to multiply yet again. This is when you start to notice that something is wrong. A classic sign of malaria is a fever that comes on every two or three days. That's how long it takes for each merozoite to multiply up to 20 times. So, by this point, even if only a single sporozoite had successfully made it to your liver in the first stage of infection, some 200,000 merozoites would now be infecting your blood cells and taking a chemical wrecking ball to their insides. Merozoites have a voracious appetite: in just a few hours, they can suck as much as a quarter of a pound of haemoglobin out of the red blood cells of an infected human. This is why those who are chronically infected with malaria suffer from anaemia, with all the associated lethargy and vulnerability to infection. Normally, when red blood cells are infected, it is the job of the spleen to spot that something is wrong and destroy them. But the merozoites have evolved a cunning plan to prevent this. They make the blood cells grow little protrusions so they become stuck in narrow blood vessels and capillaries, especially in the brain. That way, they never get to the spleen. Instead, lodged in some arterial backwater, they wait, brood pouches for Plasmodium , while enzymes leach out their iron. Then the merozoites breach the walls of the blood cells and pour out, leaving the cells' dying hulks behind. The damaging effect of malaria is due partly to a lack of oxygen. The clustering of cells stuck in the capillaries has an effect similar to that of the blocked blood vessels caused by a stroke, and the amount of oxygen reaching the brain drops off. The latest scientific thinking, however, is that some other as yet poorly-understood metabolic changes also take place, and that these are responsible for many of the symptoms - the reasoning behind this assumption is that a stroke causes irreversible brain damage, but someone who is sinking into a malarial coma can walk out of hospital within a few hours of taking drugs that target the merozoites. P. falciparum has not by any means finished its quick-change routine at this stage. So far, it has been operating by basic cell division, much like a bacterium or virus. Now it is ready for sex. Merozoites in a few of the infected blood vessels, instead of churning out copies of themselves, divide into a male and a female version, known as gametocytes. Once again, just how they decide to change is not clear. We know, however, that they indulge in some fancy footwork over sex ratios: to begin with, there are significantly more males than females; later on, the proportion evens up. Actually, the term male and female is a bit of a loose description - the females are essentially large eggs, while the males are not much more than sperm. The stage is now set for the final part of the cycle - the Plasmodium 's mission is accomplished, and it is time to ship out. Your bloodstream is by now packed with millions - if not billions - of infected cells, some of which contain the crucial gametocytes, the ones that are going to start the whole cycle all over again. If you live in a mosquito- infested area, you are likely to be bitten regularly, so when the next female mosquito sucks the blood from you that she needs to fertilise her eggs, some of the red corpuscles she ingests will contain gametocytes. Once the gametocytes are inside the mosquito's stomach, which is slightly cooler than their previous surroundings, they immediately recognise that they have successfully transferred and proceed to fuse to form zygotes. If you've only been infected by one set of sporozoites, then the mating of the gametocytes won't create any genetic variation, but if, as is more than likely in the Tropics, your original infection stemmed from the sporozoites of dozens or more mosquitoes, then this is where genes can be swapped and a resistance to drugs passed on. The zygotes then start dividing and produce - yes, you've guessed it - a new batch of sporozoites. We are nearly back at the beginning again. Relentlessly, these newly-hatched sporozoites will make their way through the dark tunnels of the mosquito's body and into the insect's salivary glands, where they will sit awaiting the next mission. The Plasmodium 's complicated life-cycle is both the key to its success and the root of its vulnerability. Some researchers are confident that the huge range of targets which this variety of manifestations offers means they will soon be able to deliver a knock-out blow. All the sophisticated techniques of modern molecular medicine are being pressed into service. Hit it with antibodies when it first arrives, jack up the T-cell response to mount an attack in the liver, tinker with the proteins it needs to bore its way into the blood cells, prevent production of the enzymes used to break up the haemoglobin, disrupt the sex ratio so only male or only female gametes are produced: variations on each of these methods are currently being researched in laboratories around the world. "Malaria is a preventable disease," argues Professor Adrian Hill, of the Institute of Molecular Medicine, Oxford. "It's a scandal that millions die from it every year. Money is at the root of the problem. The people who suffer most from malaria have little or no money." Hill is currently attempting to develop a vaccine, and that takes money. "The total budget worldwide for research on a malaria vaccine is about $20 million," he explains. "Compare that with $40 million for an Aids vaccine, and many times that for specific western diseases. A proper budget of $500 million a year could produce a really effective vaccine within a few years." Hill's vaccine approach is probably the most advanced in the world. It uses a combination of fragments from the parasite's DNA, which identify the proteins it exhibits at the liver stage, and a more traditional vaccine that was originally used against smallpox. "DNA vaccines were the next big thing about five years ago," he says. "They work brilliantly in mice, but they've been disappointing in humans. But combining them with a viral vaccine seems to boost their effect, and the early trials are looking good." Others in the field are not so sure that such vaccines are going to be the answer. Professor Eleanor Riley, an immunologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, is considerably more cautious. "There are enormous problems with getting the immune system to fight off malaria," she explains. "We still don't really know which immune responses are important. I wouldn't expect to see an effective vaccine for 10 or 15 years, if then. So far, there hasn't been a single useful vaccine against any human parasitic disease." In fact, that last statement is not entirely true. There is a way that you could be vaccinated against malaria today that would give you protection for about six months with no need to take any drugs or preventatives. The only problem is that it is a technique that no one, except the most dedicated researcher, would be prepared to use - all you have to do is irradiate a large number of mosquitoes that are infected with P. falciparum by bombarding them with X-rays, then do a large-scale version of Dr Line's trick for real and put your arm in their cage and allow at least 1,000 of them to bite you. One of the few people in the world who does expose himself to this particular form of torture is Dr Stephen Hoffman, of the US Naval Medical Research Institute, who has devoted years to the fight against the disease. His experience provides a cautionary tale for those who believe a vaccination is around the corner. More than 20 years ago, he was among the researchers who were jubilant to discover exactly why volunteers treated in this way became immune. Microscopic studies revealed that the sporozoites in their blood had lost their protective protein coat, which is why they were no longer able to infect their host. The road suddenly seemed open to create a vaccine. Isolate the protein (which was dubbed circumsporozoite, or CS), inject it and wait while the body created antibodies, because sporozoites without CS cannot invade the liver. It worked very well in mice, but 13 years ago the first highly-publicised trials with humans were a disaster. Seven of the eight vaccinated volunteers developed the disease when they were infected. CS still hasn't delivered a viable vaccine, although new versions are currently being tested. Drainage to reclaim agricultural land and the move to live in solid houses with glassed windows had the incidental effect of both reducing the mosquito population and keeping them away from people. This low-tech approach relies on using different techniques for different situations and cultures: "Nets work in Africa, because the mosquitoes there feed at night. Of course, results such as that assume a well-established and funded public health service, which is rarely available in most of Africa. But such pedestrian solutions tend not to grab the headlines. Far more exciting are the technological fixes, such as the proposal, reported earlier this year, to treat malaria patients in large trucks, where they would be exposed to oscillating magnetic fields. Professor Henry Lai, of the bioengineering department at the University of Washington, believes that the electromagnetic approach might succeed where chemicals have been failing. The key to this radical approach is that the remains of haemoglobin molecules, attacked by merozoites and bound into long stacks like "tiny magnetic bars", would be destabilised. He has found that the merozoite count was significantly reduced when blood samples were put into weak oscillating magnetic fields. The theory is that these fields cause the stacks to spin, damaging or even killing the parasites. Last month, however, it was fluorescent green mosquitoes that were being heralded as the key to "eliminating this deadly disease": researchers at Imperial College, London, reported that they had succeeded, for the first time, in genetically engineering a mosquito - they were green because the test gene the researchers inserted was one that causes fluorescence, to make the insect easier to spot when the experiment had worked. The idea is to create swarms of transgenic mosquitoes that have been engineered for sterility or resistance to P. falciparum , and then release them into the wild, where they can wreak havoc on the indigenous mosquitoes' ability to procreate or pass on their resistance. But the success of any such project depends on the very basic evolutionary principle that, if these transgenic mosquitoes are successfully to pass on their modified genes, they must either out-compete their rivals in the wild or be irresistibly sexually attractive. Such traits are a lot harder to insert than a bright green colouring. In fact, an evolutionary approach is the key to perhaps the most radical approach to malaria control of all. What both hi- and low-tech methods have in common is that they all involve waging war on P.falciparum . It is a pest, a parasite, to be fought, defeated, eradicated, disabled. But suppose you could cultivate it so that it became milder? Instead of regarding P. falciparum as some implacable enemy, how about treating it like another creature to be domesticated, such as sheep or horses? Sounds ridiculous? "Imagine that you are a rhinovirus, the sort that causes colds," says Professor Paul Ewald, a biologist at Amherst College, Massachusetts. "You want to infect people, but you want them to be able to move about and infect other people. So you are successful if you stay relatively mild. But if you are transmitted by an insect, say a mosquito, then it doesn't matter if your host is moving about or not. That's why diseases such as yellow fever and sleeping sickness are so much more virulent than others. The most successful infectious agents are those that replicate rapidly and get passed on fast." The essence of Ewald's idea is that if you can create conditions that make transmission harder, then the strains of the disease that are most successful will be the milder ones, which allow the host to move about and survive longer. One study that supports his view involves cholera, an infection carried via faeces in water - the more contaminated the water (ie, the easier it is for the cholera to be passed on), the more virulent the strains should be. Ewald's research in South America showed just that: heavily contaminated water in Guatemala was linked with a particularly vicious strain of cholera, while in Chile, where the water is much purer, the cholera is far milder. "The most preventative form of medicine," he says, "is when you change the organism so that it doesn't make you sick." Applying this approach to malaria, Ewald suggests that the key would be effective mosquito-proofing of houses. "If the really sick, infected people are kept somewhere they can't be bitten, then the ones who are walking about will be the ones with a milder version," he explains. "The selection pressures on P. falciparum will be to evolve into a milder strain." An evolutionary approach, he suggests, would also indicate that if you were developing a vaccine it should allow a mild version to persist so that people could build up natural immunity. Ewald's ideas are hardly mainstream yet, but he does have some supporters. "If he is right, it may be that the application of an evolutionary theory to public health could save millions of lives," says Professor Joseph Schall of the University of Vermont. "If we are able to manipulate the evolutionary trajectory of our friends - domestic animals and crops - why can we not do the same with our enemies such as cholera and malaria?" The widespread incidence of the gene for sickle-cell anaemia in certain African populations where malaria is endemic shows that evolution in the human host is important as well. fields.headline: Boy banned
fields.standfirst: 'The last guy I went out with kept smelling my neck and asked me, on our second date, if I would promise to always challenge him.'
fields.trailText: 'The last guy I went out with kept smelling my neck and asked me, on our second date, if I would promise to always challenge him.'
fields.body:
I had this idea, I told my therapist when I returned to Minnesota from the first leg of my book tour, that my last boyfriend would show up at one of my readings. "He's the last real relationship you had," she said. "Of course you had that fantasy. It's been, what? Two years? And you haven't let anyone else in." As if boyfriends were like Girl Scouts, going door to door, trying to look cute and move some product, which is actually not so far from the truth.

"I've been busy," I said. "I just thought maybe I'd be signing books and I'd look up and he'd be standing there." My therapist rolled her eyes. "Of course you'll fall back on what's familiar," she said. "Of course you're going to resort to that." At the mention of "resort", I pictured my romantic life as a kind of family vacation spot where everyone else is water skiing and drinking beer and grilling on the barbecue. In the resort of my heart, I'm sitting under an umbrella wearing 45-protection sunscreen and a big floppy hat.

"This has got to stop," I said. "I'm going to be 33 pretty soon. I can't keep having this fantasy that he'll show up. I have to date some real people."

"You keep pushing away the real people," said my therapist. She was playing with her lips in a way that made it look like she had only one tooth, which made it difficult to take her seriously, so I looked down, instead, at her feet. Since it's summer, she was wearing sandals, and I noticed that attached to the top of one foot was a 33-cent stamp.

"Where are you going?" I asked her.

"That's what I should be asking you," she said. "Where are you going? What will you make room for in your life in the next few years?"

"No," I said. "I mean, you're wearing a postage stamp."

The next day I left for Milwaukee, and by the time I got to New York, made my way through a day of radio interviews, book-signings and my reading, I got back to my hotel room and just burst out crying. When I had checked in earlier that day, the guy at the front desk had apologised to me for not having my room ready and had asked if I would mind taking a room on a lower floor. I said that it was fine with me, and then he asked me if I would enjoy a fish.

"A fish?" I said.

"For your room," he said. He could see I was puzzled.

"I don't know, sweetie," he said.

"Everyone should have a designated person to check in with," I said.

"Challenge him to what?" said my therapist.

"That's what I said."

"Maybe you need an imaginary boyfriend," my mother Flo says.

"I give up," I say. "I've given up. This is like the 23rd time I've given up. I just keep saying it and hoping that then the guy will show up. And he doesn't."

"He will," says Flo.

"You can say that," I say, "because you're 64 and you're already married and more young men flirt with you than with anyone I know. I'm going to be 33. The clock is ticking. I'm as old as Jesus."

"Jesus is much older than you."

"I'm talking about his mortal life."

"He was a good man," says my mother.

"It's been so long since I had sex, I'm becoming some kind of reconstituted virgin. Just add water." I know I shouldn't say things like that to my mother, but sometimes I can't help it.

"Hey! Speaking of water," my mother says, "you do have a boyfriend. Where's the boyfriend I bought you?"

I'd forgotten about the novelty boyfriend my mother had given me. A little toy called "Instant Boyfriend: Just Add Water." "I didn't take him out of the package yet," I say. "Well, go get him wet," she says, "then you won't be so lonely."

"Have you been moonlighting as a sex-line operator?" I say.

"Go get your boyfriend, Miss Dirty Mind," says Flo.

I filled a large kitchen bowl with water and plunked in my boyfriend, who, dehydrated, was about half the size of a green bean. It takes him a while to grow, but three days later, when my mom calls to check on us, he has stretched to a full eight inches, and developed decent pectoral muscles, broad, round shoulders, and washboard abs.

"Except," I tell my mother on the phone, one of his arms is kind of curled up. "And one leg is shorter than the other."

"Hey," says my Mom. "Nobody's perfect."

"He lives in a bowl," I say. "My boyfriend lives in a bowl."

"Well," she says. "You have to start somewhere."

fields.headline: Right little, tight little island
fields.standfirst: This country has kept out asylum seekers for a century.  DD Guttenplan on our exclusive past
fields.trailText: This country has kept out asylum seekers for a century. DD Guttenplan on our exclusive past
fields.body:
Three scenes from London life. (1) Westminster in 1999, when the tidal wave of "bogus asylum seekers" that would break across tabloid front pages was just a gentle swell on the horizon. A House of Commons standing committee is discussing the government's proposal to replace welfare benefits (of around £46 a week) with a system of food vouchers worth £35 a week. "Many asylum seekers come from communities where wealth may be stored in jewellery," explains the Home Office minister Mike O'Brien, "and it is right for us to take account of that wealth."

"Is the minister suggesting," asks Diane Abbott, MP, "that asylum seekers should sell their jewellery, perhaps their wedding rings, as an alternative to the government meeting its moral and international responsibilities to provide a reasonable level of support?"

When O'Brien replies: "I certainly am suggesting that," a Tory backbencher is heard to mutter: "You'll be wanting the gold fillings out of their teeth next."

(2) The David Irving libel trial in February. Reading from the transcript of an interview with Irving on Australian television, Richard Rampton, QC, barrister for the defence, asks why Irving had said that the idea of black men playing cricket for England made him feel "queasy".

Irving: "My reply to him on air was, what a pity it is that we have to have blacks on the team and that they are better than our whites."

Rampton: "Why is that a pity?"

Irving: "It is a pity because I am English."

Rampton: "Are they not English too?"

Irving: "Well, English or British, are you saying?"

Rampton: "I am saying that they are English. Most of them are born here, just as all the Jews in England were born here, most of them."

Irving: "Are we talking about blacks or Jews now?"

Rampton: "It does not matter. They are all English."

(3) A traffic jam in North London. To pass the time, my daughter and I start to argue about whether having been born here makes her English. On her mother's side her grandparents were Greek refugees; on her father's side, American Jews, themselves the descendants of the "economic migrants" of the 19th century. My daughter agrees with Rampton, and, however much I argue to the contrary, remains convinced that she is, as she puts it, "an Englander". I am too fond of her to make use of the fact that she is, unknowingly, undercutting her case by using Yiddish. Besides, she is only four years old.

When Diane Abbott asked whether asylum seekers should be forced to pawn their wedding rings, she may have thought her question was rhetorical - like Rampton's dismissal of the notion that being born here doesn't make you English. (Surely he knows that under Margaret Thatcher's 1981 Nationality Act, being born here doesn't even make you British.) But something besides wishful thinking links these episodes - a more disturbing set of associations thrown into high relief by another scene, in Dover last month, when customs officers opened the back of a lorry and found the bodies of 58 Chinese refugees piled against the back door. Press accounts said that the officers concerned would receive counselling and be allowed several days' leave.

Pulling corpses off the back of a lorry is nasty work, even when the deaths are intentional. Between December 1941, and May 1942, the Nazis used three specially adapted lorries to kill 97,000 Jews near the village of Chelmno in Poland. These vehicles were prone to breakdowns, but, according to Christopher Browning, the author of The Path To Genocide and an expert witness at the Irving trial, the real problem was with the men. Browning cites a Nazi medical report describing the crews as suffering "enormous emotional and health injuries" and complaining of headaches after each unloading. Indeed, the desire to spare the Einsatzgruppen such stresses was one of the reasons behind Himmler's decision to shift to stationary, purpose-built gas chambers.

For several months Britain has been in the midst of a Holocaust revival. From the daily coverage of the Irving trial, to David Edgar's dramatisation of Gitta Sereny"s Albert Speer at the National Theatre, to the newly opened gallery at the Imperial War Museum, public awareness of the fate of European Jews is probably greater now than at any time in recent memory. The one place it hasn't penetrated is the current debate about Britain's treatment of refugees. If it had, those politicians who profess to be "shocked and saddened" at the death of 58 illegal immigrants might find the rest of us more sceptical when they suggest that the way to avoid such tragedies is to make it even harder for refugees to enter this country. As Louise London's recent book, Whitehall and the Jews 1933-48, reminds us, we have been down that road before.

Assumptions about Britain's response to the Holocaust fall into two distinct, and diametrically opposed, schools. In 1945, Viscount Cranborne, parliamentary under secretary to the Foreign Office until 1938, and secretary for the dominions from 1943 to 1945, assured the House of Lords that Britain had done more than any other country to help the Jews. "This comfortable view has proved remarkably durable," says London, "and is still adduced to support claims that Britain has always admitted genuine refugees, and that the latest harsh measures against asylum seekers are merely designed to exclude bogus applicants."

Nor is the left, always on the look-out for a stick with which to beat the government, immune to nostalgia for a supposedly more generous past. Cranborne's assertion came in response to Viscount Samuel, who had accused the government of condemning the Jews, "not as Jews, but by means of immigration restrictions _ Out of that vast reservoir of misery and murder, only a trickle of escape was provided." Bernard Wasserstein examined this claim in some detail in Britain And The Jews Of Europe, 1939-45 (1979), as have numerous historians on both sides of the Atlantic since then.

On the numbers alone, Britain's accusers appear to have the better case. Compare the 500,000-600,000 files on families and individuals seeking refuge in the archives of Britain's main Jewish organisations with the 80,000 refugees actually admitted. Clearly, this is not a question of a glass anywhere near half full. And as London points out, even the Kindertransports had their grim aspect. Of the 7,482 children given refuge here by the end of August 1939, London writes: "Admission saved the children's lives. Exclusion sealed the fate of their parents."

Last month's disclosure that MI6 knew about Nazi plans to "liquidate" 8,000 Roman Jews, yet did nothing to warn them, made headlines. And the evidence, from documents declassified in the US, that decoded radio intercepts dealing with the deportations were circulated to Winston Churchill may well force a revision of the widely held view that, unlike some of his ministers, Churchill did what he could to help the Jews. But there were already many instances in the documentary record when Whitehall's reluctance to admit refugees is expressed in language whose brutal frankness crosses over from callous indifference to outright anti-Semitism.

In April 1943, for example, the cabinet committee on refugees, meeting on the eve of the Bermuda conference, felt compelled to point out that "the Jewish element in the population of Poland was proportionally higher than was healthy". At the time this observation was made, more than three-quarters of Poland's Jews had already been murdered. That December, RAM Hankey of the Foreign Office minuted his objection to an American request to allow funds to be sent to rescue 70,000 Romanian Jews: "I suspect the real object of the scheme is financial - Jews in Europe getting out into dollars while there is yet time!"

In July 1944, when Jewish groups in Britain begged that something be done to save their brethren in Hungary - and when both they and the British government had every reason to know the fate of deported Jews - Herbert Morrison told the foreign secretary, Anthony Eden, that it was "essential that we should do nothing at all which involves the risk that the further reception of refugees here might be the ultimate outcome".

Louise London is the daughter of Jewish refugees, but her book is not a parochial indictment. As she points out, Britain's "softly softly" approach to Nazi anti-Semitism in the 1930s was supported by prominent British Jews, including Sir Herbert Samuel, who opposed a boycott on German goods. The fear that allowing too many Jews into Britain would trigger anti-Semitism here was shared by Whitehall mandarins and the Board of Deputies. After all, it was Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish Agency for Palestine and later Israel's first president, who claimed that Jews "have proved they are an insoluble element" in European society.

When, after the Anschluss, Britain reintroduced a visa requirement - forcing refugees to apply before entering Britain - the move was endorsed by Otto Schiff, on the grounds that "Austrian Jews were largely of the shopkeeper and small trader class and would therefore prove much more difficult to emigrate than the average German who had come to the United Kingdom".

In the spring of 1933, Schiff and Neville Laski, KC, head of the board of deputies, sent the government a guarantee that no refugee would become a burden on public funds: "All expense, whether temporary or permanent accommodation or maintenance, will be borne by the Jewish community without ultimate charge to the state." But when it came to Austrian Jews, the guarantee was made conditional. And when Czech Jews started fleeing in the wake of Munich, "Jewish organisations in Britain refused to take responsibility for refugees from Czechoslovakia". Schiff's Council for German Jewry "resisted, to the last, all pressure to get directly involved in arranging the entry of Czech Jews. This made it certain that relatively few would obtain refuge in Britain."

For the most part, London tells a story without heroes. She praises Eleanor Rathbone, the Christian MP whose parliamentary questions about government inaction made her the scourge of the Refugee Department, and puts in a good word for Sir Herbert Emerson, high commissioner for refugees, who emerges as an energetic and resourceful advocate of assistance. She also displays a great deal of sympathy for civil servants, often cast as Hitler's witting accomplices, especially in Zionist accounts. "The strength of the belief of Home Office civil servants that ministers were wrong to insist that refugees should be required to leave after the end of the war is shown," she writes, "by the effort they put into arguing the case that the only proper course was one of allowing the absorption of refugees who wished to remain." Even Neville Chamberlain gets credit for expanding asylum provision after Kristallnacht.

The only conspicuous villain in her account is Herbert Morrison, whose determination to keep the Jews out of Britain didn't end with VE day. Despite civil service advice, Morrison "clung to the view that at the end of the war the Home Office should require all refugees to depart, not even excepting those who had voluntarily served in the armed forces, and that those refugees who could not emigrate could be repatriated."

London's main interest, however, is in policy, not personalities. And here what she has to say is a salutary corrective both to the view that Whitehall anti-Semitism was primarily to blame for Britain's failure to do more, and to those who feel that there has been a lamentable falling off in compas sion towards asylum seekers since the second world war. She makes it clear that "by the 1930s the UK's tradition of granting asylum to refugees had been relegated to the background. Still the source of much national pride, the humanitarian tradition had little impact on practice and had been largely superseded. The inter-war system of immigration control contained no trace of any legal obligation to admit refugees."

From the 1950 Aliens Act onwards, London argues, admission to Britain has depended on the government of the day's perception of British interest. During the Nazi period "humanitarian aid to the Jews was assigned much lower priority than, for example, the maintenance of severe restrictions on alien immigration to the UK _ Thus, while the particulars of refugee policy varied according to the ever-changing circumstances of the Jews, its limits were defined by self-interest."

In other words, there may have been times when, either because of public pressure or out of a need to keep the Americans (who had Jewish voters to worry about) onside, it was necessary to appear to act, but the limits on what might be done were never questioned, at least not within Whitehall.

When Anthony Eden said, "we should avoid any reproach that we are not doing all we can to rescue these unfortunate people," London explains that "the object was not to rescue Jews, but to avoid the reproach that Britain was not doing all it could to rescue Jews. The priority, therefore, was to reduce public pressure for action and avoid criticism of inaction." Which is why the April 1943 Bermuda conference on refugees, a disaster from the point of view of the refugees and their advocates, "was seen as a success for British policy. The conference decisions provided a rationale for refusing to act on demands for rescue. They also enabled the government to appear to be trying to ameliorate the position of refugees."

It is impossible to read London's book without a mounting sense of déjà vu. Take out the word Jews and put in its place Romanies or Ethiopians or Kosovars or Bosnians and you have the essence of New Labour's asylum policy. The 1951 Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees is often seen as an act of reparation on the part of governments that spectacularly failed to save the Jews. But it is important to remember that it was also an artefact of the cold war, which brought its own countervailing pressure to bear on the national interest. That pressure is now gone, and Jack Straw is able to tell an EU conference that the convention should be changed so that asylum seekers are allowed to submit their claims before they enter Europe.

If all the current protections are kept in place, this might be a welcome step. But it is more likely that the government means to screen asylum seekers in their place of origin, with the same hostile intent that forced Austrian and Czech Jews to apply for visas. Why else would the Tories - though they object to Straw's willingness to work through European institutions - be so supportive? That his own grandmother, a German Jewish refugee, might have been kept out by such a policy is no more of a restraining influence on the present Home Secretary than it would have been on his predecessor, himself the son of a Jewish refugee.

 A version of this article first appeared in the London Review of Books. D D Guttenplan is writing a book about the David Irving trial, to be published by Granta next year.

Schiff's Council for German Jewry "resisted, to the last, all pressure to get directly involved in arranging the entry of Czech Jews. This made it certain that relatively few would obtain refuge in Britain." For the most part, London tells a story without heroes. She praises Eleanor Rathbone, the Christian MP whose parliamentary questions about government inaction made her the scourge of the Refugee Department, and puts in a good word for Sir Herbert Emerson, high commissioner for refugees, who emerges as an energetic and resourceful advocate of assistance. She also displays a great deal of sympathy for civil servants, often cast as Hitler's witting accomplices, especially in Zionist accounts. "The strength of the belief of Home Office civil servants that ministers were wrong to insist that refugees should be required to leave after the end of the war is shown," she writes, "by the effort they put into arguing the case that the only proper course was one of allowing the absorption of refugees who wished to remain." Even Neville Chamberlain gets credit for expanding asylum provision after Kristallnacht. The only conspicuous villain in her account is Herbert Morrison, whose determination to keep the Jews out of Britain didn't end with VE day. Despite civil service advice, Morrison "clung to the view that at the end of the war the Home Office should require all refugees to depart, not even excepting those who had voluntarily served in the armed forces, and that those refugees who could not emigrate could be repatriated." London's main interest, however, is in policy, not personalities. And here what she has to say is a salutary corrective both to the view that Whitehall anti-Semitism was primarily to blame for Britain's failure to do more, and to those who feel that there has been a lamentable falling off in compas sion towards asylum seekers since the second world war. She makes it clear that "by the 1930s the UK's tradition of granting asylum to refugees had been relegated to the background. Still the source of much national pride, the humanitarian tradition had little impact on practice and had been largely superseded. The inter-war system of immigration control contained no trace of any legal obligation to admit refugees." From the 1950 Aliens Act onwards, London argues, admission to Britain has depended on the government of the day's perception of British interest. During the Nazi period "humanitarian aid to the Jews was assigned much lower priority than, for example, the maintenance of severe restrictions on alien immigration to the UK _ Thus, while the particulars of refugee policy varied according to the ever-changing circumstances of the Jews, its limits were defined by self-interest." In other words, there may have been times when, either because of public pressure or out of a need to keep the Americans (who had Jewish voters to worry about) onside, it was necessary to appear to act, but the limits on what might be done were never questioned, at least not within Whitehall. When Anthony Eden said, "we should avoid any reproach that we are not doing all we can to rescue these unfortunate people," London explains that "the object was not to rescue Jews, but to avoid the reproach that Britain was not doing all it could to rescue Jews. The priority, therefore, was to reduce public pressure for action and avoid criticism of inaction." Which is why the April 1943 Bermuda conference on refugees, a disaster from the point of view of the refugees and their advocates, "was seen as a success for British policy. The conference decisions provided a rationale for refusing to act on demands for rescue. They also enabled the government to appear to be trying to ameliorate the position of refugees." It is impossible to read London's book without a mounting sense of déjà vu. Take out the word Jews and put in its place Romanies or Ethiopians or Kosovars or Bosnians and you have the essence of New Labour's asylum policy. The 1951 Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees is often seen as an act of reparation on the part of governments that spectacularly failed to save the Jews. But it is important to remember that it was also an artefact of the cold war, which brought its own countervailing pressure to bear on the national interest. That pressure is now gone, and Jack Straw is able to tell an EU conference that the convention should be changed so that asylum seekers are allowed to submit their claims before they enter Europe. If all the current protections are kept in place, this might be a welcome step. But it is more likely that the government means to screen asylum seekers in their place of origin, with the same hostile intent that forced Austrian and Czech Jews to apply for visas. Why else would the Tories - though they object to Straw's willingness to work through European institutions - be so supportive? That his own grandmother, a German Jewish refugee, might have been kept out by such a policy is no more of a restraining influence on the present Home Secretary than it would have been on his predecessor, himself the son of a Jewish refugee.  A version of this article first appeared in the London Review of Books. D D Guttenplan is writing a book about the David Irving trial, to be published by Granta next year.

fields.headline: Trailblazer of feminism
fields.standfirst: A stubborn Yorkshire girl, she grew into a child of the 60s and a leader in thinking about women at work and at home whose own life was a series of complicated relationships.  Melissa Benn on a pioneer who got lost in the 80s but is being rediscovered by a new generation
