fields.headline: Shareholder value comes under fire
fields.standfirst:
An American consultant believes companies are making a mistake in mortgaging their future to get a higher stock price now, says Roger Cowe
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: It would be difficult to find a public company director who did not subscribe to the mantra of shareholder value - in public. They would be foolish to challenge this dominant philosophy, because that would swiftly result in City analysts marking down the company's shares.
fields.body:
It would be difficult to find a public company director who did not subscribe to the mantra of shareholder value - in public. They would be foolish to challenge this dominant philosophy, because that would swiftly result in City analysts marking down the company's shares.

After all, if a board is not running a company with the ultimate objective of maximising shareholder value, the shareholders would be crazy to leave the board in place. What is the point of investing in a company which is not trying to get the best returns for investors? And how can managers dare to tell shareholders there is any other game in town? That is why the notion caught on so quickly in this country when it first emerged from the US during the 90s, and why it is spreading through Europe.

So it is a little surprising to find a consultant from the US, with an impressive CV which includes McKinsey, publishing a book called, and calling for, The End Of Shareholder Value.

Even more surprising was the polite reception given to this absurd notion when the author, Alan Kennedy, addressed an audience of senior business figures at the London headquarters of the accountancy giant KPMG.

Mr Kennedy catalogued the destructive force of shareholder value as it tore through US industry. He described the leveraged buyouts where shareholders extracted value by selling off difficult subsidiaries, sacking employees, outsourcing services, pressuring suppliers for lower prices, then cutting research and development. And when that stopped working they had to engage in a dramatic takeover and/or buy back some of their own shares.

Mr Kennedy pointed out that GE - one of America's most respected companies, run by one of the world's most admired chief executives in Jack Welch - had spent more under his leadership in buying back shares than in any other form of investment. Mr Kennedy argues in his book that such wealth for shareholders is best achieved by focusing on other stakeholders - employees, customers and suppliers.

"Shareholder value is very destructive because of the narrow focus it adopts. The problem is by focusing on one constituency companies are alienating other groups," Mr Kennedy said.

He identified the decline in brand loyalty as customers become disaffected, said a growing number of middle-ranking executives are hiring agents to negotiate relationships because of a breakdown of trust, and warned that suppliers are beginning to gang up to bite back at customers who have applied too much pressure. All these things mean shareholder value will be hit in the future even if the share price is soaring now. "Companies are mortgaging their future to get a higher stock price now," he explained, stressing that the structure of executive options means that managers are incentivised to do exactly that.

The critical word is "now". There can be little argument against improving productivity and Mr Kennedy is no anti-capitalist. He acknowledges that the target companies of the leveraged buyout merchants were vulnerable because managers had not been on the ball.

"The problem is the unspoken 'now'," he said, suggesting that the real concept should be shareholder wealth, not value. "The word 'wealth' carries connotations of the long term. Value suggests you can cash it in today."

In the end, then, this argument is about the "inclusiveness" advocated in this country by the Centre for Tomorrow's Company (which was behind the KPMG session), plus the hoary issue of short-termism which has been around for 30 years.

Perhaps that is why the author is long on description and short on solutions. He does suggest some interesting stakeholder ideas, such as: a board committee to monitor and report on the company's impact on each constituency; a separate report on the impact on major stakeholders; a statement to shareholders setting out actions to build for the long term.

Like many stakeholder advocates, though, it is not clear whether he is really advocating "stakeholder wealth" as the true corporate objective, or a stakeholder strategy as a means of achieving shareholder wealth. The difference is crucial. A true stakeholder approach, where different interests were balanced, would mean that shareholders would sometimes lose out in favour of employees, customers or suppliers, and not just in the short term.

For example, a board could decide that spare cash should be divided between all stakeholders rather than being used only to buy back shares or pay a special dividend. Such a decision could probably be successfully challenged in the courts by the disadvantaged shareholders. The only adequate defence would probably be that this was merely a tactic to generate greater shareholder wealth in the long term. That seems to be what most stakeholder advocates really want.

The End of Shareholder Value, published by Orion, is priced at £18.99.

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst:
Alan O'Neill, Chairman and managing director of Kodak UK
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Alan O'Neill, Chairman and managing director of Kodak UK
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

In 1978 when I took charge of a polyester manufacturing unit.

What has been your best moment in management?

Recognising the power of positive reinforcement - it's a simple thing, but I've seen it have great impact on those around me.

What was your greatest mistake?

Not being four inches taller - I would have made a much better rugby player.

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Persuading people to pay good money for a bottle of water!

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Not being positive about the situation they find themselves in. I'm a great believer in positive thinking.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

No, the challenge is to make sure that everyone can make the most of their capabilities.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Thriving on chaos - it's just an excuse for bad organisation skills.

What will be the big business issue of the next decade?

E-communication overload. It's impossible to imagine a world without email now, isn't it?

What one lesson would you pass on to trainee managers?

Take an interest in activities outside your particular area of responsibility. You never know when it may come in useful and in my experience it always does.

Which management guru do you believe in?

Joe Juran, Project by Project And No Other Way.

Who is your management hero?

Jack Welch, chief executive of General Electric.

Who is your favourite politician?

My wife - I'm amazed she hasn't been snapped up by Downing Street yet!

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

"Well done", but I'm not sure that you can overuse it. It comes back to the positive reinforcement theory.

Apart from your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Having a screwdriver in one hand and a spanner in the other.

What annoys you most?

People who think they can get away with dumping their rubbish at the side of the road.

How do you relax?

Running through the woods with our dog. Apart from keeping me healthy, it gives me some valuable thinking time.

What was your last cultural experience?

Listening to the England rugby team beating South Africa in Bloemfontain.

What is your favourite city?

Melbourne.

Do you have a favourite website?

Ixquick is a great metasearch engine.

What is your greatest regret?

Not being fluent in French.

What would you really like to have been?

A surgeon. Being able to make a real difference to people's lives must be very rewarding.

fields.headline: Success was no accident
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Not many business people actually choose to go to court, but 46-year-old Michael J Symons, chief executive of Helphire Group plc, is an unusual entrepreneur. And credit hire, also known as accident management, is no ordinary industry.
fields.body:
Not many business people actually choose to go to court, but 46-year-old Michael J Symons, chief executive of Helphire Group plc, is an unusual entrepreneur. And credit hire, also known as accident management, is no ordinary industry.

Trained as a lawyer, Mr Symons is a perfect fit for this notoriously litigious sector. Essentially, companies such as Helphire exist to help the innocent parties in car accidents, such as rear-end shunts, where their insurers - rather than risk the time and expense of a claim against the guilty party's insurance firm - prefer to pay up; so the victim loses their no claims bonus and their renewal premium rockets.

Credit hire firms step in where motor insurers fear to tread. They hire the innocent motorist a car, repair their damaged vehicle, then pursue the guilty driver's insurers for costs.

"Insurance companies hate us," says Mr Symons cheerfully, "and they're constantly looking for legal loopholes."

Undoubtedly, it's Mr Symons' legal training - combined with a vigorous entrepreneurial spirit - which accounts for Helphire's particular success. "When we started in 1992, most people in the industry were from a motor trade background. In-house legal knowledge gave us the edge," Mr Symons recalls. "We could look at insurers' possible future arguments for not paying and work our way around them."

From a handful of staff - "a friend answered the phones and my brother-in-law cleaned the cars" - Mr Symons now employs 700. In 1997, the company became the only accident management company to be fully listed on the Stock Exchange, with a valuation of £16.4m. Since then, there's been a six-fold increase in profits to £6.01m.

Mr Symons himself had an inauspicious start. He was originally engaged on a consultancy basis because he couldn't afford to buy into the company, having lost around £350,000 in the property crash of the early 90s.

There is no doubt about his big break. "It was a conversation I had with a friend, Mark Jackson, after a game of squash. At the time I had no money and no job." Mr Jackson, a doctor, and another mutual friend, dentist Fred Porter, were planning to set up an accident management firm in the South, where there was little competition, and recognised that a lawyer would be a serious asset.

"I worried that it would be all grumpy people and cars breaking down; but it was a meal ticket when I needed it," Mr Symons admits. Mr Porter has now retired to Portugal; and Mr Jackson is deputy chief executive.

Mr Symons' calm demeanour seems scarcely credible in a business so fraught with risk. Aside from the endless legal battles, surely there's the danger that would-be customers lie about the circumstances of the crash? "Our operators are well-trained," he replies, "and we only take on clear-cut cases." Of an average of 3,000 cases per month, Helphire loses only two.

Even by the standards of this litigation-loving industry, Mr Symons' most recent venture looked a bold move. Last summer, he bought 1st Automotive, a small credit hire business already involved in a lawsuit over failure to comply with the Consumer Credit Act.

"We got a good price," says Mr Symons, "and, although I thought we'd lose, the technicalities behind this suit had big implications for the industry; as a lawyer I wanted to have some control over the litigation." Sure enough, although the House of Lords found against the company in May this year, the judgment stated that accident management companies fulfil a real need.

At first concerns that Helphire's own contracts were not in compliance saw the share price tumble, but following reassurances, shares are now steadily climbing again. As a long-term strategy, the risk appears to have paid off. "Across the industry, insurers were refusing settlements until they heard the outcome. Now they're being forced to pay out again," explains Mr Symons.

Shortlisted for the Ernst & Young-sponsored Entrepreneur of the Year awards, he clearly thrives on stress most would find shattering; he's now plotting a move into personal injury litigation.

"This business is stressful, but my work/life balance is fine," says the man who is currently fighting 15,000 court cases, before setting off for Royal Ascot.

Shortlisted for the Ernst & Young-sponsored Entrepreneur of the Year awards, he clearly thrives on stress most would find shattering; he's now plotting a move into personal injury litigation. webTitle: How to get on to the housing ladder

fields.headline: How to get on to the housing ladder
fields.trailText: The froth may have come off the London property market for the time being but this means little to those on moderate incomes that want to live as well as work in the capital.
fields.body:
The froth may have come off the London property market for the time being but this means little to those on moderate incomes that want to live as well as work in the capital.

The average Londoner needs to earn more than £41,000 each year to get a mortgage for a two-bedroom house on the open market, according to the London Housing Federation. At current rates, monthly payments would amount to £935.

At these prices there is no sign that teachers, nurses and other key workers are going to find it any easier to get a foothold on the housing ladder, even in the current slowdown.

Increasing numbers on ordinary incomes are turning to shared-ownership as a way of buying a house at a price they can afford. Participants pay a mixture of mortgage and subsidised rent with the option of increasing their share of the property as time goes on until they own it outright.

Some 20,000 households in the capital are in shared-ownership homes developed by housing associations. Now there are calls for a rapid expansion of the schemes. But shared ownership is not always a panacea and there are as many pitfalls as there are when buying a whole property on the open market, say critics.

There is a great deal of public support for home ownership and 69% of households are currently owner-occupiers. In its housing green paper, the government made clear it wants to support schemes that offer low cost home ownership for those on the income threshold.

Also, many social housing providers share the government's enthusiasm for schemes that help those on modest incomes join the ranks of owner-occupiers. In a report published last month the London Housing Federa tion, which represents the capital's housing associations, made a convincing case for massive expansion of shared ownership schemes. In A Foot On The Ladder, it says shared ownership is a "proven value-for-money option for housing key workers."

Steve Coleman of Notting Hill Home Ownership, part of a larger housing trust, believes it is more or less foolproof for those who want to buy. Flexible tenure means owners who get into difficulties can reduce the share of the property they own and increase the amount they rent, or even return to renting altogether, if appropriate. Similarly, owners whose incomes rise can increase the amount they own.

"The other important thing about buying is you get access to the market. If property values rise, you benefit. Someone who owns 25% of a property in Westminster will benefit more from price rises than someone who owns a property outright in some other areas."

But what happens when the market collapses? The involvement of a social landlord is likely to make buyers feel protected from the ups and downs of the property market. However, when it comes to purchasing a home, even a 50% share, buyers should apply the same criteria as they would to a conventional purchase. Buyers who used shared ownership to buy at the height of the market in the late 80s were just as stung as other buyers when property values collapsed.

Shared ownership in London is most popular with single adult households: 35% of all purchases are made by this group, according to figures produced by housing researchers at St Andrews and Dundee University. One-bedroom flats are also the properties that shoot up in value when the market is booming and plummet when prices fall.

One former homeowner who bought through shared ownership is sceptical about how many participants benefit from improving their property. "You can spend £5,000 doing up a one-bedroom flat bought for £100,000 to increase its value by £8,000.

"When the flat is sold the housing association picks up half of the value, which is £54,000. Therefore the owner will have spent £5,000 but gained only £4,000," he argues. "The housing association is supposed to get their valuer to take into account the improvements you have made but, in my experience, the owner doesn't really benefit."

His advice is to take as much care over a shared ownership purchase as you would one on the open market. Consider the location carefully, looking at amenities and transport links. You might want to move when your circumstances change, so ask yourself whether the property would sell even in a lacklustre market.

For those who are still keen, there is a range of subsidised home ownership schemes available. Buyers can opt for conventional shared ownership and part buy and part rent a home offered through a registered social landlord. Alternatively, DIY shared ownership means buyers select a property to buy on the open market and a social landlord takes over the rented share.

Last year the government introduced Homebuy, a scheme that allows local authority or housing association tenants or those on waiting lists, to buy a home in the open market with an interest-free equity loan from a social landlord for 25% of the value of the property - leaving them to secure a mortgage for 75%. There are no monthly repayments on the 25% loan, that is then repayable at 25% of the market value when the home is sold.

For further details of shared ownership, contact your local authority housing department. For a £30 registration fee, the Housing Mobility and Exchange Service (Homes) will send you a list of providers, and a property bulletin with ads for shared ownership properties. Homes, tel: 020-7963-0246 or go to www.homes.org.uk.

webTitle: When the real you is desperate to get out

fields.headline: When the real you is desperate to get out
fields.standfirst:
Helping yourself: Writer Liz Stuart reads up on possible changes of career direction
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Exceptionally unhappy people sought for challenging new roles. Successful applicants will be miserable in their current employment and apprehensive about future job prospects. Feelings of inadequacy, anxiety and copious amounts of stress an advantage
fields.body:
Exceptionally unhappy people sought for challenging new roles. Successful applicants will be miserable in their current employment and apprehensive about future job prospects. Feelings of inadequacy, anxiety and copious amounts of stress an advantage. Applications to www.iloathmyjob.com/

So goes the blurb to a new book by career consultant Nick Williams. And it will strike a serious chord with those unhappy in their job and who are looking for a change.

The idea that we should all know what we want to do for the rest of our lives before the age of 20 is a myth. A recent international job satisfaction survey, conducted by the University of Warwick, revealed that British workers are among the most unhappy in the developed world. Heart attacks are most likely to happen on a Monday morning -either on the way to, or on arrival at, work.

But there is still very little help for those who find themselves floundering about the appointment section of papers. It is easy to identify that you are unhappy in your current job, but so much more difficult to identify how to make a change and which new direction to take.

Mr Williams, whose book The 12 Principles of the Work We Were Born To Do is published in September, says the need for change - in the past seen as a symptom of a mid-life crisis - is hitting people much earlier now. "I joke that the mid-life crisis is coming much sooner these days, but in reality there is so much more change in people's lives anyway. Often people in their late 20s will start to feel unhappy, and it is also very common in people about to turn 40," he says.

There is not much help available to people who find themselves in this position and there are so many choices to be made. Changers have to decide if they want a single job or a portfolio of careers, whether they wish to remain in the UK or start looking abroad, and if they would be happier being their own boss.

Most careers advice is aimed at school or college leavers, or is high-level outplacing, which is prohibitively expensive and generally unsuitable for people looking for a complete shift in lifestyle - outplacement agencies tend to find more of the same sort of job.

Other options are seeing a career consultant, who will use a combination of psychometric testing and an interview with an occupational psychologist to indicate which career would be most suitable for you, and going to a more counselling-based service or talking to your local careers service. I test-drove all three (below) and despite the steep price, would recommend full counselling.

Even if you decide to use one of the above, it would be useful to think about what makes you happy in life, and what skills you would be able to offer an employer. It is not sufficient knowing that you could do a job, you need to either prove it, or demonstrate that you are worth the risk.

Although career change is generally about emotional issues, there are practical issues to take into account. If you quit your job before finding another, you will need to have money saved, or a short-term way of making cash. This will also mean you are not paying National Insurance and pension contributions, which may have long-term implications.

Mr Williams advises that if you can ease yourself into the change, it will be less stressful. "If you are able to move to four days a week at your current job and perhaps just do one day in your new job, this will be easier. It is also more manageable financially."

James Gladwin, an outplacement professional, adds that it is not worth the expense of using a professional CV writer. "All too often the product from the professional CV writer is a bland document which is instantly recognisable as coming from a particular stable," he says.

A final piece of advice, from careers consultant Jo Ouston: the cycle of spotting a job, applying, going for interview and then being accepted or rejected will take about 10 weeks. Keep this process fluid - in other words apply for one job each week -and do not jump for the first position offered.

 Nick Williams runs day-long workshops around the country priced around £70. Details can be found at www.heartatwork.net or 0700-781 922, Careers Services National Association (directory of career offices under contract to the DfEE) www.careers-uk.com, New Ways to Work helpline 0207-226-4026.

What the experts told Liz Stuart

Career service

Cost: Free. Career recommendation: 1 Social work, 2 Youth work, 3 Careers adviser.

I arranged to see my local careers officer, based in my local library, on a Tuesday afternoon. The consultation lasted for an hour.

I was initially sceptical about the kind of service that would be offered. I had preconceptions about how appropriate the advice would be for me, a professional of five years' standing, especially when, having mentioned that I would like to work with people, the consultant suggested I tried social work. This felt like a knee-jerk reaction and the pointing to a random career on the list of "people" jobs.

But I was wrong. Omar, my consultant, really listened to me and quickly summed up my particular situation. In the end, the hour turned into more of an emotional counselling session, which was in tune with what I needed.

He recognised that I had the capabilities to identify my own strengths and weaknesses and could consequently identify the type of job which would suit me, and that I had the skills to write a CV and follow through the application process.

What I needed was reassurance that I had the right to devote the time to myself which making a change would take. He was more guru than adviser.

But he did balance this with some pragmatic assistance. He listed the general areas which were of interest to me with the promise to do some more research on specialist databases. He also studied the sample CV I had brought with me and suggested some changes.

A couple of weeks later I was surprised to receive through the post not only a letter of encouragement, but also a list of courses which would be relevant for retraining and a new version of my CV, plus a copy on floppy disk. His letter urged me to look into the courses and to contact him again when I needed more help.

Had I wanted a knowledge-economy type career, or a complete change in working patterns, I am not convinced that Omar would have had access to sufficiently detailed information to help me. Time was also limited, although a follow-up visit would have helped. I also found it a little difficult to pour out my heart in the corner of Ladbroke Grove library.

However, considering the service was free and the highly pastoral nature of the consultation, I would recommend this as a first step in finding a new career.

The careers counsellor

Cost: £1,000-plus. Career recommendation: 1 Teacher 2 Investor relations executive, 3 Communications/ PR executive.

Reading Jo Ouston's promotional literature, all "personal motivation" and "winning strategies", I felt cynical. I feared the session, at £100 a hour plus VAT, with a minimum booking of around eight hours split over two separate days, might just be expensive aura polishing.

In fact, Jo is a warm, charismatic and deeply experienced professional - had I been writing her CV I would have stressed her excellent communication skills which centre on the telling of stories. I found this approach very encouraging and aspirational. She emphasised that she teaches people the skills to identify their own path, rather than finding it for them.

Despite 20 years in the business, she clearly still finds people's employment and life choices fascinating. Very few people are motivated by money to change career, she told me, unless they are not earning enough for the basics of living or they feel their pay level is unfair in comparison with that of their peers. The service is to tally personalised and she has a number of tests and games which match the client's particular needs. With me she quickly identified that what was needed was an analysis of my core values to recognise what I would really need from a job. This entailed my telling her my life story, from which she selected key words.

These I could select as significant, or reject as not, as I pleased (of course, they were all my own words in the first place, but out of context, some of them lost their pertinence). This was then used as a basis for drawing out what is important to me, what I fear, what excites me and what fundamentals need to be in place to make me happy. The answers were not only spot on, but also they revealed aspects of myself of which I had been aware, but had not managed to articulate.

It felt much less prescriptive than the session with the occupational psychologist and left me feeling empowered to make my own choice. I also felt that the answers took into account the unique nature of an individual's personality rather than block-fitting me into a pre-set space.

Most clients would be encouraged to opt for a follow-up session when booking the initial one and this would cover how to go about entering the career field identified in the first consultation. This includes presentation training and interview technique as well as CV writing.

It is expensive. But if you were to refer yourself to Jo early in the change process, I think it would be well worth the cost to save oneself hours of indecision and the trauma that this entails.

The occupational psychologist

Cost: £395. Career recommendation: 1 Television producer, 2 War correspondent, 3 Project manager, overseas charity .

The career development programme with London-based Career Analysis costs £395 including VAT. For this, you sit three hours of psychometric tests and have a hour-long consultation with an occupational psychologist. The results of a set of questionnaires which clients are asked to complete and submit a few days before the appointment are also analysed.

On the day of my consultation, there were two others going through the process. One, a recently divorced woman who had always worked in administration for local government, wanted a complete change and was thinking about working as a therapist. The other was a City trader who wanted out, but was not sure what to. The atmosphere was relaxed and friendly and I got the impression that all the employees of CA strongly believed in the benefits of their service. I commented that the price may be a little high for some people. The response - that it was not unreasonable for the amount of professional time on a one-to-one basis it bought and that it if it steers you towards a happy career path, it is money well spent - seemed reasonable.

The tests were enjoyable. They were designed so that you do not have time to finish each section, and this was clearly explained before starting. There was also ample opportunity for question practice. In most cases I found it easy to identify a right and wrong answer, unlike the tests I had been asked to complete before the day.

These contained questions such as "Surprise is to strange as fear is to a, brave b, anxious c, terrible." I felt I had been backed into a corner in many cases as often my real answer would have been "both" or "neither" and frequently the questions were too transparent, so I knew what qualities I would be displaying if I responded in a certain way.

When I went back to Careers House for the afternoon session, I had high expectations of interesting revelations about my personality and a suitable career. I was disappointed. The psychologist asked me a few questions about what the other members of my family did and when I had been most happy over the past five years, but she very quickly went into an analysis of my test results.

She did quickly identify very specific jobs which I would have chosen myself (project manager with an organisation like VSO, television producer and trainer), but she did not listen when I raised objections as to why these would not be quite appropriate.

I also felt that she had not really thought about precisely what these jobs entail; they were simply suggestions from a list. I think a computer-based test would have spat out similar answers, only more cheaply.

For someone who really has no self-analysis tools, the day may have been useful - I spoke to the divorced woman and she said it had really pointed her in the right direction and reassured her that her ideas were workable - but for me, the day did not reveal anything which I did not already know only too well.

Details of your local careers service are in your phone book; Career Analysts, tel: 020-7935-5452; Jo Ouston & Co, tel: 020-7821-8299.

Details of your local careers service are in your phone book; Career Analysts, tel: 020-7935-5452; Jo Ouston & Co, tel: 020-7821-8299.

webTitle: Bookshops turn over a new leaf

fields.headline: Bookshops turn over a new leaf
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A few days before the launch of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the children's book buyer at the Palmers Green Bookshop in North London, Frances Crawley, was able to tell me that the fourth J.K. Rowling book would be sold at £12.99, two pounds less than the recommended price
fields.body:
A few days before the launch of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, the children's book buyer at the Palmers Green Bookshop in North London, Frances Crawley, was able to tell me that the fourth J.K. Rowling book would be sold at £12.99, two pounds less than the recommended price of £14.99. At Waterstone's Piccadilly, the biggest bookshop in Europe, the response was: "We don't know: we're waiting to hear from head office."

Independence creates flexibility and autonomy but at the same time, if you choose to go it alone, the market is tough. If the out-of-town supermarkets rang the death knell for local shops, the arrival of bookstore chains hastened closing sales for many independent booksellers.

Yet while some people pointed out that corner shops selling shrivelled lettuces and past-their-best eggs weren't really providing what modern shoppers wanted, so it went with the critics of fusty booksellers - they just hadn't moved with the times. And just as farmers markets and specialist retailers are popping up all over the place; in the book buying market - where new titles are dramatically discounted, can be ordered on the internet or hurled into your supermarket trolley - there is still room for switched-on, independent booksellers.

"People will get bored of the uniformity of seeing a Starbucks, a Pret A Manger or a Borders on every street corner and will probably choose to go back to somewhere that looks more like a bookshop and doesn't feel like a superstore," says Phil Griffiths, who set up Metropolitan Books in Exmouth Market, London, a location that he describes as "a well kept secret: a kind of dead place between Islington and the City".

Metropolitan Books opened three days before Christmas 1998 and Phil Griffiths, who learned his craft at Muswell Hill Bookshop and Islington Bookshop, is finding that a local loyalty is developing. "Even if a Books Etc were to open in Clerkenwell, I'm sure there would still be enough people who would think: 'actually, I'll still carry on supporting the independent'," he says.

Ironically, for someone who "doesn't really like the chain store approach", Metropolitan Books is slap bang next to Starbucks, and Pizza Express is on its way. An organic farmers market could be starting up and more people are moving into the area. Phil Griffiths feels confident, as "things are heading in the right direction".

The joy of running your own bookshop, he explains, is that you get to buy your own books. "In the big chains, buying is being done centrally so booksellers are effectively just unpacking and shelving books. When that happens, the fun part of the job has gone."

At Metropolitan Books, the fun part means that as a shopper, you get a good whack of Anne Tyler, Alice Munro and Raymond Carver with Stevie Wonder's Songs in the Key of Life playing in the background.

While Phil Griffiths works 10-7 every day apart from Sunday and brings his lunch into work as he can't leave the shop, he says that it's all part of a long term goal. After three years he hopes to get someone to help and will then look for a second shop, which could be in Paris, New York or Hackney.

But even the mightiest are struggling. Waterstone's - which hit the headlines when it sacked Robert Topping, the manager of its Deansgate branch in Manchester, for refusing to toe the line on stock policies -has failed to get to grips with the internet, as has WH Smith. And Amazon, possibly one of the best known internet brands, which has never made a profit, has recently seen its share value take a nosedive.

Which makes the story of Country Bookshop at Hassop Station, Bakewell, Derbyshire, all the more astounding, and proves the original point of the so-called level playing field of the internet. Geraldine Rose and Sridhar Gowda set up www.countrybookshop.co.uk and launched a website last March with 1m titles.

Everything is done in-house, from designing the website to the "fulfilment" (the selecting, wrapping and sending bit). Their team has grown from eight people this time last year to 25, including website designers, programmers, and customer service people. Nothing is outsourced and it's all integrated.

The website is plain and simple, has no advertising and offers free delivery within the UK. It came second in the DTI e-commerce awards this month and countrybookshop.co.uk was the only bookseller in the Sunday Times e-league of Europe's top 100 internet businesses, at 41. In terms of internet traffic, according to Alexa, the web navigation tool which tracks the visits of its users, countrybookshop.co.uk overtook WH Smith, Waterstone's, Alphabetstreet and Blackwells and is hot on the heels of bol.com. Their turnover has quadrupled to more than £1m in one year. How have they managed it?

"If you understand new media, you can cut costs. The web needs people who are flexible and can adapt to changes quickly," explains Sridhar Gowda. "With some of the other book shops, like Waterstones, they outsource the internet side of their business and although they are good with their bookshops, the web is new to them: they don't understand it."

"And we're lucky because around the Peak District, within one hour's drive, lives half the population of the UK," says Geraldine Rose, who explains that many of the people they have employed locally are pleased that they can do webby jobs without needing to leave the part of the country they love to move to London.

"We didn't plan it, but it's happened this way," says Mr Gowda. As for the shop in Bakewell, it's becoming a focal point in the community.

"We're trying to make the shop into a cultural and literary centre," explains Mr Gowda. The design of the website has proved so popular that now other booksellers are approaching them to ask for help with their own internet businesses, which has prompted Ms Rose and Mr Gowda to develop another arm to their business, the web design company: Inamaste.

Diversification, or specialisation, is key to keeping an independent bookselling business alive, believes Martin Grindley, president of the Booksellers Association, and owner of Browsers Books in Woodbridge, Suffolk (pictured above).

"But some people think that it's easy to run a bookshop after doing something else. They've got a bit of cash and they buy a bookshop, thinking they're only going to do it for a few years. You've got to invest."

Running a bookshop is on a par with dreams of opening a cafe, and indeed, some people do both: in Jane Green's novel Bookends, friends set up business together, and Mr Grindley has done just that in Browsers.

"You don't want the old English country house environment," he claims. "You go into bookshops and you get the impression that the booksellers don't get out much."

Philippe Starck tables and Arne Jacobsen chairs make a statement in Woodbridge, a market town which seems to have embraced Browsers, and you can eat cakes made from recipes in Mary Berry's and Joceline Dimbleby's books, after which, of course, you're tempted to buy the books. In addition to Browsers, Mr Grindley has set up www.lostforwords.com, which asks what you're into then makes helpful suggestions about what you might fancy reading.

"If you're going to be independent, be blatantly independent," he adds. "Don't try to copy the chains." He should know, as he learned the hard way, a long time ago, when Ottaker's opened in Brentwood, forcing him out of business, long before he bandied around expressions such as footfall and retail zeitgeist.

Yet however different you need to be, as a bookseller, you might still want to attract the big names to your small store. In the Palmers Green Bookshop, which opened in October last year, Frances Crawley is getting ready to dispense coloured lemonade for the Potter City in Palmers Green event.

At Waterstone's in Piccadilly, children will be able to enter a competition to win Golden Tickets to a signing by J.K. Rowling. Can a small independent ever compete with that?

"It would be nice to get J.K. Rowling in," she admits, "we're going to start thinking about whether we can approach people like that, but we've been so busy. There's an Ottaker's either side of us, but people seem pleased that they've now got a local store. Business has snowballed."

Who to call

Palmers Green Bookshop, tel 020 8882 2088

The Booksellers Association, tel 020 7834 5477

www.booksellers.org.uk

The Country Bookshop tel 01629 813444

www.countrybookshop.co.uk

Metropolitan Books, tel020 7278 6900 www.metropolitanbooks.co.uk

Browsers, tel 01702 471166;

www.lostforwords.com

fields.headline: Company vitae
fields.standfirst:
Carphone Warehouse which last week floated on the London Stock Exchange
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse which last week floated on the London Stock Exchange
fields.body:
Using a mobile in a moving motor, isn't that illegal?

Relax. It does not sell cars and it is not a warehouse. But is the biggest independent retailer of mobile phones on the high street.

When was the first call made?

Back in 1989 when Charles Dunstone set up Carphone Warehouse, flogging mobile phones through the small ads in newspapers. With £6,000 of capital, he exploited a regulatory change in the mobile phone market which unbundled the operators from the distributors. Within a year the turnover reached £2m. Since then Carphone Warehouse has become one of the great success stories of UK retailing. The company has 450 stores in Britain and a further 430 or so trading under the Phone House name throughout countries including France, Germany and the Netherlands.

Is it still a private company?

Not since Friday of last week when it floated on the London Stock Exchange. On its debut, during the day the shares jumped 19% to a high of 237.5p before falling back to its more modest current trading range of between 203p and 201p. The flotation valued the company at £1.64bn at the offer level and raised £185m to help fund expansion.

Any tips to impress its hiring squad?

Walk in with a mobile clipped to your belt and begin by praising its decision to protect the share offer from much of the volatility normally surrounding new issues with unusual rules encouraging private investors to agree to hold their shares for at least three months. The idea was to deter the opportunistic stags who had been blamed for the flop of other recent high-profile flotations such as www.lastminute.com

Other useful statistics to reiterate are sales of replacement handsets, which are expected to rise to 227m by 2003, from 22m last year, dwarfing the 83m likely to be sold to new users. And that more than half the UK population has a mobile phone and by 2005 this is predicted to be 100%.

Is there a corporate strategy, or just grab the cash and run?

Before the float it strengthened its board with two outside directors, Des Wilson, who is retiring as communications director for BAA, and John Gildersleeve, the Tesco director who heads the grocery chain's non-food operations.

Its success in Europe means that it is more confident about rolling out new outlets more aggressively. To do that it needs the financial power that the float provides. Some of the funds will be used to develop its other services including Value Telecom, which repackages One2One airtime under the Carphone brand, and Mviva, the group's wireless internet portal.

Any corporate static?

The flotation had a mixed reaction among analysts, partly because of fears that Carphone may not sustain its profit margins as it expands across Europe. Foreign mobile phone networks do not tend to subsidise handsets as heavily as happens in the UK. Also, the fact that you can buy handsets from places such as Tesco and Woolworths underlines how close they are to a commodity product. Other potential threats to its business range from the possibility that Value Telecom and Mviva will distract management's attention from running the core retail business to the threat that its reputation for impartial advice will be undermined by its salesmen pushing these two services harder for better bonuses.

Do equal opportunities get a fair hearing?

Its workforce reflects the gender and cultural diversity of its customers. However, the boardroom and senior management seems to be a men-only zone. But it does provide serious training and some 65%-70% of in-store staff are graduates.

Do the executives ring up a lot of dosh?

Charles Dunstone, the 35-year-old chairman and founder, sold shares worth £56.3m in the flotation, while David Ross, 34, chief operating officer, made £39.4m. They still own about 37.7% and 26.4% of the company respectively.

Any idea of the rewards for the wage slaves?

Average salaries of its 3,756 workers work out at £21,500, plus there is an employee share options scheme.

Who fields job applications?

Andrew Sherwood, personnel manager, North Acton Business Park, Wales Farm Road, London W3 6RS.

webTitle: Postcards from the edge of a rediscovery

fields.headline: Postcards from the edge of a rediscovery
fields.standfirst:
A growing band of collectors are following the Edwardians in seeking out classic cards and prices are rising, says Stewart Dalby
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: A growing band of collectors are following the Edwardians in seeking out classic cards and prices are rising, says Stewart Dalby
fields.body:
Social history: Lots of people collect Edwardian postcards with photographs on

Remember postcards? Does anybody still send them in the age of email? Better still, remember cigarette cards? The cards of sportsmen, soldiers, shipping, trains, and theatrical figures that used to come in cigarette packets. They seemed to have disappeared altogether as smoking has become frowned upon.

Both are popular among collectors though, and have a devoted band of followers. They remain affordable although prices have risen in the past 10 years, sometimes quite sharply, and seem set to continue to do so.

An auction last week at Phillips in London, with more than 400 lots of series, groups and individual cigarette cards and postcards, was very well attended. Prices ranged from around £50 for various sets, to hundreds of pounds.

David Stuckey, the editor and publisher of Card Times, a monthly aimed at cigarette card collectors, says: "We have about 3,000 subscribers and we are growing. They are predominantly male and, how I shall put it, usually over 40 years old. They are people with a little bit of disposable income who want to revisit the habits of their youth. Not smoking, but collecting.

"Hardly a month goes by without three or four fairs or auctions somewhere and there is a network of clubs."

Cigarette cards are the little pictures that were usually stuffed inside a pack of 10 cigarettes produced by G&O Wills, Players and others. They were a form of advertising or really a loyalty card to ensure that smokers continued with the same brand. They ran in series of 25 to 50 or sometimes a lot more.

They were popular in Edwardian times and enjoyed a golden age from the 20s to the onset of the second world war, when they were largely discontinued to help the war effort. They straggled on into the 50s but not in any great numbers. Carreras, the cigar company, produced them until a year ago.

Picture cards could also be found in boxes of Brooke Bond tea but the company has stopped the practice. So some cards have a rarity value.

Even so, you can get individual cards for £5 with sets of up to 50 for around £40 to £50 if they are in good condition. In the Phillips sale an accumulation of 90 sets contained in a small box, including a series of Gilbert & Sullivan (13), hidden beauties (10), football caricatures (6), dogs (14) and cricketers (50), was on offer for £500 to £600.

Most people in England pursue themes, according to Stuckey, but there was a splurge of American buying four years back. They collect individuals like Marilyn Monroe and the golfer Sam Sneed. Overall, Stuckey estimates, prices have tripled in the past 10 years.

Postcards also have their followers. Brian Lund, the publisher of Picture Postcard Monthly, says he sells 4,000 copies a month and reckons each copy is read by 2.6 people, giving him a readership of 10,000 collectors.

There are many more postcards around than there are cigarette cards, although prices are roughly similar, ranging from a few pounds to hundreds or, in exceptional cases, four-figure sums.

I had thought the most sought-after were the saucy seaside ones, largely because I like them myself. The most famous exponent of these cards, was Donald McGill (1875-1962). But McGill lived a long time and was very prolific. Today, his cards can be picked up for £2 or so.

The first postcards in Britain were introduced in 1871. The attraction was not the illustration - they were buff coloured - but the price. They cost a halfpenny, against the letter post which was 1p. In the days before the telephone, let alone email, they became very popular. In 1900 the Post Office lifted the restrictions on illustrations and the Edwardian period became a great age for postcard collecting. Families had albums of actresses, seaside scenes, animated countryside views and the like.

It is these Edwardian photographs that are among the most sought after. Brian Lund says at a recent auction in Warwickshire a 1906 photograph of men digging out badgers in Sussex sold for £103. He says good well-made photographs of coal mines or countryside scenes from this period can realise £200.

Also popular are art deco and art nouveau postcards. Good examples are the work of Alphonse Mucha (1860-1939) and Raphael Kirchner (1876-1917). They can fetch £100 to £200.

Occasionally a postcard can fetch a four-figure sum. A card sent from the Titantic when it stopped in Cobh (Cork) realised £14,230. But this was very much an exception. Generally the top prices are in the low hundreds but rising.

 Phillips, tel: 020-7629-6602; Card Times, tel: 01695-423470; Picture Postcard Monthly, tel: 0115-937-4079.

Brian Lund, the publisher of Picture Postcard Monthly, says he sells 4,000 copies a month and reckons each copy is read by 2.6 people, giving him a readership of 10,000 collectors. There are many more postcards around than there are cigarette cards, although prices are roughly similar, ranging from a few pounds to hundreds or, in exceptional cases, four-figure sums. I had thought the most sought-after were the saucy seaside ones, largely because I like them myself. The most famous exponent of these cards, was Donald McGill (1875-1962). But McGill lived a long time and was very prolific. Today, his cards can be picked up for £2 or so. The first postcards in Britain were introduced in 1871. The attraction was not the illustration - they were buff coloured - but the price. They cost a halfpenny, against the letter post which was 1p. In the days before the telephone, let alone email, they became very popular. In 1900 the Post Office lifted the restrictions on illustrations and the Edwardian period became a great age for postcard collecting. Families had albums of actresses, seaside scenes, animated countryside views and the like. It is these Edwardian photographs that are among the most sought after. Brian Lund says at a recent auction in Warwickshire a 1906 photograph of men digging out badgers in Sussex sold for £103. He says good well-made photographs of coal mines or countryside scenes from this period can realise £200. Also popular are art deco and art nouveau postcards. Good examples are the work of Alphonse Mucha (1860-1939) and Raphael Kirchner (1876-1917). They can fetch £100 to £200. Occasionally a postcard can fetch a four-figure sum. A card sent from the Titantic when it stopped in Cobh (Cork) realised £14,230. But this was very much an exception. Generally the top prices are in the low hundreds but rising.  Phillips, tel: 020-7629-6602; Card Times, tel: 01695-423470; Picture Postcard Monthly, tel: 0115-937-4079.

fields.headline: Bible of dreams
fields.trailText: Millennium Mysteries Coventry Cathedral Ruins ****
fields.body:
Millennium Mysteries Coventry Cathedral Ruins ****

Little angels and devils are running about. Adam and Eve are ruddy-cheeked pensioners swinging underneath a copper tree of knowledge. Cain kills Abel in a billow of smoke that curls like a red stain across the air. God, hair like Medusa, towers above everyone, his face set in a scowl of bad temper. The wooden Ark is constructed in four minutes, a minor miracle in itself, and then stocked with giraffes, mice and crocodiles, all so cleverly and simply constructed that they wouldn't be out of place in The Lion King.

In fact, there is a similar invention and verve throughout this marvellous and very contemporary version of Coventry's age-old mystery plays. The first half consists of stories from the Old Testament presented by local community groups with a moving simplicity and visual flair. This is stupendous storytelling; the familiar tales suddenly sound new minted as they are told by the community to the community. The children of Israel make their exodus from Egypt across the Red Sea and six billowing sheets of material part and then come together to engulf Pharaoh. As they do so you hear in the rhythmic stamping of feet and staves the journeys of refugees through all time and across all terrain. And you suddenly realise what this bombed-out cathedral symbolises, its jagged ruins silhouetted against the dusk.

Among the vast structures, swaths of colour and great set pieces, the tiny moments are given due attention. As the flood recedes and the umbrellas are put away, a child dressed in white suddenly appears, a sprig of greenery in her hand. It is impossible not to be moved. Curiously, the second half, The Life and Death of Jesus Christ, which is staged by the Polish street theatre group Teatr Biuro Podrozy, is a slight let-down.

The script is pedestrian and the narrative too telescoped; some scenes outstay their welcome. Although the community are doing it better than the professionals, there is plenty to marvel at here, from the Three King's mode of transport to the Holy Family's flight into Egypt via a hot air balloon. At the end, a rough wooden effigy of Jesus hangs over the altar end of the cathedral and a host of angels run around in wild excitement waving bells. As the sound rises up through the open roof your spirits soar up with it.

Until August 5. Box office: 024-7655 3055.

fields.headline: Growing old disgracefully
fields.trailText: Happy Mondays Shepherd's Bush Empire, London **
fields.body:
Happy Mondays Shepherd's Bush Empire, London **

Shaun Ryder's face should be plastered across every classroom in the country, an object lesson in the dangers of living large. His latest antics include storming offstage at Glastonbury because he couldn't see the autocue - 20 years of substance abuse having left a hole in his memory where lyrics used to be - and missing a court case due to an extended "session". Not for him a discreet interlude at the Priory; he lives every moment as if it's his last, and each time he drags himself on stage with the reunited Happy Mondays, it feels as if it might be.

The shambling assortment of wideboys and girls currently going under the Mondays name (only Ryder, unbeautiful in huge shorts, drummer Gaz Whelan and Neanderthal mascot Bez remain from the 80s originals) took a night off touring with Oasis to bring their special magic to this headliner. Ryder admits to having stitched the group back together to pay a tax bill, so no one could complain if the resultant spectacle was sloppy, incoherent and pathetic - all of which also applied to the Mondays in their prime, but Ryder is 37 now, and not so cute any more.

"Don't whip my bollocks, I've just had a big genital wart," he implored backing singer Rowetta, who flicked a riding crop at him like a mother keeping an unruly toddler in line. Adding to the chaos were the lolloping Bez, whose freestyle freakiness embodies the Mondays' ethos far less appealingly than it used to, and one Nutz, recruited from Ryder's Black Grape project to amble around. The whole thing looked, sounded and was a mess. Sometimes, as on a lurching, celebratory Kinky Afro, it was a glorious mess. Sometimes, such as the moment the company came together to terrace-chant the chorus to Hallelujah, it was the best mess since the long-ago day a gang of Manchester louts had the idea of slipping dance loops under indie guitar and invented a new sound.

Mainly, though, it was just messy. The combined forces of the titanium-lunged Rowetta and a supremely tight rhythm section kept the show rumbling in more or less linear fashion through to the last twitches of Sympathy for the Devil, but really, what a sorry sight. Saddest of all, Ryder would probably take that as a compliment.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Business rebound raises rate fears
fields.standfirst: Worries over Brown package as growth hits two-year high
fields.trailText: Evidence that the economy rebounded strongly in the second quarter of the year yesterday increased City fears that the Bank of England would raise interest rates in August.
fields.body:
Evidence that the economy rebounded strongly in the second quarter of the year yesterday increased City fears that the Bank of England would raise interest rates in August.

After an unusually weak performance in the first quarter of the year when output expanded by 0.5%, the economy recorded 0.9% growth in the three months to June, according to a preliminary estimate from the Office for National Statistics. The annual rate rose to 3.1%, its highest since the first quarter of 1998 and well above the Bank's estimates of the level of growth consistent with stable inflation.

Manufacturing posted modest growth, though at this early stage the ONS does not give an exact figure. Services expanded by a robust 1.0%.

City hawks seized on the data as evidence that interest rates have not yet reached their peak. "At some point soon, base rates are likely to have to rise to ensure that growth does slow to trend quickly," said Michael Saunders, from Citybank. "The longer that growth stays above trend, the greater the risk that capacity strains rise so much that the MPC eventually needs to slow growth below trend to keep inflation on target."

Interest rate markets seemed to agree. The December short sterling contract fell five ticks to 93.52 after the data, implying at least one more quarter point rise in borrowing costs before the end of the year.

Richard Iley from ABN-Amro noted that there was not much room for the boost in demand given by Gordon Brown's ambitious public spending plans. "In conjunction with stronger than expected retail sales data and fresh evidence of strong consumer borrowing also released this week, today's data should confirm that the much talked about slowdown in domestic demand growth is chimerical," he added.

Other analysts said much of the rebound was due to bad weather in early summer which increased energy consumption. "The underlying growth rate is rather softer than the headline numbers suggest," said Jonathan Loynes from HSBC markets. "Smoothing this effect out, the average growth rate of 0.7% per quarter in the first half of the year is broadly consisent with the cycle having peaked in the third quarter of last year."

The economy has been expanding for 32 quarters, a post-war record, according to the ONS. As a result of revisions to older data, the last three months of 1998, which had showed no growth, now shows a gain of 0.2%.

webTitle: First Direct wades into  the online banking war

fields.headline: First Direct wades into  the online banking war
fields.standfirst: The telephone bank is baiting its internet rivals with a boast that web clients can speak to staff 24 hours a day free of charge, says Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: The telephone bank is baiting its internet rivals with a boast that web clients can speak to staff 24 hours a day free of charge.
fields.body:
Competitive rates on savings and borrowings plus the back-up of an "award-winning" telephone service so you can actually talk to a real person if you need to. That's what First Direct this week claimed it would be offering as it stepped up the internet banking war with the launch of a range of online products.

The telephone bank, part of the HSBC group, is attempting to exploit dissatisfaction with some of the stand-alone internet banks, which have come under fire on occasion for poor customer service.

Its new firstdirect.com product range includes a current account paying up to 5% gross on credit balances, a savings account paying up to 6% gross, a credit card and personal loans. While the account rates are pretty good, they are not quite as high as some of the purely online offerings - but First Direct is gambling on people accepting a slightly lower rate in return for the reassurance of knowing they can speak to someone 24 hours a day, at no extra charge.

Its motto is "the online bank that customers can talk to" - a dig at rivals such as First-e, which imposes a £5 charge for transactions conducted by phone which could have been carried out over the net.

First Direct's move comes just days after a report which claimed to show that Britain's new internet banks are struggling to win the public's trust. Just 8% of men and 6% of women would choose an online bank over a high street bricks and mortar equivalent, despite all the bad press the traditional banks have received of late, according to brand consultancy Henrion, Ludlow and Schmidt.

A contributory factor has undoubtedly been the technical problems which many online banks seem to have suffered. Earlier this month Intelligent Finance (IF), the Halifax's stand-alone internet and telephone bank, was forced to postpone its launch after a glitch almost brought its systems to a halt during the trial run. IF will now go live in August.

And last month, Cahoot, Abbey National's internet bank, suffered the embarrassment of having its website out of action for several hours after a surge in demand left its systems unable to cope.

Worries about internet security were exacerbated this week when gas and electricity supplier Powergen was forced to contact more than 2,500 of its customers after their banking details were revealed on the company's site.

First Direct chief executive Alan Hughes pledged that its customers would benefit from competitive prices, "but not at the expense of the service they receive". The bank expects a large proportion of its 1m customers to use its online service.

Those who are unable to, or don't want to, use the net, and who stick with telephone-only banking, will have to make do with First Direct's existing non-online rates, which are a lot less attractive.

So just how good are the First Direct online rates? The flagship product is a current account paying up to 5% gross - 50 times the 0.1% that the big four banks pay their standard current ac count-holders. However, the interest rates are tiered, and to get 5%, you need to have £5,000 or more sitting in your account. For those with between £1 and £999 in the account, the rate is just 1%. It rises to 2% for £1,000-£2,499, and 3.5% for £2,500-£4,999.

Of the other online banks, Cahoot (www.cahoot.com) tops the rate table because it pays between 4.5% and 6.5% gross depending on how much is in the account and whether you take a cheque book. IF (www.if.com) also beats First Direct - it will be paying a flat 5% gross no matter how much is in the account.

Similarly, Smile (the Co-op Bank's online offshoot - www.smile.co.uk) and First-e (part of the French bank Banque d'Escompte - www.first-e.com) pay 4.75% and 4.88% gross respectively on all credit balances from £1. First Direct's savings account has a rate of 5% gross for balances of between £1 and £4,999, rising to 6% for £100,000-plus.

Again, most of the other online banks beat this. Egg's no-notice account pays 6% gross from £1 upwards - 6.3% if you are happy to operate it entirely over the net.

First-e will give you 6.81% gross from £1, though this includes a 0.81% introductory interest bonus which only lasts until September 30. IF's savings account will pay 5% gross on £1 to £999, then 5.65% on £1,000-£9,999, with a top rate of 6.25% for balances of £100,000 or more.

However, some of the best online rates are available from good old building soci eties. Nationwide's e-Savings account is paying a table-topping 7% gross on balances of £1 upwards, but it has to be operated in conjunction with the society's current account. Meanwhile, Newcastle building society's NewcastleNet Savings account pays between 6.6% and 7.1% gross, though minimum investment is £1,000.

First Direct's online credit card annual percentage rate is 10.9 APR, and there is a six-month introductory rate on balance transfers of 4.9 APR. Its personal loan rates range from 9.9 APR to 12.9 APR.

Egg (www.egg.com) used to be one of the banks that, as First Direct puts it, "penalise their customers for calling them", but this week it ditched the £2 charge that customers of its internet savings account and credit card had to pay if they phoned up to request something which could have been done online.

Egg originally imposed the charge to deter people from ringing up and has scrapped it after customer feedback showed that "customers value a combination of internet and telephone servicing in managing their finances".

Egg also this week became the latest player to move into online share-dealing. It has linked up with stockbroker Charles Stanley on the service, which goes live tomorrow and will charge a flat fee of £9.99 per trade.

This is one of the cheapest deals around, but there is also a £5 monthly admin fee and you have to have an Egg savings account.

Next month Egg will launch a general insurance broking service allowing people to obtain quotes for products such as home and motor cover from a panel of insurers offering "specially negotiated rates". And a mortgage broking service, where peo ple can buy home loans from rival lenders, is due to be launched in early autumn.

Meanwhile, First-e is hot on its tail - it plans to launch its own online share-dealing and mortgage broking services within the next couple of months, plus own-brand home loans before the end of the year.

webTitle: Beckham out of bounds, Milan told

fields.headline: Beckham out of bounds, Milan told
fields.trailText: Manchester United last night told Milan they are wasting their time attempting to take David Beckham to Italy.
fields.body:
Manchester United last night told Milan they are wasting their time attempting to take David Beckham to Italy.

Milan claimed yesterday that they had made a second offer for the England player, only to see it rejected.

But Peter Kenyon, who takes over from Martin Edwards as United's chief executive on August 1, said: "We have had no offer from Milan. And if we did have an offer, we would reject it immediately."

United, he added, would resist any attempt to capture their most valuable asset, who is priced at more than £30m.

Milan's vice-president Adriano Galliani said: "Milan will make a leap in quality only if one of three players arrives - David Beckham, Rivaldo or Luis Figo. We tried with Manchester again but they really don't want to give him up."

Nicolas Anelka is about to return to his first club, Paris St-Germain, in a £22m move from Real Madrid. Anelka was quoted as saying yesterday: "I'm coming back to Paris on Friday. I think things are now going to be concluded very soon."

Barcelona's presidential candidate Joan Gaspart said yesterday he aimed to sign the Arsenal pair Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit if he wins Sunday's election.

Leeds and Rangers have been confirmed as seeds by Uefa for today's Champions League third qualifying round draw.

Massimo de Santis, whose decision in Juventus's penultimate game in May caused a nationwide furore, has been suspended for four months, according to Italian reports.

The referee disallowed a late effort by Parma, and Juventus won 1-0 to earn a two-point lead. But Lazio overtook them a week later to win the title. The ban has been backdated to May, however, so De Santis can take games from the October start of the season.

webTitle: Barmby waves a red flag at the true blues

fields.headline: Barmby waves a red flag at the true blues
fields.trailText: You rather wished that Bill Shankly was still around so he could put his arm around Houllier's shoulders and explain that football is much more important than either religion or politics.
fields.body:
Gérard Houllier is excellent at bewilderment. The Liverpool manager has the gaping mouth and the wide-open eyes of a latter-day Inspector Clouseau. Had he been around a few years ago Blake Edwards, who made the Pink Panther films, would not have given Peter Sellers a second glance.

Houllier appeared to be screen-testing for the part on Wednesday when he failed to understand the implications of Nick Barmby's transfer from Everton to Anfield.

Perplexed by the line of questioning, Houllier said: "This sort of thing happens in football now but you are talking as if he has changed religion or political labels."

At this point you rather wished that Bill Shankly was still around so he could put his arm around Houllier's shoulders and explain that football is much more important than either religion or politics.

Liverpool, after all, is the city that gave us one of football's best known pieces of graffiti in the 60s. "What would you do if Jesus returned among us?" asked the wall poster. Underneath, someone scrawled: "Move St John to inside left."

Houllier, though, is a Frenchman and is still an apprentice when it comes to the peculiarities of British football. From Barmby, though, we were entitled to expect greater intelligence.

He appeared stunned by the reaction following his £6m transfer to Liverpool despite the fact that, as a former Spurs player, he should know a thing or two about club rivalries.

When asked about the hostility he would face around Liverpool a bemused-looking Barmby replied: "You are talking about football aren't you?"

The former Liverpool striker Ian Rush was wrong to describe the fee as a lot of money for someone who might not be a first-team regular. For that money, Houllier will insist that Barmby is more than a squad player.

But Rush was right when he said: "Although he doesn't live in Liverpool, he still has to work in the city. I think he has made life very difficult for himself by admitting he always wanted to play for Liverpool." Here, Barmby was a little naive.

He may well have supported Liverpool as a boy, even though yesterday's internet was full of stories that he spent his childhood in Hull wearing a Manchester United shirt. However, saying he had always wanted to play for Liverpool was like a red shirt to a true blue.

Everton had met all his pay demands, even though the first three of his four years at the club had been disappointing. After he turned round his form he thanked Everton and the vice-chairman Bill Kenwright for rescuing his career. Kenwright pleaded with Kevin Keegan to pick him for England and Keegan obliged.

Barmby even took to kissing his Everton badge every time he scored. If he couldn't find loyalty to Goodison Park when Liverpool moved in he should, at least, have discovered a little discretion.

We have become more used to former Liverpool players turning out for Everton. Peter Beardsley, Alan Harper, Kevin Sheedy and Gary Ablett come to mind. But the last Everton player to move across Stanley Park to Anfield was Dave Hickson 41 years ago. Hickson was coming towards the end of his career at the time but he took some awful hammer from both sets of supporters.

Lee Clark (Newcastle to Sunderland), Eric Cantona (Leeds to Manchester United) and Mo Johnston (a Catholic and former Celtic player who moved from Nantes to Rangers) are just some who could tell Barmby that he might be in for a tough time. And not only when it comes to derby matches.

These are worrying times to be an Everton supporter. There is talk of a move from Goodison Park. Then there is the bizarre decision to sign the remains of Paul Gascoigne.

Walter Smith, who managed Gascoigne at Rangers, really should know better. Clearly he thinks the same way as the former England manager who once picked a half-fit Gascoigne for an important international.

As my colleague David Lacey drily observed at the time, the manager had obviously concluded that half an oaf was better than no oaf at all. This week, however, Barmby looks an even bigger chump.

webTitle: The best break-up scene: High Fidelity

fields.headline: The best break-up scene: High Fidelity
fields.trailText: Chicago. Rob (John Cusack) sits in his apartment listening to The 13th Floor Elevators' You're Going To Miss Me very loudly indeed. His face is a vision of glumness. He turns to camera.
fields.body:
Chicago. Rob (John Cusack) sits in his apartment listening to The 13th Floor Elevators' You're Going To Miss Me very loudly indeed. His face is a vision of glumness. He turns to camera.

"What came first, the music or the misery? People worry about kids playing with guns or watching violent videos, as if some kind of culture of violence will take them over, but nobody worries about kids listening to thousands - literally thousands - of songs. Songs about heartbreak. Rejection. Pain, misery and loss. Did I listen to pop music because I was miserable_ or was I miserable because I listened to pop music?"

Rob's girlfriend Laura (Iben Hjejle) appears from the bedroom. Laden with bags, headed for the front door, she's obviously leaving him. He tries to catch her eye as she walks past him.

"You don't have to go this second. You can stay until whenever."

Laura turns back.

"No, we've done the hard part. Now I might as well just ..."

Rob interrupts her.

"Just stay for tonight then."

She doesn't reply.

"Laura?" Laura walks out of the door. It slams behind her.

See also: Casablanca, Gone With The Wind, Annie Hall

Don't see also: Fatal Attraction

Pointless trivia: John Cusack trained as an actor at the Piven Theatre Workshop, Illinois, run by the parents of Jeremy Piven, his co-star in Grosse Point Blank.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Glenn McGrath was at it again for Worcestershire as the Second Division leaders took control of their match against fourth-placed Essex in Chelmsford.
fields.body:
Glenn McGrath was at it again for Worcestershire as the Second Division leaders took control of their match against fourth-placed Essex in Chelmsford.

The Australian took five of the 20 wickets to fall on the second day. Worcestershire added eight to their 232 for seven and dismissed Essex for 131 before ending on 124 for seven, an overall lead of 233. Vikram Solanki made 53.

In the First Division second-placed Lancashire owed much to John Crawley (117) as they reached 299 for four at Old Trafford, replying to Durham's 370. Saurav Ganguly (65) and Mike Atherton (64) also contributed well.

Third-placed Yorkshire took a first-innings lead of 218 against Somerset in Scarborough. The hosts moved from 144 for three to 400 with David Byas (84) and Darren Lehmann (77) the mainstays. Somerset are 12 for two second time around.

 Sri Lanka's former captain Arjuna Ranatunga has announced his retirement from international cricket. The 36-year-old took part in his country's first and 100th Tests.

His successor Sanath Jayasuriya hit a sparkling 148 off 156 balls against South Africa on the first day of the first Test in Galle. With 96, he narrowly missed out on joining the Australians Victor Trumper, Charlie McCartney and Don Bradman plus Pakistan's Majid Khan as the only men to score a Test century before lunch on the first day. Sri Lanka ended on 341 for five.

fields.headline: Donald provides vintage hostility
fields.standfirst:
Warwickshire 260 & 38
Gloucestershire 254
fields.trailText:
Warwickshire 260 & 38
Gloucestershire 254
fields.body:
This could be Allan Donald's last season of county cricket. Everyone used to cite him as the fastest white bowler in the world, a match-winner for his lovingly adopted Warwickshire and, of course, South Africa. But injury and perhaps psychological weariness from the constant strain of so much cricket took its toll.

Yesterday, as if in a mid-afternoon statement of semi-valedictory venom, he produced several overs of vintage hostility. Just as Gloucestershire seemed to be composedly moving towards a first-innings lead, Donald called up a short-leg again. The wicketkeeper Keith Piper was stationed half-way back to the boundary and the ball would hurtle noisily into his gloves. Once the sheer speed took it between the startled keeper and first slip to the fence.

The surprise was that he took only one wicket. He had been bowling well enough, but not at much more than medium pace by his standards. But the large festival crowd sensed he meant business.

Matt Windows, a generous scorer on this ground, straight-drove Donald sweetly for his 14th boundary. Next ball he thrust his bat forward, edging helplessly to Piper. On his walk back, Windows was too preoccupied to acknowledge the applause for his well-made, discerning innings.

This has developed into an intriguing balance between bat and ball. Warwickshire gained a first-innings lead of just six runs in a match of nostalgic and true championship merits, devoid of modern cricket's distractions.

The fielding, too, was keen, as reflected by Trevor Penney's one-handed catch off Dominic Hewson's beefy square-cut in the second over. Tim Hancock was stumped off Ashley Giles's first ball when so near to a deserved half-century.

Among the other batsmen, Imraan Mohammed gained useful experience; Chris Taylor grew in the promise of recent months; but Mark Alleyne revealed few signs of ending his tentative, untypical spell at the ground where he has garnered runs so attractively in the past.
