fields.headline: Masterful Dravid frustrates Warne
fields.standfirst:
Hampshire 320 & 16-1
Kent 252
fields.trailText:
Hampshire 320 & 16-1
Kent 252
fields.body:
Nine quid isn't bad for a master class; Rahul Dravid batting against Shane Warne, the only cricketer of the century still playing. And it all happened in this boisterous naval town, a way station for holidaymakers hotfooting it to the Isle of Wight. But those who bought tickets to Ryde missed a blockbuster, played under perfect, blazing skies.

Warne bowled two spells from the Pavilion end. A 16-over, pre-lunch exertion of one for 49 and a mid-afternoon spell of 17 overs, one for 28. He was mesmeric and magnetic, bowling in front of his wife, Simone, his two kids and a hushed crowd.

White wristband, gold necklace, white Adam Ant sun cream stripes and a surprisingly slight figure. Twirl, turn - step, step, step, step, step, step - skip, skip - unfurl. Then it was hands on hips or a squat down on his haunches, first finger and thumb drawn to his nose in anguish.

At times he spun it two inches, sometimes two feet, sometimes it went straight on; one bounced high over Dravid's shoulder early in the day. He even tried a bouncer. But he could not faze the Indian batsman. As early as the 13th over Warne was bowling to him with just one slip.

Everything about Dravid is fluent, measured and curved, his bat like a sparkler, slowly drawing smooth shapes in the air. Dravid has claimed that he can pick Warne from the hand. It certainly looked like it. Sometimes he padded Warne away, sometimes he stepped back and cut him, sometimes he drove him, sometimes he stretched forward to muffle the spin. Sometimes he stood legs crossed, left hand on hips, resting on his bat just watching - watching his team-mates flap away at the other end. In between overs he would go down and whisper comforting words and touch gloves. But most importantly he kept the strike.

Spin appeared to pose no problems for Dravid until, that is, the arrival of Giles White (who had been thwacked on the shin by Dravid when fielding at short leg). White had taken only one wicket this season, that of Min Patel in his previous over. Dravid got a bat on one that spun back and he played on. He had made his 29th hundred in first-class cricket and his first in the county championship for Kent. The Hampshire players clapped him off the ground.

At tea the ground was flooded by children, almost all bowling leg spin. Maybe the next generation of kids who saw this innings, will want to practise wristy Dravid-style strokes in their spare time.

White wristband, gold necklace, white Adam Ant sun cream stripes and a surprisingly slight figure. Twirl, turn - step, step, step, step, step, step - skip, skip - unfurl. Then it was hands on hips or a squat down on his haunches, first finger and thumb drawn to his nose in anguish. At times he spun it two inches, sometimes two feet, sometimes it went straight on; one bounced high over Dravid's shoulder early in the day. He even tried a bouncer. But he could not faze the Indian batsman. As early as the 13th over Warne was bowling to him with just one slip. Everything about Dravid is fluent, measured and curved, his bat like a sparkler, slowly drawing smooth shapes in the air. Dravid has claimed that he can pick Warne from the hand. It certainly looked like it. Sometimes he padded Warne away, sometimes he stepped back and cut him, sometimes he drove him, sometimes he stretched forward to muffle the spin. Sometimes he stood legs crossed, left hand on hips, resting on his bat just watching - watching his team-mates flap away at the other end. In between overs he would go down and whisper comforting words and touch gloves. But most importantly he kept the strike. Spin appeared to pose no problems for Dravid until, that is, the arrival of Giles White (who had been thwacked on the shin by Dravid when fielding at short leg). White had taken only one wicket this season, that of Min Patel in his previous over. Dravid got a bat on one that spun back and he played on. He had made his 29th hundred in first-class cricket and his first in the county championship for Kent. The Hampshire players clapped him off the ground. At tea the ground was flooded by children, almost all bowling leg spin. Maybe the next generation of kids who saw this innings, will want to practise wristy Dravid-style strokes in their spare time.

fields.headline: Surrey lifted by one-man show
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 318 & 33-6
Surrey 288
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 318 & 33-6

Surrey 288
fields.body:
James Ormond did his damndest with six wickets, ditto Ian Ward, author of a worthy century, yet trying to filch the limelight from Martin Bicknell on his home patch is fast assuming Sisyphean proportions.

The parallels between the two first innings verged on the eerie. Each featured a patient hundred, a second highest score of 47, no end of accurate foot-shooting, a bruised ego for a vaunted Asian spinner and a one-man show that Robin Williams would have been proud of.

The upshot was a narrow lead for the visitors that Bicknell, with five evening wickets in 37 balls on a pitch betraying signs of sneaky bounce, has probably rendered utterly irrelevant. Given the twists and turns of this absorbing contest, though, dogmatic statements are ill-advised.

After Bicknell had polished off Leicestershire's first dig, removing Ormond to finish with seven for 72, his best championship return since 1991, the victim took centre stage and refused to budge. That said, this swarthy fast bowler will surely be the first to concede that his initial wicket, to the second legal ball of the reply, owed virtually all to a lone, half-hearted appeal from Neil Burns, whose imaginative plea for a caught-behind against Mark Butcher convinced nobody bar the umpire Neil Mallender.

With Nadeem Shahid in fluent fettle, the score rattled along until the last ball before lunch, when Shahid, having collected nine from Anil Kumble's first five deliveries of the day, contrived to pull a longish hop to midwicket. After that Ormond waxed as Surrey wantonly waned, twice breaking through in the first over of a spell, on the second occasion terminating a promising knock from Ben Hollioake with an off-break. Vince Wells's prospects of a second career as a clairvoyant are looking rosy.

Ormond's most telling blow was the one that bruised Alistair Brown's right wrist and, although he returned to guide Ward to the third hundred of his career, the impetus was lost. Kumble wound up with three wickets but will not look back on his day's labours with relish. Plundered for four an over, those snaky leg-breaks and googlies posed little threat as he consistently pitched too short or full, evidence, perhaps, of a chap in need of a sizeable breather.

Ward's five-hour stint, spiced with clean straight drives and exquisitely angled glides, ended with a tired hoist to extra-cover as the last five wickets tumbled for 22, whereupon Bicknell rumbled back with a vengeance. Plucking out the off and middle stumps of Darren Maddy and Iain Sutcliffe in his first two overs, he proceeded to elicit nicks to slip from Aftab Habib and Darren Stevens, either side of pinning the nightwatchman Burns leg-before, each wicket an elbow to the ribs of the selectors who have ignored him for so long.

webTitle: Gaffer great but England edged out

fields.headline: Gaffer great but England edged out
fields.standfirst:
West Indies steal victory as defiant Stewart posts second century of week
West Indies 195-9
England 192
West Indies win by three runs
fields.trailText: With a clip of the heels, a tightening of his facial muscles and a check of his cuffs, Alec Stewart has brushed every speck of dust from his one-day career.
fields.body:
With a clip of the heels, a tightening of his facial muscles and a check of his cuffs, Alec Stewart has brushed every speck of dust from his one-day career.

Two hundreds in a week have possessed such an orderly, spruced-up feel that had the Gaffer been spotted in Horse Guards Parade, the Queen Mother would have stopped the pageant celebrating her own century, remarked with interest upon that "smart young man" and added another salute to the 26 she had already bestowed.

Stewart's unbeaten 100 failed by three runs to stop a West Indies victory yesterday, but for that he could be completely exonerated. He received little support in pursuit of 196 for victory in an innings tainted by three run-outs and a bungled finale when England's tail-enders failed to get him on strike.

England needed six from 10 balls, with three wickets left, when Stewart reached three figures. Disastrously, he faced only one more ball. Paul Franks, briefly nonplussed over Stewart's understandable urgency for a leg bye, was run out by Mahendra Nagamootoo; Gough infuriatingly stole the strike by calling Stewart for another leg bye and then was yorked first ball; Alan Mullally swung twice when he might have pushed and fell leg before.

Chris Gayle was made man of the match, an off-spinner who held his nerve in the final over. There is a presumption that the man of the match must win the game, and it is preferable if he is involved in the shake-up, but there are times when the proviso is crass.

A few months ago, England were phasing out Stewart as a one-day player. Add his 101 against Zimbabwe at Edgbaston and he has made as many one-day hundreds since Tuesday as he had in the previous 11 years. Neither match particularly mattered, as England and Zimbabwe had already qualified for tomorrow's NatWest series final, but he does not do "irrelevant".

He started cagily, happy just to get a bat on it while Marcus Trescothick was briefly clumping the pace bowlers around in what has already become his trademark fashion. There were also a couple of early inside edges, and a reprieve from the TV umpire when a legside catch claimed by the wicketkeeper, Ridley Jacobs, proved to be a half-volley.

In such cases the fielder can sometimes be the last to know and Stewart, who has claimed a few dubious ones in his time, gestured that there were no hard feelings. There were 46 runs by the 11th over, but Reon King then took three for two in nine balls, having Trescothick and Andrew Flintoff caught at the wicket and bowling Graeme Hick first ball, England's sole contribution to a day of five drag-ons. Flintoff's hungry front-foot heave at a ball that discomfited him with extra bounce will leave England deeply uncertain as to whether he has the aptitude to bat at No3.

Graham Thorpe hesitated over a second run to Franklyn Rose at square leg, Ricardo Powell's throw beat Craig White by inches, Nasser Hussain got a bad decision and Mark Ealham unnecessarily slog-charged Rose to midwicket with 26 needed off six overs.

West Indies' 195 for nine had not looked challenging. The weather was blissful and the pitch was sedate. They suffered appalling misfortune as four of the top six deflected the ball on to their stumps.

Sherwin Campbell and Ramnaresh Sarwan contrived two of the unluckiest dismissals imaginable. Campbell stood in disbelief after playing the ball on to his elbow and back on to the stumps; Sarwan, the young Guyanan who was making his debut, suffered for his follow-through and diverted the ball off the back of his bat.

Jimmy Adams, plodding to 36 from 71 balls, deliberated upon it all with the melancholic air of a Midwest barman long hardened by life's little hardships and the propensity of his customers to drink too much and collapse around him.

By the end, though, as the captain recognised, they were no longer on a losing streak.

webTitle: Dalmiya's home searched in Indian dawn raid

fields.headline: Dalmiya's home searched in Indian dawn raid
fields.trailText: Indian income tax officials and criminal investigators yesterday launched a dramatic series of raids on more than 80 homes and offices belonging to the country's top cricketers, senior cricket officials and bookmakers.
fields.body:
Indian income tax officials and criminal investigators yesterday launched a dramatic series of raids on more than 80 homes and offices belonging to the country's top cricketers, senior cricket officials and bookmakers.

Those targeted in what amounts to an audacious direct challenge to some of the power centres of Indian cricket included the national coach Kapil Dev and the players Mohammad Azharuddin and Ajay Jadeja.

Also searched were the homes and offices of Jagmohan Dalmiya, the former president of the International Cricket Council, the game's world governing body, the sports promoter Mark Mascarenhas and the bookmaker Mukesh Gupta.

Officials later said they were hunting for evidence of involvement in match-fixing and concealment of assets. The raids began at 8.30am and carried on for 11 hours. Investigators took bank statements, "incriminating material on papers" and floppy discs. Some 100 officers struck in nine major cities including Delhi, Bombay and Hyderabad. They also visited properties belonging to the relatives of players.

The raids were carried out jointly by the income tax department and the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), India's equivalent of the FBI, which began its preliminary criminal inquiry into match-fixing last month. The raids were to continue today, officers said.

"Countrywide searches and seizures under the Income Tax Act are being carried out at business and residential premises of renowned cricketers and high-profile officials associated with cricket, along with certain bookies," said PK Sarma, the director-general of the income tax department.

"The department has sealed bank lockers and identified bank accounts," Sarma added.

Speaking from Calcutta after his home had been raided, Dalmiya denied any wrong-doing. He said the officials who visited him said they did not want to "single out anybody" but were carrying out an "all-India operation".

"They asked me 20, 30, 40 questions," he said. "I told them as many replies as I could." He added that he had already been asked "70%" of the questions, which concerned the sale of TV rights to the 1996 World Cup, on previous occasions.

Armed with search warrants, the investigators descended on Kapil Dev's house in an upmarket suburb of Delhi, as well as on properties belonging to his wife and in-laws in Bombay. In Bombay and Hyderabad two homes belonging to Azharuddin, who was on his way to London to play in a charity match, were searched.

Other players and former players whose properties were raided include the wicketkeeper Nayan Mongia, Nikhil Chopra, Navjot Sidhu and Ajay Sharma. In an indication of the scale of the investigation, the Bombay office of the Board of Cricket Control in India (BCCI) was also raided, as was the home of one of its officials, PM Rungta.

Revealing details of the operation yesterday, India's finance minister Dhananjay Kumar hinted that Mascarenhas, the president of the US-based firm WorldTel which won the TV rights to the 1996 World Cup, was involved in bookmaking. But in an interview with India's Star TV channel Mascarenhas angrily denied the charge.

"I'm amazed by this," he said. "The minister is obviously ignorant and doesn't understand what a bookmaker is and is not. We at WorldTel are cooperating with the income tax department. We have nothing to hide."

fields.headline: Kadosh
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Loses some of its focus about two-thirds of the way through, but this is a film with a very intelligent and searching gaze
fields.body:
Amos Gitai's Kadosh, or Sacred, has an unanswerably impressive address to the viewer: one of great severity and massive, formal seriousness. Set in the ultra-Orthodox Mea Shearim quarter of Jerusalem, it is part of Gitai's growing corpus of work about contemporary Israel.

Kadosh is a kind of modern Old Testament story about Meir (Yoram Hattab) an observant Jew whose ardent and loving 10-year marriage to Rivka (Yaël Abecassis) is poisoned by their childlessness. Meanwhile, Rivka's sister Malka (Meital Barda) has been forced into a loveless marriage with crude and boorish Yossef. With perfectly cold, pellucid clarity Gitai shows the arrogance and cruelty of the menfolk in this intensely religious community; they shun Rifka for her "barrenness" - despite the fact that it appears to be Meir who is at fault.

The difference between the religious and the secular world is vividly present at all times in Gitai's vision, and it is only Malka's defiant sorties into the modern parts of town to visit a lover that remind you that this story is actually happening at the end of the second millennium, and not the beginning of the first. For all the ugliness and authoritarianism of this male society, Gitai finds in it a context and an idiom for a deeply reverent evocation of married love. Kadosh loses some of its focus about two-thirds of the way through, but this is a film with a very intelligent and searching gaze.

fields.headline: High Fidelity
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw finds that Nick Hornby's tale of lovelorn blokes and their records makes the journey across the Atlantic well
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A respectful yet perceptibly upbeat account of this compelling and mawkish novel of male self-pity and self-forgiveness
fields.body:
High Fidelity without the whingeing? It's like Hamlet without the Prince! That is going to be the reaction of many Nick Hornby readers - fans and non-fans alike - to Stephen Frears' screen version of Hornby's modern classic. It is a respectful yet perceptibly upbeat account of this compelling and mawkish novel of male self-pity and self-forgiveness: retaining much of the original text but transferring the action from the gloomy Holloway Road (easily London's most Soviet boulevard) to a bright and sunlit Chicago.

John Cusack is Rob, the owner of Championship Vinyl, which is that most old- fashioned of things, a "record shop" or rather record store. It's where he and his two sad-case employees, Dick and Barry, hang out all the livelong day. Rob has recently been dumped by his girlfriend, Laura. Dick and Barry seem never to have had one. Neither wicked nor virile enough for out-and-out misogyny, the guys retreat into an avoidant world of music snobbery, attacking each others' anally retentive "top five" music lists of all-time highs and lows.

He and his colleagues are strangers to the MP3 player; not for them the illicit delights of napster.com, and even CDs are a bit too fancy and modern. Vinyl is what thirty-something Rob sells, though this doesn't mean any attachment to dance music or clubbing, subjects on which Rob and his fiercely opinionated colleagues are strangely silent. No, it means proper LPs, the shop specialising in blues, country, vintage soul and new wave (though for the film "trip-hop" is unconvincingly added to the list).

Although it is notionally set in the present, High Fidelity gestures backwards 10 or 20 years. One of the best moments is when Dick puts on Stiff Little Fingers' Suspect Device in the store and smiles knowingly when a saucer-eyed customer asks if this is something new by Green Day. (There is even a notice put up in the store appealing for "hip young gunslingers" - a reference, surely, to the legendary job advert placed by the NME in the 70s, which got a reply from youngster Julie Burchill.) All the way through the film, from the opening titles to closing credits, there is a passionate, encyclopaedic love of music, combined with a disconcerting sense that this love is a kind of autism or arrested development, a symptom of some poignant deprivation of real love.

Cusack is a very plausible Rob, hangdog, clever, alienated, mopey and dopey. Involved in this project from the outset, and credited as co-producer and co-writer, Cusack spends much of the time doing speeches direct to camera, talking to us in his lonely apartment, on the way down the stairs, out on the street and all the way up to the shopfront - speeches taken almost word for word from Hornby's book. The fidelity is a bit too high and the stuff to camera is an uneasy, self-conconscious and pedantic gimmick that Stephen Frears could well have done without, and in fact does without as the film progresses and the action complicates, causing a perceptible improvement in lightness and fluency.

The other big departure from realism is Bruce Springsteen making a hefty cameo appearance hanging out in Rob's apartment, giving him advice about life, love and music, like Woody Allen's Bogart. It is a nice touch, but the picture does not handle fantasy sequences particularly convincingly: there is a moment where Rob mentally beats up Laura's unctuous hippyish new boyfriend Ian (Tim Robbins), and the effect is somehow not as funny as it ought to have been - a diversion from the more satisfactory comedy of real life.

Where a film adaptation could ventilate the humid bachelor atmosphere of Hornby's novel is in giving opportunities for women. Iben Hjelje is a very likeable Laura, Nick's nice, accessible and down-to-to-earth girlfriend. And among his exes, Lili Taylor is funny as the neurotic and needy Sarah, and Catherine Zeta-Jones is well cast as Charlie, terrifyingly superior and sexy, yet strangely shallow in her apparent emotional and social invulnerability.

Tellingly though, they are all upstaged 100% of the time by the guys, with whose hurt and pain we are always invited to identify more strongly. That said, Jack Black is excellent as the boorish and pain-free Barry, insensitive and bull-headed to a fault, a man who will not hesitate to ignore or even evict the shop's customers if their tastes don't come up to scratch.

High Fidelity has what Nick Hornby's book has: a stylish and unusual way of making music fanhood give an unexpected glimpse into the male psyche: a getting in touch with, not the feminine side exactly, but the part of the male mind which is concerned with its own desire for emotional literacy. It is still a bit wimpy and sugary, but it's definitely entertaining, and the translation to American accelerates the tempo refreshingly.

Cusack is a very plausible Rob, hangdog, clever, alienated, mopey and dopey. Involved in this project from the outset, and credited as co-producer and co-writer, Cusack spends much of the time doing speeches direct to camera, talking to us in his lonely apartment, on the way down the stairs, out on the street and all the way up to the shopfront - speeches taken almost word for word from Hornby's book. The fidelity is a bit too high and the stuff to camera is an uneasy, self-conconscious and pedantic gimmick that Stephen Frears could well have done without, and in fact does without as the film progresses and the action complicates, causing a perceptible improvement in lightness and fluency. The other big departure from realism is Bruce Springsteen making a hefty cameo appearance hanging out in Rob's apartment, giving him advice about life, love and music, like Woody Allen's Bogart. It is a nice touch, but the picture does not handle fantasy sequences particularly convincingly: there is a moment where Rob mentally beats up Laura's unctuous hippyish new boyfriend Ian (Tim Robbins), and the effect is somehow not as funny as it ought to have been - a diversion from the more satisfactory comedy of real life. Where a film adaptation could ventilate the humid bachelor atmosphere of Hornby's novel is in giving opportunities for women. Iben Hjelje is a very likeable Laura, Nick's nice, accessible and down-to-to-earth girlfriend. And among his exes, Lili Taylor is funny as the neurotic and needy Sarah, and Catherine Zeta-Jones is well cast as Charlie, terrifyingly superior and sexy, yet strangely shallow in her apparent emotional and social invulnerability. Tellingly though, they are all upstaged 100% of the time by the guys, with whose hurt and pain we are always invited to identify more strongly. That said, Jack Black is excellent as the boorish and pain-free Barry, insensitive and bull-headed to a fault, a man who will not hesitate to ignore or even evict the shop's customers if their tastes don't come up to scratch. High Fidelity has what Nick Hornby's book has: a stylish and unusual way of making music fanhood give an unexpected glimpse into the male psyche: a getting in touch with, not the feminine side exactly, but the part of the male mind which is concerned with its own desire for emotional literacy. It is still a bit wimpy and sugary, but it's definitely entertaining, and the translation to American accelerates the tempo refreshingly.

fields.headline: Search engine
fields.trailText: With the inexorable rise of internet culture, those myths, rumours and falsities seem to spread as fast as those nasty e-viruses. So, too, does the number of sites set up to debunk them. One of the best is www.snopes.com (should that be snoops?). Split into topics such as animals, politics, sex, and radio & TV - the site gauges the accuracy and origins of tall tales, such as the Rolling Stones' Mars bar myth, Neil Armstrong's crazy moon mutterings and a categorical, once-and-for-all denial of folk law concerning gerbils or the death of Catherine the Great. A great pub conversation stopper.

With the inexorable rise of internet culture, those myths, rumours and falsities seem to spread as fast as those nasty e-viruses. So, too, does the number of sites set up to debunk them. One of the best is www.snopes.com (should that be snoops?). Split into topics such as animals, politics, sex, and radio & TV - the site gauges the accuracy and origins of tall tales, such as the Rolling Stones' Mars bar myth, Neil Armstrong's crazy moon mutterings and a categorical, once-and-for-all denial of folk law concerning gerbils or the death of Catherine the Great. A great pub conversation stopper.

Speaking of killing off pub banter, why not visit the best pub band of all time, at www.chasndave.co.uk, to get the lowdown on the Londoners' latest CDs, gigs and fan memorabilia, as well as a discography and lyric sheets with a rhyme-and-slang glossary - presumably to fathom out all the chirpy chinwag. There's even a chat-room. Worth it just to see Glasgow Rangers give it more rabbit than Sainbury's.

For more classic blasts from the past, visit www.TVparty.com, a celebration of all that's good, bad, ugly or just plain tacky on the small screen, from classic 50s, 60s and 70s shows to catchy jingles, and from forgotten theme tunes to hilarious out-takes, such as William Shatner's moody indignation at being told to be more emotional in his acting. There's also a host of "did-u-knows" such as Casey Kasem being unmasked as the voice of Shaggy in Scooby Doo. Though a tad American, the site is often hilarious, not least the excerpt involving a bad-mouthed car salesman using back-seat sex as a selling point live on TV.

For all matters of romance, check out www.e-crush.com, a new site trying to bring lovelorn secret admirers together ("345 couples matched on e-crush today," it boasts). All you do, apparently, is tell the webmaster who you fancy, and they will quiz your intended to see if it is mutual. A small-screen Cupid; a bit like that car salesman.

Seen a site worth visiting? Then write to the.editor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: The forbidden zone
fields.standfirst: Mea Shearim is the ultra-Orthodox Jewish quarter of Jerusalem - so they really didn't want someone as controversial as Amos Gitai filming there
fields.trailText: Mea Shearim is the ultra-Orthodox Jewish quarter of Jerusalem - so they really didn't want someone as controversial as Amos Gitai filming there
fields.body:
Israel, says film-maker Amos Gitai, "is a country that consumes its own history at incredible speed." There's not always time for reflection there, he says, and that's where he comes into his own as a film-maker. "I like to use the medium to pose questions, to deal with this very irritated place called Israel."

If Israel's internal and external conflicts have fuelled his film-making for nearly 13 years, Gitai has got under his country's skin sufficiently to make himself very unpopular in some quarters. Anti-militarism and sympathetic representation of Palestinians got a number of his documentaries rejected by Israeli TV and, in the 80s, he left the country for 10 years - and made films on the theme of exile.

Back in Israel since 1994, Gitai has completed a fictional trilogy on three Israeli cities. The third, Kadosh, is set in Mea Shearim, the ultra-Orthodox Jewish quarter of Jerusalem which sets itself apart from the rest of Israeli society, and where the ancient codes of eastern European Judaism still determine everyday life and ritual.

"The fascinating thing about Jerusalem," Gitai says, "is that it is a very divided city. This mosaic of communities from different origins is really the city's character. When you move from one quarter to another, you feel yourself crossing borders - whether it's between Israelis and Palestinians, or Orthodox and non-Orthodox, or Muslim and Christian. The idea was to choose one of these borders."

Mea Shearim's borders are more visible than most, with a barrier of posters dissuading tourists from entering. It has a population that maintains the traditions of the old European shtetl settlements: "You feel that the people who choose to live there are making a statement, almost to make a homage to communities that don't exist any more."

Mea Shearim wasn't entirely a no-go zone, as Gitai discovered, and he was even able to film there. "I was 'advised' not to try to film there, but we didn't have major problems. People were willing to talk."

Kadosh focuses on sexual relationships, their relation to Orthodox law and women's place in an assertively patriarchal society. It also deals with the ancient laws of the Talmud. "Its decrees are a complete scenario of what a human being should do, every hour, every day. Cinema is a modern ritual - because you move objects in space, you use texts and so on - so I wanted to have a modern ritual looking at an archaic one."

Gitai and his cast - non-religious Jews, like himself - rose to the occasion, immersing themselves in their subject. He didn't want to take a purely critical stance but to understand the pull of hard Orthodoxy. "You have to look at what is attractive to people, especially when Israel is going through an identity crisis."

Gitai's family background is not short of the contradictions he relishes in Israeli life. His mother, whose parents were socialist Jews from Odessa, studied psychoanalysis in Vienna but returned to Palestine in 1932 to be told everyone there was too healthy to need analysis, so she taught theology. Gitai followed his father, a former Bauhaus student: he trained as an architect, then began making short films in the 70s.

Gitai has filmed in Bangkok, Germany, Hawaii and the US, where he made a documentary on fame (American Mythologies, 1981). Big names who have worked with him include Bertolucci, Fuller, Saul Bellow and the Eurythmics - the unlikely subjects of his 1987 concert film, Brand New Day. His next film, Homely Girl, is based on a recent play by Arthur Miller, who told Gitai to let rip and not respect the text too much.

If Kadosh caused little stir in Israel, expectations of controversy are high over its follow-up. Kippur is a largely autobiographical account of Gitai's experience in a medical unit in the 1973 Yom Kippur war, a crucial moment in the nation's history, he believes. "It broke the crest of arrogance after the Six Day War. Maybe it's the moment when the Israelis understood the fragility of military power and had to work out other ways of relating to the region."

Gitai narrowly survived a missile hit on his helicopter. "Heroism and hatred are not present in my memory - just chaos and great fatigue."

Gitai insists he is committed to working in Hebrew: "The thing I can adhere to most in the Jewish heritage is that it's a great critical school of thought. Even the Old Testament is a very critical text."

What keeps him committed to cinema, he says, is its ability to change the world indirectly. "Didactic cinema is kind of a poison, I think - but I like to provoke questions."

 More about Kadosh

fields.headline: Lord Justice Judge's conclusions
fields.trailText: The Guardian Newspapers Ltd
fields.body:
The Guardian Newspapers Ltd

The information against the Guardian was unspecific. Without repeating all the matters set out in the information it was said that parts of the submission "may" contain extremely sensitive material. No damage assessment was referred to in the information. In the application concerning the Guardian, I have considerable doubts whether there is any sufficient evidence to justify the conclusion that there were reasonable grounds for believing that a serious arrestable offence had been committed.

Judge Stephens decided that condition (a)(ii) was fulfilled, notwithstanding the unchallenged evidence of Mr Elliott that it was "extremely unlikely that a copy of the E-mail is still on the backup tapes". From the judgeÕs comments that "such material may be recoverable by persons of appropriate expertise", he proceeded to the conclusion that there "is" special procedure material at the GuardianÕs premises. I respectfully disagree on the evidence, at most, there was the possibility that such material might be available. Ms Montgomery persuasively sought to explain how material in electronic form could be recovered. But the evidence of DS Flynn was less convincing than Ms MontgomeryÕs submission, not because he was dissembling or untruthful, but No doubt because he had very little personal knowledge of the process and the likelihood of success.

I further doubt whether the evidence being sought, that is, Shayler's email address, would have provided relevant and admissible evidence against him. Although he wrote a letter to a newspaper when interest in his activities, and his allegations, was heightened, and did so without claiming confidentiality, it has not been demonstrated that anything in that letter as printed would do more than help the general police enquiry. That would not make it relevant and admissible as evidence at Shayler's trial and there was no evidence to explain why his email address would, or should, of itself be so treated. Given the scarcity of information about Shayler's alleged offences it is also difficult to examine whether the material sought by DS Flynn was likely to be of "substantial" value to the investigation of Shayler's alleged offences. In all the circumstances I am not impressed with the proposition that ability of the Crown unequivocally to prove that Shayler actually wrote the letter published under his name in the Guardian is of substantial importance. And if it were, the point could be proved by calling a witness from the Guardian, to explain that the original was no longer available.

I must deal with the suggestion, implicit in Mr Tugendhat's argument, that prior and extensive publicity of material falling within the Official Secrets Act should lead to the conclusion that it may be repeated with impunity. Constant repetition may be a relevant consideration in civil proceedings for an injunction, but every repetition may constitute another serious offence. Nevertheless, when the judge's final exercise of discretion comes to be made, he should balance precisely what national interest, or which individual's safety was being endangered, by repetition of material already in the public domain. In short, although Shayler would not avoid conviction for criminal disclosure merely because he had constantly repeated his disclosures, repetition might make it disproportionate for the special procedure to be deployed against a newspaper which printed a letter from him in response to its own earlier publication of an article critical of him, particularly when the letter contained nothing of any fresh significance.

In my judgment the necessary access conditions were not established. No question of the exercise of the judge's discretion arose. The order should not have been made. The appeal should be allowed.

The Observer and Mr Bright

This case is more difficult.

Judge Stephens proceeded on the basis that only the relevant available offence or offences were committed by Shayler: so he ignored DS Flynn's evidence in so far as it related to possible criminal proceedings against Mr Bright and the Observer. As far as he was concerned, the application related to Shayler's activities alone.

Mr Bright's article purported to report details of his conversation with Shayler. There is a clear distinction between material which is likely to be of "substantial value" to the investigation (paragraph 2(a)(iii)) and material likely to provide "benefit" to the investigation (paragraph 2(c)(I)) and the presence on the Observer's premises of evidence likely to be relevant and admissible at Shayler's trial (paragraph 2(a)(iv)). What Shayler said to Mr Bright would be admissible against Shayler, but Mr Bright's notebooks and records of what Shayler said to him would prove nothing against Shayler. Although the information given to Mr Bright from Shayler might be extremely interesting, probably of value to the overall investigation, apart possibly from ss23 and 24 of the Criminal Justice Act any admissible evidence against Shayler arising from his discussions with Mr Bright is to be found either in Shayler's comments on his own website or in oral testimony from Mr Bright. In this context therefore he would be a potential witness against Shayler and apart from refreshing his memory from any contemporaneous notes, it is difficult to see how the records of his conversations would fall within paragraph 2(a) (iv).

So what is left? ShaylerÕs website entry suggests that on 25th February he sent the Observer a copy of the submission he had made to the Government in the previous November. Mr BrightÕs article purports to refer to the submission or letter, apparently sent to Mr Straw, the Home Secretary. From the details given in the article it is reasonable to infer that Mr Bright was either in possession of the letter, or at the very least of his own note taken directly from it when the article was written. Shayler was scathing of the article complaining, but only in a general sense, that journalists "cannot even copy accurately out of the documents I give them". Therefore notwithstanding those words, I am unable from the material as a whole to draw the further conclusion that there are reasonable grounds for believing that Shayler disclosed or sent any other document to Mr Bright or the Observer.

The slow development of the ObserverÕs claim that "relevant" records would "normally" be destroyed, and the absence of any evidence from Mr Alton or Mr Bright to the effect that he had never been or was not still in possession of the November 1999 letter, or that he had indeed destroyed all his records, entitled the judge to approach the case on the basis that there were reasonable grounds for believing that Mr Bright or Mr Alton was still in possession of this letter.

The proper analysis of the information about the letter has forced me to pause and reflect. There is no evidence from any police officer about the possible significance of the document, nor that the original was indeed sent to the Home Secretary by Shayler, nor any explanation of why ShaylerÕs original letter cannot be produced to the police. However the document must be put into context, and examined as part of the overall concern about ShaylerÕs criminality, and for the purposes of the access conditions not simply ringfenced and isolated from the rest of the case. Therefore, for different reasons to those which attracted Judge Stephens, I have concluded that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the access conditions in paragraph 2(a) are fulfilled in relation to this single document, but not in relation to any other material included in the application.

As indicated earlier in this judgment Judge Stephens rejected the suggestion that there were reasonable grounds for believing that any offence had been committed under s5. I simply note that if ShaylerÕs website entry is accurate, Mr Bright incited him to commit an offence or offences under s1 of the 1989 Act. For present purposes I doubt whether the Crown would regard Shayler as a witness of truth. He is, in any event, unlikely to return willingly to the jurisdiction, to be called to give evidence against Mr Bright. The prospect of criminal proceedings against Mr Bright or the Observer arising from ShaylerÕs decision to disclose to the Observer a copy of the letter he had sent to the government in November 1999 is theoretical. In reality, in relation to this single document, the risk of self incrimination is non existent. Finally, there is no realistic possibility that a warrant issued under s9 in relation to this single document could possibly serve to stultify the proper functioning of the press. Shayler disclosed that he had sent the letter. It was a copy of a letter he had already sent to the Secretary of State. He invoked no journalistic confidence for it, and save on an imaginary basis none could be implied. I have considered the particular public interest conditions identified in paragraph 29(c). In my view the public interest is properly served by an order limited to this single document. In effect therefore, this appeal, too, is allowed.

If I were wrong about the very limited ambit of the order which might follow in this case, I should add, by way of footnote, that, notwithstanding the considerations of paragraph (c), for the purpose of exercising discretion should have much more closely analysed the dangers of prosecution against Mr Bright for incitement, and assuming also that I am wrong about the proper construction about s9 in relation to self-incrimination, and second, and even more important in this particular case, I should have attached considerable importance to the potential danger that would have followed an order.

In the wide terms sought in the original application, I believe that an order would have had a devastating and stifling effect on the proper investigation of the Shayler story. Virtually any journalist who made contact with him, and any newspaper publishing an article based on discussions with Shayler, would be at risk of a similar application to the present. To my mind that would be an unhealthy development, quite disproportionate to any practical advantages to the prosecution process.

Finally, I should add that this judgment is concerned only with the deployment of warrants under s9 and schedule 1. Nothing said in it is intended or should be regarded as having any bearing on civil proceeding for an injunction.

Finally, there is no realistic possibility that a warrant issued under s9 in relation to this single document could possibly serve to stultify the proper functioning of the press. Shayler disclosed that he had sent the letter. It was a copy of a letter he had already sent to the Secretary of State. He invoked no journalistic confidence for it, and save on an imaginary basis none could be implied. I have considered the particular public interest conditions identified in paragraph 29(c). In my view the public interest is properly served by an order limited to this single document. In effect therefore, this appeal, too, is allowed. If I were wrong about the very limited ambit of the order which might follow in this case, I should add, by way of footnote, that, notwithstanding the considerations of paragraph (c), for the purpose of exercising discretion should have much more closely analysed the dangers of prosecution against Mr Bright for incitement, and assuming also that I am wrong about the proper construction about s9 in relation to self-incrimination, and second, and even more important in this particular case, I should have attached considerable importance to the potential danger that would have followed an order. In the wide terms sought in the original application, I believe that an order would have had a devastating and stifling effect on the proper investigation of the Shayler story. Virtually any journalist who made contact with him, and any newspaper publishing an article based on discussions with Shayler, would be at risk of a similar application to the present. To my mind that would be an unhealthy development, quite disproportionate to any practical advantages to the prosecution process. Finally, I should add that this judgment is concerned only with the deployment of warrants under s9 and schedule 1. Nothing said in it is intended or should be regarded as having any bearing on civil proceeding for an injunction.

fields.headline: Accidental millionaires sell First Tuesday
fields.standfirst:
From party to powerhouse in 21 months
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: It started as a drinks party in a Soho bar, organised by four friends intent on bringing a bit of Silicon Valley-style networking to London's nascent internet entrepreneur community.
fields.body:
It started as a drinks party in a Soho bar, organised by four friends intent on bringing a bit of Silicon Valley-style networking to London's nascent internet entrepreneur community.

This morning, just 21 months after it was founded, First Tuesday is expected to announce that its founders are selling to Yazam, an Israeli firm which specialises in finding funding for early stage internet companies. The price for the venture, whose survival in its early days depended on fivers being thrown into a bucket by the door after each cocktail party: around $50m.

Since the first Tuesday of October 1998 the informal monthly gathering has evolved into a global network hosting regular events in 85 countries that bring entrepreneurs with ideas together with venture capitalists, bankers, legal advisers and other like-minded people.

In the process it has made accidental millionaires of its four youthful founders - John Browning, Nick Denton, Adam Gold and Julie Meyer -and transformed the way through which individuals in the UK with a big dot.com idea can meet the backers capable of turning their vision into a reality.

Internet businesses such as Confetti.co.uk, Lastorders.com, Clickmango.com and AIM-listed Kazoo3D have all come about largely through First Tuesday events - which have raised around $130m in total funding capital.

Today's sale will also put an end to rumours that the First Tuesday phenomena was on the verge of going sour. There have been reports that, in common with many internet start-ups, it was suffering cash shortages and that staff had not been paid in weeks. The founders always denied there was any problem, promising that news of some hefty funding would soon be disclosed.

At first glance this looks like a fire sale. But the indicated price says otherwise - and so do those close to the deal, who insist that the combination of Yazam and First Tuesday is "the perfect fit". Yazam's backers include Charles Schwab, the online stockbroking pio neer, and Carlyle Internet Partners, the venture capital fund backed by Tim Jackson, founder of QXL.com.

First Tuesday's events across the globe will bring entrepreneurs and ideas together. Yazam, with the support of other shareholders - including Texas Pacific Group, JP Morgan, Merrill Lynch and Apax Partners - will provide the best start-ups with seed funds with which to get off the ground.

How it will fit with First Tuesday's existing sponsors, many of whom are venture capital groups, is unclear. Some, already unhappy at paying First Tuesday 2% commission on any deals struck at its events, could well refuse to work with the enlarged group if they believe it will gain unfair access to deal flow.

It will also be interesting to see how the volunteer regional representatives, who made First Tuesday popular around the world, are rewarded.

But for the next generation of Tim Jacksons - he set up QXL.com in 1997 when very few people were using the net and there were hardly any start-ups in London - it could be a very valuable service.

"First Tuesday has become a community and a popular movement," he said.

"It is not about fashionable twenty-somethings meeting at cocktail parties, rather it is a mechanism for helping entrepreneurs, financial backers and service providers to meet and do business."

fields.headline: Letsbuyit goes for cut-price flotation
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Letsbuyit.com is due for the stock market flotation it craves this morning, albeit at the third attempt and with a vastly reduced value.
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com is due for the stock market flotation it craves this morning, albeit at the third attempt and with a vastly reduced value.

The London-based online retailer originally sought to list on Frankfurt's Neuer Markt for around 1bn euro (£625m) but yesterday announced an expected valuation of about 310m euro, reflecting declining investor enthusiasm for internet retailers.

Last week Letsbuyit was hoping to issue shares at 6-7 euro each but will now place 17.8m shares at 3.50 euro, raising around 62.5m euro. It had intended to raise double that amount.

The fundraising will take Letsbuyit's cash reserves to around 77m euro, giving it 12-15 months before it needs to raise more money, a spokeswoman said.

Martin Coles, the chief executive, acknowledged that the market would be keeping a watchful eye on Letsbuyit's financial performance. "Our performance will be scrutinised and evaluated by the public, and we relish the opportunity to prove our mettle."

Letsbuyit arranges for consumers to pool their buying - and bargaining - power for goods such as TVs and personal stereos. It relies heavily on marketing to draw in customers and wants the cash to boost its firepower.

It is not expected to turn a profit until 2003. Sales are expected to rise to 734m euro by then, from 48.8m euro this year.

webTitle: Speeding Straw 'just like the rest of us'

fields.headline: Names, shames and automobiles
fields.standfirst: 'Speeding' Jack Straw is just like the rest of us, says home affairs editor Alan Travis
fields.trailText: 'Speeding' Jack Straw is just like the rest of us, says home affairs editor Alan Travis
fields.body:
They say that if you are a special branch officer driving a top-of-the-range Jaguar down an almost empty M5 at 9am on a Sunday morning then it's extremely difficult to keep the car under 70 mph, even if you do have the home secretary in the back of your wagon.

That's all well and good but every driver who has ever been done will have loudly cheered the news that Jack "zero tolerance for speeding motorists" Straw's car had been stopped by the traffic police.

Straw was on his way to attend a national policy forum in Exeter where Tony Blair was also speaking. Indeed it must be the first recorded case in history of anyone breaking the speed limit just to get to a Labour party meeting.

But it was yet another salutary reminder for the home secretary - and the rest of the cabinet for that matter after Euan Blair's drinking and William Straw's minor drug involvement - that they don't live by different rules from the rest of us.

Although nobody imagines that Jack Straw was sitting in the back seat cracking the whip Ben Hur-style shouting 'faster, faster' as his special branch driver hit 103 mph, government ministers, in their cocooned world of chauffeur-driven limousines, diary secretaries and political advisers, soon lose touch with those irritating aspects of ordinary life that drive the rest of us crazy.

But hopefully the episode will be a good reminder to Straw when he launches his next crackdown that the "criminal classes" may be staring him in the face in the mirror every morning. Some one in three adult men are said to have a criminal conviction for a non-motoring offence. There are more of us about than you think, Jack. I bet he wishes now he had gone to Exeter in the helicopter with Tony instead.

fields.headline: Lourdes nets its virtual pilgrims
fields.trailText: At last, a dot.com in which you can place a little more faith than the all too ephemeral rest: www.lourdes-france.com, the website of the celebrated Roman Catholic shrine, has been attracting more than 10,000 cyber-pilgrims a day since its relaunch last month .
fields.body:
At last, a dot.com in which you can place a little more faith than the all too ephemeral rest: www.lourdes-france.com, the website of the celebrated Roman Catholic shrine, has been attracting more than 10,000 cyber-pilgrims a day since its relaunch last month .

"It's a big, big success," Lourdes' IT manager, Philippe Leroux, said. "People can now petition for a prayer by email, see the celebrated grotto of Notre Dame on the webcam and tune in to the daily rosaries on live audio. If they're lucky, a priest will have selected their petition from the daily download and include it in his service."

More than 5m real pilgrims a year visit the small town in the foothills of the Pyrenees where, in 1858, the Virgin Mary apparently appeared 18 times in the Massabielle Grotto before Bernadette Soubirou. With 270 hotels and 13 campsites - more tourist beds than any French town except Paris - Lourdes caters to the faithful who flock there to sample its record of miracles.

Thousands suffering from afflictions as diverse as blindness and tumours claim to have recovered after a visit, although the church has classified only 66 as miracles.

To qualify, a cure must be declared "certain, definite and medically inexplicable" by a commission of 30 experts and submitted to the pilgrim's local bishop for ratification. The latest official miracle was announced last year, 12 years after a man was inexplicably cured of multiple sclerosis.

Mr Leroux said the 670-page multilingual website was not intended as a commercial exercise to drum up more business for Lourdes, but for communicating directly with pilgrimage organisers, Catholic believers, the plain curious, and "those who have no one else to turn to". It was also aimed at thwarting rogue Lourdes sites.

"Virtual pilgrimage can never be a substitute for the real thing," he said. "But it can be a help to the truly desperate. We get up to 60 requests for prayers a day, and I think people are comforted by being able to email the Virgin Mary."

fields.headline: Internet book sales treble
fields.trailText: Internet booksellers accounted for 6% of all British book purchases between February and May - a threefold growth compared with the same period last year, according to figures out yesterday.
fields.body:
Internet booksellers accounted for 6% of all British book purchases between February and May - a threefold growth compared with the same period last year, according to figures out yesterday.

Their "phenomenal" growth is said to have taken a high number of sales from small independent bookshops, although chain book stores like WH Smith and Waterstone and book clubs were also heavily hit.

The claim, by the research group Whitaker BookTrack, is based on the first results of a new survey which tracks the buying habits of a panel of 10,000 consumers.

The author of the survey, Paul Richardson, of Oxford Brookes University, said it showed the internet books market had grown enormously in a single year.

But he warned internet companies that they were endangering their own futures by using large price cuts to help sell more books.

"The market, whether for publishers or retailers, cannot be built through the success of a diminishing number of bestsellers," he wrote in the survey.

fields.headline: Viduka granted permit at last
fields.trailText: After a few heart-fluttering moments, Leeds finally learnt today that their £6m striker Mark Viduka has been granted a work permit by the department of education and employment. Viduka will now be able to play for Leeds in tomorrow's friendly match against Swedish side Lysekils.
fields.body:
After a few heart-fluttering moments, Leeds finally learnt today that their £6m striker Mark Viduka has been granted a work permit by the department of education and employment. Viduka will now be able to play for Leeds in tomorrow's friendly match against Swedish side Lysekils.

There had been some fears that Leeds would not be granted a permit for the Australian international after the DfEE asked for extra time to consider their verdict following an appeal hearing on Tuesday. Viduka had originally been denied a permit because he had failed to make the required number of international appearances in the last two years.

Leeds' application was fully supported by Soccer Australia, however, and their guarantee that the 24-year-old would have played if he had been available seems to have persuaded the DfEE. Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale said of the decision this afternoon: "We were always confident we would get the permit, and it is good to have it confirmed."

webTitle: Hillsborough policeman not guilty of manslaughter

fields.headline: Hillsborough policeman not guilty of manslaughter
fields.standfirst: More about Hillsborough
fields.trailText: A former South Yorkshire police superintendent was today cleared of killing football fans crushed to death at Hillsborough stadium in Sheffield.
fields.body:
A former South Yorkshire police superintendent was today cleared of killing football fans crushed to death at Hillsborough stadium in Sheffield.

Bernard Murray was found not guilty of two sample charges of manslaughter resulting from the disaster in April 1989, when 96 people died during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest.

The verdict on Mr Murray, 58, of Pontefract, West Yorkshire, came after 21 hours and 26 minutes of deliberations by the jury of eight men and four women at Leeds Crown Court.

A verdict has not yet been returned on former chief superintendent David Duckenfield, of Bournemouth, who faced the same charges of the manslaughter of John Anderson, 62, and James Aspinall, 18. The jury has been sent home to return to the court on Monday morning.

The case, a private prosecution brought by the Hillsborough Family Support Group, centred on the officers' failure to close a tunnel leading to pens three and four, where the victims died after exit gate C was opened to relieve pressure on the turnstiles and thousands of fans flooding into Sheffield Wednesday's ground.

The judge, Mr Justice Hooper, warned more than 50 members of the victims' families in the packed public gallery they must not react when the verdict was announced as it would be a "serious contempt of court".

The courtroom remained hushed as the foreman of the jury announced the two not guilty verdicts and the jury then retired to continue its deliberations on the charges against Mr Duckenfield. Asked by the judge if there was a realistic possibility that they would reach a majority verdict, the foreman replied: "I believe with a little more time we may."

Murray held his head in his hands after the verdict was announced. He looked stunned as he left the court with his solicitor. His counsel, Michael Harrison QC, had argued that it was the situation which had led to football supporters being caged in pens that caused the deaths, rather than the failures of the police.

The prosecution has claimed that neither of the officers had taken the, "simple and obvious steps" of diverting fans from the tunnel which led to the already overcrowded pens.

fields.headline: Passports, putters and pints
fields.trailText: WHAT'S UP DOC?
fields.body:
WHAT'S UP DOC?

Who knows where Edu gets his excuses from, but it appears that, after all the Brazilian's attempts to rebuff accusations that he tried to get into the UK on a false passport, that is exactly what he did. Not surprisingly, Arsene's Arsenal Wenger, who had hoped to have the 22-year-old in his side next season, was a little miffed by the news. Wenger has now abandoned any attempt to sign the player, and told Mr Murdoch's Sky TV thing that he felt "cheated".

"The problem was that he did not have a passport," Arsenal explained to nobody, because they already knew what he was talking about. "We were assured before he came over that he had all the necessary papers and qualifications. That was obviously not the case, and we feel we have been cheated. Happily he got caught. If he had got through then he would only have got into trouble when he next tried to leave the country, because then the problem would have been ours. It is good for us that people were doing their job well."

So hurrah for the fellows in Customs and Excise, what? Well, perhaps not, because if Edu's Brazilian club Corinthians are to be believed, they've already received payment for Edu and don't intend to give any money back. Which leaves the Gunners the victim of a £6m sting. And Edu's agent/document provider Juan Figer with a reputation slightly more tarnished than a piece of viking jewellery.

OPENING FIXTURES

Afternoon y'all, golfing sensation Tiger Woods here. I'm currently out on the old course at St Andrews competing in this year's Open, but to be perfectly frank I'm bored out of my skull... hold on, just let me drive the green on this 400-yard hole... now, what was I saying? Ah yes. It's far too easy, y'see, so I've decided to relieve the tedium between shots by reporting on how Leeds and Rangers have fared in the draw for the qualifying rounds of Big Cup. Should be a doddle.

Leeds have been drawn against TSV 1860 Munchen in the third qualifying round. It's a tough draw against opponents who came fourth in last season's Bundesliga and boast the likes of... just got to chip in from this steep-faced bunker... there we go... rejuvenated German trickster Thomas Haessler and Norway midfielder Erik Mykland in their ranks. "If you look at last year when we drew tough ties every time, it seems like we're having the same bad luck this time around," said Leeds chairman Peter... even if I say so myself, that's not a bad snaking 60-foot putt... Ridsdale.

Rangers have an easier task. If they beat Lithuanian side FBK Kaunas in the... just let me quickly knock this three-iron to within three inches of the pin... oh well, six'll do... second qualifying round, they'll play Herfolge BK of Denmark in the third. The Danes are managed by former Arsenal goalscoring machine John Jensen, who has adapted his public speaking from his playing style. "They are a better side than us given their playing staff and European experience," he droned today.

Good news for the Gers, then, but Shelbourne can forget it - they've got a tough draw against Hadjuk Split or Dunaferr SE and that's if they beat Big Cup stalwarts Rosenborg, so they're as good as out. Hey look... I've just got a hole in one. On a par five. Again. Pretty neat, huh?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"There's going to come a time when I don't have a great season. Who knows, it could be this season" - Kevin Phillips with the words every Newcastle fan wants to hear.

REFUELLING UPDATE

With a popular music career that took in such greats as Fog on the Tyne and Geordie Boys, Paul Gascoigne is the type to keep up with the latest trends in popular music. So how gutted he must have been when top Liverpool "superclub" Cream announced that they would be barring Everton's new signing for fear he might get langered.

"Being life long Everton fans, we realise the temptations that Cream could be for Gazza," Cream said in a statement that was in no way intended to get the club some free publicity at the expense of a laugh at one of the greatest men this country has ever seen (sorry, please excuse the Fiver). "With his recent off-field activities we thought it best if Gazza remained fit and at his best for the team. The only dancing we want to see from Paul is into the opposition's box!"

It may be funny for them, but the Fiver fears that Gazza could suffer if he isn't allowed to experience the latest in hot sounds, designer fruit juice and alcohol gob swill. So it's with great relief that we can bring you the news that the Café Jazbar on Liverpool's trendy Albert Dock, who already "have a lot of the footballers down here anyway" pledge to maintain their open door policy "as long as there is no discomfort or problems".

Can't think what that might mean. However, because the Jazbar are "running a business", they won't be giving out any free drinks. Unlike the G Bar, who will be glad to offer Gazza a free cocktail while he checks out the latest tunes. "It would be better if he phoned up in advance," the Fiver was informed, "but I don't think it would be a problem. My daughter loves him." Rave on!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal are planning a £7m bid for Belgium striker Emile Mpenza.

Chelsea are interested in Internazionale defender Christian Panucci. The 27-year-old Italian would prefer to move to Roma, but Gianluca Vialli has not given up hope - he will offer either Didier Deschamps or Frank Leboeuf in a £5m player-plus-cash deal.

Bradford are ready to follow up the £1.5m signing of Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee with a bid for Coventry striker John Aloisi.

Who knows where Edu gets his excuses from, but it appears that, after all the Brazilian's attempts to rebuff accusations that he tried to get into the UK on a false passport, that is exactly what he did. Wenger has now abandoned any attempt to sign the player, and told Mr Murdoch's Sky TV thing that he felt "cheated". "The problem was that he did not have a passport," Arsenal explained to nobody, because they already knew what he was talking about. "We were assured before he came over that he had all the necessary papers and qualifications. That was obviously not the case, and we feel we have been cheated. Happily he got caught. webTitle: Alan Rusbridger comment on Shayler verdict

fields.headline: 'A ringing defence of reporters' rights'
fields.standfirst:
The editor of the Guardian, Alan Rusbridger, explains why today's ruling in the Shayler case was vital for all investigative journalists
Guardian and Observer win Shayler case
fields.trailText:
Friday, 2pm: The editor of the Guardian, Alan Rusbridger, explains why today's ruling in the Shayler case was vital for all investigative journalists.
Guardian and Observer win Shayler case
fields.body:
Lord Justice Judge's ruling today will have the greatest significance for investigative journalists. It is a ringing defence of the right of reporters to investigate matters in the public interest, regardless of whether they are "inconvenient or embarrassing" to the security services or public authorities.

His judgment - read out in the court of appeal today - unequivocally rejected the sweeping terms of a police application to seize Guardian and Observer emails and documents relating to David Shayler, the former M15 agent now living in exile in France.

The order the police wanted would, he said, have had "a devastating and stifling effect on the proper investigation of the Shayler story. Virtually any journalist who made contact with him, and any newspaper publishing an article based on discussions with Shayler, would be at risk of a similar application to the present."

The judge said that journalists were entitled to investigate Mr Shayler's allegations and that the public had the right to know the facts. "Legal proceedings directed towards the seizure of the working papers of an individual journalist, or the premises of the newspaper or television programme publishing his or her reports, or the threat of such proceedings, tends to inhibit discussion."

In future the police would have to demonstrate "compelling evidence" that the public interest was served by such proceedings.

The judgment could not have come at a better time. Although the crown prosecution service has dropped charges against Tony Geraghty over his book on the security services in Northern Ireland, there are still proceedings against the former army officer alleged to have been his source. The Sunday Times is also under siege over its reporting of Northern Ireland. The proposed prevention of terrorism and RIP legislation both contain measures which could severely inhibit the free flow of information which is in the public interest.

It has been left to a judge to offer protection to legitimate journalism. Lord Justice Judge's judgment was dismissive of precedents relating to the European Convention of Human Rights - due to be incorporated in our own law from October. The freedoms it defined and defended, he said, were already "bred in the bone" of our own common law.

The route by which he arrived at the destination matters less than the destination itself. And that destination was right - and important.

webTitle: Top publicist Max Clifford takes on job of polishing Harrods owner's image

fields.headline: Mountainous task for Mohamed's man
fields.standfirst: Top publicist Max Clifford takes on job of polishing Harrods owner's image
fields.trailText: Max Clifford, Britain's most high profile PR man, is to take on his most challenging client yet in the shape of Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods. News of the potentially volatile partnership emerged after it was announced that Laurie Mayer is to leave his post as Mr Fayed's director of public affairs at Harrods at the end of the month.
fields.body:
Max Clifford, Britain's most high profile PR man, is to take on his most challenging client yet in the shape of Mohamed Al Fayed, the owner of Harrods. News of the potentially volatile partnership emerged after it was announced that Laurie Mayer is to leave his post as Mr Fayed's director of public affairs at Harrods at the end of the month.

Mr Clifford has relished representing infamous clients - the au pair Louise Woodward, the farmer Tony Martin and disgraced South African cricket captain Hansie Cronje among them - but handling convicted killers and cheats may prove easier than acting for a man who accused the Duke of Edinburgh of masterminding a secret service plot to kill his son, Dodi, and Diana, Princess of Wales, and who once described Tony Blair's cabinet as "dishonest bastards and crooks".

The relationship should be mutually productive. Mr Fayed will expect Mr Clifford's influence within the tabloid press to thaw his relations with newspapers which, the Mirror apart, have been hostile to his attempts to gain British citizenship. Mr Clifford for his part will enjoy an annual retainer of £350,000.

Libel suit
With a criminal investigation continuing into allegations that Mr Fayed paid £10,000 for advance information about the ex-Tory MP Neil Hamilton before his succesful defence of a libel suit, and a former employee claiming £3m for wrongful dismissal, there could be regular trips to court.

In addition, at least six female employees have made claims of harassment against Mr Fayed. He denied four of them and two were settled out of court.

Then there is Mr Fayed's unpredictability. He is capable of undoing the best-laid plans, as he proved in May 1999 when his application for British citizenship was rejected by Jack Straw, the home secretary. Despite Mr Mayer's attempts to keep Mr Fayed from the waiting press, he burst out of Harrods and made a string of wild allegations against Tony Blair and the government.

Mr Clifford's company, Max Clifford Associates, will take over all press and publicity duties for Mr Fayed's empire, both in Britain and abroad, where 75% of his interests lie.

There will be no written contract, meaning the deal could be terminated with immediate effect by either party. Mr Fayed is renowned for his strident manner with staff, while a friend of Mr Clifford's said: "He can be just as volatile as Al Fayed."

The move formalises the pair's working relationship. Mr Clifford provided informal advice to Mr Fayed's son Dodi on how to handle press interest in his relationship with the Princess of Wales. He also assisted Mr Mayer and his predecessor, Michael Cole, a former BBC court correspondent.

For the last six months Mr Clifford has been handling press relations for Fulham football club, bought by Mr Fayed in September 1997 for £10m.

Phil Hall, the former editor of the News of the World who recently joined Mr Clifford's company, will advise Mr Fayed on strategic media development, including internet projects and the possible acquisition of newspapers and other media outlets.

There are understood to be no specific plans to acquire a British newspaper, but titles including the Daily Express might be attractive to Mr Fayed. The Express newspapers have been the subject of much speculation while parent company United News and Media is in merger talks.

Mr Clifford said he was looking forward to working with Mr Fayed: "I've known Mohamed for a long time and I have been working with him very succesfully for the last few months with Fulham.

"I am looking forward to the challenge ahead ... and what a challenge it is. It won't be boring. Mohamed's his own man but I'm very very happy to be working for him."

Day to day press inquiries at Mr Fayed's Harrods office will be handled by Alexander Hitchen, who resigned as deputy picture editor at the News of the World on Tuesday and will start work on Monday, his 28th birthday. "I'm delighted. It should be brilliant, terrific," he said.

Mr Hitchen, whose official title will be press secretary to Mr Fayed, will work under the supervision of both Mr Hall and Mr Clifford. Despite his youth, he has the right pedigree. His father was Brian Hitchen, former editor of the Daily Star and the Sunday Express, who was a confidant of Mr Fayed's and acted as an intermediary between him and the former prime minister John Major in the period leading up to the launch of the cash for questions inquiry.

Mr Mayer, a former BBC newsreader, had occupied his post since 1998 overseeing some of Mr Fayed's stormiest encounters with the British media.

Commenting on a period that saw his boss succesfully defend a libel action brought by the disgraced former MP Neil Hamilton and Harrods stripped of its royal warrant as a result of Mr Fayed's outburst against Prince Philip, Mr Mayer said: "Working for Mohamed for the past couple of years has been both fascinating and a tremendous personal challenge."

In a statement issued by his office, Mr Mayer, who is on holiday, said he was resigning to pursue writing and media interests. But a source close to Mr Fayed indicated he had been removed from his post for failing to provide enough positive coverage for his colourful employer.

Mr Fayed, temporarily without a spokesman, was unavailable for comment.

In store: more trials and tribulations?

From Monday Max Clifford will be responsible for portraying the exploits of Mohamed Al Fayed in a positive light. It should be a challenge:

In 1995 a Harrods safety deposit box belonging to Tiny Rowland, Mr Fayed's rival bidder for the House of Fraser chain, was broken into by a locksmith hired by Mr Fayed and his head of security. Mr Rowland said emeralds, a cigarette case and documents had been stolen. In March this year Mr Fayed admitted liability and undertook to pay Mr Rowland's widow Josephine £1.4m in costs and damages.

In May 1999 Mr Fayed was refused British citizenship shortly after terminating Kevin Keegan's contract as manager of Fulham, the football team he owns, so that he could become England coach. Mr Fayed said: "I have made the sacrifice for the glory of England. The politicians can go to hell. I thought Tony Blair was going to change the system. They are all dishonest bastards and crooks. All their cupboards are full of skeletons."

During the libel trial brought by the disgraced former Tory MP Neil Hamilton in December 1999, Mr Fayed was described as "the biggest crook in this bloody town", and "the Ali Baba of deceit". He responded by accusing the Duke of Edinburgh of plotting to kill Diana, Princess of Wales, and said that Mr Hamilton would "sell his mother for money".

In January Harrods lost three of its four royal warrants, including one bestowed by the Duke of Edinburgh. In response Mr Fayed barred him from shopping at the store. Other members of the royal family were still welcome, he added. A week later a former employee, Gerhard Janetzky, issued Mr Fayed with a writ demanding up to £3m in a wrongful dismissal suit.

In March Trevor Rees-Jones, the only survivor of the crash that killed Diana and Dodi, accused Mr Fayed of being a fantasist and blamed Dodi's arrogance for the accident. Mr Fayed's response was typically measured: "He is talking rubbish."

Last week 40 of Harrods' Knightsbridge neighbours met at Chelsea town hall to register their objection to Mr Fayed's plans to install a helipad on the roof of the store. They said: "If Mohamed Al Fayed can do this, so can anyone and we could have helipads everywhere." In one of his last pronouncements, Mr Mayer said that the helicopter Mr Fayed had in mind was "extremely quiet".

fields.headline: Reiss womenswear
fields.trailText: Reiss has been giving style-conscious guys aspirational looks at affordable prices since the early 70s. Founded by Yorshireman David Reiss, the company emerged in the 80s and swiped the Menswear/FHM retailer of the year award in 1997. But prepare for kitten heels clicking across your territory, boys - Reiss Womenswear launches this autumn, and looks set to give high street OAPs such as Karen Millen and Oasis a fright.
fields.body:
Reiss has been giving style-conscious guys aspirational looks at affordable prices since the early 70s. Founded by Yorshireman David Reiss, the company emerged in the 80s and swiped the Menswear/FHM retailer of the year award in 1997. But prepare for kitten heels clicking across your territory, boys - Reiss Womenswear launches this autumn, and looks set to give high street OAPs such as Karen Millen and Oasis a fright.

If you don't drool like a bloodhound when you see the chocolate brown leather trench coat, knee-length tan leather wrap skirt, blue side-tie blouson top or the lusher-than-Liz's-best-effort backless "Hollywood" dress, you must have had your style surgically extracted.

Jumpers and skirts come in luxurious plaid mohair, while fluid jersey wrap dresses will flatter "curvies" and "stickies" alike. Accessories are just as desirable; mustard suede handbags, argyle-knit bags and cord trilbies.

A new flagship store opens in London this September in Market Place, W1, in the area north of Oxford Street termed NoHo. Whereas before we'd bide our time doing "nice bum counts" while he sifted through rails of stylish clothing, now we too can grab an armful and head to the fitting rooms. On second thoughts ...
