fields.headline: Most everywhere:  colour therapy make-up
fields.trailText: Time was choosing make-up was no more complicated than picking a colour you liked and ensuring it didn't make you look like you were sickening for something. But no longer.
fields.body:
Time was choosing make-up was no more complicated than picking a colour you liked and ensuring it didn't make you look like you were sickening for something. But no longer.

These days your lippy and eyeliner should do nothing short of promoting a higher state of consciousness. US-based Tony&Tina founded their cosmetics range on the principles of colour therapy and vibrational remedies. Products include seven nail polishes that correspond to the colours of the chakras and face-glitter that "sends a message to the universe that you want to attract positive light and love". And you thought it was just for making your eyelids sparkly. Now the message is going mainstream: Craig Hamilton-Parker, a leading medium and psychic, helped develop Superdrug's new Kolor range. He maintains that the shades of our auras reflect our moods - and we can change the latter by adding a bit of colour to our lives: "You can use colour to try to compensate for what you're missing," he says. If you're in need of a confidence boost, for example, "Try a good, strong red. Red is the base colour. It's go-getting, sexy, powerful." And if you think a new blusher isn't going to change your life, think again: "Even little, subtle things can help. The choice of a colour is a conscious decision, and a spiritual one as well."

If all this sounds a little too New Age for you, you can still enjoy the quite-sensible-really aspects of therapeutic make-up. Tony&Tina cosmetics also contain all manner of aromatherapy oils, including St John's "herbal Prozac" Wort in the Mood Balance Lipstick and soothing chamomile for the Colour Frequency Eye Shadow. Colour me happy.

fields.bodyText: Time was choosing make-up was no more complicated than picking a colour you liked and ensuring it didn't make you look like you were sickening for something. But no longer. These days your lippy and eyeliner should do nothing short of promoting a higher state of consciousness. US-based Tony&Tina founded their cosmetics range on the principles of colour therapy and vibrational remedies. Products include seven nail polishes that correspond to the colours of the chakras and face-glitter that "sends a message to the universe that you want to attract positive light and love". And you thought it was just for making your eyelids sparkly. Now the message is going mainstream: Craig Hamilton-Parker, a leading medium and psychic, helped develop Superdrug's new Kolor range. He maintains that the shades of our auras reflect our moods - and we can change the latter by adding a bit of colour to our lives: "You can use colour to try to compensate for what you're missing," he says. If you're in need of a confidence boost, for example, "Try a good, strong red. Red is the base colour. It's go-getting, sexy, powerful." And if you think a new blusher isn't going to change your life, think again: "Even little, subtle things can help. The choice of a colour is a conscious decision, and a spiritual one as well." If all this sounds a little too New Age for you, you can still enjoy the quite-sensible-really aspects of therapeutic make-up. fields.headline: Rio bravo
fields.standfirst: Gisele's curves on the catwalk, bikinis that bare all, and cutting-edge design - Brazil is now the most fashionable place on the planet.  Alex Bellos  reports
fields.trailText: Gisele's curves on the catwalk, bikinis that bare all, and cutting-edge design - Brazil is now the most fashionable place on the planet. Alex Bellos reports.
fields.body:
Luciana Morad was changing into a mango bikini backstage at Rio fashion week a few days ago when she explained why Brazil is currently the darling of the fashion world. "Gisele was part of it, but it started before that," said Brazil's second most famous model of the first. "Brazil is full of natural resources. It has racial types from everywhere. And we are the people of the 'jeitinho ' - the crafty little way of getting what we want."

It is not just the attentions of priapic rock dinosaurs that are being held by Latin America's largest country. "The whole world is in love with Brazil," declared Vogue recently, "The sand may be golden but the mood is red hot." Brazil is enjoying its moment of fashion glory. It's not just Gisele and fellow full-bodied Amazons colonising the northern hemisphere's catwalks and magazine racks. It is the musicians and designers, and the fabrics and jewellery, and - of course - the romantic image of a vast, passionate, laid-back, multicultural and sexually charged nation finally achieving its potential.

"I think that after all the minimalism that there was in the 90s, people want colour. People want what Brazil has got," says the designer Fause Haten. "It's a happiness. Everything that people understand about us is linked to happiness - football, carnival, samba, beaches. Our women exude healthiness. Brazil is starting to be a focus. It is starting to be a style. People come here and they find that there is already a fashion scene. It's young, the shows haven't yet been going a decade, but it's strong."

The current Brazilian boom has been helped by the crash of their currency 18 months ago, when its value dropped by about half against the dollar. This made exports much cheaper. "There is a real 'thing' for Brazil at the moment. Brazil is very creative, and this is a great opportunity for us," says model-turned-swimwear designer Patricia Viera. For the past six months Viera's bikinis have been on sale in Browns in London's South Molton Street, where they have been snapped up by some of the world's most glamorous women. At her showroom two blocks from the beach, Viera holds up a bikini consisting of three tiny pink tie-dye triangles. "This was made for Elizabeth Hurley," she says. "Elizabeth wears my clothes all the time."

Rio and São Paulo, Brazil's two pivotal metropolises, are the opposite sides of the Brazil fashion scene. São Paulo is urban, more temperate, richer and more dynamic. Its fashion week, a fornight ago, attracted international coverage. Some of its designers already show in the established fashion circuit: Alexandre Herchcovitch in London and Fause Haten in New York. Both Herchcovitch and Haten produce edgier, more cutting-edge clothes than the kind of beach-bunny fashion usually associated with Brazil.

Rio is more provincial, although attracting increasing amounts of attention: this week, for the first time, the fashion director of Barneys New York flew down to Rio to see the shows, sending a strong message that upmarket retailers are ready to take Brazil seriously. "She was amazed. No one realises that there is a proper fashion industry in Brazil. There is such a lot of potential here," says fashion consultant Robert Forrest.

Other Brazilian designers may be moving on, but at Rio fashion week, swimwear still dominates with designers intent on exploring all the different ways of wearing as little as possible. Lenny Niemeyer - whose show received a standing ovation - explored a common theme among Brazilian desgners: using unconventional primary materials discovered from around the country. One line of bikinis was made of hundreds of tiny tropical shells. One used alligator skin. Another was made from fibres taken from a palm tree in the Amazon. "I use a lot of craftwork and prints. They all export fabulously," she said.

Tatiana de Camargo Nigri, 25, makes bikinis using a new process of heat-pressing crocheted leather inspired by basketmaking and sells to New York and London stores. "Brazil is going through a process of discovery. Our fashion is much more professional than it used to be. It is much more sophisticated. It really is a thing of the first world now."

The best known natural resource in Brazil, however, is its models. Gisele Bündchen, Vogue's model of the year last year, has led the way. Rio's models are known for their bikini-friendly physiques, and a different, more sassy way of walking - some say learned from walking along the beach. Flavour of the day is 16-year-old Raica, who has already been signed up by Christian Dior. Like Gisele, she is accompanied everywhere by her pet dog, a Japanese miniature. "I think Gisele opened the door for us," she said. "But there are lots of us and we are all different."

But they are not that different. The Brazil that you see at Rio's fashion week reflects the country only myopically. Brazil has the largest number of black people of any country outside Africa, and yet in the shows I saw there was only one mixed-race model among dozens of blondes and brunettes.

Rio's newfound chic, however, has not superseded its tropical characteristics - such as a less than rigorous approach to punctuality and organisation. From the timing of the shows to export schedules, Brazilians obey their own rules. The very thing which makes Brazil attractive could also be its undoing.

webTitle: A land of sun and hospitality

fields.headline: A land of sun and hospitality
fields.standfirst: This week and next we will be carrying reports from the Dragon School's cricket tour to Barbados. Find out how the First XI and the Under-12s get on by reading regular updates from James Schneider, captain of cricket, on wisden.com
fields.trailText: Days 6 and 7
fields.body:
Days 6 and 7

It's the weekend and we have no cricket. I spend Saturday in the pool of the Coral Reef Club, where my parents and Timothy are staying, and give myself sunburn and heatstroke. This gives me time on the Sunday for reflection on the first week.

Firstly, it really is hot and humid without relief. This makes it difficult to maintain concentration in the field and our fast bowlers can only be used in two- or three-over spells. Everyone, especially the masters running the first XI - RAK and John Carroll (JC) - is mindful of the twin perils of sun and dehydration. You simply have to remember to drink water whether you want to or not. Batsmen can fade suddenly and a fielder has once lost the ball in the sun's glare. From now on, I think we will use two keepers in each match, as it seems a bit much for just one player to endure. Luckily, we have two good ones, Baggy and Bertie.

Secondly, when cricket was invented, either the weather in England was much better (so much for the Greenhouse Effect) or the inventors were masochists. It is hard to warm to the thought of playing cricket in England's cold and soggy fields come next April, May, June, July.... More seriously, the weather in several other Test-playing countries is such that outdoor cricket year-round is possible. We are learning that sunshine is the best coach, giving uninterrupted opportunity to play and keeping muscles warm and relaxed. This week, we have seen two of our team-mates, Archie and Shazi, score career-bests.

Thirdly, club-level colt cricket is less well-developed in Barbados than in England. But it is catching up very quickly with many great players putting something back into the game. We have already seen a number of excellent batsmen, with superb natural strokes. Matchwinning bowlers are rarer at our age and so not having seen one yet means little, although we are all surprised and relieved not to be facing a barrage of pace bowling. Also surprising is the number of young players producing high-quality spin bowling and there are some names already on my list to be avoided in the future! In a few years' time, we will see most club first XIs comprised of colts who have come through the system, like my club Brondesbury in London. If you think we've had trouble against the Windies in the past, just wait for the future.

Fourthly, despite the pessimists who blame American television for the waning interest in cricket here, the fact is that the game is everywhere: played in parks and on beaches, discussed passionately, remembered in the names of roads, roundabouts and public buildings. People seem interested in our tour, and the island is crammed with English schoolboys meeting local clubs and schools. It's great that our societies are sufficiently affluent to permit young players to meet here, in a beautiful nation that loves its cricket.

Fifthly, the hospitality is amazing. I have particularly enjoyed meeting the players on the other side. Our parents have chatted and taken tea (and sometimes Bajan tea, spelt "Banks Beer") with their parents and all the younger children on the tour have played with the young local children at all the matches. Match lunches are abundant with tasty fodder such as grilled flying fish and sweet local tomatoes and plums.

On Sunday night, Barbados played Costa Rica in a football World Cup qualifier. Most of the group went to the match. Costa Rica scored first, Barbados levelled it and then scored the winner with a minute or so left. A large number of Brits were present, waving large flags and generally making a lot of entirely innocent noise. I like to think that we showed them how to be real football supporters, pace Mr Straw.

webTitle: Farmer claims compensation over Sarah search

fields.headline: Farmer claims compensation over Sarah search
fields.trailText: The farmer who has lodged a £10,000 compensation claim for damage caused to his cornfield in the search for  murdered eight-year-old Sarah Payne today said his actions were "entirely proper".
fields.body:
The farmer who has lodged a £10,000 compensation claim for damage caused to his cornfield in the search for murdered eight-year-old Sarah Payne today said his actions were "entirely proper".

While a police source who has visited the Payne family said they had reacted with "disbelief" to the claim, farmer Paul Langmead said that the cost of the damage could not be ignored.

The damage occurred in the cornfields adjacent to Kingston Lane near East Preston, West Sussex, where Sarah disappeared after playing there with her brothers Lee, 13, Luke 11, and six-year-old sister Charlotte.

Police have estimated that damage across approximately three acres of the fields was caused by the extensive searches but they are still awaiting clarification.

This afternoon a middle-aged woman who refused to give her name issued a written statement at the Littlehampton farm run by Mr Langmead in which he pledged to donate any money received to the Sarah Payne fund.

"I am very upset that someone with Sussex police has seen fit to publicise the fact that I notified the police of damage to crops on my farm in the course of the search for Sarah Payne," Mr Langmead said. "I and my farm staff have been deeply distressed by the tragic disappearance and murder of Sarah.

"However we cannot afford to ignore the fact that, through no fault of the police, many thousands of pounds of damage has been done to our crops during the course of searches for Sarah.

"It was entirely proper that the police should have been notified properly that a quantified claim was submitted in due course so that they or their insurers can make their own assessment of the damage."

Mr Langmead said he and his staff would continue to help police with their inquiries. He also passed on his condolences to the Payne family, including Sarah's grandparents Terry and Lesley Payne who live just 150 yards from the field. He hoped the police would soon find Sarah's killer.

A police spokesman said: "Sussex Police have received a claim for compensation and we have asked for clarification.

"It is part of the normal procedure during any investigation where there inevitably at some stage will be damage caused that a claim will be made and financial matters sorted at a later date."

webTitle: World leaders will today promise to help the poor. Empty words again?

fields.headline: World leaders will today promise to help the poor. Empty words again?
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The leaders of the world's seven richest nations plus Russia will today sit down at the start of their annual summit. The so-called Group of Eight will meet in a new conference centre called Bankoku Shinryo ("bridge across the world"), purpose built on a palm-fringed bay on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa.
fields.byline: Mark Atkinson in Okinawa and Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
The leaders of the world's seven richest nations plus Russia will today sit down at the start of their annual summit. The so-called Group of Eight will meet in a new conference centre called Bankoku Shinryo ("bridge across the world"), purpose built on a palm-fringed bay on the southern Japanese island of Okinawa.

About 22,000 officers and eight destroyers will ensure their safety. A thousand artists and musicians will perform for them on a floating stage on the shoreline tonight.

The eight leaders will assemble around the summit table today to discuss the question of third world debt. Mr Blair, under increasing pressure to deliver, will lead the session and urge his fellow world leaders to move speedily towards cancelling debt outright for many of the poorest nations.

"The prime minister will tell them, 'Let's make that a reality'," a Downing Street spokesman said.

Mr Blair is expected to set out an accelerated timetable for debt relief, with a commitment to push the deal through by the end of the year. The British government's position is that the more debt is written off, the more able developing countries in Africa and elsewhere will be to cope with such devastating problems as Aids, illiteracy and environmental degradation.

At the last G8 summit in Cologne in June last year, he made a strikingly similar declaration.

"We can't tolerate a situation where some countries spend 10% of their income on health and education and 60% on servicing debt," he said.

At the end of the Cologne summit Mr Blair declared a breakthrough: "I believe this summit will mark probably the biggest step forward in debt that we have seen for many years."

He was echoed by Bill Clinton who said an "historic step" had been taken towards helping the world's poorest nations "achieve sustained growth and independence".

Under the deal agreed in Cologne the G7 rich countries - Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the US - pledged to push through "faster, deeper and broader" debt relief, with a target of cutting the overall amounts owed by 41 poor countries by more than half.

Between them, they agreed, they would write off an extra $45bn of debts as soon as possible.

A year later, none of that debt relief has been delivered. None of the earmarked poor nations have had their debt cancelled. Only nine have had small reductions in their debt service.

The US has failed to stump up with cash to pay for its share of debt relief because President Clinton has been unable to get his request for funds through Congress- and the European Union and Japan have used the US failure as an excuse for delaying their own contributions. In fact Japan has spent more on hosting its fellow world leaders this weekend - $750m (£500m), the most ever spent on a G8 summit - than it has contributed so far to the cause of cancelling the debts of the world's poorest countries.

The outcome is that poor countries continue to be drained of scarce resources. Christian Aid calculates that poor countries are paying their wealthy lenders $21.9bn every year at a rate of about $60m a day. At least three quarters of this, the charity says, is servicing debts that can never be repaid.

The impact is felt most keenly in Africa, where Kofi Annan, general secretary of the United Nations, has estimated 40% of all government income is now servicing a total debt of some $350bn.

Mr Annan this week wrote to the G8 leaders pleading for action on a debt burden that was "to the detriment of health, education and other es sential services" of all countries struggling against debt.

At today's summit talks, Mr Blair will attempt to wrestle the programme back on track. No one questions the prime minister's determination - Britain has rallied efforts to tackle the problem and in the past year is the only G7 country unilaterally to have written off debt.

Ann Pettifor of Jubilee 2000, the global coalition of charities campaigning for debt relief, said: "After a year of failure we don't want new promises that are not going to be kept and token measures presented as major development."

"Six months ago the British government was at the forefront of efforts to drop third world debt, but now Tony Blair seems to have lost the initiative," says Daleep Mukarji, the director of Christian Aid.

Olusegun Obasanjo, the president of Nigeria which has a total debt of $30bn, spoke for many indebted African countries yesterday when he said that without help they were powerless to break out of cycles of poverty and disease.

And he issued a challenge to the eight men sitting around today's summit table: "It is no longer a question of what we should do. We all know what we should do.

"The question is do we have the political will? Do we have the moral ability?"

Broken pledges

The 1999 pledges

 $100bn in debt write-offs for the world's poorest countries

 25 countries to begin debt relief process by end of 2000

 G7 countries to cancel 100% of debts owed to them

 Major economies to build a $2.25bn fund to cover debts owed to World Bank and International Monetary Fund

12 months on

 G7 has offered just $10bn in debt write-offs, all under older debt agreements

 No G7 country apart from Britain has delivered 100% debt relief

 US promised $600m for the fund to cover World Bank and IMF's share of debt relief. So far it has delivered nothing

 World Bank/IMF trust fund is in danger of running out of money by the end of the year

SOURCE: JUBILEE 2000

At least three quarters of this, the charity says, is servicing debts that can never be repaid. The impact is felt most keenly in Africa, where Kofi Annan, general secretary of the United Nations, has estimated 40% of all government income is now servicing a total debt of some $350bn. Mr Annan this week wrote to the G8 leaders pleading for action on a debt burden that was "to the detriment of health, education and other es sential services" of all countries struggling against debt. At today's summit talks, Mr Blair will attempt to wrestle the programme back on track. No one questions the prime minister's determination - Britain has rallied efforts to tackle the problem and in the past year is the only G7 country unilaterally to have written off debt. Ann Pettifor of Jubilee 2000, the global coalition of charities campaigning for debt relief, said: "After a year of failure we don't want new promises that are not going to be kept and token measures presented as major development." "Six months ago the British government was at the forefront of efforts to drop third world debt, but now Tony Blair seems to have lost the initiative," says Daleep Mukarji, the director of Christian Aid. Olusegun Obasanjo, the president of Nigeria which has a total debt of $30bn, spoke for many indebted African countries yesterday when he said that without help they were powerless to break out of cycles of poverty and disease. And he issued a challenge to the eight men sitting around today's summit table: "It is no longer a question of what we should do. We all know what we should do. "The question is do we have the political will? Do we have the moral ability?" Broken pledges The 1999 pledges  $100bn in debt write-offs for the world's poorest countries  25 countries to begin debt relief process by end of 2000  G7 countries to cancel 100% of debts owed to them  Major economies to build a $2.25bn fund to cover debts owed to World Bank and International Monetary Fund 12 months on  G7 has offered just $10bn in debt write-offs, all under older debt agreements  No G7 country apart from Britain has delivered 100% debt relief  US promised $600m for the fund to cover World Bank and IMF's share of debt relief. So far it has delivered nothing  World Bank/IMF trust fund is in danger of running out of money by the end of the year SOURCE: JUBILEE 2000

fields.standfirst: First there was Bridget. Then came Jemima, Venetia, Tiffany, Jacqueline, Honeymoon, and now Clara. Bridget said 'Ohmigod'. Honeymoon says 'Oh My God'. Jemima? 'Oh my God, oh my  God, oh my God'. But how much do the torrent of angst-ridden novels seeking to emulate the success of Helen Fielding really  have in common? To help plan your beach reading this summer,  Emma Brockes has produced this definitive guide to the genre

fields.body:
THE PLOT

Bridget Jones by Helen Fielding: the diary of a single woman negotiating the sometimes complex, often hilarious path between nine stone and nine stone four, by 'one of the funniest writers in Britain'.

My Life on a Plate by India Knight: a 'wickedly funny and painfully honest' account of a married woman's search for happiness in the face of an unresponsive husband and cellulite.

Honeymoon by Amy Jenkins: should Honey marry dependable Ed? Or run off with romantic Alex? A journey through the minutiae of her thought processes, which is both 'powerful and funny'.

Does My Bum Look Big in This? by Arabella Weir: the 'very funny and unexpectedly touching' diary of a woman who worries about her weight whilst juggling the attentions of Attractive Andy, Perfect Peter and Keen John.

The Trials of Tiffany Trott by Isabel Wolff: 'Tiffany Trott is attractive, eligible and sparky - so why is she a complete failure with men?' A 'light hearted yet honest' diary about the nightmares of dieting, dating and thinking in italics.

Hens Dancing by Raffaella Barker: the 'modern, witty' diary of a divorcee negotiating a course between her children, her chickens and the brooding handyman doing up her bathroom.

Jemima J by Jane Green: a 'brilliantly funny, honest' peek into the life of Jemima Jones, seven stone overweight, in love with her colleague and under persecution from her THIN BITCH FLATMATES.

THE OPENING LINE

Bridget Jones: 'Noon. London: my flat. Ugh.'

My Life on a Plate: 'What should happen is, I should somehow catch my reflection in a mirror, or a shop window, fifty or so pages in, and describe myself to you that way.'

Honeymoon: 'We're in this white limo purring through crowded Saturday-night streets.'

Does My Bum Look Big in This: 'MY DIARY. IF FOUND PLEASE RETURN TO: Jacqueline M. PaneI'm not saying what the M stands foranyway it's not important.'

The Trials of Tiffany Trott: 'Ok. Champagne - tick; Cheesy Wotsits - tick; flowers - tick; balloons - tick; streamers - tick; cake - tick; candles - tick - oh God, oh God, where are the candleholders?'

Jemima J: 'God, I wish I were thin.'

Hens Dancing: 'Seven valentine cards have been delivered to the house this morning by the postman and not one of them is for me.'

The narrator BJ: Bridget Jones, a thirtysomething singleton who lives in London and works in the media, devised by Helen Fielding, a thirtysomething singleton who lives in London and used to work for the BBC and the Independent.

MLOAP: Clara Hutt, a thirtysomething mother of two, who lives in east London and works as a journalist, devised by India Knight, a thirtysomething mother of two, who lives in east London and is a journalist for the Sunday Times.

Honeymoon: Honeymoon Holt, a twentysomething who lives in west London and house sits for a millionaire, devised by Amy Jenkins, who lives in west London and is a millionaire.

Bum: Jacqueline Pane, a thirtysomething who lives in north London, works as a conference organiser and wants to be a writer, devised by Arabella Weir, who lives in north London and is a writer.

Tiffany T: Tiffany Trott, a thirtysomething who lives in London and works in the media, devised by Isabel Wolff, a thirtysomething who lives in London and worked in the media.

Jemima J: Jemima Jones, a twentysomething who lives in London and works as a journalist, devised by Jane Green, who lives in London and was a freelance journalist for eight years.

Hens: Venetia Summers, a thirtysomething mother of three who lives in Norfolk, devised by Raffaella Barker, a thirtysomething mother of three who lives in Norfolk.

THE LOVE INTEREST

BJ: Mark Darcy, a 'super dooper top-notch lawyer' who Bridget meets at a turkey curry buffet. Embarrassingly, she tries to impress him with her knowledge of Susan Faludi's feminist manual, Backlash. He's read it. She hasn't.

MLOAP: Sam Dunphy, a 'dark n' brooding' Irish dancer who Clara meets at an interview. Embarrassingly, she gets drunk and asks him if he wears tights and shags the other dancers.

Honeymoon: Ed, a gardener, who Honey orders a Japanese water garden from. Embarrassingly, she answers the door to him in stripy pyjamas and birds nest hair.

Bum: Andy from marketing. Jacqueline nearly dies of embarrassment when, after drinking too much on their first date, she wakes up the next morning and has no idea what happened the night before.

Tiffany Trott: Damien Clutterbuck, a managing director. On their first date, he admits that he's married. She abandons the date, humiliated.

Jemima J: Ben Williams, deputy news editor at the Kilburn Herald. To Jemima's embarrassment, she downloads some hardcore porn while Ben is passing.

Hens: David Lanyon, a carpenter who Venetia hires to do her bathroom. Embarrassingly, his first glimpse of her is asleep on the grass with her mouth wide open.

THE MOTHER

BJ: posh, overbearing and critical, with a better social life than her daughter's. 'What on earth do you think you're wearing, darling? You look like a common prostitute.' Separated from Bridget's father.

My Life: posh, overbearing and critical, with a better social life than her daughter's. 'I do wish you'd stop eating like an Italian peasant, darling. Look at what happened to your father.' Separated from Clara's father.

Honeymoon: Honeymoon's parents died in a plane crash over the Mexican jungle.

Bum: posh, hard done by and critical. 'Do you ever think you might have a drink problem?' 'Is this what passes for normal driving in London?' Separated from Jacqueline's father.

Tiffany: posh, overbearing and critical. 'Darling, I do wish you could get a proper job again.'

Jemima J: posh, selfish and conceited. 'What about the diet? Lost any more weight?' 'That's too thin for you, you must look like a scarecrow.'

Hens: posh, eccentric and reproachful, with a better social life than her daughter's. 'Far too hasty in your approach - it's always been your trouble.'

KEY RHETORICAL QUESTION

Bridget Jones: 'Oh, why am I so unattractive? Why?'

My Life: 'Why is my life like this?'

Honeymoon: 'What exactly is slim? Do you have to be Kate Moss - or will Jennifer Aniston do?'

Bum: 'Why oh why did I buy those platforms?'

Tiffany Trott: 'Isn't it annoying being dumped?'

Jemima J: 'How can I make myself sound interesting?'

Hens Dancing: 'How can my standards be so low?'

KEY WHIMSICAL OBSERVATION

BJ: 'How can I have put on 3lb since the middle of the night? I can understand weight coming off, but' (cue funny observations about weight loss).

My Life: 'Cows do that thing of' (cue funny observations about cows).

Honeymoon: 'Am I the only person who thinks airports are sexy places?' (cue funny observations about airports).

Bum: 'I felt like a gooseberry. NB - I wonder why it's gooseberry?' (cue funny observations about gooseberries).

Tiffany Trott: 'Tennis always takes my mind of my troubles. It gets the seratonin going, or is it endorphins?' (cue funny observations about tennis).

Jemima J: 'Can somebody turn the sunshine off?' (cue funny observations about hangovers).

Hens: 'Do I want to be a dolphin?'

KEEPING-IT-REAL COLLOQUIALISMS

Bridget Jones: ugh, oops, humph, gagging, hmmm, goody, git, sod, aargh.

My Life: saddo, scuzzy, grouchy, balistic, arse, epi.

Honeymoon: shagged, wuss, enuff, respect, sorted, wicked, geezer and some Americanisms - goddamn and boy!

Bum: gosh, trippy, chuffed, WOW, yuk, oops, arse, erm, eeeeek!

Tiffany Trott: bloke, wow!, fagged, fabbo, aarrrggghhh!!!

Jemima J: dumb ass, snazzy, bugger, bitch-face, arse, phwooargh.

Hens Dancing: freak out, groovy, troll, pukesome, gross, yum yum.

FAVOURITE EXCLAMATIONS

BJ: Ohmigod.

My Life: oh, God.

Honeymoon: Oh. My.God.

Bum: OH MY GOD.

Tiffany: Oh God, oh God.

Jemima J: Oh my God, oh my God, oh my God.

Hens: Oh, God. Never. Ever. Again.

WORST LINE

BJ: 'You can't be ironic about dead people.'

My Life: 'Hello, Tarka. Otterly delighted to meet you.'

Honeymoon: 'Will it be enough, the not-enoughness of it all?'

Bum: 'Mmm, maybe normal people like people who like them, just like that.'

Tiffany: 'It did make me wonder whether Tiffany Trott will always be standing in attendance, off-stage, in the wings, watching, and waiting on others. Waiting, I thought ruefully as the band played on. Waiting. Waiting. Waiting.'

Jemima J: 'I love the English language, playing with words, watching sentences fit together like pieces of a jigsaw puzzle, but sadly my talents are wasted here at the Kilburn Herald.'

Hens: 'Am I pursuing him? Why have I come? What shall I drink? Will I look deliberately suggestive if I have crisps?'

LUDICROUS NAMES

BJ: Perpetua, Cosmo, Una, Magda, Piggy, Desdemona

Honeymoon: Honeymoon, Della, Venice, Cherelle, Jesus

My Life: Araminta, Ismene, Myrtle, Digby, Candy

Bum: Bee, Kyle, Queline

Tiffany: Portia, Kit, Mungo, Saskia, Conrad, the advertising firms Blow Coward Spank and Gurgle Gargle and Peggoty

Jemima J: Dimitri, Cindy, Alexia, Jemima's nickname 'mimey'

Hens: Venetia, Calypso, Carmel, Byron, Gawain, Diptych, Peregrine

TERMS OF SELF-REFERENCE

BJ: Miss Havisham, singleton, Stepford Wife, Bitch Queen from Hell, garish clown with two dead crows for eyes.

My Life: White Trash Slutmum, Bad Mother, a gigantic, huge, clumsy, lumpen oaf of a creature, pustulant porker, corpulent teenager, sumo champion, a cross between an old potato and a diesel dyke.

Honeymoon: Ethnic cleanser, Alice in Wonderland, Amazonian, fake, loony

Bum: The porker, hopeless wino, bloated and leaden with breasts like five day old party balloons, one of those dogs you see in the back of cars.

Tiffany: Professional spinster, the Concealer Queen, on the shelf, going down the pan, quite ancient, plebeian, Lone Ranger.

Jemima J: Ungainly oaf, dull, idiot, fat, miserable, a balloon with legs.

Hens: Bag lady, big lemon

LISTS

BJ: Bridget lists calories, alcohol units, Valentines cards, boyfriends, New Years Resolutions including 'reduce circumference of thighs' and 'make better use of time'.

My Life: Clara lists five reasons to Count My Blessings including 'I am a MARRIED WOMAN' and 'I have regular sex.'

Honeymoon: Honey lists the six-step guide to Happy Ever After Living including, 'tell him your favourite film is the Sound of Music'.

Bum: Jackie lists My Good Points, Learning To Live with Cellulite and New Years Resolutions including 'be thinner' and 'start thinking ahead'.

Tiffany: Tiffany lists What Can a Man Give Me That I Haven't Already Got? and Ten Good Things About Being Single, including 'you can eat crisps in bed'.

Jemima J: Jemima doesn't make lists. She occasionally refers to herself in the third person, as in 'Jemima Jones, what the hell are you doing?' and 'Jemima Jones now has a waist.'

Hens: Venetia lists Valentine's cards.

PRODUCT PLACEMENT

BJ: Blind Date, Harvey Nichols, Silk Cut, Cadbury's Dairy Milk Tray, Café Rouge, Le Creuset, Tatler, Reader's Digest

My Life: Harvey Nichols, Sainsbury's, M&S, Manolo Blahnik, Yves St Laurent, Prada, Jimmy Choo, Wonderbra, Patrick Cox, Vogue, Clarins, Galeries Lafayette, Teletubbies

Honeymoon: Harvey Nichols, M&S, Pet Rescue, Abbey National, Peter Jones, Levi's, Diesel, DKNY, Haagen Dazs, Just 17, Stars in their Eyes, Harrods

Bum: Harvey Nichols, Sainsbury's, M&S, Ryvita, Pret a Manger, McDonald's, Baby Gap, The Bill, Hob-Nobs, Kit Kat

Tiffany: Blind Date, M&S, Manolo Blahnik, Marlboro Light, Waitrose, Harrods, Question Time, DH Evans, Monsoon, Bang and Olufsen, Galeries Lafayette, One2One, Vivienne Westwood, the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital

Jemima J: M&S, Silk Cut, Louis Vuitton, Virgin Airways, Seinfeld, the K Bar, Visa, Blockbuster, the Daily Mail, Habitat, the book The Rules

Hens: Silk Cut, Teletubbies, Barclays, Hello!, Weetabix, Baywatch, Guinness Book of Records, Reader's Digest

AFTER BRIDGET: THE ANXIETY OF INFLUENCE

My Life: India Knight's My Life on a Plate does for divorcees what Bridget Jones's Diary did for singletons.' (Daily Telegraph)

Bum: 'A BJ clone, this fictional diary rehashes the formula - career woman can't get boyfriend panic. Does My Bum Look Big in This? is full of 'ironic' self-loathing about fat thighs and facial hair. (Guardian)

Honeymoon: 'It's just one more novel on the teetering pile about 30-something women and the M word - a story that's been told countless times in countless guises in the wake of the Bridget Jones phenomenon.' (The Mirror)

Jemima J: 'A Bridget too far, the only hope is that soon the tedious girls' names used as titles - Jemima J by Jane Green - will run out and the genre will dry up like tears on a pillow case.' (The Times)

Tiffany Trott: 'Originally conceived as a long-running Bridget-esque column in the Telegraph, poor Tiff's initial foray into newsprint was dumped when the real Bridget was lured to the paper.' (Independent on Sunday)

Hens Dancing: 'Written in diary form, it is a rural Bridget Jones with three kids in place of a job.' (Independent on Sunday).

(The Times) Tiffany Trott: 'Originally conceived as a long-running Bridget-esque column in the Telegraph, poor Tiff's initial foray into newsprint was dumped when the real Bridget was lured to the paper.' webTitle: Guardian and Observer win high court battle over Shayler emails

fields.headline: Guardian and Observer win high court battle over Shayler emails
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Shayler case
fields.trailText:
The high court today ruled that the Guardian and Observer newspapers are not legally obliged to hand over documents and emails relating to former MI5 officer David Shayler.
Special report: the Shayler case
fields.body:
A victory for press freedom was claimed today by two national newspapers in a high court ruling over the Shayler affair.

The court warned against the making of court disclosure orders against newspapers which might "stifle" investigative journalism unless there was "compelling evidence" the orders were in the public interest.

The Guardian and Observer won ground-breaking decisions that they were not legally obliged to hand over documents and e-mails following allegations by the former MI5 officer that British security services were involved in a failed bomb plot to assassinate Libyan leader Colonel Gaddafi.

Lord Justice Judge, sitting with Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mr Justice Gibbs, ruled the wide terms of production orders made by an Old Bailey judge "would have a devastating and stifling effect on the proper investigation of the Shayler story".

Quashing the orders, he added: "Virtually any journalist who made contact with him, and any newspaper publishing an article based on discussions with Shayler, would have been at risk of a similar application to the present.

"To my mind that would be an unhealthy development, quite disproportionate to any practical advantages of the prosecution process."

Mr Shayler, now in exile in France, is facing attempts in Britain to prosecute him under the Official Secrets Act.

Judge Martin Stephens made orders at the Old Bailey in March at the request of the prosecuting authorities requiring Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger to produce "all files, documents and other records" relating to an unsolicited e-mail letter sent to it by Mr Shayler, part of which had been published on February 17.

The letter was in response to a Guardian article suggesting there had been exaggeration by Mr Shayler which had given foreign secretary Robin Cook "an easy way out" when he denied British involvement in the alleged assassination attempt in which innocent bystanders died.

In The Observer case, similar orders were made under the 1984 Police and Criminal Evidence Act against editor Roger Alton and the newspaper's home affairs correspondent Martin Bright relating to material e-mailed by Mr Shayler and used in a front page article on February 27 headlined "Two Spies Named in Libya Plot".

Both newspapers fought the orders, arguing they would "strike at the roots" of their independence in a way which was both unlawful and unfair.

They also accused the Government of attempting to "suppress or shoot the messenger".

webTitle: Briton freed after Thai drugs pardon

fields.headline: Briton freed after Thai drugs pardon
fields.trailText: Convicted heroin smuggler Sandra Gregory today walked to freedom after serving seven years of a 25-year sentence.
fields.body:
Convicted heroin smuggler Sandra Gregory today walked to freedom after serving seven years of a 25-year sentence.

Tearful Gregory, 35, strolled from the gates of Cookham Wood prison in Rochester, Kent, to be met by her mother, Doreen.

Gregory was jailed after being caught with heroin inside a condom in her body at Bangkok airport in 1993. She was freed after the King of Thailand gave her a pardon.

She said: "It is absolutely marvellous. I only found out yesterday when my mother told me. I was not expecting it at all and am humbled by it. I have learned an awful lot in the past seven and a half years. It has given me empathy with other people."

Gregory, looking healthy in a red jacket and blue jeans, added: "I think more than anybody I would like to thank my parents for everything they have done."

Gregory said she accepted responsibility for what she did. "I was guilty of breaking the law in Thailand and I take full responsibility for what I have done. I still think Thailand is a marvellous country."

She was sentenced to 25 years' imprisonment in Bangkok but was repatriated to Britain in 1997 to serve her sentence as part of the UK-Thai prisoners transfer agreement after a visit by the Queen and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, to the state.

Gregory said she was still in shock and she did not know what she would do with her life or what the first thing she would do when she returned to Scotland. "I would like to do something with drug rehabilitation," she said. "There is a big demand for it. Most girls in prison have a drug problem."

She said she was looking forward to seeing her 89-year-old grandfather and to taking a long walk.

Speaking from the family home near Pitcaple in a rural part of Aberdeenshire, her father, Stan Gregory, 66, said he was "over the moon" at the news of his daughter's release. He said that he and his wife Doreen had been informed unofficially yesterday by the Foreign Office.

He said of Gregory's incarceration: "The punishment was quite right - it was the length of the sentence that has always been the issue." Mr Gregory said he felt "relief" at his daughter's relase, and added: "I don't feel like opening champagne, because it's not that sort of thing."

James MacKay, who had campaigned for the release of Gregory, said there was relief in her parent's home town of Inverurie, near Aberdeen, at the move.

"This is wonderful news," said Mr MacKay, an elder of the Church of Scotland who had used this year's general assembly of the church to call for Gregory's release. "It is ridiculous that she has been incarcerated for so long. It is terrible that the government has done so little to help. It will be wonderful for her to be back home with her parents."

webTitle: United and Carlton - it was never going to work

fields.headline: United and Carlton - it was never going to work
fields.standfirst: With Granada lurking in the wings, the proposed merger between United News & Media and Carlton Communications was always doomed, thinks media editor Janine Gibson
fields.trailText: With Granada lurking in the wings, the proposed merger between United News & Media and Carlton Communications was always doomed, thinks media editor Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
There will be many today tutting and saying "I told you so", but it's important to remain compassionate. The break-up of a relationship is never easy, especially one subject to the pressures of the public eye.

Granted, few of their friends truly believed that Michael Green and Lord [Clive] Hollick would pull off the merger between their Carlton and United empires. Despite their common aim - to become the dominant player in ITV - their many differences were all too apparent.

Where Michael likes expensive art, Margaret Thatcher and the Saatchis; Clive prefers grubby newspapers and the Labour pollster Philip Gould. It was never quite a match made in heaven.

The £8.3bn deal to merge Carlton and United was lobbed from the start into a regulatory minefield.

But the greater threat was always the third player, Charles Allan's Granada. Even as Michael and Clive announced their engagement, all eyes were on the gooseberry Charles. Would he step in? An elopement perhaps?

And last week's decision by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, to give the green light for ITV companies to merge subject to certain conditions, merely reinforced the strength of Granada's suit.

Officially, the merger has been dropped because of the two companies' reluctance to co-operate with the condition laid down by Mr Byers - that they sell Meridian TV. Meridian, currently owned by United, is one of the richest ITV licences, serving the lucrative homes of the south-east so beloved by advertisers. Selling it would "undermine the strategic rationale behind the merger", said the companies.

In reality, little has changed. We all await Granada's move. Will it be the bookmakers' favourite United? Will it be the increasingly spinsterish Carlton? Either way, Charles Allan is laughing all the way to the altar.

webTitle: My Life on a Plate by India Knight

fields.headline: My Life on a Plate by India Knight
fields.standfirst:
(Penguin £5.99) Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Not very funny, plotless chick-lit for the media in-crowd who prefer their humour in limp-wristed designer off-white rather than full-bodied noir
fields.body:
"Ooh, I do love writing fiction," cooed India. "You can be absolutely anyone you like."

"Really?" said Jeremy without looking up.

"Yes, yes. So I'm going to be Clara and you're going to be Robert."

"Great."

So here I am, Clara Hutt. My friends call me Jabba, ha ha. I'm a Size 16: bit fat really, but extremely beautiful, obviously. I'm married - to Robert - have two kids and I fit in the odd bit of freelance journalism in between shopping at Prada and lunch at the Ivy. Oh, that's another thing - I label and name drop.

I should be happy. Neither of us is having an affair, unlike some of my friends, but I feel there should be more to a marriage than this. I'm so emotionally articulate but Robert is just so remote.

Omigod. I got really, really drunk and completely fucked up an interview with Sam Dunphy, the modern dancer. I accused him of being gay. Still, Araminta can always get someone else to do it. I can feel another shop coming on.

My stepfather has invited me to a family christening. For some reason, I always feel less important to him than his real children.

"I'd really like you to come with me," I say to Robert.

"I don't feel like it," he replies, his eyes fixed on the fashion pages.

Wow. I must have made a bit of an impression on Dunphy after all; I've been invited to his party. What will I wear? I want to look fabulous.

"I've bought a diaphanous, glittering mermaid dress with bias cut in size 14," I tell Robert. "Did you get the matching shoes?"

Is that beautiful blonde in the designer mini-dress Dunphy's girlfriend? Perhaps not. Robert stays and I flirt demurely and chastely with Dunphy.

Fuck. I've got a helluva hangover and Robert and I are off to Paris for the weekend to rekindle our marriage.

"Do you want to make love to me?" I ask.

"No," he yawns.

The next day Robert has something to tell me.

"I'm not going back to London with you. I'm staying to edit French Vogue."

I should feel devastated for months, but because this is fiction - honest - I don't. I feel unlocked from my loveless marriage. Now. Will I get it together with Dunphy or not?

And if you really are pressed - The digested read, digested:
Not very funny, plotless chick-lit for the media in-crowd who prefer their humour in limp-wristed designer off-white rather than full-bodied noir

fields.headline: Thumb and thumber
fields.standfirst: There was a time when film studio heads would tremble at the mention of critics Siskel and Ebert - when they panned a movie, it stayed panned. Then Siskel died. Can Ebert's new partner recapture the magic? By  Lance Gould
fields.trailText: There was a time when film studio heads would tremble at the mention of critics Siskel and Ebert - when they panned a movie, it stayed panned. Then Siskel died. Can Ebert's new partner recapture the magic?
fields.body:
Not since Caesar had any man become so singularly associated with a digit. But Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert arguably wielded more power in their thumbs than Tom Cruise, Clint Eastwood or Arnold Schwarzenegger did in their entire bodies. Siskel & Ebert, as the duo became known, were the two most powerful film critics in the US - if not the world - and a thumbs-up (positive review) from them could mean millions of dollars in revenue for a film and its studio. A thumbs-down could spell disaster and lead to studio heads rolling.

On their weekly show, Siskel & Ebert, the duelling critics would debate, often passionately, the merits of that particular week's crop of new releases. They developed such a rabid audience that a simple thumbs-up could give life to the lamest of films. Taking out ads for their films, studios would often reduce a Siskel or Ebert review to its lowest digital denominator: "Thumbs up! - Gene Siskel", or "Thumbs way up! - Roger Ebert".

But it wasn't just film aficionados who became fans of the show. Many tuned in to see if the critical sparring could once again descend into a form of verbal mud-wrestling. The two were fierce rivals - Siskel was movie critic for the Chicago Tribune, Ebert was his Chicago Sun-Times competitor - and it was almost a given that they'd be at each other's throats once the cameras were rolling.

The oral slugfests broke out between them so frequently, in fact, that it transcended their individual personae and became their "act". The travelling insult show carried beyond the confines of their own programme, and made them popular talkshow guests. Whether it was on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, the Late Show with David Letterman or the Howard Stern radio show, Siskel & Ebert would bring their unique brand of filmic fisticuffs to entirely new audiences.

One of the show's highlights was the attention they gave to the lowlights of Hollywood. Every week, their Spot The Wonder Dog would designate the week's worst film (dog) - the "dog of the week".

Spot, and public TV, were replaced in 1982 by, respectively, a skunk and well-financed syndication TV, bringing them an even wider audience in the form of At The Movies. Payday increased again in 1986, when they were lured away to another syndicator for an even better offer. This fourth version of their programme made them household names, and even landed them on Entertainment Weekly magazine's list of 100 most powerful people in Hollywood. Ebert even made a brief appearance as himself, albeit years later, in Independence Day.

Still, many had trouble telling them apart. Siskel, follicularly challenged, was cleverly dubbed "the bald one", while Ebert, who could hold his own in the eating department, was "the fat one". The national phenomenon that was Siskel & Ebert still couldn't guarantee individual name recognition for the gentlemen.

Nevertheless, both Siskel and Ebert were articulate, forward-thinking critics, unusual for a mass-market medium like TV. They roundly and vocally criticised the Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Oscar-governing body, for the ludicrous electoral system that awarded the documentary category and which worked against Hoop Dreams, one of the films they championed. They devoted entire episodes of their show to condemning colourisation (using computers to colour black and white films) and it was their campaign for an alternative rating to "X" for adults that led to the creation of the "NC-17" film rating. Siskel and Ebert were cinematic heroes.

Ebert even had his own footnote in film history. It was he who penned the script to Beyond The Valley Of The Dolls, the cult film from breast-obsessed director Russ Meyer about three girls trying to make it in Hollywood in the late 60s/early 70s. Siskel had no such pedigree, but the two were equally revered in cinematic circles. As champions of independent and "foreign" films, Siskel and Ebert earned many friends in the fringes of movie culture.

All of which made it even sadder when, quite unexpectedly, the 53-year-old Siskel passed away in February 1999, nine months after undergoing surgery to remove a growth from his brain. Since Siskel's death, Ebert has bravely carried on with a rotating cast of about 25 temporary critics. But now it seems that one of them, Richard Roeper, is being announced as Siskel's permanent replacement. Roeper, like Ebert, is affiliated with the Chicago Sun-Times, leaving the Chicago Tribune as odd man out in this unfortunate turn of events.

The new programme will be called Ebert & Roeper And The Movies, which is lacking in mellifluousness but should bring some stability back to the franchise movie review programme. "Richard stood out because his writing style was excellent and he wasn't afraid of Roger", said Mary Kellogg, an executive at Buena Vista Television, which syndicates the programme. "He was able to stick to his opinions and not move off of them." Roeper signed a five-year contract with Buena Vista. All he needs now is a nickname. "The fat one" is taken.

fields.headline: Debt relief
fields.standfirst: As leaders from the world's seven richest countries and Russia meet at the G8 summit in Okinawa, Japan, Mark Tran and Charlotte Denny explain the glacial pace of debt relief
fields.trailText: As leaders from the world's seven richest countries and Russia meet at the G8 summit in Okinawa, Japan, we explain the glacial pace of debt relief.
fields.body:
What did the G8 promise on debt relief?
At the Cologne summit last year, the G8 promised to write off £70bn of debt owed by the world's poorest countries, with 25 countries to begin the debt relief process by the end of 2000. But with five months go to, only nine have qualified and only £7bn of the £70bn has been delivered. And the £7bn had already been agreed under existing debt-cutting agreements.

When did the ball get rolling on debt relief?
Non-governmental organisations such as Oxfam have been putting pressure on governments and international financial institutions for years. In the mid to late 90s, the World Bank, under president James Wolfensohn, accepted the idea of debt relief and started pushing the idea. The International Monetary Fund went along after some initial reluctance. Britain has been at the forefront of debt relief, with John Major's Tory government very active on the issue.

Why has it taken so long to implement debt relief proposals?
Poor countries must prepare detailed plans for the IMF and World Bank, explaining how they will spend the money. But they lack the expertise to draw up such proposals and the process is taking much longer than expected. Many countries have been tempted to ask staff from Washington financial institutions to write anti-poverty plans which will satisfy the fund and the bank.

Any other reasons?
The IMF and the World Bank are demanding more reforms. For example, the IMF demanded that Honduras include plans to privatise its electricity sector. Some of the countries on the list are in conflict, and G8 countries are reluctant to see money to being spent on weapons rather than social programmes.

Isn't there a problem with funding debt relief proposals?
Yes. In Cologne, the G8 promised large sums for a special trust fund to help cover the debts owed to the World Bank and the IMF. But the richest nations have been slow in putting their money where their mouths are. The US promised £400m, but congress has rebuffed President Bill Clinton's request for the money. In time-honoured fashion, the EU and Japan are using this as an excuse to delay their own contributions.

Any proposals for breaking the logjam?
Oxfam has suggested that any country prepared to put the savings from debt relief into a fund for spending on social programmes such as health and education should have the money immediately. Another possibility is to drop the requirements for countries to prepare detailed anti-poverty plans before they get their loans cancelled.

How much of a drain are debt payments?
Tanzania, for example, has had its debt interest payments reduced by just under 20% over the next three years, so it will be paying the west an annual average of £100m in 2001-3. That is still considerably more than the £59m Tanzania spends annually on basic education. Meanwhile, Tanzania is one of the few countries in the world where illiteracy is rising.

fields.bodyText: What did the G8 promise on debt relief? At the Cologne summit last year, the G8 promised to write off £70bn of debt owed by the world's poorest countries, with 25 countries to begin the debt relief process by the end of 2000. But with five months go to, only nine have qualified and only £7bn of the £70bn has been delivered. And the £7bn had already been agreed under existing debt-cutting agreements. When did the ball get rolling on debt relief? Non-governmental organisations such as Oxfam have been putting pressure on governments and international financial institutions for years. In the mid to late 90s, the World Bank, under president James Wolfensohn, accepted the idea of debt relief and started pushing the idea. The International Monetary Fund went along after some initial reluctance. Britain has been at the forefront of debt relief, with John Major's Tory government very active on the issue. Why has it taken so long to implement debt relief proposals? Poor countries must prepare detailed plans for the IMF and World Bank, explaining how they will spend the money. But they lack the expertise to draw up such proposals and the process is taking much longer than expected. Many countries have been tempted to ask staff from Washington financial institutions to write anti-poverty plans which will satisfy the fund and the bank. Any other reasons? The IMF and the World Bank are demanding more reforms. For example, the IMF demanded that Honduras include plans to privatise its electricity sector. Some of the countries on the list are in conflict, and G8 countries are reluctant to see money to being spent on weapons rather than social programmes. Isn't there a problem with funding debt relief proposals? Yes. In Cologne, the G8 promised large sums for a special trust fund to help cover the debts owed to the World Bank and the IMF. But the richest nations have been slow in putting their money where their mouths are. The US promised £400m, but congress has rebuffed President Bill Clinton's request for the money. In time-honoured fashion, the EU and Japan are using this as an excuse to delay their own contributions. Any proposals for breaking the logjam? Oxfam has suggested that any country prepared to put the savings from debt relief into a fund for spending on social programmes such as health and education should have the money immediately. That is still considerably more than the £59m Tanzania spends annually on basic education. Meanwhile, Tanzania is one of the few countries in the world where illiteracy is rising. fields.headline: The Ford Escort
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the boy racer's favourite wheels
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the boy racer's favourite wheels
fields.body:
1. Today marks the end of the line for the Ford Escort. The last one rolls off the line at the sprawling Halewood plant in Liverpool.

2. Launched in 1968, the Escort has become one of the world's favourite boring little cars. Ford has sold more than 18m of them worldwide, including 4.6m in Britain.

3. The Escort is high in the league of much-loved mass-produced motors, along with the Volkswagen Beetle, the Morris Minor and the Mini .

4. Escorts are favoured by boy racers and others who do stupid things on wheels.

5. You can find out lots of not especially interesting things on the net about the Mark One, the Mark Two, and the, um, Mark Three.

6. You can join the global owners' club, or, if you are not an owner, you can read the corrosively boring notes of one.

7. The much slimmed-down and perennially troubled Halewood plant will not be redundant. Indeed it is moving markedly upmarket, turning out Jaguars.

8. Sales of the luxury cars are booming, but taxpayers still bunged Ford nearly £50m to keep Halewood open.

9. Ford itself seems to be moving away from Escort Man and Woman. It has also bought Land Rover, which makes off-road vehicles for people to show off in their suburban drives.

10. The Escort just might survive in India, which has a long tradition of vehicular reincarnation. They're still turning out the Hindustan Ambassador, which is the1954 Morris Oxford.

fields.headline: Bumper year for box-office champions
fields.trailText: With the year only just half through, 2000 has already produced two films that join the list of the top 50 worldwide box-office champions of all time
fields.body:
With the year only just half through, 2000 has already produced two films that join the list of the top 50 worldwide box-office champions of all time. Gladiator has moved into the number 39 position, with takings of $378.6m worldwide. The Ridley Scott-helmed picture is likely to further improve on that ranking, as the film is still raking in the cash in cinemas all over the world.

The second to join this exclusive list is the Tom Cruise vehicle Mission: Impossible 2 (pictured). John Woo's picture just squeaked into the number 49 spot with worldwide box-office earnings of $357.8m.

M:I-2 is also bound to move up a few notches. The movie is still in the UK and US top five, holds the number one spot in Germany, Italy, Spain and Japan, and is yet to be released in many countries.

But it still has a way to go before it matches the first film's worldwide succcess: the original Mission: Impossible, released in 1996, stands at number 24 in the top 50, having grossed $464.9m internationally.

Meanwhile, Scary Movie, although nowhere near the top 50 of all time, is doing very nicely for its makers Dimension. Yesterday - its 14th day of release - it passed the $100m mark in the US. X-Men is expected to reach a similar figure over the weekend, making it one of the 10 fastest films to reach the milestone.

The year's other movies to have made over $100m in the US are Dinosaur, The Perfect Storm, Erin Brockovich and Big Momma's House.

webTitle: July 21: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: New blood for X-files, Courtney Love loses out through injury, Gabriel Byrne to star in sitcom, and John Cleese joins Rat Race
fields.body:
 Robert Patrick, who played the evil liquid-metal cyborg opposite Arnold Schwarzenegger in Terminator 2: Judgment Day (pictured), is joining the cast of the X-Files next season, filling the gap in the episodes that star David Duchovny will be sitting out. Duchovny will only appear in 11 of the 20 episodes scheduled - his character, FBI agent Fox Mulder, was abducted by aliens in the season finale. Patrick will appear in all 20 episodes as FBI agent John Doggett, a former policeman assigned to help in the search for Mulder. Series creator Chris Carter said yesterday: "He's not a replacement for David, he's a new character coming in."

 Courtney Love has lost her role in John Carpenter's Ghosts of Mars after injuring her ankle earlier this week while getting into shape for the film. She was due to have played a police lieutenant opposite Ice Cube. According to a production insider, a tight $30m budget and an even tighter August 8 start date means that producers cannot wait for Love to mend.

 Gabriel Byrne is to play the lead in an American sitcom. The actor will play an Irish architect living in New York with his teenage son and feisty retired father in Madigan Men. Byrne will also be executive producer on the show, which he sees as a male version of Sex and the City.

 John Cleese has joined the ensemble cast of Rat Race, a remake of the 1963 comedy It's a Mad Mad Mad Mad World.

webTitle: Leeds face tough Champions League test

fields.headline: Leeds face tough Champions League test
fields.trailText: Leeds United will face German side TSV Munich 1860 in the third qualifying round of the Champions League after this morning's draw in Switzerland. Leeds will be at home in the first leg against Bayern Munich's local rivals who finished fourth in last season's Bundesliga.
fields.body:
Leeds United will face German side TSV Munich 1860 in the third qualifying round of the Champions League after this morning's draw in Switzerland. Leeds will be at home in the first leg against Bayern Munich's local rivals who finished fourth in last season's Bundesliga.

TSV's most famous name is the diminutive, and ageing, Thomas Haessler, whose form for Bayern's "little neighbour" last season won him a recall to the Germany squad ahead of their disastrous Euro 2000 campaign. TSV have added Norwegian midfielder Erik Mykland to their ranks during the course of the summer, and former QPR defender Ned Zelic also turns out for them in defence.

Rangers have a slightly easier task, facing the winners Danish champions Herfolge BK if, as expected, they come through their second round clash with Lithuanian side FBK Kaunas. Herfolge romped to their first ever Danish title last season under coach John Jensen, the former Arsenal favourite. Rangers will be away for the first leg, which will be played on either August 8 or 9.

Return legs will be played on August 22 or 23.

webTitle: Eye trips cancelled for safety checks

fields.headline: Eye trips cancelled for safety checks
fields.trailText: Visitors were being urged to stay away from the London Eye today after rides were cancelled so that safety checks could be carried out.
fields.body:
Visitors were being urged to stay away from the London Eye today after rides were cancelled so that safety checks could be carried out.

One of the 16 drive mechanisms which propels the giant wheel failed just before 9pm last night and several hundred passengers were turned away, said a British Airways spokeswoman.

About 10,000 people had booked tickets for rides on the millennium attraction, on London's South Bank, today.

The latest mishap follows problems with ventilation eight weeks ago, when customers had to be offered extra water and the number of people in each capsule was reduced to aid airflow.

BA London Eye spokeswoman Kate Gay said: "Regrettably we have decided to suspend operations today to allow further inspections.

"We appreciate how frustrating and disappointing this is and we will be offering to re-book or refund flights.

"A telephone help-line is being set up to give operational updates for people planning to visit the London Eye but we would ask those with pre-booked tickets for today not to go to the attraction." Ms Gay stressed that the recent problem with ventilation was due to a particularly hot spell of weather, and not any inadequacy in the air conditioning, which was up graded several months ago.

webTitle: Why is veggie food so bad?

fields.headline: Why is veggie food so bad?
fields.standfirst: Millions of us have given up meat. So how come a tin of tomatoes on dry pasta is often the most a veggie can expect from a meal out, asks  Matthew Fort. Meanwhile, below,  Simon Rogers  gives a first-hand account of life in a culinary underclass
fields.trailText: Millions of us have given up meat. So how come a tin of tomatoes on dry pasta is often the most a veggie can expect from a meal out, asks Matthew Fort. Meanwhile, below, Simon Rogers gives a first-hand account of life in a culinary underclass.
fields.body:
There are moments when you cannot but feel sorry for vegetarians. It's goat's cheese, you see, although soi-disant wild mushrooms are as much to blame. Pick up almost any menu you care to mention, and you can bet your bottom dollar that the vegetarian option for the first courses will involve goat's cheese: frequently grilled, plonked on top of, well, take your pick - "mixed salad leaves", grilled vegetables, tomatoes, and, in the rare, a virtuoso burst of originality: pesto, harissa, or some other equally unsuitable condiment.

Turn to the main courses and it's the same again. Not goat's cheese this time, but "wild mushrooms", a hideous, viscous mass, like compost in the early stages of decomposition, piled on to - what shall we have? - pasta, polenta, pastry. And that, all too frequently, is that for the vegetarian in our midst.

The situation in those restaurants that are devoted to the cause is generally worse. Any pretence of culinary sophistication is rejected with a rigour reminiscent of early Christian saints. I have eaten in a great many, and, with the exception of those restaurants where the food is a natural expression of cultural vegetarianism, such as in Gujarati cooking, I have found only one that remotely approaches the standards of non-vegetarian restaurants: Dennis Cotter's exemplary Café Paradiso in Cork. But Cork is a long way to go for lunch.

Don't get me wrong. There is good vegetarian food to be had in restaurants, especially Indian, Italian, Lebanese and Turkish, though few of these are exclusively dedicated to vegetarians. The winner of the vegetarian section in the last Time Out awards was Tas, a Turkish restaurant in south-east London, which caters as admirably for the offal lover as for the vegetable aficionado.

You can even find imaginative and satisfying vegetarian menus in fine dining establishments. Paul Gayler, who set the ball rolling some years ago with ground-breaking dishes at Inigo Jones, now struts his stuff at the Lanesborough Hotel in London. Raymond Blanc offers a spectacular display of kitchen firepower at Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons. Alexis Gautier produces an exquisite vegetarian menu at Roussillon. But this is food which needs the resources, time and skill of a professional kitchen to pull off. And that's the trouble with vegetables. They require an awful lot of trouble to make into something substantial and memorable.

It is OK, up to a point, to hurl together a salad, to slice a tomato and splosh good olive oil over it, boil an artichoke and dab the leaves in vinaigrette, but if you want to progress beyond that level, say into the hedonistic world of chickpeas, rice or polenta, then you have to be prepared to work at it. And, of course, in this work-ridden, stress-raddled, time-starved world, we simply aren't. As one of my colleagues commented: "I used to be a veggie, but I gave up in boredom and apathy."

For me, not eating meat would be like a painter striking blue from his palette. However, I eat a great deal of meat-free food, and am the happier for it, but I know that, compared to simple protein, meat-free dishes take a disproportionate amount of time and ingenuity to cook. Grilling, frying, or steaming a piece of meat, fish or poultry is but a single action, requiring not a vast amount of skill. A splodge of mustard and a dab of cream or butter, and you're away.

To invest a cabbage, potato, courgette or broad bean with a similar degree of interest requires making subsidiary sauces, creating combinations, bringing a whole battery of additional ingredients to bear.

Vegetarians are not helped much by the publications set up to exploit the market. Take the cover of the recently published 21st Century Vegetarian; not that there's anything remotely 21st century about it. It has all the sophisticated production values of a 70s student magazine.

Anyway, most of the front is taken up by a photo of a few crudely hewn hunks of courgette smeared with the contents of a tin of tomatoes, with a pile of couscous - the all-purpose bulk item of the moment - to one side. Quick, certainly. Cheap, naturally. Edible, hardly.

With very few exceptions the books written by vegetarians for vegetarians suffer from a similar poverty of thought, originality and instinct for simple pleasure. There are only so many wonderful ways with pasta that anyone can stomach. Yet it need not be so. The Café Paradiso Cookbook, by Denis Cotter, and any number by the great Colin Spencer, show how.

The prepared meals stacked so temptingly and obligingly in supermarket freezer chests and chiller cabinets should provide relief from this dreariness, as they do for so many carnivores. Yet even here the curse of vegetarianism casts its long and dreary shadow.

I have given many of the offerings a proper trial: some, such as the pasta dishes, can be passable, with some brands notably better than others. But pasta is not specifically aimed at vegetarians, merely suitable for them. Those products developed specifically for them are, in my experience, devoid of any interest as food.

The underlying proselytising nature of vegetarianism is made clear by the tolerance of meat lookalikes, sausages, burgers, bacon and mince, made from various kinds of soya-based products, most of which are aimed at children. It seems contradictory to place your faith in the fake foods when the real things are so much more interesting, just because they resemble the familiar excrescences of the food industry.

In the final analysis, vegetarians could, perhaps, call upon their noted qualities of tolerance and humour, and recognise that they have only the intractable nature of the vegetable world to blame for their plight.

Life in a culinary underclass

When I was a kid, for a treat my brother and I would be fixed our own special meal for dinner. If we were lucky it was fish fingers and beans, or bangers and mash.

Twenty-five years later and whenever I have dinner with one particular friend, she makes me a special separate meal. If I was nostalgic for being six again, it would be great, but the reason now is that I don't eat meat.

By now it should be easy to be a vegetarian in Britain. The polls show that at least 5% of the population are totally veggie. Another 3% eat meat less than once a week.

The specialist veggie food market is worth £450m (double what it was in 1992), and that's not counting the normal food (ie stuff that isn't meat) that veggies buy anyway.

You can't open an issue of Hello! without falling over veggie celebs; loads of people either do it, flirt with it or have tried it. So why are vegetarians still treated like second-class citizens with an attitude problem?

I became a veggie about eight years ago because I didn't consume that much meat anyway, and BSE put me off eating burgers. Now I don't eat anything "with a face or a fin", to quote a friend.

Anyway, after a while it became obvious that good veggie food is actually more interesting than meat and two veg. That's because it requires more imagination. Yet people I know and respect in every other part of their lives treat us as if we are part of some odd cult.

Here's what it's like in Britain if you choose not to eat meat. Most restaurants now have one vegetarian option, which is either a wild mushroom tart or maybe some type of goat's cheese salad.

Alternatively, it will be what another friend calls "some cheesy pasta shit". And heaven save us from the courgette-and-couscous option. If you are eating with another veggie and ask if maybe, perhaps, the chef could give you a choice, the answer is dumb incomprehension, as if to say: "Look, you chose this weird lifestyle. If you don't like it, tough luck."

The fact still is, if you want a guaranteed good eat out, it is either south Indian or Italian. And that's it. Anti-vegetarianism permeates every aspect of British life. B&Bs often advertise vegetarian breakfasts, for example. But what this means is that they provide egg, bacon, sausages and black pudding without the bacon, sausages or black pudding. The other week we ate in a hotel restaurant for an aunt's birthday. There was a huge and enticing veggie menu. Unfortunately, the chef hadn't made any of the options and it was back to a tin of ratatouille over dry pasta.

Flying is another favourite. You can book a vegetarian meal three months in advance, fax the airline, and confirm it in triplicate, but when you get to the airport you find no record of your booking and only one veggie meal on the plane. Flying to Canada last year, the budget airline we went with wanted to charge £8 per head. For airline food.

There are so many others. At every official dinner I've ever been to, the vegetarians have been served last and ended up getting an indeterminate stuffed vegetable while everyone else on the table is tucking into dessert.

In pubs there is always the ploughman's, but if you don't fancy a dry hunk of bread with some crusty old cheese and a thimble of pickle, you're stuck.

I'm tired of soggy egg and cress sandwiches and quiche at weddings - which are always eaten by the carnivores anyway. Tired of the fact that food critics never mention vegetarian food because they are all confirmed meat eaters, so there's no pressure on restaurants to change or be inventive. And tired of being treated as if I'm some sort of lower life form.

The veggie pound is not going to disappear. Get used to it.
