But this is food which needs the resources, time and skill of a professional kitchen to pull off. And that's the trouble with vegetables. They require an awful lot of trouble to make into something substantial and memorable. It is OK, up to a point, to hurl together a salad, to slice a tomato and splosh good olive oil over it, boil an artichoke and dab the leaves in vinaigrette, but if you want to progress beyond that level, say into the hedonistic world of chickpeas, rice or polenta, then you have to be prepared to work at it. And, of course, in this work-ridden, stress-raddled, time-starved world, we simply aren't. As one of my colleagues commented: "I used to be a veggie, but I gave up in boredom and apathy." For me, not eating meat would be like a painter striking blue from his palette. However, I eat a great deal of meat-free food, and am the happier for it, but I know that, compared to simple protein, meat-free dishes take a disproportionate amount of time and ingenuity to cook. Grilling, frying, or steaming a piece of meat, fish or poultry is but a single action, requiring not a vast amount of skill. A splodge of mustard and a dab of cream or butter, and you're away. To invest a cabbage, potato, courgette or broad bean with a similar degree of interest requires making subsidiary sauces, creating combinations, bringing a whole battery of additional ingredients to bear. Vegetarians are not helped much by the publications set up to exploit the market. Take the cover of the recently published 21st Century Vegetarian; not that there's anything remotely 21st century about it. It has all the sophisticated production values of a 70s student magazine. Anyway, most of the front is taken up by a photo of a few crudely hewn hunks of courgette smeared with the contents of a tin of tomatoes, with a pile of couscous - the all-purpose bulk item of the moment - to one side. Quick, certainly. Cheap, naturally. Edible, hardly. With very few exceptions the books written by vegetarians for vegetarians suffer from a similar poverty of thought, originality and instinct for simple pleasure. There are only so many wonderful ways with pasta that anyone can stomach. Yet it need not be so. The Café Paradiso Cookbook, by Denis Cotter, and any number by the great Colin Spencer, show how. The prepared meals stacked so temptingly and obligingly in supermarket freezer chests and chiller cabinets should provide relief from this dreariness, as they do for so many carnivores. Yet even here the curse of vegetarianism casts its long and dreary shadow. I have given many of the offerings a proper trial: some, such as the pasta dishes, can be passable, with some brands notably better than others. But pasta is not specifically aimed at vegetarians, merely suitable for them. Those products developed specifically for them are, in my experience, devoid of any interest as food. The underlying proselytising nature of vegetarianism is made clear by the tolerance of meat lookalikes, sausages, burgers, bacon and mince, made from various kinds of soya-based products, most of which are aimed at children. It seems contradictory to place your faith in the fake foods when the real things are so much more interesting, just because they resemble the familiar excrescences of the food industry. In the final analysis, vegetarians could, perhaps, call upon their noted qualities of tolerance and humour, and recognise that they have only the intractable nature of the vegetable world to blame for their plight. Life in a culinary underclass When I was a kid, for a treat my brother and I would be fixed our own special meal for dinner. If we were lucky it was fish fingers and beans, or bangers and mash. Twenty-five years later and whenever I have dinner with one particular friend, she makes me a special separate meal. If I was nostalgic for being six again, it would be great, but the reason now is that I don't eat meat. By now it should be easy to be a vegetarian in Britain. The polls show that at least 5% of the population are totally veggie. Another 3% eat meat less than once a week. The specialist veggie food market is worth £450m (double what it was in 1992), and that's not counting the normal food (ie stuff that isn't meat) that veggies buy anyway. You can't open an issue of Hello! without falling over veggie celebs; loads of people either do it, flirt with it or have tried it. So why are vegetarians still treated like second-class citizens with an attitude problem? I became a veggie about eight years ago because I didn't consume that much meat anyway, and BSE put me off eating burgers. Now I don't eat anything "with a face or a fin", to quote a friend. Anyway, after a while it became obvious that good veggie food is actually more interesting than meat and two veg. That's because it requires more imagination. Yet people I know and respect in every other part of their lives treat us as if we are part of some odd cult. Here's what it's like in Britain if you choose not to eat meat. Most restaurants now have one vegetarian option, which is either a wild mushroom tart or maybe some type of goat's cheese salad. Alternatively, it will be what another friend calls "some cheesy pasta shit". And heaven save us from the courgette-and-couscous option. If you are eating with another veggie and ask if maybe, perhaps, the chef could give you a choice, the answer is dumb incomprehension, as if to say: "Look, you chose this weird lifestyle. If you don't like it, tough luck." The fact still is, if you want a guaranteed good eat out, it is either south Indian or Italian. And that's it. Anti-vegetarianism permeates every aspect of British life. B&Bs often advertise vegetarian breakfasts, for example. But what this means is that they provide egg, bacon, sausages and black pudding without the bacon, sausages or black pudding. The other week we ate in a hotel restaurant for an aunt's birthday. There was a huge and enticing veggie menu. Unfortunately, the chef hadn't made any of the options and it was back to a tin of ratatouille over dry pasta. Flying is another favourite. You can book a vegetarian meal three months in advance, fax the airline, and confirm it in triplicate, but when you get to the airport you find no record of your booking and only one veggie meal on the plane. Flying to Canada last year, the budget airline we went with wanted to charge £8 per head. For airline food. There are so many others. At every official dinner I've ever been to, the vegetarians have been served last and ended up getting an indeterminate stuffed vegetable while everyone else on the table is tucking into dessert. In pubs there is always the ploughman's, but if you don't fancy a dry hunk of bread with some crusty old cheese and a thimble of pickle, you're stuck. I'm tired of soggy egg and cress sandwiches and quiche at weddings - which are always eaten by the carnivores anyway. Tired of the fact that food critics never mention vegetarian food because they are all confirmed meat eaters, so there's no pressure on restaurants to change or be inventive. And tired of being treated as if I'm some sort of lower life form. The veggie pound is not going to disappear. Get used to it.

fields.headline: The fine art of fashion
fields.standfirst: Look after that designer dress in your wardrobe - it could be a masterpiece, says  Hadley Freeman
fields.trailText: Look after that designer dress in your wardrobe - it could be a masterpiece, says Hadley Freeman.
fields.body:
Combining fashion and art used to suggest only one thing: Mona Lisa T-shirts, available from all good museum gift shops at £10.99. Now, though, art and fashion are not just having a light flirtation, but are dating, moving in together and having a full-blown love affair, and this marriage has parented a whole host of fashionably arty and artistically fashionable events.

In the United States, fashion has had an artistic credibility for longer, due in part to the appointment in 1972 of former Vogue editor Diana Vreeland as consultant to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute. There, visitors have been able to enjoy exhibitions celebrating Yves Saint Laurent (1983), Haute Couture (1995) and Christian Dior (1996), among others. Next May, instead of celebrating JFK's political achievements, the Costume Institute is f ting his wife's sartorial ones, with "Jacqueline Kennedy, the White House Years", curated by US Vogue's European editor-at-large, Hamish Bowles.

The Guggenheim has responded in kind, with a celebration of Giorgio Armani's 25 years in fashion opening this October, as well as a retrospective of the current designer du jour (again), Azzedine Alaia. And as befits a designer whose work emphasises artistry and construction, Yohji Yamamoto is planning to curate a fashion exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

Nor is this veneration of fashion designers happening only in famously fashion-conscious New York. Fashion fiends around the world can visit exhibitions on Viktor and Rolf (Utrecht), Gianfranco Ferre (Florence) and Alexander McQueen (Avignon) this year. Meanwhile, London has recently played host to an exhibition on Vivienne Westwood and for the past year the V&A has been putting on monthly fashion shows by modern designers, such as Matthew Williamson and Stella McCartney. Fear not if you've missed these: next month Newcastle's Laing Art Gallery will be exhibiting dresses by Todd Oldfield, and in 2001 the Zandra Rhodes Museum of Fashion and Textiles opens, featuring the works of Rhodes and her contemporaries.

This intermixing of art and fashion is not happening only in cold museum exhibition halls, but also on a more practical level, with fashion designers creating works of art and vice-versa. This month, fashionable French boutique Colette is putting on an exhibi tion with works by Jeremy Scott, Nicholas Ghesquiere and Veronique Branquinho. Conversely, artists such as trendy British sketcher Ben Saffer have been invited to customise pairs of Levi jeans. Now that fashion photography is accepted as an art form in its own right, fashion, too, seems to be gaining a (fashionably late) admittance into the artistic canon.

Like art, fashion can reflect sociological and political beliefs, such as the birth of the androgynous look in the 60s which anticipated the emergence of feminism, or the old truism that skirt lengths rise when the economy is strong, reflecting the public's sense of self-confidence. A look back at the fashions from the past - from herringbone corsets and pantaloons, to vest tops and combat trousers - provides an insight into our changing self-perceptions and beliefs; in this way, it is not a world apart from an examination of medieval Crucifixions and Damien Hirst's dead sheep. And if art history is finally an accepted academic pursuit, why not fashion history?

Edwina Ehrman, curator of Costume and Decorative art at the Museum of the City of London, agrees. "I think, certainly, dress historians are looking at clothes as cultural artefacts, how they relate to the economic conditions of the period. Just 10 years ago, this was definitely not an accepted study, but now it is becoming so.

"The public has become more aware of fashion in this context, simply because the media is so full of different perspectives of it, looking at why there is an 80s revival, and so on."

This attitude is reflected in the museum exhibitions. They do not simply present a load of frocks hanging on inert dummies, but place the designer into a kind of fashion context. The Guggenheim, for example, will show the influences at play in Armani's designs, as well as the effect of his designs on popular culture.

And not only is art becoming more fashionable, but fashion is becoming more arty. Hussein Chalayan's Autumn/Winter 2000 show was more performance art than fashion show, with models reshaping their outfits into items of homewear. Ehrman cites this more conceptual approach to fashion as further proof that art and fashion "are moving closer together".

As if in return for putting fashion in museums, art is now creeping into fashion and beauty stores. At the New York flagship store of beauty supermarket Sephora, one quarter of the space is devoted to temporary art exhibitions, so shoppers can now admire sculptures of nudes while they shop for the perfect shade of lipstick. Similarly, at the Shu Uemera store on Boulevard St-Germain in Paris there is currently an exhibition of works by the sculptor Gudy, whose husband, in a further crossover between art and fashion, was formerly the creative partner of fashion designer Daniel Hechter. "Fashion is an applied art and you get so many cross-elements," says Ehrman. "So it seems to me perfectly right to show art in fashion stores, and it will probably come to London soon."

Occasionally, the art shows in stores become about fashion itself. Last March at Colette, much of the clothing on sale was in "rodeo country style", coinciding with their exhibition, Rodeo Girl by Lisa Eisner. At Sephora, the artworks are used to promote the general mood and idea of the store. "Everything I select to show is based on conventional ideas of beauty - no elephant dung paintings here!" laughs creative director Tanya Pushkine-Rojas. "We want to show the artistic equivalent of what Sephora aims to do for women."

We wear clothes for practical purposes, but few would argue that aesthetics come into the equation. Indeed, looking at a woman shivering in a strappy dress at midnight, or a man sweating it out on a summer's day to show off his cashmere coat, you could say that aesthetics has the greater pull.

High streets are currently choking with patterned fashion, with people looking like canvasses of modern art: blouses with polka dots, dresses with swirling Pucci prints ... So is fashion simply wearable art? Colette's co-owner, Sarah, is cautious about taking this idea too far. "There is a crossover between fashion and art, but fashion is not art and art is not fashion. However, they do inspire one another."

As for art popping up in stores, one could take a more cynical approach. At lifestyle stores such as Colette and DKNY in New York, the artwork displays are part of the lifestyle experience, convincing the shopper that they are part of a cultural movement and not just shopping. Anjali Lewis, vice-president of marketing and communications at DKNY, points out that the artwork is also financially beneficial to the store, binging in customers to visit the exhibitions. Sephora has also figured this out and, says Pushkine-Rojas, takings have increased "significantly" since the store became a "cultural destination" last April.

Lewis is quick to add, though, that Donna Karan's appreciation of the art is not simply mercenary: "Donna loves all things designed, and it doesn't stop at clothing."

With museums putting on fashion exhibitions, and fashion stores putting on art exhibitions, fashion may begin to disrobe itself of the public's prejudices against the popularly perceived superficiality of the fashion world. Few can afford a Versace dress or an Armani suit, but that shouldn't blind us to the artistry of the design, just as the price tag on a Picasso shouldn't hinder our enjoyment of the painting.

Of course, fashion should always be fun, and if you take it too seriously, you risk becoming a po-faced, irony-free fashion dullard - not very stylish at all. But with Armani at the Guggenheim and Anna Sui at the V&A, perhaps fashion will at last be seen as more than just a guilty pleasure. Tom Ford as the new Damien Hirst? Truly, art is the new black.

fields.headline: Most wanted: caffeine lipstick
fields.trailText: Life is just full of complications. Take mornings, for example. There you are, washed, dressed, beautifully made-up. You down that much needed hit of caffeine as you run for the bus, you glance at the cup as you're about to throw it away and ... it's all a disaster. Your perfectly applied lipstick is now smeared inelegantly all over the Styrofoam instead of on your mouth.
fields.body:
Life is just full of complications. Take mornings, for example. There you are, washed, dressed, beautifully made-up. You down that much needed hit of caffeine as you run for the bus, you glance at the cup as you're about to throw it away and ... it's all a disaster. Your perfectly applied lipstick is now smeared inelegantly all over the Styrofoam instead of on your mouth.

This really is a quandary to rival that of the chicken and the egg - which should come first, the make-up or breakfast? Praise heaven for those lovely people at Hard Candy who have resolved this beauty paradox for us. Hard Candy's Caffeine Lipsticks (£13.50 each) are laced with caffeine and menthol, so you get that requisite chemical wake-up call from within your cosmetics, without having to sacrifice one for the other.

The only problem is, though, you will have as much difficulty dithering over which shade of lipstick to use as you do over which kind of coffee to slurp. Shall it be Lip Achino, Latte Lip or Cafe O Lip? Make-up and coffee all in one - what else could a glamourous modern-day girl require?

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours given electro-shock therapy yet still expected to function as normal
fields.trailText: All the papers seem to think AC Milan are coming back for more in their bid to land David Beckham. Or coming "Beck" for more, as some of them so excellently put it. Apparently, despite being told to sling their hook by new Manchester United chief executive Peter Kenyon, the Italian giants are convinced they can persuade Beckham to join them, claiming he has already discussed the move with his wife Victoria. "Beckham cannot manage to free himself," said Milan's frustrated vice-president Adriano Galliani, who is now prepared to pay Beckham £125,000 a week.
fields.body:
All the papers seem to think AC Milan are coming back for more in their bid to land David Beckham. Or coming "Beck" for more, as some of them so excellently put it. Apparently, despite being told to sling their hook by new Manchester United chief executive Peter Kenyon, the Italian giants are convinced they can persuade Beckham to join them, claiming he has already discussed the move with his wife Victoria. "Beckham cannot manage to free himself," said Milan's frustrated vice-president Adriano Galliani, who is now prepared to pay Beckham £125,000 a week.

Milan's shopping list does not end with David Beckham, by the way. They are also waving £37m at Valencia in order to get their hands on Gaizka Mendieta.

The Express claim Arsenal are planning a £7m bid for Belgium's Emile Mpenza. The striker nearly moved to Rangers but Dick Advocaat was unwilling to match Schalke 04's valuation - Arsene Wenger has no such problem.

Chelsea are ready to join Roma in the chase for Internazionale defender Christian Panucci, according to the Daily Mail. The 27-year-old Italian would prefer to stay in his homeland, but Gianluca Vialli has not given up hope - he will offer either Didier Deschamps or Frank Leboeuf in a £5m player-plus-cash deal.

Barcelona presidential candidate Juan Gaspart has promised to sign Marc Overmars and Emmanuel Petit if he is elected on Sunday. He will offer Arsenal £32m for the pair.

Bradford are ready to follow up their £1.5m capture of Sunderland's Nicky Summerbee with a bid for Coventry striker John Aloisi.

Charlton are interested in South Africa international Shaun Bartlett. The FC Zurich striker would cost Alan Curbishley £2m.

Celtic have joined West Ham and Leicester in the race for Newcastle's Temuri Ketsbaia.

Spurs goalkeeper Espen Baardsen wants to move to Gillingham, but talks are stalling over his wage demands.

Wimbledon are close to signing Newcastle striker Paul Robinson. Terry Burton has agreed a £1.5m fee with Bobby Robson for the 21-year-old.

Argentinian wonderchild Julio Arca is set to sign for Sunderland in a £3.5m deal.

Wimbledon and Wolves are battling to land Reading's Darren Caskey. Meanwhile, Portsmouth are planning to entice Royals defender Leroy Primus away from the Madjeski Stadium.

Roberto Baggio is interested in a move to Udinese. The Internazionale midfielder said: "I want to go to a club where I will be able to demonstrate quality and continuity. Udinese is one serious side. In effect, it is not far for me and will perhaps make the Uefa Cup. And it has a trainer, De Canio, that appeals to me."

webTitle: Doctor guilty of poor work spanning a decade

fields.headline: Doctor guilty of poor work spanning a decade
fields.standfirst: General Medical Council, which let gynaecologist practise despite Canadian ban, will now rule on whether to strike him off
fields.trailText: Richard Neale, a consultant gynaecologist given a job in Yorkshire 15 years ago after being struck off in Canada over the death of a patient, was yesterday found guilty of a catalogue of incompetence, bad practice and lies spanning his time in Britain.
fields.body:
Richard Neale, a consultant gynaecologist given a job in Yorkshire 15 years ago after being struck off in Canada over the death of a patient, was yesterday found guilty of a catalogue of incompetence, bad practice and lies spanning his time in Britain.

A disciplinary tribunal of the General Medical Council, the doctors' regulatory body, found he had operated without the full consent of patients, carried out unnecessary and substandard treatment and failed to monitor his patients properly.

All but one of 34 allegations against Neale relating to bad practice between 1986 and 1996 and claiming qualifications he did not have in 1997 were found proved by the GMC's professional conduct committee yesterday at the end of nearly six weeks of hearings.

Neale faces being struck off the medical register in the UK if the committee decides next week, after mitigation hearings, that his behaviour amounted to serious professional misconduct.

The case is likely to have serious repercussions. At the heart of the campaign against Richard Neale has been Sheila Wright-Hogeland, who led a victim support group and was also one of the complainants whose case was heard by the GMC's professional conduct committee.

She was first diagnosed and treated in Paris in 1990. Apparently recovered, she returned to London, but later that year she collapsed. She saw Mr Neale who told her she was suffering from ovulation pains.

Over the next five years, she continued to suffer acute shooting pains in the pelvis and abdomen. By December 1994, she was also suffering bleeding and in January 1995, Mr Neale noticed her swollen abdomen.

The following month she had a total hysterectomy for what Mr Neale told her was the worst case of endometriosis he had seen.

fields.headline: Jagger wants Jude
fields.trailText: Jude Law is Mick Jagger's choice to portray the Rolling Stones singer in a movie based on the rock group's life
fields.body:
Jude Law is Mick Jagger's choice to portray the Rolling Stones singer in a movie based on the rock group's life.

The ageing rocker reckons that the fresh-faced and Oscar-nominated actor would be ideal for the film, which is loosely based on the singer and the 1970s music scene. "It's mainly about the Machiavellian deals and relationships in the record industry," said Jagger.

A friend of the singer said, "Jude has been pencilled in for the part - at least as far as Mick's concerned."

"Mick has already written the script and it's going to be filmed by Martin Scorsese. Someone suggested Jude to him, saying that the actor had the same kind of presence Mick had as a young man."

Jagger recently formed a production company, Jagged Films, which is currently working on its first project - a version of Robert Harris's second world war thriller Enigma, starring Kate Winslet and Dougray Scott. The Rolling Stones film will be its second project.

fields.headline: I is coming
fields.trailText: Ali G is leaving Staines and heading for Hollywood to star in a series of movies
fields.body:
Ali G is leaving Staines and heading for Hollywood. The character's creator, the Cambridge-educated Sacha Baron Cohen, has signed a multi-million dollar contract to write, produce and star in movies centring on his infamous comic creation.

A source said, "This is the deal of all deals - it is extraordinary in the business. He may make Ali G act naively, but Sacha himself is totally aware of the business side of things. He doesn't miss a trick."

The 'Ali G Project' will also see the 28-year-old's other characters hitting Hollywood - including his politically-incorrect roving reporter from eastern Europe, Borat Karabzhanov.

webTitle: How England almost played a World XI this summer

fields.headline: How England almost played a World XI this summer
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's gossip column today, Charles de Lisle lifts the lid on the ECB's contingency plans to replace Zimbabwe, explains how Keith Medlycott has made the big-time at last and reveals the cricketer who still admires Hansie Cronje
fields.trailText: The series that never was: England v Rest of the World - this summer
fields.body:
The series that never was: England v Rest of the World - this summer

It could easily have been New Zealand, not Zimbabwe, contesting this weekend's one-day final at Lord's. It has emerged that, when it looked as though Zimbabwe's tour of England might have to be called off owing to the escalating political crisis back home, the ECB drew up contingency plans to rescue its most ambitious international schedule.

As the ECB confirms, New Zealand would have been invited to replace Zimbabwe in the triangular one-day tournament, and a Rest of the World XI would have been hastily assembled to take on England in the first two Tests of the season. "We would have had to fulfil our commitments to everyone, sponsors included," says an ECB spokesman. "But we never started picking a Rest of the World team."

Who might have been chosen? Well, West Indies and Pakistan were busy in the Caribbean in May, so the World XI would have had to comprise players from India, Sri Lanka, Australia, South Africa - and New Zealand. Much would have depended on the counties' willingness to release highly paid stars such as Shane Warne and Rahul Dravid, though in its desperation to fill grounds and airtime the ECB might have offered considerable compensation.

The match-fixing scandal would have been another complication for the selectors, as the reputation of this or that big name suddenly became sullied following almost daily revelations. Other difficulties would have been players' previous commitments - Shaun Pollock and Lance Klusener were both on honeymoon at the time - and injuries (Allan Donald was, as it turned out, out of action).

How about this for a suitable XII to take on England in "Tests" at Lord's and Trent Bridge, chosen from those who were then in the top 20 of the PricewaterhouseCoopers Test rankings ? Gary Kirsten, Dravid, Justin Langer, Jacques Kallis, Aravinda de Silva, Steve Waugh (captain), Adam Gilchrist, Chris Cairns, Warne, Javagal Srinath, Glenn McGrath and Daniel Vettori.

On second thoughts, the ECB might have been tempted to invite a weaker, perhaps slightly younger, side, to give England more of a chance.

Whatever the line-up, the series would surely have proved more attractive to sponsors, broadcasters and the public than the two Tests against Zimbabwe which actually took place. If the matches had been half as entertaining as the only previous England-Rest of the World meeting - in 1970, when Garry Sobers' powerful side beat England 4-1, in a series which replaced the cancelled South Africa tour - they would have been worth every penny.

Medlycott finally gets his 15 minutes of fame

The all-star exhibition game at The Oval next week marks a long-overdue appearance in the big time for Keith Medlycott, the Surrey cricket manager, who has been chosen to manage the Rest of the World XI taking on Asia.

The Rest of the World job is the ultimate accolade for Medlycott. A left-arm spinner who could really turn the ball, he never played for England, despite touring the West Indies under Graham Gooch in 1989-90, at the age of 24.

Within three years, Medlycott had been dropped from the Surrey staff after suffering a disastrous loss of confidence and control on an England A tour of Sri Lanka and going through the 1992 season without getting a first-team game. His playing days were over: the yips, as spinners call the affliction, had, sadly, done for him.

That nightmare period will be a distant memory on Saturday July 29, when Medlycott, still only 35 and already a County Championship-winning manager, will be in charge of the likes of Courtney Walsh, Shane Warne and Heath Streak. Decked out in specially designed navy outfits, they take on an all-star Asia line-up led by Sachin Tendulkar and including Wasim Akram, Mohammad Azharuddin and Surrey's own Saqlain Mushtaq, clad in yellow.

And Medlycott's role? "Basically being a nursemaid, " says Surrey's spokesman, Toby Codrington. "Medders will make sure the guys turn up on time for everything, from the dinner at Greenwich 36 hours before the game to the team photocall shortly before play starts. He'll also take nets, though they will mostly be voluntary."

The match will be played to one-day international rules, televised by Sky Digital and others, and should raise £400,000 towards the ground's planned interactive museum and educational facility. For tickets, ring 020 7582 7764. And there's one star turn I almost forgot to mention: Dickie Bird is emerging from retirement to umpire.

The England player who still admires Cronje

Among those hoping to make a mark for England Under-19s in the one-day series against Sri Lanka, starting next week, is Ian Pattison. An all-rounder from Durham, Pattison is an outswing bowler who made his county debut last August and made the tour party for the Under-19 World Cup in Sri Lanka last winter.

However the most remarkable thing about the well-built Pattison may be his choice of role model. In his official pen portrait, released by the ECB last week, he says his favourite players are Steve Waugh - and Hansie Cronje.

Waugh is an uncontroversial choice, shared with several Under-19 team-mates, but Cronje? "I admire the way he leads - or rather led - South Africa," replies Pattison, fresh from hitting 89 for Durham Under-19s against their Yorkshire counterparts.

Isn't Cronje rather a tarnished hero? "I wouldn't like to comment," says Pattison, adding quickly: "I admire him as a cricketer, as an all-rounder. And I admired his leadership skills."

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). You can e-mail him at cdelisle@compuserve.com

webTitle: Strong pound blamed as steel firm axes 1,300 jobs

fields.headline: Strong pound blamed as steel firm axes 1,300 jobs
fields.trailText: Steel firm Corus today announced it is to axe 1,300 jobs in an attempt to cut costs, blaming the strong pound.
fields.body:
Steel firm Corus today announced it is to axe 1,300 jobs in an attempt to cut costs, blaming the strong pound.

Corus said the latest redundancies will mainly hit its plants at Llanwern, Port Talbot and Ebbw Vale. The job losses follow 2,400 job losses announced in the past few weeks at other Corus plants, which were also blamed on the strength of sterling.

Nick Cragg, managing director of Corus Strip Products, said: "The competitive position of Corus in the UK has been severely affected by the sustained strength of sterling against the euro."

Unions today described the announcement as a "devastating blow" to workers, whose productivity they said was amongst the highest in the world.

Michael Leahy, general secretary of the Iron and Steel Trades Confederation, said steel unions would hold a special summit next week to try to save jobs in the industry."Britain will need a manufacturing base with a strong steel industry if fast and stable economic growth is to be maintained," he said.

Corus, formed by last year's merger between British Steel and Dutch firm Hoogovens, said most of the job losses would be achieved next year. Volunteers would now be sought, but the firm admitted it could not rule out compulsory redundancies.

Corus said there will 450 job losses at Llanwern, which employs 3,000 workers, and 400 at Port Talbot, which has a workforce of 3,500. Both plants produce sheet steel for the motor industry, goods such as freezers and cladding for buildings. There will be 300 redundancies split between Ebbw Vale and Trostre, near Llanelli, which produce tin plate. Most of the losses will be at Ebbw Vale. Another 150 job losses will be spread between Shotton in North Wales, Tafarnaubach, near Tredegar, Bryngwyn in Gorseinon, Pontardulais, and a coated strip mill near Birmingham.

Mr Cragg said the job losses were "regrettable", but despite the recent weakening of the pound, it remained 15% higher than at January 1999. "In a business where we and our customers rely significantly on exports to mainland Europe, we have seen our financial position seriously eroded. We have to reduce our costs and become more efficient in order to secure a viable future."

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "This is a short term fix that will hit steel communities very hard."

Bill Morris, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, voiced anger that Corus had not discussed with unions how overcapacity problems can be tackled. "This is another example of British workers being too cheap and too easy to sack," he said.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, said: "This action by Corus is disgusting. They are destroying the industry with a thousand cuts. Our members in the Welsh communities affected are distraught and we are seeking urgent talks with the company."

The Welsh first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, urged Corus to "look seriously" at its strategy for the European steel industry. "The steel industry makes a vital contribution to the Welsh economy," he said. "The knock-on effect will be considerable."

The Welsh secretary, Paul Murphy, added: "I very much hope that, notwithstanding the very regrettable job losses, this will consolidate the position of the Welsh plant."

Employment minister Tessa Jowell said: "Anyone who is made redundant will benefit from all the support and advice offered by the employment service's rapid response unit, which was set up to deal with major job losses."

fields.headline: Obituary: Vahe Oshagan
fields.standfirst: Icon and iconoclast for the Armenian people
fields.trailText: Vahe Oshagan, who has died aged 78, was a critic, political activist, renegade poet and prolific novelist, professor of literature and iconoclast.
fields.body:
Vahe Oshagan, who has died aged 78, was a critic, political activist, renegade poet and prolific novelist, professor of literature and iconoclast. Known as the voice of the Armenian diaspora, he also infuriated clerics, politicians and intellectuals by challenging the foundation myths of his ancient and far-flung people; he even queried whether there was one Armenian culture.

Yet Oshagan ended his days cherished as a cultural icon in his own right, both in his adopted homeland of America, and in the newly independent Caucasian republic of Armenia. Above all, he inspired future generations of diaspora Armenians. His message for young Armenian writers, was "Move! Do not remain paralysed in one place, change your environment!" His own journeying showed that he practised what he preached.

Oshagan was born in Plovdiv, Bulgaria, to the literary critic, Hagop Oshagan, and his wife, Araxie Astardjian Oshagan. He grew up first in Egypt, and then in Cyprus; the family later settled in Jerusalem, whose Armenian Quarter remains a valued religious outpost of the global Armenian community.

He gained a doctorate in comparative literature from the Paris Sorbonne in 1951. It was in Beirut, however, where he established his reputation as a firebrand. From 1952 he taught philosophy, psychology and literature at numerous institutions, including the American University of Beirut.

As a poet, he alarmed literary circles by spurning the traditional metre of Armenian verse, and by using the vernacular instead of formal Armenian. Three of his eight volumes of poetry were published there: Baduhan (Window), 1956; Kaghak (City), 1963; and Karughi (Intersection), 1971. He also joined Dashnaktsutiun, the Armenian Revolutionary Federation, and later published weekly columns for their American paper, Asbarez.

In 1975, uprooted once again as civil war swept Lebanon. he spent the next quarter century in Philadelphia. From 1976 to 1982 he taught Armenian literature, history and culture at the University of Pennsylvania. The American cityscape became the focus of his work, as exemplified by his 1980 epic, Ahazank (Alert). By contrast, most Armenian writers remained wedded to the rural settings of an idyllic past.

Yet Oshagan still felt compelled to move. He spent two years from 1992 lecturing at the University of Macquarie in Sydney, Australia; then held classes at the University of California at Berkeley, California; and taught in Canada, Europe and the Middle East.

In his last years, he renewed his bond with "eastern Armenians". Braving the war of the 90s, he lectured at the state university of Nagorno-Karabakh, Armenia's beleagured enclave within the rival state of Azerbaijan. His last book, as yet unpublished, is The Spirit of Karabakh.

True to form, Oshagan lambasted the shortcomings of the republic's new rulers. At the first major conference to reunite the two wings of the Armenian world, held last September in Yerevan, he criticised easterners for unwarranted disdain towards, and ignorance of, their diaspora cousins. "The diaspora is [also] a front", he said. "We are all soldiers of the Armenian people."

Oshagan analysed the impact of the region's bloody history on Armenian prose and poetry and argued that its people should not close themselves off from the outside world. Nor should they jettison their identity by totally assimilating into western society.

One of his greatest feats was to introduce the richness of Armenian culture to the English-speaking world, as editor of the yearly periodical, Raft, first published in 1987.

Oshagan reserved his fiercest attack for the church. In his 1988 short story Odzum (Consecration), published in a volume entitled Around the Trap, he describes how three masked revolutionaries enter a tired old Armenian church in downtown Philadelphia, shout, kiss, smoke, and ultimately strip the parish priest to his underpants. Not surprisingly, many Armenian clerics called Oshagan a blaspheming pornographer, even "an Armenian Rushdie". Yet Oshagan hints at the true message in Odzum. The priest continues administering the sacrament despite his literal defrocking. To Oshagan, his personal integrity represents true Armenian heroism - not the trappings of faith and custom, nor the self-pitying ranting of the hotheads.

Clearly others saw the true worth of his writing. In 1994, diaspora Armenians celebrated a 50-year retrospective of his achievements; two years later he received the St Mesrob Mashtots Medal from the Catholics of the Armenian church; and in 1998 Armenia's president awarded him a prize for contribution to Armenian letters.

Oshagan was a living paradox: a rebel, a champion of individual liberty, and a one-man repository of his nation's rich heritage. He saw in the survival and creativity of his people reason to dispel their fears and confusions, and offer real hope for the future.

He is survived by his wife, Arsine, and two sons.

Vahe Oshagan, writer, lecturer, critic, political activist, born 1922; died June 30 2000

webTitle: Hurley to stand trial for strike-breaking

fields.headline: Hurley to stand trial for strike-breaking
fields.trailText: The Screen Actors Guild are to try Liz Hurley later this month after she crossed a picket line to film an advert for Estee Lauder
fields.body:
Liz Hurley is to stand trial for crossing a strike picket line to film an advert for Estee Lauder. Hurley has apologised to her fellow actors in the Screen Actors Guild (SAG), and claims she didn't know about the strike (see our earlier story).

Her movie agent Tracey Jacobs defended her dippy charge: "Liz was completely unaware of the situation because she doesn't live in [the US] and she is extremely apologetic about it. Had she known it was strike work, she would have never done it. She is very supportive of her union."

This doesn't cut any ice with Hurley's fellow union members. Strike co-ordinator Gordon Drake said, "Elizabeth Hurley has aggravated a great many people. She doesn't even have the respect to apologise directly. Her agent has said she had no idea it was going on. Our response to that is that it is crap. She must read papers or watch TV and we simply don't believe her agent didn't know or tell her."

Hurley will now be ordered to attend a trial later this month so that SAG members can determine if the actress will be fined or simply thrown out of the guild.

Drake added, "We have started the process of Ms Hurley's trial. If she doesn't attend we will throw her out. If she does attend we will make her donate her fee for the advert to the strike, publicly apologise and pull the advert. We won't accept anything less."

webTitle: US elections prove a TV turn-off

fields.headline: US elections prove a TV turn-off
fields.standfirst: Fewer Americans than ever before are likely to watch this year's party conventions on television, which may mean fewer people at the ballot boxes too, writes Washington correspondent Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: Fewer Americans than ever before are likely to watch this year's party conventions on television, which may mean fewer people at the ballot boxes too, writes Washington correspondent Martin Kettle
fields.body:
For years, the central axiom of modern campaigning has been that elections are won and lost on television. So, it must say something about the state of American politics that fewer people than ever are expected to watch this summer's two party conventions on television than ever before.

It is also ironic that America's national television networks are busy scaling down their coverage of the upcoming conventions to the lowest in years.

Four years ago in San Diego, the Republicans ran a slick, controlled convention from which every possible negative image was ruthlessly expunged. Journalists began moaning that what had once been a fibrous and newsworthy part of the political process was being turned into an "infomercial". The ABC network anchor Ted Koppel even pulled out of San Diego after two days in protest, taking his crew with him.

When the Republicans gather in Philadelphia on July 31 for their 2000 convention, the television networks will be back. But only just.

Until this week, when they were forced to change their plans, ABC had been intending to cover the opening night of the convention only in the halftime interval of a pre-season American football game, with longer reports on the other three nights. CBS, which had been planning to cover just two of the four nights at Philadelphia, said on Monday that it now intends to offer at least some coverage every night.

But the bottom line in Philadelphia - and in the August 14-17 Democratic convention in Los Angeles too - is that things ain't what they used to be. In the 1970s, the networks were there every night offering extensive live coverage. In 1976, a peak year, the conventions had a combined rating of 35. points, meaning that 35 per cent of all American households were watching the conventions in an average broadcasting minute.

By 1996, the rating was down to 24 points, the lowest yet recorded. The average family watched less than four hours during the two conventions last time round. No one expects that record to survive the 2000 convention season.

Part of the reason for the likely slump this year is the revolution in television news. While the networks stay away, or scale down their coverage, their cable subsidiaries and their competitors are actually increasing their broadcast hours. MSNBC will in effect take over political coverage from its parent NBC. CNN will offer nearly 100 hours coverage from each of the conventions.

But the mathematics of such flexibility points steadily downwards. CNN may hope to put 10 per cent on its audiences in convention weeks, but the cutbacks on the networks - which reach many more households than the cable channels do - mean that the overall numbers of convention viewers will be the smallest ever.

This decline is matched by a downturn in interest. Harvard university's Kennedy School of Government reported this week that 43 per cent of voters in a poll for their "Vanishing Voter Project" said they did not plan to watch any of the Republican convention, while 38 per cent didn't expect to tune in to the Democrats. Four years ago - when the record low was set - the corresponding figures were 23 per cent and 21 per cent.

One significant consequence is that both parties will feel driven to compensate by buying more advertising time. To pay for the increase in slots, the campaigns will have to raise even more money, including the "soft money" that so many people feel is debauching the electoral process. The break-up of the old media monopolies is increasing the power of the rich donors, another paradox.

The parties have invested a lot of time and muscle in trying to get more coverage for their conventions. The changes of heart by both ABC and CBS about their coverage only came after the Democrats scheduled Bill Clinton for an opening night address in LA, forcing the networks to cover the president and compelling them - on grounds of balance - to also cover General Colin Powell's opening night speech to the Republicans.

But the parties also know that the process of change is irreversible, and they are adapting to it. Both the conventions will be available live on the internet, as the parties try to reach out to more voters. The Republicans are inviting net surfers to become "dot.com delegates", while the Democrats are promising "E-mersion coverage".

From a media point of view, coverage of the 2000 conventions will be the most innovative yet. But the sober fact, in spite of all the new media, is that viewing will slump overall. It is not surprising that most forecasters think that, come election day on November 7, this lack of contact will ultimately mean that fewer people will vote this year than in any presidential election on record.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
You may have recently come across an email, which has been doing the rounds for the last week or so. It purports to be a transcript of out-takes from one of last year's episodes of BBC2's Have I Got News for You, featuring Sir Jimmy Saville.

With it goes just about every lesson you ever needed to learn about the perils of the electronic revolution: anything goes if it's in electronic form but you really shouldn't treat every email you read as gospel.

TV producers could never be accused of telling the truth, relying, as they do, on a whole series of out-takes before they hit on a version of events they're happy to broadcast. And this seems to have been the case with this particular episode of Have I Got News.

The supposed out-takes are said to have come from sources close to the producers and were being widely circulated over the internet at the end of last week.

Paul Merton is always a man to push the televisual boundaries of libel laws as far as they will stretch but the transcript went a lot further than anything you would have seen on the show. The trouble is - according to sources - a huge chunk of the middle section of the email is fabricated.

In one particularly terse exchange appearing in the "transcript", for example, Merton supposedly attacks Saville about his personal hygiene. In another, the comedian seemingly loses the plot completely and launches into an incoherent rant before being asked by a rattled Angus Deayton if he wants to stop the recording.

It may have been a piece of fiction, but it made an afternoon wading through 112 messages in Outlook a lot more amusing than it might otherwise have been.

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

webTitle: Mandelson makes euro peace with chancellor with Brown

fields.headline: Mandelson makes euro peace with chancellor with Brown
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson last night buried the hatchet with Gordon Brown over the European single currency when he gave his unequivocal backing to the chancellor's stance on the euro.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson last night buried the hatchet with Gordon Brown over the European single currency when he gave his unequivocal backing to the chancellor's stance on the euro.

In an attempt to heal the cabinet split over the currency, the Northern Ireland secretary lavished praise on Mr Brown as he threw his weight behind the government's "prepare and decide" policy.

Earlier, Tony Blair had attempted to maintain momentum over the euro when he reassured the Japanese prime minister that, in principle, he wanted Britain to join the currency. In a meeting with Yoshiro Mori in Tokyo, the prime minister attempted to reassure Japanese investors by speaking of his enthusiasm for the euro.

In London, Mr Mandelson insisted that the cabinet was united around the government policy to wait until after the next election before making an assessment of the suitability of British membership.

"There is no division over the principle, the tactics, the timing or any other aspects of joining the euro - and people should contrast that with the chasm in John Major's cabinet," Mr Mandelson told the cross-party Britain in Europe group.

Mr Mandelson, one of the most fervently pro-European members of the cabinet, set himself apart from the likes of Michael Heseltine when he voiced strong support for the chancellor's five economic tests. Mr Heseltine has dismissed the tests - set out in October 1997 - as a smokescreen to allow the government to wait until public hostility fades away.

fields.headline: Anti-euro campaign row
fields.standfirst:
Anti-euro Danish campaign sparks row

Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: British Eurosceptics last night sparked an international row over plans to spend nearly £100,000 campaigning for a "no" vote in Denmark's referendum on the single currency.
fields.body:
British Eurosceptics last night sparked an international row over plans to spend nearly £100,000 campaigning for a "no" vote in Denmark's referendum on the single currency.

Anti-euro diehards in the UK are to take out adverts in the Danish press urging that country to retain the kroner in a plebiscite on September 28.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, accused the Eurosceptics, backed by prominent Tories including Lady Thatcher, of meddling in Danish affairs.

The latest opinion poll showed Denmark effectively split over the single currency.

The European Commission fears a "no" vote could deal a potentially fatal blow to the fledgling currency, starting what one senior official described as a "domino effect" in other states.

Mr Cook said last night: "They must make their own decision in their own interests. Tory anti-Europeans should practise what they preach and stop interfering in Denmark's internal debate.

"Their intervention is nothing more than a cynical attempt to exploit the referendum to advance their agenda of withdrawal from the European Union."

Anders Panum, secretary general of the pro-single currency Danish European movement, said: "What would people in Britain say if the French and Germans were pouring money into a British referendum? I find this inappropriate."

The British-based Danish referendum campaign has so far raised £97,630. Among the fund-raising events was a £35 a plate dinner last Monday organised by the Romford Conservative Association with Lord Tebbit as guest speaker.

Far-right organisations, including the Bruges group and Anti-Common Market league, sponsor the appeal, which is chaired by the Tory MP John Townend with the former Labour cabinet minister Lord Shore a trustee.

The campaign claimed that if Denmark voted "yes", Sweden would probably follow next year, increasing pressure on Britain - the only EU country outside the eurozone - to give up sterling.

"If, however, the Danes vote 'no', the pro-euro campaign in Britain will be over before it begins," said a campaign leaflet which went on: "We are appealing directly to British men and women to defend the freedom of a friendly country. Here is an opportunity to assist our Danish allies while at the same time striking a blow for the pound here in Britain."

Daniel Hannan, the Tory Euro MP, denied the campaign represented unwarranted interference in another EU member. "We will not directly fund the 'no' campaign in Denmark, nor will we directly advise them," he said. "We will explain to them how we are keeping the pound and how if they vote 'no' they will be in perfectly good company and won't be isolated."

Simon Buckby, director of the pro-euro Britain in Europe group, said: "This is a cynical move by British anti-Europeans who are constantly saying that they want nothing to do with other European countries, but who have no qualms whatsoever about interfering with Denmark's referendum. Their campaign is not about the euro. It is about total withdrawal from Europe and British isolation."

The latest opinion poll for Denmark's Politiken newspaper found 40% in favour and 38% against, ending a series of "no" majorities, though still far below the 15% lead when the referendum was called last April.

Among the fund-raising events was a £35 a plate dinner last Monday organised by the Romford Conservative Association with Lord Tebbit as guest speaker. Far-right organisations, including the Bruges group and Anti-Common Market league, sponsor the appeal, which is chaired by the Tory MP John Townend with the former Labour cabinet minister Lord Shore a trustee. The campaign claimed that if Denmark voted "yes", Sweden would probably follow next year, increasing pressure on Britain - the only EU country outside the eurozone - to give up sterling. "If, however, the Danes vote 'no', the pro-euro campaign in Britain will be over before it begins," said a campaign leaflet which went on: "We are appealing directly to British men and women to defend the freedom of a friendly country. Here is an opportunity to assist our Danish allies while at the same time striking a blow for the pound here in Britain." Daniel Hannan, the Tory Euro MP, denied the campaign represented unwarranted interference in another EU member. "We will not directly fund the 'no' campaign in Denmark, nor will we directly advise them," he said. "We will explain to them how we are keeping the pound and how if they vote 'no' they will be in perfectly good company and won't be isolated." Simon Buckby, director of the pro-euro Britain in Europe group, said: "This is a cynical move by British anti-Europeans who are constantly saying that they want nothing to do with other European countries, but who have no qualms whatsoever about interfering with Denmark's referendum. Their campaign is not about the euro. It is about total withdrawal from Europe and British isolation." The latest opinion poll for Denmark's Politiken newspaper found 40% in favour and 38% against, ending a series of "no" majorities, though still far below the 15% lead when the referendum was called last April.

fields.headline: Why has Gene Hackman written a novel?
fields.standfirst: Michael Ellison talks literature over coffee and croissants with a living legend
fields.trailText: Michael Ellison talks literature over coffee and croissants with a living legend
fields.body:
The elderly gentleman in the black leather jerkin and baseball cap is more relaxed than any first-time novelist has a right to be. He leans back in his chair, affable as anything, releasing a throaty chuckle every now and then. The only sign of discomfort comes when he walks a little stiff-legged across the room to fetch a coffee and croissant. He offers no delineation of his literary vision; there is no agonising over the great issues tackled in the work; no discussion of the author's all-consuming need to write.

In fact, this one does not need to write. After more than 70 movies, two Oscars (for The French Connection and Unforgiven) and more nominations than he can recall, Gene Hackman doesn't need to do anything. His latest movie, Under Suspicion, will be released in the UK in the autumn. But there it is: at the age of 70, Hackman, a voracious reader, has published his first book. And then, out of nowhere, he mentions the reviews. Hackman says he never reads what people say about his movies, and maybe he doesn't, but the book is evidently a different matter.

"We had a review of the book, I don't know where it was, it said something about the book being, ummm, like it was immature or whatever. Maybe that wasn't the word but we set out to do a story about a young man who is 16 years old. You have to write it from his viewpoint."

But nobody ever called The Catcher in the Rye immature. "Maybe the narration could have been possibly a bit more intellectual, I don't know." Hackman might not know, but Daniel Lenihan, his friend, New Mexico neighbour and co-author, believes he does. "I don't think it's immature," he says. "There was one reviewer saying that this would be really good for young adults."

Apparently this was not the effect they were striving for. "Yeah, it's like the kiss of death really," says Hackman. "It doesn't hurt. Actually, in many ways it helps. I think many of the criticisms that we've received, even though we've got 90-something per cent good reviews, it's mainly valuable, ummm, unless they're talking about personalities. You know, here's another book from a movie actor, celebrity or whatever."

This double act, one of the world's most recognisable faces and his collaborator, who makes his living under the waves as a marine archaeologist, cooked up the idea for a novel one day in a cafe in Santa Fe. "We used to talk about books that we enjoyed," says Lenihan, head of the Submerged Cultural Resources Unit of the National Park Service, "and Gene of course is evaluating scripts all the time; and then we came up with 'Heck, why don't we just come up with a book like we like to read?' "

They like to read Robert Louis Stevenson, Conrad and Melville. What they came up with is Wake of the Perdido Star, a ripping yarn set in the early 19th century and replete with heroes and villains, rip-offs, revenge and redemption. It is a rite of passage which takes young Jack O'Reilly - a seafarer's name if ever there was one - halfway round the world, and sometimes the reader round the bend with its slight, sometimes cartoonish characterisations - a surprise given Hackman's stock-in-trade as an actor.

Much of it is written in a succession of short sentences so that there is a staccato effect, rather like reading old Daily Express accounts of the round-the-world voyages of Sir Francis Chichester and Sir Alec Rose before such ventures became a commonplace for almost everyone in possession of a compass.

The writers discuss the reaction to their book as though they were a couple of mature students considering a lecturer's observations. Hackman takes his time, deliberate in his choice of words; Lenihan, dressed just so in a sports jacket, is more jumpy and eager to make his points.

"You know, about the criticism," says Lenihan, "what I tend to find the most useful is the criticism that came from people who were writing basically laudatory critiques. 'This is a really fine book,' then they get about halfway through the sixth 'but,' which they have to do, and then you find the stuff that you really have to look at because you know this person didn't have some kind of agenda."

One review that they did not find helpful was in the Washington Post. It took a cat-o'-nine-tails to the story and then keelhauled it for good measure, ripping into the story for alleged technical and period detail errors. Lenihan wrote to the paper to take issue. "He found three or four mistakes, technical, which weren't mistakes," says Hackman. "And he was wrong about those too. This guy was a great fan of Patrick O'Brian (the late master of high seas fiction) and obviously he was trying to protect Patrick O'Brian's reputation. The funny thing is, Dan and I, neither one of us had read any Patrick O'Brian. Not that we had heard bad things about him. It's just one of those things." Lenihan then rather contradicts this apparant ignorance of O'Brian's work: "He's a fine writer. That's not our remit."

Hackman, at any rate, can live with a little negativity. As a young actor at the Pasadena Playhouse, he was one of two people voted least likely to succeed. The other was Dustin Hoffman. And what happened to the other actors, the ones who delivered the indictment? "Haven't heard from them," he laughs. "I'll tell you a funny story. There was this guy in our class at Pasadena and, oh, probably 10 or 12 years after I got out of the playhouse I was in California, brought out to a little part in a television show or something.

"I'm driving along and I see this guy on the street and I yell out the window, 'Hey, Steve, I saw you on Blue Light, I think it was called, on television.' So he said, 'Oh.' He didn't remember me. So I drove off and suddenly in my rear-view mirror I see this car going zin, zin, zin [motions from side to side] and it's this guy trying to catch me, driving like hell. So he gets up to me and we're driving along like that and he comes up aside of me and says 'It's gonna be repeated.' It wasn't enough that I like it, he wanted to make sure that I'd see it a second time."

There might be no second time for the writing team of Hackman and Lenihan. They took three years over this book and, even though they believe they could do another in a third of that time with the experience they have now, they discovered that their idea for a more contemporary novel has been used already in a recent book.

Hackman is not sure how his work in theatre and the movies informs his writing but agrees tentatively that he might have turned to the printed word as a way of validating himself in much the same way that many screen actors yearn to give the world their Hamlet. "Maybe. I've always kind of admired writers, the control or something."

He sees no reason why he should be restricted to one means of expression any more than he should make films that don't interest him. "That career planning that a lot of actors do backfires because you end up doing things that you feel are either going to be easy or financially attractive at the time as opposed to trying to stick with what you know about acting, which is all that any of us really knows. And, you know, let the chips fall where they may."

Gene on screen

Lilith (1964) His first substantial role, as an asylum inmate in Robert Rossen's bizarre fable of sexual desire, with Warren Beatty and Jean Seberg.

Bonnie and Clyde (1967) With Beatty again, playing Clyde's brother Buck in the seminal lovers-on-the-run thriller.

The French Connection (1971) Definitive star performance, as hardass cop Popeye Doyle on the track of drugs smuggled into New York via Marseilles. Won best actor Oscar.

The Poseidon Adventure (1972) Key entry in the disaster-movie cycle, as a butt-kicking padre who gets the survivors out of the upturned liner.

The Conversation (1974) As the sound recordist who overhears sinister goings-on in Coppola's paranoid classic.

Superman (1978) Nastily over-the-top as eternal baddie Lex Luthor in groundbreaking comic-book fantasy.

Mississippi Burning (1988) A crafty FBI agent after killers in the deep south in Alan Parker's 60s-set race-issue drama.

Unforgiven (1992) Another Oscar, for best supporting actor, for his portrayal of sherriff Little Bill Daggett in Clint Eastwood's revisionist western.

Crimson Tide (1995) Heavyweight talent opposite Denzel Washington in Tony Scott's subs-and-nukes drama.

Get Shorty (1995) Small-time producer Harry Zimm, object of mobster Travolta's movie-world ambitions.

Antz (1998) The voice of ruthless General Mandible in insect-world animation.

Enemy of the State (1998) Backwith Bruckheimer, as ex-spook helping on-the-run lawyer Will Smith, in a loose reworking of The Conversation.

webTitle: Home secretary's Jaguar stopped by police for speeding

fields.headline: Home secretary's Jaguar stopped by police for speeding
fields.trailText: Jack Straw, the home secretary, was pulled over by police as his official government car travelled at "high speed" down a motorway, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Jack Straw, the home secretary, was pulled over by police as his official government car travelled at "high speed" down a motorway, it emerged last night.

Traffic officers stopped the car on the M5 as Mr Straw was being driven by a special branch officer to Labour's national policy forum in Exeter.

The car was reported by the Sun newspaper to have been a Jaguar, travelling at 103mph. The car was stopped at 8.55am, when Mr Straw was allegedly late for a meeting with Tony Blair. The incident is particularly embarrassing for the home secretary who has called for "zero tolerance" policies.

Under court guidelines, any motorist going over 100mph can be banned from driving and fined up to £800.

Scotland Yard confirmed "an unmarked Metropolitan police car carrying the home secretary to an engagement was stopped on the M5 motorway by Avon and Somerset constabulary in relation to the speed that the vehicle was travelling".

The driver was reportedly booked by police. The Home Office confirmed that the incident had taken place.

A Home Office spokesman said: "We are confirming that the home secretary's car was stopped by Somerset and Avon police on Sunday, 9 July. We understand they are continuing to investigate the incident and it would be inappropriate to comment further."

Avon and Somerset police have yet to decide whether to take any further action, saying: "In common with normal procedure we are investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident."

It is another embarrassment for the government, coming just days after the damaging leak of a string of Downing Street documents and emails.

The leaks have caused difficulty for the government, and Tony Blair, particularly when it emerged that one of the memos penned by the prime minister mirrored an editorial published in the Daily Mail on the day that he put pen to paper.

Also, two weeks ago, Mr Blair's son Euan was arrested after being found slumped drunk in London's West End - shortly after he had called for action against drunken yobs.

Mr Straw's son was ticked off by police in December 1997 for selling £10 worth of cannabis to an undercover reporter.

The home secretary came under immediate fire from Glen Smyth, chairman of the Metropolitan police branch of the Police Federation, which represents rank and file police officers.

Mr Smyth told the Sun: "It makes the promise to be tough on crime and the causes of crime to be a shabby one. The home secretary needs to lead by example and this is not the example to set."

fields.headline: Cook fends off rights criticism
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, defended his ethical foreign policy yesterday in the face of criticism that he was soft on human rights abuses in China, Russia and Saudi Arabia.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, defended his ethical foreign policy yesterday in the face of criticism that he was soft on human rights abuses in China, Russia and Saudi Arabia.

The accusations followed the publication yesterday of the Foreign Office's annual report, detailing its record in dealing with human rights worldwide.

Amnesty International and other groups accused Mr Cook of toning down criticism in countries where Britain had a strong commercial interest. In the report, Human Rights, Mr Cook defended engagement with China, Russia and Saudi Arabia. He said a tough line worked with some countries but "there will be other times when critical engagement, dialogue and encouragement is more likely to produce results."

The report acknowledged that human rights in China had been marked last year by high profile arrests and maltreatment of activists, but added that the British government has "combined criticism with encouragement for reform."

webTitle: Livingstone claims 'stitch-up' over £104m Jubilee line bill

fields.headline: Livingstone claims 'stitch-up' over £104m Jubilee line bill
fields.standfirst: London Charge 'will delay projects'
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone reignited his feud with Labour yesterday when he rounded on the government for "stitching" him up over the £3.2bn spending   package for transport in London.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone reignited his feud with Labour yesterday when he rounded on the government for "stitching" him up over the £3.2bn spending package for transport in London.

The recent thaw in relations between the London mayor and the government came to an abrupt end when Mr Livingstone discovered that he had been lumbered with an outstanding £104m debt for the Jubilee line extension.

"It's bizarre," Mr Livingstone told a news conference called in the wake of John Prescott's statement about his national transport plan. "Did someone in the Treasury forget to pay the bill and were they waiting for the first available sap to pay for it? It is tragic to have come so close and then to hear the Treasury have done a great doo-doo on the mayor's doorstep."

Mr Livingstone said that the government's decision to deduct nearly half of his initial £218m allocation to pay for the Jubilee line would delay a series of projects in London. These include the extension to the east London line, a new Wimbledon to Hackney tube line, a new east Thames river crossing, and improvement of links to Heathrow airport to cope with the new terminal five.

Mr Livingstone, who is due to receive £3.2bn phased in over three years, said he was only told about the Jubilee debt on Wednesday. "In a devastating blow at 4.30pm [on Wednesday] we had a fax from the government saying: 'By the way we have discovered we still owe £104m for the building of the Jubilee line and you'll have to pay for that as well."

Keith Hill, minister for London, said that the government had met Mr Livingstone's demands for more money. "We gave Ken the £3bn he asked for - and more - and this [Jubilee line] money is over and above that sum. All in all this is a great deal for London and Londoners."

webTitle: War widows who wed get pension lift

fields.headline: War widows who wed get pension lift
fields.trailText: War widows and widowers who remarry or move in with a new partner will retain the right to collect a pension when new rules are introduced in the autumn, the government announced yesterday.
fields.body:
War widows and widowers who remarry or move in with a new partner will retain the right to collect a pension when new rules are introduced in the autumn, the government announced yesterday.

The changes, presented by the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, will recognise and reflect the "exceptional circumstances" of those who die serving their country.

Since 1973 those whose spouses died either in service or "for reasons attributable to service in the armed forces" have been eligible for a pension from the Ministry of Defence's armed forces pension scheme unless they remarry or cohabit.

Mr Darling said yesterday the government had listened to the representations of the War Widows' Association and others and accepted that members of the armed forces were in a "unique position".

webTitle: Jerusalem is still the stumbling block

fields.headline: Jerusalem is still the stumbling block
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The peace negotiations that came back from the dead resumed at Camp David yesterday without President Clinton, who flew to the G8 summit in Okinawa, leaving his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, to keep alive the hope of progress.
fields.byline: Julian Borger  in Washington and  Brian Whitaker
fields.body:
The peace negotiations that came back from the dead resumed at Camp David yesterday without President Clinton, who flew to the G8 summit in Okinawa, leaving his secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, to keep alive the hope of progress.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, agreed in the early hours of yesterday to continue talks in Mr Clinton's absence.

"We all thought it was over," Mr Clinton told a press conference. "Then we discovered that nobody wanted to quit. Nobody wanted to give up. And that should be encouraging."

But, he warned, "There should be no illusion about the difficult task ahead."

The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, stressed that the decision did not reflect any last-minute progress towards finding a solution to the substantive outstanding issues, in particular the future of Jerusalem.

Richard Boucher, the state department spokesman, said discussions would continue with Ms Albright's mediation, with "the same pattern and intensity" as the first nine days.

Officially, both sides welcomed the chance to carry on talking. "We need to really turn every stone to find a solution," an Israeli representative, Eldad Yaniv, said. The Palestinian envoy in Washington, Hassan Abdel Rahman, said: "This is a new opportunity."

But others were pessimistic. The Israeli spokesman, Uzi Bar-Am, said Mr Barak had "made a huge effort" on the Jerusalem dispute.

"I don't think he can make another effort on this, and I'm not sure that Arafat's room for manoeuvring on this issue is too big."

The view emerging yesterday was that offering concessions on Jerusalem to clinch a deal would be political suicide for Mr Arafat and Mr Barak. But neither side can afford to admit failure. One Palestinian official has already suggested that the result will be "not a permanent peace but a permanent peace process".

Without an agreement, Mr Barak will be spared the inevitable cries of treachery from Israeli hardliners. But he was elected, primarily, to make peace, and if he fails Israelis may ask whether they have any further need for him.

Mr Arafat's problem in the absence of a deal is similar. He will come under pressure to carry out his threat to declare a Palestinian state unilaterally. He would probably like to avoid the declaration if he can, because at this stage no one can predict the outcome.

Both sides might be able to stave off these difficulties if they could salvage an interim agreement from Camp David, with the promise of more talks to come. But although progress has been reported on the issues of refugees and the West Bank and Gaza, the Palestinians are reluctant to separate them from the issue of Jerusalem.

webTitle: Rail authority to oversee £7bn cash injection

fields.headline: Rail authority to oversee £7bn cash injection
fields.standfirst:
Trains: Ministers show commitment to capital grants

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A £7bn plan to fund the railways over the next three years will include an acceptance by the government that it will also have to back capital expenditure projects like the £5.8bn west coast main line plan between London and Glasgow.
fields.body:
A £7bn plan to fund the railways over the next three years will include an acceptance by the government that it will also have to back capital expenditure projects like the £5.8bn west coast main line plan between London and Glasgow.

Ministers have decided that rail expansion must be supported by capital grants rather than through access charges. These will be administered by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority. Among the £29bn of government money over the next 10 years, £4bn will go on renewal schemes and £5bn for the completion of the Channel tunnel rail link and a new rail hub at St Pancras station in London.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the SSRA, said to the government:"Show us the money and we'll do the job." The SSRA would play its part by providing additional capital to support private sector investment. "We are now in a position to develop rail and to integrate it more successfully with other public transport, the private car and land use planning." Government rail subsidies were due to decline from £1.1bn this year to £850m by 2002. But yesterday's announcement will halt the decline, backing the industry's judgment of a 50% increase in passengers by 2010.

The benefits for London are a £3.2 bn investment in public transport over the next three years. But the money excludes anything the government will put into the private public sector partnership for the London Underground. Private investors will put up the bulk of the cash, but ministers have drawn up plans to remove up to £2.5bn from the contingency fund to underpin the project.

Other plans are a new east-west London link called CrossRail, and completion of the Thameslink 2000 rail project, linking the northern and southern home counties at Blackfriars. Both these projects are still nothing more than paper projects, although the Thameslink project has got as far as a public inquiry. Mr Prescott has also set aside £4 bn for the rail freight industry. Philip Mengel, chief executive of ESW, Britain's biggest rail freight operator said that the money would put rail freight back on track and could lead a doubling of growth in 10 years.

The extra money will also help the SSRA in awarding new rail franchises, extending main line termini and recapturing parts of the railway axed almost 40 years ago by Lord Beeching.
