fields.headline: Prescott's £180bn revival scheme
fields.standfirst:
Biggest ever cash injection to revitalise creaking system will mean a decade of disruption on rail and roads

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: A decade of disruption on rail and road was forecast last night as the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, unveiled his £180bn plan to revitalise Britain's creaking and underfunded public transport system.
fields.body:
A decade of disruption on rail and road was forecast last night as the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, unveiled his £180bn plan to revitalise Britain's creaking and underfunded public transport system.

The forecast was made by the shadow strategic rail authority, which has the job of re-claiming parts of the railway scrapped almost 30 years ago by Lord Beeching. "Passengers will have to expect more pain than gain. Miracles cannot be achieved overnight," said the SSRA.

Mr Prescott was careful not to overegg the fact that he has just won the largest amount of money ever put into public transport by government. He gave no promises of a "rosy traffic free future", but said that his plan addressed the issues in a "realistic and business like way".

The main criticism of the plan was that it was a "smoke and mirrors" job, relying heavily on grand figures and targets, but short on detail, particularly on what the government will do in the next few years.

It particularly upset Ken Livingstone, London's new mayor, who claimed that he had been "stitched up" by Mr Prescott.

Mr Livingstone thought that he had been given £3.2bn without any strings, but then he was informed about what he called the "unpleasant sting in the tail".

Within the past 24 hours, he was told that £104m would be needed from his allowance to pay for the mounting costs of the Jubilee line extension to the London Underground, which are now expected to total almost £4bn, more than double the original cost.

The spiralling cost of the Jubilee line extension contains hidden dangers for the government. Plans for the next 10 years are predicated on capital projects which often turn out to be far more expensive than budgeted.

Many of Mr Prescott's projects will be on road development, where budgeting is more accurate. But projects like the west coast main line and the Channel Tunnel rail link are expected to cost considerably more.

Mr Prescott told the Commons that decades of under-investment and the lack of strategic planning had left Britain with a transport system in crisis. It had been dogged by stop-go funding and a short term approach, but the government had now decided on "a step change".

Bernard Jenkin, the shadow transport minister, accused Mr Prescott of "promises, promises and promises". He said the only guarantee with the announcement was that people would still be "ripped off at the pumps and congestion on the roads would get worse".

Mr Jenkin said that the £180bn was a "fantasy land spending increase". He suggested that at the next election the government would have nothing to show for its labours. The figures were designed to mislead, he said. "How much is double counted or reannounced? How much is just pious hope, empty promises and post-dated cheques?"

Of the £180bn, some two-thirds will come from the public sector and the rest from private business organisations. It includes £60bn for railways, £59bn for roads and almost £26bn for local transport schemes. It was described by Mr Prescott as delivering "a radical improvement for passengers, motorists, business and for all of us citizens".

He conceded that the £180bn was not all new money. Projects like the Channel Tunnel rail link and some light rail and road schemes have already been budgeted for.

The plan is short on information about what the government will do to speed up public transport over the next three years.

But a senior aide to Mr Prescott said afterwards that the SSRA would be laying out its strategy for rail in the autumn, together with the cost of new capital projects.

Within the next few months, local authorities will also be presenting their plans to reduce congestion, including workplace charging, although this will not cost the government much money.

The plan was enthusiastically received across a wide section of the transport industry. Sir Christopher Foster, chairman of the RAC Foundation described it as a "tonic for all travellers" which would cut congestion and provide a "massive boost for the environment".

John Dawson, policy director of the AA, said: "It's the sort of balanced package they've been used to in Europe for decades. The challenge now is to deliver the programme quickly enough for people to notice that the record motoring taxes they pay are finally being used to improve things."

The Association of Train Operating Companies said that the money would provide the industry with a launch pad. "It will allow us to remove bottlenecks in London, Manchester and Birmingham, and help us run longer and more comfortable trains."

Railtrack said the government's targets for growth in the industry matched their own expansion projects, and they were delighted by the clarity the plans provided.

One of the country's largest bus operators, FirstGroup, hailed the plan as "the best news public transport has had for many years".

The CBI's director general, Digby Jones, hailed the plan as a "monumental victory for the business community". Coincidentally, the CBI had been pressing for exactly the same budget as Mr Prescott produced.

He said businesses throughout the UK had been crying out for an efficient transport infrastructure. It would contribute "hugely to our global competitiveness".

The British Chambers of Commerce warned that the money should not be spent on quick fixes. "The government must overcome delays in capital investment and enable local authorities to borrow now against future income from road user charging," said the deputy director general, Ian Peters.

While welcoming the plan, Friends of the Earth said that Britain's transport problems could not be solved by throwing money at every possible option. There had to be a fall in the number of cars on the roads. But that would not happen and there would be "environmentally damaging road schemes".'

webTitle: Ministers give green light to city trams

fields.headline: Ministers give green light to city trams
fields.standfirst:
Buses: Aim for 10% increase in use over 10 years

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Up to £3bn is to be invested in light rail or tram schemes to fund 25 new lines in large cities and conurbations.
fields.body:
Up to £3bn is to be invested in light rail or tram schemes to fund 25 new lines in large cities and conurbations.

The aim is to double tram usage by 2010. Ministers believe that people are more attracted to light rail projects rather than buses. Their popularity is such that they can move large flows of passengers quickly, comfortably and reliably.

Manchester, Croydon, Birmingham and the Docklands light railway in London are examples of their increasing use.

The Croydon tram scheme - the first trams in London for almost 50 years - has reduced car parking in the centre of Croydon by 9% in the six weeks since the £200m project was launched.

Tramlink, a consortium of both private and public interests, said that 40,000 passengers were daily using the tram and that 20% more people were coming into central Croydon.

Roger Harding, Tramlink's general manager, said that he was astonished at the public response. "It is a very popular, quality way to travel. We are getting ready to cater for eventually 60,000 passengers a day."

The green light has already been given to six new lines, involving £900m at Nottingham, Sunderland, and three Manchester Metrolink extensions. In addition, a number of local authorities have plans for new systems or extensions. These include Leeds, Portsmouth, and Bristol, with a further expansion planned for the Midland Metro in Birmingham.

The government expects local contributions towards their costs to go with the extra resources in the 10-year plan. These could include developer and operator contrbutions, and the proceeds of local congestion charging schemes.

The plan for buses is to deliver a 10% growth in bus use over the next 10 years, even though it is currently rising at barely 1% a year. Some £95m will be spent on rural bus services, including nearly 2,000 new or rural bus services in England.

The government is also guaranteeing half fares for elderly and disabled people, with free bus passes for 7m others. This promise depends on the passage of the transport bill.

Local authorities will be able to bring forward new schemes to make walking and cycling easier. More traffic calmed 20 mph zones, particularly in residential areas and near school will be developed. The plan should achieve an 8% reduction in congestion in the largest cities and reductions in projected growth from 15% to 7 % in other urban areas.

Ministers are expecting local authorities to submit their plans for congestion charging before the end of the year. At least eight cities are said to be ready to introduce charging and 12 authorities want to introduce workplace charging.

But Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, is likely to be first out of the starting block with inner London charges of at least £5 by 2003.

Route to beating jams

 Total public and private investment of £180bn

 £60bn on rail to allow it to grow by 50%.

 £59bn on roads widening 360 miles of motorway and trunk roads.

 £59bn on local transport spending on town and city roads and public transport schemes.

webTitle: Pioneer puts trust in integrated strategy for city

fields.headline: Pioneer puts trust in integrated strategy for city
fields.standfirst:
The future: Hopes high for 'jewel in crown'

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: In the Perfect Leeds, a supertram will rock you past lanes reserved for bicycles, buddy-sharing cars and guided buses, to slide open its doors at the gateway to the central pedestrian precinct - all restored historic buildings, buskers and flower stalls - while cars spin contentedly round the one-way inner loop.
fields.body:
In the Perfect Leeds, a supertram will rock you past lanes reserved for bicycles, buddy-sharing cars and guided buses, to slide open its doors at the gateway to the central pedestrian precinct - all restored historic buildings, buskers and flower stalls - while cars spin contentedly round the one-way inner loop.

That contentment and the tram are the two missing pieces of the jigsaw in a city which has pioneered many of the government's favourite urban transport reforms, and now has crossed fingers that increased public spending will bring the whole strategy together.

The supertram would be the "jewel in the crown of Leeds's transport system", said Kieran Preston, director of Metro, the West Yorkshire passenger transport authority which has built up the pattern of bus experiments, bike encouragement and acres where people can potter about in the middle of former roads. "We think there has been a sea change in government attitudes to light rail - tram systems - after their success in places like Manchester."

He said Manchester's packed trams show the appeal of fixed routes/fixed times. "Buses are very important, but you always have that uneasiness that the number 43 might turn into the 65, or go round the block a different way, or stop that particular route altogether. We've also found people will move house or relocate a company to be near a tram stop, in a way which doesn't apply to bus routes."

The first Leeds supertram line, from a proposed park-and-ride centre by the M1 and M621 south of the city, has had royal assent since 1993, plus local all-party support and a route which has ironed out almost all compulsory purchase glitches. As far as the government's new spending is concerned, the hope is that funding will at last follow, and that route 2 - north into Headingley - and route 3 - east to St James's hospital and Thackray medical museum - may come a lot sooner than expected; even all three at once.

The city's optimism also rest on an integrated transport strategy which won centre of excellence status from Mr Prescott's department last year. It consists of a massive central pedestrian area, including innovations such as "React" beacons for the blind broadcasting directions when activated by a card, disabled buggies, and bus stops which tell your their route.

fields.standfirst:
Roads: Plan to widen sections of busiest routes routes areas

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Plans to add an extra lane to 360 miles of trunk roads and motorways are at the centre of the government's roads plan.
fields.body:
Plans to add an extra lane to 360 miles of trunk roads and motorways are at the centre of the government's roads plan.

Ministers say this will be enough to widen some of the most congested sections of the network. Among options being looked at are a widening of the M6 between Birmingham and Manchester, key sections of the M1, M25, M42, M62 between Manchester and Leeds, the M60, and the A1 west of Newcastle. The cost of widening per mile ranges from £9m to £21m.

Some 80 improvements to tackle bottlenecks at key junctions have been identified. They will include flyovers to replace roundabouts and traffic light junctions, widening slip roads and filter lanes.

The first tranche from among 70 local road by-passes are due to be announced by the end of the month, with an average cost of £15m a scheme.

Under the plan, 30 strategic by-passes will be built at an average cost of £19m. The government may encounter opposition from environmenal groups on some of them, as they will pass through large tracts of country.

Road study groups are to report on schemes which will start next year. They include Lamberhurst and Polegate by-passes in Kent and Sussex, Aston Clinton in Buckinghamshire and Selby, North Yorkshire.

Automatic hold-up warning systems will be installed on 30 % of motorways by 2004, reducing accidents at the backs of queues on the most congested lengths.

A national traffic control centre to start delivering services in 2002, will be fully open in 2003 in a private public partnership. It will provide strategic traffic management on all motorways and most important A-roads as well as real time driver information.

Two hundred more motorway monitoring cameras are to be installed by 2004 to give faster response to accidents. The idea is to provide improved flow control on motorway access roads to smooth flows on to the main carriageway.

Mr Prescott dubbed the controversial M4 bus lane on the approach to London a success and suggested that more may be in the pipeline, as well as special lanes for lorries, particularly at peak periods.

webTitle: Ancient quarrels pothole the road to peace

fields.headline: Ancient quarrels pothole the road to peace
fields.standfirst:
Competition for the holy city as a capital remains the main hurdle to a peace agreement

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: For 33 years an invisible barrier has sliced through the heart of this breathtaking yet maddening city. It is called "the seam": the line tracing the barbed wire and concrete walls which, until 1967, divided Arab east Jerusalem and the ancient walled city from the Jewish districts in the west.
fields.body:
For 33 years an invisible barrier has sliced through the heart of this breathtaking yet maddening city. It is called "the seam": the line tracing the barbed wire and concrete walls which, until 1967, divided Arab east Jerusalem and the ancient walled city from the Jewish districts in the west.

The seam, a divide both psychological and physical, is testimony to the fierce tribal loyalties that came so close to wrecking the Camp David summit, and could easily do so in the days to come.

It is also the expression of a far greater truth than the professions of Israeli negotiators at Camp David that this city is the "eternal and undivided capital of the Jewish people". This is not one city but two: Jewish Jerusalem and Palestinian al-Quds. In their respective ghettos, 625,000 Jews and Palestinians live an entirely separate existence.

Jewish west Jerusalem is a modern city of shopping malls, and clean, well-lit boulevards, lush parks and well-watered gardens. Behind the pre-1967 borders, east Jerusalem is a monument to neglect. Israel's bulldozers rigorously enforce a building code that bars Palestinians from building on 86% of the available land; its bureaucrats revoke the residency rights of families who have lived there for years.

At Camp David, the negotiators are trying to extract some virtue from these divides. Guided by Israeli and Palestinian academics, who have quietly been discussing solutions, their talks now hinge on redefining boundaries and concepts such as sovereignty.

The idea is that Israel should relinquish parts of the city foreign to Jews to give Mr Arafat a twin Palestinian capital, albeit a shrunken one.

The Israelis tried to sell the plan to the Palestinians by saying that Mr Arafat would control substantial areas in the north of the city where 150,000 Palestinians live. They also promised to build tunnels so that Mr Arafat could travel to his domains in eastern Jerusalem without setting foot in areas reserved for Israel. But it falls short of the Palestinian vision of two separate municipalities with open borders and universal access to holy places.

The talks are believed to have foundered on the fate of Palestinian neighbourhoods bordering the seam, such as the village of Silwan. Mr Arafat is also believed to have balked at the price asked for his scrap of a capital: Israel's annexation of the largest Jewish settle ment in the West Bank, Maale Adumim, and its vow to keep control of areas inside the walled city.

Menachem Klein, a fellow of the Israel Institute of Jerusalem Affairs, the thinktank which drafted the Israeli proposals under discussion, says both parties should relinquish their over-arching ideas of sovereignty and concentrate on the minutiae and the symbolic: refuse collection, taxes, education, health care, flags. "They should leave aside what is written in God's books about who is owner of the city and come to terms on articles of daily life".

But in a city groaning under the weight of three millennia of history and its attendant symbols, it is exceedingly difficult to abandon the past.

Amos Elon, the Israeli author of a much-praised book on the city, says: "For both Palestinians and Israelis, Jerusalem is a manipulated mantra, a politically manipulated mantra that has so overwhelmed the manipulators that they are all trapped in their own crap now.

"You can't preach something for 33 years, and then overnight run contrary to it."

fields.headline: War strategy ridiculed
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Britain's second most senior defence minister during the Kosovo conflict has made a scathing attack on the conduct of the war, the inadequacy of British intelligence and the role of President Jacques Chirac of France in endangering the safety of his own pilots.
fields.body:
Britain's second most senior defence minister during the Kosovo conflict has made a scathing attack on the conduct of the war, the inadequacy of British intelligence and the role of President Jacques Chirac of France in endangering the safety of his own pilots.

During the war, Lord Gilbert was defence minister of state formally responsible for intelligence. In evidence to the defence select committee published yesterday he claimed that allied forces forced Slobodan Milosevic into a war.

"I think certain people were spoiling for a fight in Nato at that time. I think the terms put to Milosevic at Rambouillet were absolutely intolerable: how could he possibly accept them? It was quite deliberate."

He accused his own intelligence chiefs of adopting a patronising attitude and refusing to give him information.

In a rare attack on a fellow Nato member, Lord Gilbert singled out Mr Chirac for criticism, especially his admission that he vetoed the destruction of bridges across the rivers in Belgrade. He described this as "one of the most extraordinary remarks for a western statesman ever to have made".

He sarcastically praised Mr Chirac for "having the courage to take responsibility for the fact that the hostilities went on far longer than they need have done, that the poor people in Kosovo suffered consequently far more than they need have done, and that his own pilots were put at risk far more than was necessary". He said the Nato policy of choosing targets in staged increments was "a military nonsense from the very beginning, based on political timidity".

Lord Gilbert ridiculed the suggestion made by the chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, that Nato would have been in a position to mount an opposed invasion into Kosovo last September in time to drive out the Serbian army.

"I think a land invasion of Kosovo would have been possible by September but by September this year, not by September last year," he said, adding that Ministry of Defence intelligence ought to "be picked up by the scruff of the neck and shaken. A very serious look needs to be taken at the quality of British and US intelligence."

Lord Gilbert said: "We also got extremely varying intelligence on the state of Serb morale and what was happening post-Milosevic. I have to say that it was very difficult to know what to believe from one day to the next."

He also found that Dera, the defence evaluation and research agency, "employs no fewer than 100 psychologists. I was very surprised when I found this out." In vetted evidence, Lord Gilbert discussed its role and said: "You know how it is, you ask a question three times and if you do not get an answer you give up asking the question; you are only a humble minister of state."

webTitle: A win, win, win and win again with Prescott

fields.headline: A win, win, win and win again with Prescott
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The prime minister is in Japan, where a train driver once commited  seppuku after bringing in the emperor's train two minutes late.
fields.body:
The prime minister is in Japan, where a train driver once commited seppuku - self-disembowelment - after bringing in the emperor's train two minutes late.

Tragically, this measure is not available to John Prescott, who made a statement on transport yesterday. The only delay that would gladden the hearts of all rail users would be because of the wrong kind of corpses on the line. Think of it. All those wealthy privatised rail bosses who have made a fortune out of providing worse services than ever, all obliged to commit ritual self-slaughter on the track, the train wheels spinning helplessly on their intestines!

In cases of obligatory hara-kiri , the authorities sent a kenshi (witness) to make sure the guilty samurai did the decent thing. Travellers from Manchester and Glasgow would pay a fortune to be Richard Branson's kenshi, so freeing yet more money for investment. This may sound a crazy idea, but no madder than marching yobs to cashpoints. I expect Tony Blair is making a careful note of the idea now.

For once Mr Prescott made a more-or-less coherent speech, although he was continually interrupted by camp giggles from the Tories at his more ludicrous lines, such as "in three years we have made real improvements" and "today I am announcing the new resources to bring about a step-change in transport".

(You might assume that a step-change in transport means that we will all have to walk instead, but it's just the new cliche. Until recently all changes were "sea-changes", also for no apparent reason.)

One of Mr Prescott's speech curiosities is the way he adds or removes the indefinite article, apparently at random. So we heard about "providing bigger, better, safer railway", and "with new modernisation fund". But he throws them in as well. "And a longer-term projects," he said about something, adding mysteriously that the new railway system would be "indeed, a win, win, win and win again".

None of this much matters, and at least the speech was better than his normal oration, which resembles the tube train the other day that ran half a mile backwards while the driver was asleep and terrified passengers thought they were about to die.

But it is the substance of a Prescott speech that is worrying. Analyse it, and you will see that all the listed achievements are in fact only plans for achievements. "We have laid the foundations for the long term," he said. "We needed a new strategy; we've done that. We needed radical new legislation; we've done that - new ideas, new powers, new resources - a new approach for a new century!"

This is perfectly coherent blather, but blather none the less. The real achievements, "a railway system which is better for passengers, better for freight, better for the economy and a good deal all round", exist, like all the deputy prime minister's promises, in a permanently receding future.

Mr Prescott was, again, lucky in his opposition. The lacklustre Asda chairman Archie Norman had been put in the quick-sale bin and replaced by his understrapper, Bernard Jenkin.

Mr Jenkin, who does know a bit about transport, started well. "After three wasted years, he has the nerve to come here and say, 'I have a 10-year plan'," but he soon started to unravel. "Why is the government reserving the roads for the rich and for ministers in their Jaguars?" he frothed.

Metaphors swayed in the air like snakes: "The endless string of longer and longer telephone numbers conveys nothing but the whiff of panic," he said, as the comparison fell in a twisted heap, back into its basket.

webTitle: Tories back Young for Speaker as rules queried

fields.headline: Tories back Young for Speaker as rules queried
fields.standfirst:
Labour resist candidate amid calls for secret ballot

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The former Conservative cabinet minister Sir George Young has emerged as the overwhelming choice among Tory MPs to become the next Speaker according to a private survey of backbenchers, his supporters claimed last night.
fields.body:
The former Conservative cabinet minister Sir George Young has emerged as the overwhelming choice among Tory MPs to become the next Speaker according to a private survey of backbenchers, his supporters claimed last night.

But their chances of winning over a crucial block of Labour MPs to back his candidacy, when Betty Boothroyd's successor is elected in October, will meet with stiff resistance from Labour stalwarts who regard him an an Old Etonian toff, not a backbench champion.

Though a clutch of MPs from all the main parties have signalled their willingness to stand, no one has yet emerged as a clear favourite.

Even Tony Benn, now 76 and scheduled to retire at the election, confirms that some Tories have asked him to stay on and fight for parliament's rights from the Speaker's chair. Though "honoured" by the appeal, the MP for Chesterfield is unlikely to run.

Equally romantic, though also unlikely, would be the choice of the Tories' most distinguished libertarian and champion of MPs rights, Richard Shepherd, MP for Aldridge-Brownhills since 1979. Some MPs mention his name - though without much hope that he would garner enough votes.

Signs of disquiet surfaced yesterday when MPs on both sides appealed for clearer rules or a secret ballot to prevent colleagues being "browbeaten" into voting for a semi-official candidate.

The Tories tried and failed to impose one in 1983 and 1992.

Sir George's promoters claim to have canvassed 130 of the 164 Tory MPs and found around 100 of them pro-Young - a claim which raises eyebrows among party whips and supporters of declared Tory rivals like Sir Patrick Cormack, Michael Lord, John Butterfill and Nicholas Winterton, who declared yesterday.

On paper, Sir Alan Haselhurst, one of Ms Boothroyd's Tory deputies, has strong claims. But he is not thought tough enough by some colleagues to stand up for their rights against Tony Blair's executive-minded ministers.

That is why several Conservatives - including Nicholas Soames - are openly backing Gwyneth Dunwoody, the 69-year-old Labour MP for Crewe

She is famously fierce and independent, but also 69, only a year younger than Ms Boothroyd. The Young canvass team admits she is no 2 choice for up to a quarter of Tory MPs.

But another Boothroyd deputy, Labour's Michael Martin, who has the support of many fellow Scots and parliamentary modernisers, is tipped to become the dark horse by some old hands, though that title is also being awarded to another would-be moderniser, John McWilliam, the convivial Labour MP for Blaydon.

Mr Martin, MP for Glasgow Springburn, is regarded as a tough but fair chairman, controlling the often unruly Commons when the discliplarian Ms Boothroyd is off duty.

Being seen as a Blair candidate will be the kiss of death for all but the loyalest Blairites, some of whom are already telling friends that Sir George may be acceptable. Old Labour lags suspect that may be a tactical ruse to deliver the bulk of Labour support to Menzies "Ming" Campbell, the Lib Dem foreign affairs spokesman.

While the rules governing the election of the Speaker prevent MPs from personally asking for votes, behind-the-scenes campaigns and counter-campaigns are well under way three months before a decision must be made.

Mr Campbell has already come up against a "stop Menzies" drive by Tory and Labour MPs to prevent the job falling to someone from a minority party and a Scottish constituency, whom they see as a rather grand lawyer in a striped shirt.

Mr Campbell cannot even muster full support from his own party to become the first Liberal speaker since 1928, since the deputy leader Alan Beith is also vying for the job.

While party leader Charles Kennedy has told both men that, as party leader, he plans to remain strictly impartial, Mr Beith is already understood to be capitalising on his networking talents, which extend to some Labour MPs from the North-east.

webTitle: City economists warn of inflation threat

fields.headline: City economists warn of inflation threat
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Independent economists have warned that the chancellor's boost in public sector spending announced on Tuesday could fuel inflation, forcing the Bank of England to raise interest rates.
fields.body:
Independent economists have warned that the chancellor's boost in public sector spending announced on Tuesday could fuel inflation, forcing the Bank of England to raise interest rates.

Spending by government departments is set to rise more than 7% next year - the biggest increase in several decades.

David Walton, chief economist at Goldman Sachs, told backbench MPs on the Treasury committee that the plans were affordable but they would provide a considerable boost to growth.

"If the economy keeps growing at trend rate, we will need slower demand in the private sector. The question is: will that come automatically, or will the Bank of England need to raise rates?", Mr Walton said.

His comments came as separate figures showed Whitehall departments have already started spending, causing government finances to dip sharply into the red in June.

According to the office for national statistics, the shortfall between spending and revenues during June was £7.7bn - the highest gap ever recorded for that month - on the cash measure of the government's finances.

After May's large surplus, when receipts from the auction of mobile phone licences swelled the Treasury's coffers by a record £11.6bn, City analysts said yesterday's figures were slightly disappointing.

"The figure for June was considerably worse than the market expectation of a £5.8bn deficit and higher than the £5.9bn recorded last June," said Richard Iley from ABN Amro.

"However, it would be ludicrous to present this as a worrying deterioration in the public finances."

On the government's preferred measure of its financial position - public sector net borrowing - the deficit was much smaller, at £2.7bn.

"If the economy keeps growing at trend rate, we will need slower demand in the private sector. The question is: will that come automatically, or will the Bank of England need to raise rates?", Mr Walton said. His comments came as separate figures showed Whitehall departments have already started spending, causing government finances to dip sharply into the red in June. According to the office for national statistics, the shortfall between spending and revenues during June was £7.7bn - the highest gap ever recorded for that month - on the cash measure of the government's finances. After May's large surplus, when receipts from the auction of mobile phone licences swelled the Treasury's coffers by a record £11.6bn, City analysts said yesterday's figures were slightly disappointing. "The figure for June was considerably worse than the market expectation of a £5.8bn deficit and higher than the £5.9bn recorded last June," said Richard Iley from ABN Amro. "However, it would be ludicrous to present this as a worrying deterioration in the public finances." On the government's preferred measure of its financial position - public sector net borrowing - the deficit was much smaller, at £2.7bn. webTitle: Minister offers help to church secondary schools

fields.headline: Minister offers help to church secondary schools
fields.standfirst:
Special report: religion in the UK

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government has promised to help the Church of England find the money to set up 100 secondary schools over the next five years, capable of educating at least 100,000 teenagers in a religious environment.
fields.body:
The government has promised to help the Church of England find the money to set up 100 secondary schools over the next five years, capable of educating at least 100,000 teenagers in a religious environment.

Estelle Morris, the education minister, wrote yesterday to Lord Dearing, head of a committee reviewing education provision for the church, saying the government would consider ways of helping dioceses raise the estimated £2m they will need to meet the initial costs of each school.

Lord Dearing said: "We are not in the business of trying to put existing secondary schools out of business if they are doing a good job but we can offer a responsiveness to parental choice.

"There is an unsatisfied demand and I am very clear from the meetings I have had with all three main political parties that they are all well disposed to the creation of more church schools."

An interim report issued by his committee yesterday calls on all 42 Anglican dioceses to consider establishing at least two additional secondaries in each of their areas.

The report says that although a quarter of all primaries are church schools, only one in 20 secondaries is. There are 790,000 places for children in church primaries but only 150,000 in secondaries. Additionally, about 120,000 children attend church independent secondaries.

With the church pleading poverty, the report suggests it could persuade developers and local authorities to help set up the schools.

fields.headline: Kent challenge over section 28
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest education authority yesterday voted to defy the government by introducing its own version of section 28.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest education authority yesterday voted to defy the government by introducing its own version of section 28.

After a stormy debate, Tory-controlled Kent county council voted by a narrow margin to resurrect the ban on "promotion of homosexuality" in the 600 schools it controls.

The amendment to council policy revives the language of the section including the controversial warning against equating homosexuality with "a pretended family relationship".

Conservative councillors acted after realising that attempts to keep the original clause were again set to be defeated by the government. The council leader, Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, said: "We are making a stand on this issue and will keep the spirit of the existing legislation alive in Kent."

However, the government and teachers questioned yesterday whether the council had the power to impose its own guidance.

Liberal Democrats on the council tried to block the move, describing it as morally offensive and claiming it would lead to an upsurge in homophobic bullying. Speaking after the vote, Mr Bruce-Lockhart said: "What we are saying is that we want to give reassurance to parents in Kent that the county council will not spend taxpayers' money on purchasing material which intentionally promotes homosexuality. That is a bad use of money."

Kent's decision could set it on a collision course with the Department for Education and Employment, which earlier this month published its sex education guidance for schools.

That guidance will have legal force once the learning and skills bill becomes law, which is expected before the Commons rises for the summer.

That guidance refers to "marriage and stable relationships as key building blocks of community and society", while Kent's guidance puts the stress on marriage alone.

A spokesman for the Department for Education said yesterday that sex education was a matter for school governors, and not for councils.

The spokesman added that the guidelines in the learning and skills bill, once it became law, would take precedence over the policies of local authorities.

webTitle: How g-factor helped scientists find powerhouse of the brain

fields.headline: How g-factor helped scientists find powerhouse of the brain
fields.trailText: They have been hunting the elusive quarry of human intelligence for generations. Now a team of British and German scientists believe they have got it cornered.
fields.body:
They have been hunting the elusive quarry of human intelligence for generations. Now a team of British and German scientists believe they have got it cornered.

The researchers claim that intelligence does not, as many specialists believe, dwell in the whole human brain: using advanced scanning equipment, they say they have tracked it down to a lair at the front of the head.

In an effort to link IQ tests to the activity of nerve cells in the brain, the team, led by John Duncan of the Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit in Cambridge, gave subjects a series of puzzles to solve involving patterns of circles, triangles and sequences of letters. When they were solving the most difficult tasks, scans showed that blood flow increased in the front of the brain, suggesting increased mental activity, and not in other areas.

The scientists' definition of "intelligence" was that set in 1904 by Charles Spearman, a philosopher turned career army officer turned psychologist. He invented the concept of "general intelligence", known as "g".

The mysterious g-factor was what enabled intelligent people to be good at many different tasks, Spearman said, sparking a hunt for "g" which continues today despite suggestions that it is a myth. Critics of the g-hunters tend to be sceptical about the relevance to real life of the series of stylised paper puzzles used in IQ tests.

The Duncan group's research is published in the latest edition of the journal Science, which also carries a lengthy article attacking the group's approach under the headline "The Holey [sic] Grail of General Intelligence".

In the article Robert Sternberg, a Yale University psychologist, points out that neither candidate for the next presidency of the US did particularly well in the IQ tests they sat for university entrance.

"It is possible, of course, that notable success in politics depends little on intelligence, but it is also possible that there is more to intelligence than is measured by conventional tests (such as those used by Duncan et al) that use analytical skills," he writes.

"The mental-atlas approach taken by [the British-German team] implies that the understanding of intelligence depends upon finding the locus or loci of intelligence in the human brain. Their claim is similar to the weak claim that we understand the intelligence of a computer when we localise its artificial intelligence in a silicon chip embedded deep within the hardware."

webTitle: EU to sue tobacco firms over claims that they aided smugglers

fields.headline: EU to sue tobacco firms over claims that they aided smugglers
fields.trailText: US tobacco companies are to be sued for billions of dollars in lost revenue after the European commission alleged yesterday that it has evidence that a number of them are implicated in smuggling operations.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
US tobacco companies are to be sued for billions of dollars in lost revenue after the European commission alleged yesterday that it has evidence that a number of them are implicated in smuggling operations.

The unprecedented decision to lodge the lawsuit marks a turning point in the fight against cigarette smuggling in Europe, thought to be the biggest single drain on the EU's $95bn annual budget.

Officials refused to name either the companies or the precise details of court action yesterday. However, anti-smoking campaigners believe that the commission may use US anti-racketeering laws to target two of the biggest companies: Phillip Morris and RJ Reynolds. Last night both companies denied that the EU had taken any action against them.

Under these laws, introduced to stamp out mob crime in the early 1970s, the EU can claim three times the amount of lost revenues in compensation.

According to figures compiled by the pressure group Ash, the UK alone lost £2.5bn from excise fraud involving cigarettes last year.

An EU spokesman said yesterday: "The case concerns the alleged implication of these companies in cigarette smuggling into the European Union. The aim is to achieve a degree of compensation for the alleged loss of revenues. We want our money back."

The US tobacco industry is already struggling under the impact of lawsuits filed by governments and individuals around the world. Last week, a Florida court demanded that the five biggest US companies pay an unprecedented $145bn to sick smokers, the first such class action to succeed.

Under a deal reached with 41 US states last year, the industry must also pay $246bn over a 25-year period as compensation for the health costs associated with smoking. The US government may also file a lawsuit for compensation.

The weight of the industry's legal woes has seriously depressed share prices over the past year. David Adelman, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the US investment bank, said in response the EU action: "They should just get in line. It's just another absurd lawsuit."

The decision to pursue legal action was taken at a meeting of the commission on Wednesday in its role as guardian of the treaties and of the community's budget.

EU officials refused to say where or when the alleged smuggling had taken place but said the legal action would begin in about two months.

A spokesman for Philip Morris refused to comment on the case and confirmed that the company had not been told of any potential action by the EU.

RJ Reynolds also said it could not "comment specifically on the alleged suit" particularly as it had not seen it.

In a statement, however, the group added: "To suggest that Reynolds Tobacco has been involved in smuggling activity - in Europe or elsewhere - is unsupportable and untrue. In fact, the domestic company has never even marketed or sold cigarettes in Europe."

Clive Bates, the director of Ash, said that the EU decision could also prompt an official investigation into the allegations that British American Tobacco is involved in smuggling activities.

Ash has demanded an inquiry by the Department of Trade and Industry. "This strengthens our case because it shows that this kind of business practice goes on in the in dustry," Mr Bates said. "It is a big step."

Yesterday's announcement follows a two-year investigation by the EU's independent fraud-busting office, and national police and customs authorities. Cigarette smuggling constitutes the biggest single fraud against the EU's annual budget. In some countries, contraband cigarettes account for 10% of sales.

Suspicions of tobacco industry involvement in cigarette smuggling have been growing since 1997, when researchers compared annual global exports with global imports to demonstrate that about a third of all cigarettes entering international commerce each year could not be accounted for.

Explaining why the commission had decided to file the case now, the spokesman said: "We believe that cigarette smuggling has increased in the past few years quite dramatically. To launch that kind of action with some certainty of success you need to have evidence."

The British Labour MEP Philip Whitehead said: "We have long suspected that this was not just smuggling, but smuggling with the active collusion of major American companies."

webTitle: Shipman inquiry must be held in public

fields.headline: Shipman inquiry must be held in public
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: Families of 55 victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman yesterday won their high court battle for a public inquiry into how the GP got away for so long with murdering so many patients.
fields.body:
Families of 55 victims of the serial killer Harold Shipman yesterday won their high court battle for a public inquiry into how the GP got away for so long with murdering so many patients.

In a landmark decision, two judges in London ruled that Alan Milburn, the health secretary, breached article 10 of the European convention on human rights, the right to freedom of expression, when he decided that the inquiry should be held in private.

The ruling will have far-reaching implications for official inquiries into matters of public concern and could significantly limit the scope for ministers to hold inquiries behind closed doors.

Lord Justice Kennedy, sitting with Mr Justice Jackson, said Mr Milburn's decision contravened article 10 because "it constitutes unjustified governmental interference with the reception of information that others wish or may be willing to impart".

The high court challenge was brought by 113 relatives of 55 victims known or believed to have been murdered by Shipman, 54, of Mottram in Longdendale, Greater Manchester. The GP is serving a life sentence after his conviction at Preston crown court of murdering 15 middle-aged and elderly female patients, but police suspect the real toll is nearer 200. The families were supported by eight national newspaper groups and the BBC in their bid for an open inquiry.

The ruling means that Mr Milburn will have to reconsider his decision.

The judges have delivered a more resounding defeat in his case than the education secretary, David Blunkett, suffered last week over teachers' pay. Unless the judgment is overturned on appeal, it will be virtually impossible for Mr Milburn to deny the families what they want: an entirely open inquiry in the full glare of publicity "to restore faith and confidence in GPs and the NHS".

Mr Milburn was given permission to appeal against today's ruling, but the judge said he was "not encouraging" an appeal. Mr Milburn must decide by Wednesday whether to appeal and, if so, the appeal must be heard by the end of September, said the judge.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said the judgment would be considered and added: "From the outset, we have wanted to make sure we learn the lessons from the Shipman case as quickly and effectively as possible so that we can take all the necessary measures to protect patients."

Peter Wagstaff, 52, of Hyde, Greater Manchester, whose mother Kathleen, 81, was a victim, said he was pleased with the result but added: "We had to go through the ordeal of the trial and this is a secondary ordeal when, on the face of it, it was common sense to have a public inquiry."

Ann Alexander, the families' solicitor, said: "The families are hopeful there will be an announcement in the next 24 hours in the House of Commons, having waited for so long."

Lord Justice Kennedy said there were "many powerful considerations in favour of an open inquiry" when Mr Milburn made his final decision in favour of a private hearing in April. Among them were "the scale of the tragedy and the normal governmental reaction to tragedy on such a scale".

Other considerations were "the uncertainty as to who were the victims, and the worry about why the murderer was not detected sooner and why checks and controls on stockpiling drugs and on unusual deaths did not work".

Other advantages of public hearings were "witnesses being less tempted to exaggerate or pass on blame, publicity tending to lead to disclosure of valuable information, openness breeding confidence, and there being less risk of inaccurate and damaging reporting".

Lord Justice Kennedy said Mr Milburn had decided on a closed inquiry because it would be quicker and witnesses would speak more freely. But those reasons were insufficient to justify the decision.

webTitle: Mugabe shows opposition a clenched fist

fields.headline: Mugabe shows opposition a clenched fist
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The opening of Zimbabwe's newly elected parliament yesterday was marked by a competition between the clenched fist salutes of the ruling Zanu-PF party and the open-handed waves of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. The friendly waves won.
fields.body:
The opening of Zimbabwe's newly elected parliament yesterday was marked by a competition between the clenched fist salutes of the ruling Zanu-PF party and the open-handed waves of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change. The friendly waves won.

Although President Robert Mugabe's party controls 92 of the 150 parliamentary seats, the MDC has overwhelming support in Harare, and the crowd of more than 5,000 outside the House of Assembly became a sea of waving hands when the MPs arrived.

A stony-faced Mr Mugabe came in an open-roofed Bentley. He looked straight ahead to avoid acknowledging the MDC crowd waving red cards, which symbolise the opposition's call for Mr Mugabe's team to be sent off from the political game.

The crowd's chants, calling for change, reached the panelled parliamentary chamber. But Mr Mugabe gave no indication in his opening speech that for the first time since he came to power in 1980 there is a significant opposition party in parliament.

MDC leaders have said one of their first parliamentary actions will be to call for Mr Mugabe's impeachment, on the grounds that he incited violence and other crimes during the election campaign.

The MDC has the votes needed to force a debate on the motion, which means Mr Mugabe will face unprecedented criticism in parliament.

In his opening speech, the president promised to accelerate the redistribution of land from white farmers to poor black Zimbabweans.

The address, which was generally bland, was broadcast outside on loudspeakers and was greeted with laughter and heckling from the crowd.

The police tried to prevent the display of support for the opposition.

They pushed back the crowd and made MDC supporters sit down and keep quiet, while members of the much smaller band of Zanu-PF supporters and war veterans moved around freely.

"It is the same as during the election campaign," said one MDC supporter.

"The police have one rule for the opposition supporters and a different rule for those supporting Zanu-PF."

Another MDC supporter, Patrick Ndlovu, said he had come to see the opening of parliament "because I wanted to see the new MDC members of parliament. They can bring change to this country. I am delighted".

Some scuffles broke out between supporters of the two parties, but for the most part the rivalry remained good-natured and peaceful.

Mr Mugabe was jeered as he left the building and his cabinet ministers frantically rolled up the windows of their Mercedes to avoid direct contact with opposition supporters.

The newly elected Chenjerai Hunzvi, leader of the war veterans, crossed the street to get close to his supporters and wave his fists in the air.

The MDC MPs, who also went over to greet their supporters, wore black armbands in mourning for the 31 people killed by Mr Mugabe's supporters during the election campaign.

"We cannot forget those who died to help bring change to Zimbabwe," said one of them, Priscilla Misihairambwi.

Mr Mugabe usually holds a reception for all MPs on the eve of the opening, but he cancelled the event at the last minute on Wednesday, on the grounds that the government must trim its spending. Another explanation is that he could not bring himself to entertain the new opposition.

"We were going to boycott it anyway," said Paul Themba Nyathi, another MDC MP.

"We didn't want to dine with murderers."

As parliament opened, Mr Mugabe's supporters continued to invade white-owned farms and tell the farmers to leave immediately, under threat of death. More than 20 farms in the Glendale area north of Harare stopped work because of the threats of violence from the war veterans.

Following the opening the crowd dispersed throughout Harare city centre. A group of Zanu-PF women, wearing dresses featuring portraits of Robert Mugabe, threatened a white woman journalist and chased her down the street.

Nearby a band of MDC supporters clambered on to a pickup truck singing: "If I die because of political violence, it will be because of Zanu. Don't cry for me because I will be bringing change."

The friendly waves won. Although President Robert Mugabe's party controls 92 of the 150 parliamentary seats, the MDC has overwhelming support in Harare, and the crowd of more than 5,000 outside the House of Assembly became a sea of waving hands when the MPs arrived. A stony-faced Mr Mugabe came in an open-roofed Bentley. He looked straight ahead to avoid acknowledging the MDC crowd waving red cards, which symbolise the opposition's call for Mr Mugabe's team to be sent off from the political game. The crowd's chants, calling for change, reached the panelled parliamentary chamber. But Mr Mugabe gave no indication in his opening speech that for the first time since he came to power in 1980 there is a significant opposition party in parliament. MDC leaders have said one of their first parliamentary actions will be to call for Mr Mugabe's impeachment, on the grounds that he incited violence and other crimes during the election campaign. The MDC has the votes needed to force a debate on the motion, which means Mr Mugabe will face unprecedented criticism in parliament. In his opening speech, the president promised to accelerate the redistribution of land from white farmers to poor black Zimbabweans. The address, which was generally bland, was broadcast outside on loudspeakers and was greeted with laughter and heckling from the crowd. The police tried to prevent the display of support for the opposition. They pushed back the crowd and made MDC supporters sit down and keep quiet, while members of the much smaller band of Zanu-PF supporters and war veterans moved around freely. "It is the same as during the election campaign," said one MDC supporter. "The police have one rule for the opposition supporters and a different rule for those supporting Zanu-PF." Another MDC supporter, Patrick Ndlovu, said he had come to see the opening of parliament "because I wanted to see the new MDC members of parliament. They can bring change to this country. I am delighted". Some scuffles broke out between supporters of the two parties, but for the most part the rivalry remained good-natured and peaceful. Mr Mugabe was jeered as he left the building and his cabinet ministers frantically rolled up the windows of their Mercedes to avoid direct contact with opposition supporters. The newly elected Chenjerai Hunzvi, leader of the war veterans, crossed the street to get close to his supporters and wave his fists in the air. The MDC MPs, who also went over to greet their supporters, wore black armbands in mourning for the 31 people killed by Mr Mugabe's supporters during the election campaign. "We cannot forget those who died to help bring change to Zimbabwe," said one of them, Priscilla Misihairambwi. Mr Mugabe usually holds a reception for all MPs on the eve of the opening, but he cancelled the event at the last minute on Wednesday, on the grounds that the government must trim its spending. Another explanation is that he could not bring himself to entertain the new opposition. "We were going to boycott it anyway," said Paul Themba Nyathi, another MDC MP. "We didn't want to dine with murderers." As parliament opened, Mr Mugabe's supporters continued to invade white-owned farms and tell the farmers to leave immediately, under threat of death. webTitle: Big public money demands big results

fields.headline: Travelling sceptically
fields.standfirst:
Big public money demands big results

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott's £180bn plan for public transport runs into an instant problem with the travelling public. No one believes big figures any more. We have been drowning in numbers while the nation's roads and railways have been deteriorating under our feet.
fields.body:
John Prescott's £180bn plan for public transport runs into an instant problem with the travelling public. No one believes big figures any more. We have been drowning in numbers while the nation's roads and railways have been deteriorating under our feet.

The new figure differs from previous ones only in that it is bigger and stretches farther into the future. It is a mixture of public and private money and includes projects now being built - like the fast rail link from the Channel - as well as others unannounced. The plans are huge, but mainly because previous ones have been as badly delayed as the trains while ministers dithered over whether to confront motorists and how much public money they ought to put in.

The new package should be judged against two criteria. First, whether it delivers measurable and cost-effective solutions. Some proposals - like a 5% reduction in road congestion over 10 years - will be difficult to judge even if successful. Others - like cutting the London to Edinburgh journey to three hours 30 minutes - can be easily checked against delivery.

Second, where extra public money is being invested it should bring a proper return on capital for the investor - the taxpayer. It is very welcome that the extra £7bn allocated to rail should be funnelled through the parsimonious hands of Sir Alastair Morton, head of the Strategic Rail Authority. But it should not end there. This is public money, and there is no case for it being used in a way which is going to enrich Railtrack and the operating companies. They have already profited outrageously from assets bought at fire-sale prices when the Conservatives rushed privatisation through to beat an election deadline. The sum of £7bn is more than twice what the taxpayer got from privatisation. Rail companies must make decent returns - but not excess profits at the taxpayer's expense. There is a strong case for demanding an equity stake in exchange for public money.

webTitle: Camp David hangs on the answer

fields.headline: A new Jerusalem
fields.standfirst:
Camp David hangs on the answer

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Jerusalem, that eternal city, controlled in its time by Romans, Persians, Ottomans, Christendom's crusaders and the British, is the last, thin red line dividing Arabs and Jews at the Camp David peace summit.
fields.body:
Jerusalem, that eternal city, controlled in its time by Romans, Persians, Ottomans, Christendom's crusaders and the British, is the last, thin red line dividing Arabs and Jews at the Camp David peace summit. Important steps have been taken in bridging the other contentious issues. On borders, settlements, and refugees, compromise deals are within tantalising reach. Hence Bill Clinton's extraordinary, feverish machinations and the indefinite detention without trial in Maryland's Catoctin mountains of Israel's Ehud Barak and Palestine's Yasser Arafat. But as ever, all is contingent upon Jerusalem.

Mr Arafat wants Arab-dominated east Jerusalem as his new state's capital, having renounced his claim to control all of the city by his 1993 recognition of Israel's legitimacy. Mr Barak sticks to the even less flexible position that a united Jerusalem is forever Israel's, by dint of history, conquest, and divine right. Yet in plain terms, the two sides already agree on much. They agree that Jerusalem, as a transcendent religious and spiritual capital, must remain undivided. They agree it must be an open city, its places of worship accessible to all. And they agree Jerusalem must be shared by all its peoples. What remains is the issue of sovereignty or, less inspirationally speaking, who has titular control of the real estate.

The Arafat-Barak talks are focusing on ideas first formulated by negotiators Yossi Beilin and Abu Mazen back in 1995. Involving land swaps, expanded city boundaries, flagpoles and local autonomy in east Jerusalem, they provide the trappings and symbols but not the old-fashioned, fully fledged sovereignty to which Mr Arafat aspires. In return for this and other compromises, he is offered Israeli recognition of his state-to-be. Mr Barak digs in; Mr Arafat hesitates.

This is the hinge upon which Camp David's door to peace now swings open, now shut. On this, the whole package rests. It must not be allowed to collapse. With imagination and goodwill, it should be possible for the two sides, while concentrating on practical issues, to accept a form of parallel sovereignty in east Jerusalem that may be interpreted to suit the purposes of both. If not, Mr Clinton may have to insist that the issue be put to binding arbitration by an international commission created for the purpose. Concepts of sovereignty are changing the world over. The Middle East is no different. Eternal city or not, Jerusalem does not justify a perpetual strife.

fields.headline: Disillusion 2001?
fields.standfirst:
Jubilee 2000 must not be betrayed

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Jubilee 2000 has been astonishingly successful in mobilising mass support. At both the last two G8 summits, in Birmingham and Cologne, the campaign got thousands of protesters on to the streets in what became the biggest international movement since anti-apartheid.
fields.body:
Jubilee 2000 has been astonishingly successful in mobilising mass support. At both the last two G8 summits, in Birmingham and Cologne, the campaign got thousands of protesters on to the streets in what became the biggest international movement since anti-apartheid.

Thousands of activists across the world have collected signatures in tiny villages, sprawling shanty towns and the heart of middle-England parishes. A remarkable coalition of the prosperous and the poor has rallied around a simple and ancient ideal of jubilee for the year 2000. Perhaps its greatest achievement is as a mass education campaign, explaining the complex world financial system to peasants and western office workers alike.

And yet, this weekend in Okinawa there is a real danger that the politicians will fail this global millennial aspiration. There, on the sandy beaches of the Pacific island, enjoying the unprecedentedly lavish hospitality of the Japanese, debt is again likely to be the subject of lavish rhetoric. But fine words and big promises do nothing for the poorest countries still waiting to benefit from the deal announced a year ago. We were told in Cologne that the enhanced heavily indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC) would deliver faster, deeper debt relief. Yet one year on, only $12bn has been cancelled out of $100bn which was pledged, and with only five months left to the end of 2000, only nine countries, out of the 25 scheduled to receive relief, have done so. According to Christian Aid, poor countries are still paying $21.9bn a year to rich countries: that is $60m a day.

The truth is that, contrary to the hyperbole, HIPC was never an adequate response to the scale of the problem. Debt-burdened poor countries such as Nigeria and Haiti were left out altogether. Cologne's contribution was to add more conditions with the promise of more money for the few who managed to qualify; countries with frail, overstretched civil services are now expected to devise poverty reduction strategies (with extensive consultation) before they are eligible.

Debt relief has been turned into an obstacle race with such stringent conditions - both of macro-economic management and poverty reduction - that few qualify. That gives the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Washington huge power to discipline developing countries' economies (their sovereignty counts for little). Oxfam sensibly suggests that the system be simplified, and with one condition attached: all funds saved by debt relief must be transferred into a ring-fenced, independently audited fund for poverty reduction, accountable to the debtor government, creditors, non-governmental organisations and civil society. That has been pioneered in Uganda, and it works.

There are huge issues here. Debt relief is a small part of a much, much bigger problem in which globalisation is cruelly exacerbating economic inequality in the world. Tragically, underdevelopment has a frightening capacity to reinforce itself in an escalating spiral of poverty, disease, environmental destruction and political instability. To begin to reverse the process is a hugely difficult challenge; debt relief is a necessary beginning - but no more than that.

An effective system of debt relief has to be put in place fast to enable governments to move on to much bigger problems such as the Aids pandemic in sub-Saharan Africa, highlighted in Durban last week. At stake here is the credibility of world leaders to identify the real global challenges and act on them. That is what they were elected for, and they cannot dodge it - even in the remote isolation of Okinawa.

webTitle: Nato picked Belgrade targets for propaganda targets

fields.headline: Nato picked Belgrade targets for propaganda targets
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: The cruise missile attacks that badly damaged the Serbian television and socialist party headquarters in Belgrade during the Kosovo war were specifically intended to maximise their domestic and international propaganda value, according to senior US officials.
fields.body:
The cruise missile attacks that badly damaged the Serbian television and socialist party headquarters in Belgrade during the Kosovo war were specifically intended to maximise their domestic and international propaganda value, according to senior US officials.

The attacks, among the most controversial of Nato's bombing campaign, killed 16 civilians and injured 16 others.

They are singled out by US officials in an article in the latest issue of Jane's Defence Weekly, which also reveals that the British submarine Splendid fired 20 Tomahawk cruise missiles during the war, 17 of which hit their targets.

It was the first time British forces had used American-made cruise missiles in a military operation.

US ships and submarines fired 218 cruise missiles at 66 targets, and 181 reached their "intended aim-points", naval officers told the magazine.

Planners assessed which parts of the television and party building were most likely to contain the controls for fire alarms and sprinkler systems and the missiles were programmed to hit these spots - they were directed into the sixth floor and on to the roof - to increase the chance that any fire they caused would spread."

The building burned for three days, according to a senior US naval officer, who highlighted the propaganda value of having a well-known and highly visible government building lighting up the Belgrade skyline.

Human Rights Watch in New York sharply criticised the attack in April last year. It rejected claims by General Wesley Clark, then Nato's supreme commander, and British ministers that the building was a "legitimate military target". Amnesty International also condemned the attack as unlawful and said it constituted a war crime.

Nato governments say the building was used to pass information to Serb military units in Kosovo and to promote Serb propaganda.

Another precise target was one floor of a building in Pristina housing the Yugoslav interior ministry police.

Meanwhile it emerged that the families of Serbs killed in the missile attack on the building are suing the television station's bosses and Nato for damages.

"We think they are both equally responsible and both sides are running away from their guilt," said Zanka Stojanovic, whose son Nebojsa was killed during the attack.

The families say the state television company "violated the law by not allowing employees to go into shelters during an air raid".

webTitle: BAE eyes growth in customer service sector

fields.headline: BAE eyes growth in customer service sector
fields.trailText: BAE Systems yesterday set its sights on capturing a large slice of the £50bn global market in customer services over the next 10 years as an engine for future growth.
fields.body:
BAE Systems yesterday set its sights on capturing a large slice of the £50bn global market in customer services over the next 10 years as an engine for future growth.

The Ministry of Defence alone spends £6bn a year servicing its equipment, including fighter aircraft, and BAE wants to more than double its current 2% share of that business over the next three years in a variant of the private finance initiative.

John Weston, chief executive, said on the eve of next week's Farnborough Air Show that the group has signed an agreement with the ministry's defence logistics organisation to help it meet its 20% cost savings target.

These can then be used to fill gaps in the ministry's equipment budget.

BAE Systems already provides some 10% of servicing for Britain's fleet of fighters but admits that it now takes 264 days simply to repair the flap on a Tornado, and this can be sharply reduced.

The group wants to extend its expertise into the navy and army, and provide services such as training as well as repairs and maintenance.

Mr Weston said: "We will then leverage the competencies we are pioneering in the UK in overseas markets."

The group, formed from last year's merger with GEC's Marconi defence business, said that it was on course to meet more than the promised £275m annual savings within three years.

Mr Weston said that senior directors could win enhanced incentive bonuses if they produced £400m savings.

The group has shed some 1,000 managers and recently set out plans for a further 3,800 job losses among its workers.

BAE Systems shares rose 9p, or 2.1%, to close yesterday's session at 438p.

webTitle: Fraud goes to back of crime queue

fields.headline: Fraud goes to back of crime queue
fields.trailText: Alleged frauds are not being investigated because officers are being taken off cases involving white-collar crime to tackle murders and muggings.
fields.body:
Alleged frauds are not being investigated because officers are being taken off cases involving white-collar crime to tackle murders and muggings.

The move has led to a scaling back in regional fraud squads - particularly in the West Midlands, which is at a quarter of its previous strength, and lengthened investigations.

Rosalind Wright, director of the serious fraud office, is worried that the increased time it is taking to investigate more complicated offences might see potential criminals resort to human rights legislation to have their investigations terminated.

The human rights act, which comes into force in October, requires that investigations take a "reasonable" amount of time. "I'm sure one of these days we'll have a successful application [to halt a trial]," Ms Wright said.

The SFO's annual report, which was published yesterday, shows that it is investigating a record 81 cases.

It will receive an additional £13.8m in funding over the next three years under this week's government spending review, which Ms Wright said would be used to hire an additional 30 staff who would take on work normally conducted by regional police forces.

During the year 19 cases were committed or transferred to the crown court, with the average time between acceptance and committal being 32 months - well above the long-run average of 15.3 months.

"Significant improvement will be needed to prevent the figure creeping higher," the SFO said.

webTitle: £50m is just a start for Skipton

fields.headline: £50m is just a start for Skipton
fields.standfirst: 'Nice' banks raise price of loyalty
fields.trailText: Loyalty: it is the new buzz word for the financial services industry. Instead of forever working to lock in customers to high borrowing and low savings rates, banks and building societies appear to be looking for new ways to reward customers who stick by them. Perhaps it is a sign that competition - or at least the threat of it - is finally kicking in.
fields.body:
Loyalty: it is the new buzz word for the financial services industry. Instead of forever working to lock in customers to high borrowing and low savings rates, banks and building societies appear to be looking for new ways to reward customers who stick by them. Perhaps it is a sign that competition - or at least the threat of it - is finally kicking in.

HSBC, for instance, is thinking about ways it can change interest rates for customers who have more than one of its products, a relatively unusual move in the world of quoted banks.

Rewarding loyalty is something more usually associated with the building societies, which have tended to beat their public rivals hands down when it comes to public relations.

Skipton Building Society's move yesterday is a classic example of how the mutuals can still steal the show. The building society is rewarding its "long-term" members who are both borrowers and savers with up to £1,000 in "interest credit".

It is its reaction to record first-half profits, helped by sale of its share dealing subsidiary Dealwise. In all, Skipton plans to give some £50m back to customers who were members in September 1996, when Dealwise was established.

In its gushing announcement, Skipton claims this is on top of the £50m or so it is passing back to members through "interest rate margin" - lower mortgage rates and higher savings rates than a traditional bank - during 2000.

The building society is quick to say that rewarding members for their loyalty is nothing new and part of an ongoing strategy aligned to its "modern approach to mutuality".

While a regular bank would be more likely to reward its shareholders with increased dividends or share buybacks when its cash pile becomes embarrassing, Skipton does not address the question of what its customer-members might get if it decided to end mutuality through a stock market float or a trade sale.

The rewards for ending mutuality might well be higher in the short term. Skipton and the other building societies might just be getting the nudge they need to keep the rewards coming, to keep the anti-mutual movement at bay. They are also having to fight harder against those big bad banks which are latching on to the merits of a friendly approach to customers.

Letsavoidit

The message behind Letsbuyit.com's high-profile television advertising campaign is that as the number of buyers of an item goes up, so the price goes down and down.

Yesterday the fledgling internet retailer discovered a rather more established rule of microeconomics: namely, that if there are not many buyers, the price can plummet.

A few weeks ago starry-eyed company executives were predicting a billion dollar valuation for their young venture. John Palmer, its bullish founder, was even half-jokingly telling people that on crystallisation of his fortune he might just buy Chteau Palmer, the famous Margaux property.

It is unlikely Letsbuyit directors will be toasting each other with too much of the 3eme cru classé stuff today, assum ing the twice postponed float finally goes ahead.

Instead they will probably have a stiff drink and say a little prayer of thanks that the issue has finally got away.

Letsbuyit is expected to come to the market with a rather more sober valuation of around €310m (£190m) and is yet another stark lesson that in the world of cyber-finance, perceived value can disappear even faster than the internet speed at which it was created.

As an idea Letsbuyit is great and it is doubtful the business could exist without the web. But as an investment - particularly at a time when online retail shares are under pressure - it remains a case of letsavoidit.com.

One of the beneficiaries of the chancellor, Gordon Brown's spending spree is the serious fraud office, set up a dozen years ago to bust big and complex financial crime.

The SFO's reputation does not match its success record (68%) and it has been complaining that the police officers traditionally seconded from the City of London and elsewhere to solve these big cases are too busy on other jobs to help.

So a further £13.8m is on its way over the next three years to help the SFO get back on top of its record workload. In practice, it means a further 30 or so investigators on the pay roll.

However, all of this new money will not buy any more clarity over the issue of how the SFO will work with the newly empowered financial services authority.

It is still a muddle, as is the relationship between the FSA and the Department of Trade on the issue of insider dealing cases.

Instead of forever working to lock in customers to high borrowing and low savings rates, banks and building societies appear to be looking for new ways to reward customers who stick by them. HSBC, for instance, is thinking about ways it can change interest rates for customers who have more than one of its products, a relatively unusual move in the world of quoted banks.
