fields.headline: Regulator scuppers Yorkshire Water plan
fields.trailText: Energy regulator Ofgem yesterday effectively scuppered Kelda's plans to turn Yorkshire Water into a mutual by condemning them as inimical to consumers.
fields.body:
Energy regulator Ofgem yesterday effectively scuppered Kelda's plans to turn Yorkshire Water into a mutual by condemning them as inimical to consumers.

Callum McCarthy, Ofgem's director-general, said: "Our duty is to protect customers, and it is absolutely unclear that this proposal is good for customers. Until and unless a series of issues are dealt with properly there seems to me no argument in favour of it."

Mr McCarthy's views on mutualisation in general are certain to be echoed by Sir Ian Byatt, outgoing Ofwat director-general, when he gives his initial response to the Kelda plan next week.

But Kelda insiders insist that even if their plans for a mutual are holed, alternative proposals will have to be developed to address what they say is the water industry's inability to raise enough capital.

Kelda wants to give the assets of Yorkshire Water, its pipes and network, back to its customers in a new mutual entity, which would fund its £1.5bn investment programme entirely through debt. Kelda would initially run its day to day operations.

But Mr McCarthy said there was no evidence that electricity and gas companies had problems raising capital, and dismissed arguments that water was a special case. Mutuals could be forced to seek equity injections, which would undermine the case for a community-owned company.

Kelda sources say: "We will not set up a mutual and finance it unless it has an A rating, as otherwise it will not enjoy a lower cost of capital... banks will demand assurances about its prudence and performance."

But senior managers admit they cannot so far meet a key demand of regulators: the mutualisation must be endorsed by customers in some form of plebiscite. Kelda has received just 11 letters on the issue, and insiders say it is hard to raise the interest that would be caused by a takeover.

Mr McCarthy said it was unclear for whom a mutual's chief executive would speak. Customers would need to be consulted regularly and could, as owners, run into conflicts when the mutual could be forced to raise prices. "The present shareholder structure has delivered lower prices and higher standards," he said.

fields.headline: Vodafone in £1bn watch row
fields.trailText: A fierce row erupted last night in the £1bn battle for control of Les Manufactures Horologères, the Swiss luxury watch business which Vodafone AirTouch inherited as part of its takeover of German rival Mannesmann.
fields.body:
A fierce row erupted last night in the £1bn battle for control of Les Manufactures Horologères, the Swiss luxury watch business which Vodafone AirTouch inherited as part of its takeover of German rival Mannesmann.

There were claims that the luxury goods groups Gucci and LVMH had been pushed out of the formal auction for the business in favour of their Swiss rival, Richemont, which has a portfolio of famous brands such as Cartier, Alfred Dunhill and a 60% stake in Van Cleef and Arpels.

Vodafone is understood to have signed an exclusivity agreement with Richemont, which is also an indirect joint venture partner with Vodafone in the South African mobile phone market.

This brought complaints that Gucci and LVMH were unable to table their best offers for the business - which includes Jaeger-LeCoultre and other luxury watch brands.

Swiss sources claimed that Vodafone had stopped the auction at just over £1bn (2.6bn Swiss francs) despite the fact that Les Manufactures Horologères might attract bids of £1.3bn or more.

"It seems very odd that an exclusivity agreement has been put in place before the auction has run its course," one adviser close to the negotiations said. "I thought the auction was to ensure shareholder value." A Vodafone spokesman refused to comment.

At £1bn, bids for the watch group value the business at a hefty 10 times annual sales. Before the auction commenced, it was presumed it would raise little more than £500m.

The Richemont group is controlled by the South African Rupert family, who also control the Rembrandt Group.

In turn, Rembrandt owns 13.5% of Vodacom, the South African mobile phone business which is 31.5% owned by Vodafone and 50% by the Pretoria government.

Telecoms analysts have speculated that the government may be a willing seller of its stake, with Vodafone the natural buyer. Vodafone has a strategy of trying to take 100% control of associate companies.

Morgan Stanley is understood to be advising Gucci, while Goldman Sachs is working for LVMH. Coincidentally, UBS - one of Vodafone's advisers - also acts as Richemont's investment banker.

The row over sale of the watch business comes at an irritating time for Vodafone chief executive Chris Gent, who is expected to face a stormy annual meeting of shareholders on Thursday in the wake of the controversy over the £10m bonus handed to him as a reward for winning control of Mannesmann in the world's biggest ever hostile takeover battle.

The sale of the watch business follows a string of disposals of non-core Mannesmann assets, including the German company's tubes business and the £27bn sale of Orange, its rival in the British mobile market, to France Telecom.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Positive signals from Greenspan
fields.body:
Positive signals from Greenspan

Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan yesterday welcomed early signs of slowing in the American economy but cautioned that it was too soon to declare victory after a year-long campaign of raising interest rates. Delivering the Fed's twice yearly monetary policy report to Congress, Mr Greenspan said that softening consumer spending might help bring demand back into line with the economy's potential to produce. But he warned that tight labour markets and rising energy prices still posed risks to price stability. The financial markets, braced for a more negative assessment, rallied after his remarks; and the Dow Jones industrial index in New York rose by more than 147 points, ending the day at 10843.87.

£100m rebate for converts.

Four former building societies which converted to banks - Halifax, Woolwich, Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock - are in line for a combined £100m tax rebate. They have won the right to claim corporate tax relief on costs accrued in their flotations, although the Inland Revenue can appeal.

The existence of the potential windfalls were revealed by Northern Rock yesterday as it reported half-year profits of £122m, up 10%. Bob Bennett, the finance director of Northern Rock, said the bank had an ambition to enter the FTSE 100 index, which might ease the volatility in its share price. But the shares still have some way to go to achieve that goal, even after yesterday's 8% rise to £3.25.

Northern Rock sold a record £2bn of new mortgages in the first six months and will pay a 5.1p dividend. said John-Paul Crutchley, an analyst at Merrill Lynch."They are the only mortgage bank growing in their core market".

Engineers face skills shortage

Three out of five engineering companies are having problems recruiting or retaining skilled and professional staff, according to a new survey. Incomes Data Services said more than one in three firms were forced to pay more to recruit staff.

Its survey, covering 100 firms employing 77,000, found that the median basic craft rate was £300 a week; the Engineering Employers Federation says average earnings are closer to £430. The EEF said one in six members has imposed a pay freeze, but IDS says many firms are forced to offer double-digit increases.

New threat to knitwear jobs

Six hundred jobs were threatened last night when Courtaulds warned that a factory at Worksop, Notts, faced closure. The factory makes knitwear for Marks & Spencer and others.

PO chief attacks staff

Post Office chief John Roberts yesterday attacked workers and sub-postmasters. He told MPs that the PO had to deal with "pockets of resistance" to change among workers, and that he could not guarantee that there would be no further strikes.

fields.headline: US threatens BA-KLM deal
fields.standfirst: Washington wants new open skies pact
fields.trailText: British Airways yesterday insisted it could find ways of overcoming any regulatory problems in the United States if it agreed a merger with the Dutch airline KLM.
fields.body:
British Airways yesterday insisted it could find ways of overcoming any regulatory problems in the United States if it agreed a merger with the Dutch airline KLM.

The British airline's comments came after American officials accused it of trying to buy KLM as a Trojan horse to further its interests in the US and promised to block its ambitions.

KLM has an agreement with Northwest Airlines which has anti-trust immunity, something US officials have refused to grant to BA's rival pact with American Airlines.

The Americans are warning that KLM's deal with Northwest - which allows them to operate interlocking flight schedules and joint fares - would have to be dismantled if BA won control of the Dutch carrier.

KLM said last week that it hoped to file an official merger proposal with European regulators by the first week in August. The British flag carrier insisted its dialogue with KLM was still at an early stage and success was by no means guaranteed.

But if a deal were struck, a BA spokesman said he would be "confident that any [US] regulatory issues can be resolved." He declined to be drawn on how it would get round any objections and the City got the jitters, marking down BA shares 10p to 378p.

BA insiders insisted the KLM talks were triggered by the need to consolidate European operations, which lost BA £300m last year, rather than to increase access to the US.

Washington officials appear to be trying to use the possible BA-KLM marriage as a way of furthering their interests in talks between Britain and the US on liberalising their current transatlantic air services pact, known as the Bermuda II treaty. This is regarded as one of the most restrictive treaties in the aviation world. It has run since 1977, and talks on its successor between London and Washington are set to resume in September.

The Americans want Heathrow opened up to more of their airlines and they are aware that BA has been exerting pressure on the British government not to agree to this without big concessions in return.

Dorothy Robyn, a White House official, told the International Aviation Club in Washington: "The US will not allow British Airways to use a merger with KLM, the Dutch carrier, as a back door to achieve greater access to our market".

She warned that, if KLM came under effective control of BA while the Bermuda II treaty remained in force, "KLM will immediately lose the benefits of the US-Netherlands open skies agreement".

BA has been looking at the possibility of taking economic control of KLM while leaving its majority voting rights in Dutch hands. But US experts warn that regulators there would not see KLM as Dutch under such a scheme.

Under the bilateral treaties that govern international aviation, an airline's rights to fly a route are tied to the identity of its national ownership.

fields.headline: Paul Coverdell
fields.standfirst:
Senator from the peanut state who emerged as a major fixer in Washington politics

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The death of the Republican senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia at the age of 61 is a nasty blow to Governor George W Bush of Texas.
fields.body:
The death of the Republican senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia at the age of 61 is a nasty blow to Governor George W Bush of Texas.

Coming only days before his nominating convention, the Republican presidential candidate must now find a last-minute replacement for one of the leading members of his campaign team. The senator, a long-standing and highly-influential family friend, was the Bush's chief link with the Republican majority in the US Senate.

Coverdell's reserved manner and lack of rhetorical sparkle masked a considerable talent for backroom wheeling-and-dealing on which the success of American legislative politics depends. His skills also brought him a major role in revitalising the Republicans in Georgia, effectively a Democratic one-party state for more than a century.

In recent years Senator Coverdell had lived in the shadow of his flamboyant colleague, Congressman Newt Gingrich, until the House majority leader self-destructed after his futile budget fight against President Clinton. Gingrich's consequent defeat and humiliating retirement gave even greater credibility to the senator's quiet diplomacy.

Born in Iowa, he moved south with his parents as a teenager. He took a while to settle into politics, first gaining a degree in journalism at the University of Missouri and then opting briefly for a career in the army. In 1964, after two years' service in Okinawa, Taiwan, and Korea, he returned to civilian life to take charge of the family insurance business.

At 31, he successfully fought his first election, becoming one of the few Georgia Republicans to be returned to the state Senate. Almost immediately he demonstrated his interest in legislative results rather than doctrinal purity, regularly collaborating with Democratic colleagues on projects he thought worth it. He gradually rose to become minority leader in the state Senate. With only five Republicans against 51 Democrats, it was hardly an onerous job and he concentrated most of his energies on building up the local party.

His eventual success was not quite the outcome President Johnson had envisaged when he forced the Civil Rights Act through Congress in 1964. That, however, turned out to be the engine of the southern Republicans' revival. In the 1964 presidential contest, Georgia gave its vote to Barry Goldwater. Next time it backed George Wallace and so confirmed the end of the state's century-old post-Reconstruction tradition. In 1996 Georgia not only voted against Clinton but sent eight Republican congressmen and a mere three Democrats to Washington, a tribute to Coverdell's unremitting organisational efforts.

In 1988, as chairman of the Georgia Republicans, he played a substantial role in Vice-President Bush's presidential campaign in the South. When Bush took over the White House, he rewarded Coverdell with the directorship of the Peace Corps. Faced with the unexpected collapse of communism, Coverdell then spent the next two years establishing new Peace Corps centres across Eastern Europe.

His own bid for election to the US Senate in 1992 was a rude re-introduction to domestic politics. After a very raw campaign, inflamed by furious arguments about the Gulf war, the Democrats initially won the seat with 49% of the vote. State law, however, requires the winner to have an absolute majority and the election had to be re-run. Though President Clinton and Vice-President Gore campaigned hard for the Democrats and more than $1m was spent by each side, Coverdell eventually scraped home with 51%.

On Capitol Hill he initially concentrated on the protection of the peanut industry, on which Georgia relies so heavily. In time, however, his long-term interest in foreign policy came to the fore and he became chairman of the sub-committee dealing with Central America and the Caribbean. That brought him up against two of the country's most sensitive issues, illegal immigration and drug trafficking. He successfully piloted new laws to impose tougher penalties on smugglers and to deport immigrants convicted of crime. He also became the leading proponent of a $1,300m US aid package to help Colombia's fight against drug traffickers and their insurgent protectors.

Once again, however, Coverdell's main work was done behind the scenes. By now ranked fourth in the Senate party leadership, he was a close friend of the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott. As secretary to the Republican conference, Coverdell had to stitch together the sometimes unlikely alliances required in a constitutional system designed around deadlock. Georgia's other (Democratic) senator observed after his colleague's death, "He never showed a trace of personal ego or animosity. He loved politics and he loved to contribute".

This self-effacement could, however, occasionally prove expensive. When Coverdell faced re-election in 1998 he was little known across the state in spite of his six years in the Senate. Opposed by a free-spending multi-millionaire, Coverdell stood doggedly on his Congressional record. He won by 52%, to become the first incumbent to be re-elected to the seat for more than 20 years. But the victory had cost him $7m.

He is survived by his wife, Nancy.

When Bush took over the White House, he rewarded Coverdell with the directorship of the Peace Corps. Faced with the unexpected collapse of communism, Coverdell then spent the next two years establishing new Peace Corps centres across Eastern Europe. His own bid for election to the US Senate in 1992 was a rude re-introduction to domestic politics. After a very raw campaign, inflamed by furious arguments about the Gulf war, the Democrats initially won the seat with 49% of the vote. State law, however, requires the winner to have an absolute majority and the election had to be re-run. Though President Clinton and Vice-President Gore campaigned hard for the Democrats and more than $1m was spent by each side, Coverdell eventually scraped home with 51%. On Capitol Hill he initially concentrated on the protection of the peanut industry, on which Georgia relies so heavily. In time, however, his long-term interest in foreign policy came to the fore and he became chairman of the sub-committee dealing with Central America and the Caribbean. That brought him up against two of the country's most sensitive issues, illegal immigration and drug trafficking. He successfully piloted new laws to impose tougher penalties on smugglers and to deport immigrants convicted of crime. He also became the leading proponent of a $1,300m US aid package to help Colombia's fight against drug traffickers and their insurgent protectors. Once again, however, Coverdell's main work was done behind the scenes. By now ranked fourth in the Senate party leadership, he was a close friend of the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott. As secretary to the Republican conference, Coverdell had to stitch together the sometimes unlikely alliances required in a constitutional system designed around deadlock. Georgia's other (Democratic) senator observed after his colleague's death, "He never showed a trace of personal ego or animosity. He loved politics and he loved to contribute". This self-effacement could, however, occasionally prove expensive. When Coverdell faced re-election in 1998 he was little known across the state in spite of his six years in the Senate. Opposed by a free-spending multi-millionaire, Coverdell stood doggedly on his Congressional record. He won by 52%, to become the first incumbent to be re-elected to the seat for more than 20 years. But the victory had cost him $7m. He is survived by his wife, Nancy. Paul Coverdell, insurance executive and politician, born January 20 1939; died July 18 2000

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Beguiled/Dancing At Lughnasa/Saving Private Ryan/Wild Things
fields.body:
The Beguiled

(Don Siegel, 1970)

8pm, Sky Cinema

Brooding, gothic western with Clint Eastwood's wounded Union soldier seeking refuge in a seminary for Confederate ladies. It veers close to farce, but grows darker as sexual tensions rise. Siegel cooks up menacing tones, and the women are chilling: don't eat those mushrooms, Clint!

Dancing At Lughnasa

(Pat O'Connor, 1998)

8pm, FilmFour

Five sisters live a hard, smalltown life in Donegal, 1936, until the arrival of two men disrupts their quiet domestic routine. One is their missionary brother Jack (Michael Gambon) who's returned, witless, from Africa; the other is Jerry (Rhys Ifans) roving father of the boy of the house. Recounted through the eyes of the child, it's full of wistful longing and wondrous Irish countryside. The acting is faultless, with Meryl Streep and Kathy Burke among the sisters.

Saving Private Ryan

(Steven Spielberg, 1998)

9.30pm, Sky Premier

Reactions to Spielberg's second world war epic ranged from best war movie ever down to cliché-ridden failure. The truth, inevitably, is somewhere in the middle. The plot - a platoon is sent to find Matt Damon's Private Ryan and bring him back safe, his three brothers having died in combat - is contrived comic-book stuff, but there are vivid, emotionally jolting scenes: the opening battle; a knife-fight in a ruined house where you can almost smell the fear; and, more peacefully, the young GIs' faces angelic in candlelight. Tom Hanks is a quietly noble platoon leader, Tom Sizemore his granite-like sergeant.

Wild Things

(John McNaughton, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

Denise (Starship Troopers) Richards and Neve (Scream) Campbell are young women to be wary of, as Matt Dillon's likeable teacher discovers to his cost. They're both alleging rape, and although cop Kevin Bacon suspects a plot, only ramshackle lawyer Bill Murray stands between Dillon and prison in McNaughton's very sly, dark and devious comedy.

fields.headline: Swimming against the tide
fields.trailText: Another day, another puzzle. The FTSE 100 should have ended sharply higher yesterday but it did not and the cause was to be found lurking in the telecom and oil sectors.
fields.body:
Another day, another puzzle. The FTSE 100 should have ended sharply higher yesterday but it did not and the cause was to be found lurking in the telecom and oil sectors.

On the face of it everything looked fine. After all the Dow and the Nasdaq were both showing three-figure gains at the close of play in London and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, had said nothing controversial in his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony.

But the FTSE 100 closed with a rather anaemic gain of 3.6 point to 6,469, hamstrung by the performances of the three market heavyweights. BT eased 11p to 906p, Vodafone AirTouch lost 5p to 307p, and also BP Amoco fell 11p to 586p.

BT was under pressure from reports that it is again encouraging analysts to lower profit forecasts. At least five are said to have reduced their pre-tax profit forecasts by as much as 35% following meetings with the company. They are now understood to be looking for pre-tax profits of around £1.7bn this year, down from £2.9bn last year.

Meanwhile, Vodafone - which moves the index by three points for every penny it rises or falls - was hit by news that one the jewels it acquired through the takeover of Mannesmann is under pressure.

The news came out of a visit Vodafone organised for analysts to D2, its German mobile phone operation. It seems that higher than expected customer acquisition costs will hurt margins at D2. The Vodafone roadshow moves on to Italy today and analysts are praying for no more nasty surprises.

After savaging Kingfisher (down 23p at 553p) on Wednesday, the retail team at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney decided to get stuck into Marks & Spencer, 9.5p lighter at 225p.

Even at its depressed current level, the broker believes the rating of M&S relative to its peers looks demanding. The broker points out that M&S is currently trading on 17.7 times March 2001 earnings, in contrast to Next (15 times) and Debenhams (nine times), which are both showing stronger revenue trends.

ICI, down 16p to 484p, was lower for a second consecutive session unsettled by weak figures from Clariant. But dealers insist there has been some interesting buying in the stock. ICI presents half-year figures next Thursday and dealers claim there could be some exciting news on disposals.

British Airways, down 10p to 378p, was knocked by concerns that the US government will oppose its merger with KLM of the Netherlands.

Anglo American declined 110p to £34 on fears it might be tempted to trump Rio Tinto's offer for Australian mining group North.

The strength of Nasdaq was reflected in the moves of ARM, up 57p to 837p, CMG, 61p better at £11.38 and Logica, 95p stronger at £18.

Banking stocks were firmer, led by Lloyds TSB , up 26p to 627p, and Barclays, 43p higher at £15.63. Both were helped by a positive note from broker CSFB.

On the speculative front, a late surge in Durlacher was watched with interest. Those in the know insist that a big announcement is due from the internet investment group any day. The shares closed the day up 6p at 77.5p.

IT training outfit Skillsgroup shot up 10p to 137.35p on heavy turnover of 8.3m shares on whispers that NTL was building a stake as a prelude to a takeover.

Predictably, those close to the company were groaning at such a suggestion. First, it was pointed out directors had recently acquired more than 230,000 shares (hardly the action of those party to takeover discussions) and second that the heavy trading was related to an institution switching its holding between funds.

Alterian, the database specialist, made a sparkling market debut. Shares in the company closed at 300p, up 100p from its placing price.

fields.headline: At this price?  BT
fields.trailText: Managers at British Telecom must be feeling they cannot put a step right. Despite restructuring the group into four divisions and plans for partial flotations for divisions such as internet, mobile and its Yellow Pages directory service, the share price continues to bob below the £10 mark.
fields.body:
Managers at British Telecom must be feeling they cannot put a step right. Despite restructuring the group into four divisions and plans for partial flotations for divisions such as internet, mobile and its Yellow Pages directory service, the share price continues to bob below the £10 mark.

The aim of the restructuring and mooted flotations was to create greater transparency of the company's share market value, management and operation.

It failed to work. Analysts want still more detailed information on BT's strategy and, more importantly, a timetable for the flotations.

BT knows it lags its peers embarrassingly in pursuing an aggressive sell-off strategy such as France Telecom, Deutsche Telekom and Telefonica have pursued.

There are also the results from BT's recent spending, awaited by investors. Some are becoming impatient.

The group has splashed out £4.3bn on a third-generation mobile phone licence, £4.6bn on upgrading its local network to accommodate digital subscriber line technology that will deliver high-speed internet access. Mopping up subsidiaries cost £1.2bn for Telfort and £1.5bn for Esat.

That has raised BT's inter est bill to an expected £1.1bn in the 2001 financial year, and some analysts knocked back profit forecasts from £1.9bn to £1.7bn. Those who failed to adjust for all this spending in their profit forecasts for BT murmured "downgrade" and shares slipped 11p to 905p.

BT denies it directed any analysts to adjust their profit forecasts downward but, with first quarter results out next week, managers appear to have fumbled the investor relations side of things.

While BT is looking like a clunky former state-owned monopoly there is no denying the value that lies in its businesses, particularly its mobile arm, Cellnet, given France Telecom bought Orange for £27bn.

BT is worth buying for those with patience.

fields.headline: Alarms at Inchcape
fields.trailText: When Sir Ron Brierley's activist investment vehicle, Guinness Peat Group, appears on a shareholder register, investors can be sure of fun and games. Just ask John Young, chairman of south London brewer Young & Co, who had to use a megaphone to drown out a GPG representative at this week's annual meeting.
fields.body:
When Sir Ron Brierley's activist investment vehicle, Guinness Peat Group, appears on a shareholder register, investors can be sure of fun and games. Just ask John Young, chairman of south London brewer Young & Co, who had to use a megaphone to drown out a GPG representative at this week's annual meeting.

GPG has now popped up on the register of automotive services group Inchcape with a 10.76% stake and while sources insist it is early days - GPG has yet to meet the management - fireworks are inevitable.

Ominously for Inchcape, this is a business Brierley knows well, having sold it an operation in the distant past.

This has all the makings of a classic. Inchcape investors would do well to recall that with its stake GPG can call for an emergency meeting. Inchcape shares, which trade at discount to net asset value, closed up 2.5p at 262.5p.

webTitle: Shoe clue in hunt for child killer

fields.headline: Shoe clue in hunt for child killer
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case<
fields.trailText: Police hunting the killer of eight-year-old Sarah Payne have found a child's shoe near where her body was discovered in undergrowth.
fields.body:
Police hunting the killer of eight-year-old Sarah Payne have found a child's shoe near where her body was discovered in undergrowth.

Officers, who are also investigating screams heard by campers nearby, said the shoe could provide vital evidence and they renewed their appeal to find Sarah's blue dress and other clothes.

Detective Superintendent Peter Kennet, taking over as main investigating officer in the murder hunt, said DNA tests would be carried out to confirm the shoe was Sarah's. "There is the possibility of fibre transfer from someone that has been in contact with it. That is a big hope for us."

The black Velcro-fastening right shoe was found on Tuesday night, in a hedge near the village of Coolham about a mile from Pulborough in West Sussex. Police said it appeared to have been casually discarded.

Sarah went missing from a country lane near her grandparents' home in Kingston Gorse, West Sussex, on the evening of July 1. Her body was discovered hidden in a field 12 miles away. Police revealed yesterday that campers had heard screams on the night Sarah vanished.

They came forward to report the cries after realising their campsite was only three miles from where the child's body was found. They had been concerned about the screams, but did not attach importance to them.

Chief Inspector Mike Alderson said: "It may be significant, or it may not, we just don't know. It could just have been a little girl playing - it was a pleasant enough evening."

Police believe Sarah was killed between 7.30pm on the day she went missing and the morning of the next day. A postmortem did not uncover violent external injuries. It is possible she was strangled or suffocated.

An appeal fund has been set up by police as a focus for the hundreds of people who have sent money for the family. Anyone wishing to contribute can send cheques payable to M Payne to Littlehampton police station, West Sussex.

webTitle: Grants woo more graduates as would-be teachers

fields.headline: Grants woo more graduates as would-be teachers
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Applications for postgraduate teacher training have increased by nearly 50% since the government promised £6,000 grants for trainees, figures out yesterday show.
fields.body:
Applications for postgraduate teacher training have increased by nearly 50% since the government promised £6,000 grants for trainees, figures out yesterday show.

But separate figures from the universities and colleges admissions service, published today, show a 4.6% decline in applications for four-year undergraduate BEd courses, with which teachers qualify.

Applications for secondary school BEd courses fell by 12.8% to 8,967, suggesting the grants may not so much encourage new people to teach as change the way that those who were going to be teachers anyway are trained.

Overall, applications for higher education courses are down 0.4% on last year.

A Ucas spokesman said many students who would have taken a BEd course may instead complete a subject-based degree course and then take the postgraduate qualification, with the £6,000 bursary.

Since the bursary was announced in March 2,830 graduates have applied for teacher training, an increase of 48% on the same period last year, the teacher training agency said.

Applications for postgraduate teaching courses had been falling since 1995, but have risen this year by 1%. Whereas 16,936 applications had been made by July 15 last year, 17,463 were made by the same date this year.

The Department for Education and Employment said that until March 30 this year, before the new recruitment bursaries were announced, applications were 11% down.

Estelle Morris, the schools minister, welcomed the rise as a vindication of the bursaries and the £4,000 "golden hellos" for teachers in shortage subjects.

The awards, available from last September in maths and science, are being extended this year to modern languages and technology.

Across those four subjects, applications are up by more than 1,000, including 432 applications for modern languages and 288 for technology.

There has been a fall in maths teacher applications this year, Ms Morris conceded, but she said they were still 30% up on 1998, before the golden hellos were introduced. There were still shortages in London.

"We still need more teachers, but our introduction of training salaries has stopped a long-term decline in applications," Ms Morris said.

Teachers will receive the £4,000 when they are qualified, after the post-graduate course and an induction year in schools.

But NUT general secretary Doug McAvoy said: "A quick fix always produces an instant response, but this is a limited response and doesn't deal with the shortfalls that have built up over the years.

"The government has chosen to conceal the fact that applications do not turn into trainees and may never turn into teachers. This leaves the profession struggling to have sufficient teachers to maintain existing provision let alone deliver on government plans," said Mr McAvoy

The Ucas figures show a 2.5% increase in students who want to study from home.

The government has decided not to appeal against its high court defeat last Friday over performance-related pay. The threshold standards will now be put before the school teachers review body for consultation.

Ms Morris promised teachers would receive money backdated to September 1 this year, "so long as there are no further problems".

fields.headline: Reporter and officer cleared
fields.trailText: A tabloid newspaper journalist and a detective were yesterday cleared of having a corrupt relationship.
fields.body:
A tabloid newspaper journalist and a detective were yesterday cleared of having a corrupt relationship.

Neville Thurlbeck, the News of the World's chief crime reporter, and Detective Constable Richard Farmer were each cleared of conspiracy to corrupt, after a judge at Luton crown court ruled there was no case for either to answer.

Thurlbeck was also cleared of corruptly offering a police officer payment in return for information.

Stephen Kramer QC, prosecuting, had alleged that Thurlbeck paid DC Farmer to supply information about people on confidential police computer records. DC Farmer was said to have supplied information for 36 stories, including an unnamed Labour MP with a conviction for committing an obscene act; a sex offender who raped a child shortly after being released from prison; and an alleged threat to the Queen from stalkers.

Thurlbeck also supplied information, but there was no suggestion that Thurlbeck behaved illegally or benefited financially as a result of his role as a "confidential police source", the court heard.

"This was a symbiotic or two-way relationship," said the judge, Mr Justice McKinnon. "Mr Thurlbeck undoubtedly supplied information to Mr Farmer which was of interest to the police. In return for which, Mr Farmer provided to Mr Thurlbeck, not confidential or sensitive information, but information principally about criminals' previous convictions which he obtained from the police national computer."

fields.headline: No: 1682
fields.standfirst: Ali G
fields.trailText: Ali G
fields.body:
Hood: Staines.

I be da real Ali G. Check dis out . Bookaprize! Fantastic. You must be only the 5,000th person to mimic Mr G's distinctive patter. Don't you know it's offensive to real players from the street like myself?

For real? Well, about as real as Ali creator Sacha Baron Cohen. The Cambridge graduate is set to trouser enough money to buy Staines, never mind live there.

Yes. Which, curiously, brings us right back to Hugh Grant ...

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the National Dairy Council ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the National Dairy Council ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: A cartoon version of Frank Carson stands on stage in a northern club cracking his usual gags. "It's the way I tell 'em," he says, to a highly amused audience. He then launches into one of his fabled mother-in-law jokes when suddenly he spots the fine lady in question at the back of the club, staring menacingly at him. Thrown by her presence, he stumbles over his words, begins to sweat, and then completely dies on stage.

"That, erm, was not a cracker," he mutters feebly, as a Jonathan Woss voiceover chirrups: "The White Stuff. Are you made of it?"

The jargon: This ad is based on the notion that people who drink milk are admirable and heroic and have more backbone than those who don't (they're made of the right stuff, basically). Frank Carson was chosen because the agency BMP DDB wanted someone immediately identifiable. He's also funny.

Personality: You're an adult, especially a parent, who already drinks the odd glass of milk but who could potentially drink more. In a sort of reversal of Pester Power, the thinking is also that if you drink milk, your kids are likely to drink it more too (it's tricky targeting kids directly because they think milk is boring, etc).

Financial status: The ad is fairly populist, aimed at anyone of any social or financial standing who likes milk. A pint costs between 25p (supermarket) and 40p (delivered) so it's all very affordable.

Telling lifestyle detail: You're not Worcester Woman or Mondeo Man but a Regular Dad who might have a young daughter and who grabs a swig of milk from the fridge when you get home from work.

Other relevant data: The ad uses the real voice of Frank Carson, who was recorded at home in Sheffield. It's one of a series of three spots, the others starring George Best having a pint (of milk, that is) and Chrith Eubank. An animated Tom Jones version is coming next.

fields.headline: Size is everything
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Masterblasters/Head On Comedy/Motoring Madness
fields.body:
There are few things more exciting than a good firework display, as anyone who was sober enough to remember the millennium celebrations will know. Television programmes about fireworks, however, are quite a lot less exciting than the real thing. Masterblasters (BBC2) followed the preparations for the biggest display ever in Houston, Texas last October, and inevitably we were headed for disappointment. What makes you go "oooooh!" in real life barely raises a flicker on the small screen; even the extremely expensive kaleidoscope shells that topped the bill looked like small, damp squibs.

As if to compensate for this inevitable anticlimax, the bulk of the programme focused on the build-up to the main event, and sought to impress us with figures. Eighteen tons of explosive, one million people, 162 square blocks, 20 years of experience, 106 helicopter lifts, 20,000 fireworks, 75 tons of sands, three French hens, two turtle doves. Narrator Bill Paterson repeated the figures like a mantra, hoping to bludgeon the viewer into admiration. This was all very impressive, but not very interesting. Ultimately, you can only watch a man fiddling with a computer screen or packing sand round a cardboard tube so many times. Pyro-maestro Eric Tucker was a nice, uncharismatic man who oversaw a very efficient operation. Nothing went wrong. There were no last-minute hitches. Despite the concerns of the jobsworth from the fire department, nobody was pelted with red-hot debris in the "fall-out zone". Rockets went off in time to music, lasers raked the sky, and not even a pigeon got fried. The faces of the crowd suggested that the spectacle was worth seeing, but you really had to be there.

Judging by the faces of the panellists in Head On Comedy (BBC1), this was another show that was a lot more fun in the flesh. Two teams of comedians debated the motion "This house believes the earth will not survive the next millennium" under the watchful eye of Jo Brand, and while each speaker did their turn the rest of the guests grinned politely. Barry Cryer managed to raise a certain amount of splenetic mirth, while Leslie Phillips was vague and fruity. Arabella Weir and Doon McKichan seemed completely at sea with identikit routines about how useless men are. This left team captains Ed Byrne and Bill Bailey to witter aimlessly on without point or punchline. Their hair was much funnier than anything they said. Highpoint of the debate was Phillips saying the word "panties" for no particular reason. One suddenly realised why Kenneth Williams was always in such demand for this kind of thing: at least he could be relied upon to inject a bit of life into the proceedings. This lot seemed to be partially sedated.

The biggest laugh of the evening was provided by Motoring Madness , a breathtakingly dumb piece of television from ITV. You might have thought in these post-Driving School days that we'd had enough of people freaking out at the steering wheel. Apparently not. Motoring Madness introduced us to Sam and Tracey and their children, "the angriest family on four wheels", who swore violently all the way down to the seaside, had a lovely time then swore some more (and had an accident) on the way back. There were so many bleeps it began to sound like a Kraftwerk record, but this didn't deter Sam, who got his point across loud and clear with a masturbatory hand gesture when words failed.

Star of the show was an unnamed clamper in Harrogate, who lurked behind a wall outside a video shop then sprang into action to clamp anyone foolish enough to park there. Each sting bagged him £75, and he took no prisoners. Concealed cameras looked on as a hearse drove up and parked. Would Clampitt do the decent thing, or would he bleep! Clamps went on, and the driver (a production stooge) protested he was on his way to a funeral. While he went to the cashpoint, Clampitt and his mate celebrated their victory with a few photos and much mirth ("He's got a dead body in the back of it!"). Finally the cameras moved in for the sting, but Clampitt was unrepentant and demanded his £75 without apology. Here at least is a man who loves his work, although he might want to think about moving out of the Yorkshire area for the foreseeable future.

fields.headline: What leak?
fields.trailText:
How long will the media and political parties perpetuate the myth that the latest round of beautifully timed and toned press releases by the government are "leaks"? The first one of the week included the wonderful phrase "touchstone issues" which found its way on to every TV and newspaper graphic within hours. What we want next is a leak about a leak, in the hope of double bluffing the clever people of the media.
Adam Potterton
Oxford

 The leaked memos reveal a worrying set of priorities at No 10. Traditional Labour voters are not likely to be won back by the revelation that the concerns of the party leadership on issues of nationalism, law and order, and the rights of asylum seekers are not dissimilar from those of the British National party.
Dennis Douglas
Oxford

fields.headline: A very ordinary school
fields.trailText: Contrary to the impression given by Nick Davies (School where crack dealers and yardies came calling - for the headteacher, July 17), Stamford Hill primary school is not under siege from crack-dealing yardie gangs. This caricature of the daily life of our school is severely damaging to every child, parent and member of staff. Stamford Hill is an ordinary inner-city school whose pupils are getting on with their education after receiving two Ofsted inspections that praised the school for its achievements.
fields.body:
Contrary to the impression given by Nick Davies (School where crack dealers and yardies came calling - for the headteacher, July 17), Stamford Hill primary school is not under siege from crack-dealing yardie gangs. This caricature of the daily life of our school is severely damaging to every child, parent and member of staff. Stamford Hill is an ordinary inner-city school whose pupils are getting on with their education after receiving two Ofsted inspections that praised the school for its achievements.

The only extraordinary fact about Stamford Hill primary is the profound betrayal of trust visited upon it by the former headteacher and the school's admirable capacity to maintain the safety and education of the pupils during this very traumatic period.

To return to mundane facts, the governors' disciplinary committee heard evidence that resulted in a unanimous decision to dismiss Angela Ellis for gross misconduct. She was invited to attend many times but declined and has not taken up the opportunity of an appeal. We cannot comment too much on the bizarre story she has offered (to the newspaper, not to us) in mitigation of her actions.

Governors are gratified that Haringey LEA has agreed to replace the computers taken from the school and look forward to receiving the New Deal money they have told newspapers they will be trying to obtain for us. It is not the way we wanted to draw attention to our hard-working and consistently under-funded school, but it seems to have achieved what many unacknowledged letters to the LEA have not.
Stamford Hill primary school board of governors
London

fields.headline: Personal tragedy, public sensation
fields.trailText: I can't see the point of June Purvis's letter (July 20) complaining that the Guardian did not put a picture of Sarah Payne on its front page on July 18 or 19. What does she think would have been achieved? That the killer would confess? That we would gain a new insight into the case?
fields.body:
I can't see the point of June Purvis's letter (July 20) complaining that the Guardian did not put a picture of Sarah Payne on its front page on July 18 or 19. What does she think would have been achieved? That the killer would confess? That we would gain a new insight into the case?

Doesn't she understand that continued coverage when there is nothing new to add is a species of the intrusion and violation that has already devastated the family? Hasn't she considered that the conventions of reporting too often convert personal tragedy into public sensation or, more insidiously, that they flatter our sense of right and wrong at a dangerously visceral level?

Look at those newspapers which have pictured Sarah on their cover. They have whipped up a lynch-mob mentality where vicious self-righteousness overpowers more sober attempts to understand why such things happen. Undoubtedly there are evil people in the world, but how many paedophiles were themselves victims of abuse? The truth is that most are not born bad, but made that way. Sadly, their perverse habits are then reinforced by living in a society that sexualises young children, particularly girls. And aren't we all partly responsible for that?

I suggest Purvis reads Oliver James's account of the press treatment of Sarah Payne's murder (Playing on parents' fears, July 20). This might answer her question as to why Gordon Brown and not Sarah was on the front page on July 19.

The government's new spending plans give some support to families on low incomes. It is this group who, because of the pressures of poverty, poor education and social exclusion, represent a greater danger to children, especially their own, than any passing stranger. By making such connections James, in a very small way, is helping us to move forward on this highly sensitive issue.
Gary Day
Bedford

 There was a lack of humanity about Oliver James's piece. I suspect most parents followed the coverage of the Sarah Payne case, putting themselves in the position of her family. Those outside the target group for murdering their offspring did not, I contend, harbour thoughts of what it would be like to be killed and tortured nor did we imagine being the killer. We did not view this like an episode of Morse or Cracker but with intense sympathy for a family enduring the worst thing we can imagine befalling us.
Robert Shrimsley
London

 Dea Birkett (If it's daddy, we don't care, July 20) is absolutely right. A lengthy moral panic about paedophilia has diverted attention from the family as the main site for the physical and sexual abuse of children. Violent or sexual gratification is presented as the motivation of a few perverts when - as with other manifestations like football hooliganism - the ultimate problem is "normal" masculinity. Men have nothing to fear from this systematic distortion; children have.
Chas Critcher
Sheffield Hallam University val@meadowhead.free-online.co.uk

 The reason the public react so much more to a killing of a child by a stranger than a parent is simply fear. We fear for own children's safety, especially when the killer is still at large. When a child is killed by a parent, most parents do not feel threatened because they know it could not happen in their family. Perhaps it is complacency which makes us less sympathetic.
Maggie Vine
Blandford, Dorset fatal.femmes@virgin.net

 Dea Birkett seems to have mixed up two very different things - what the media see fit to publish on the front pages of newspapers, and what we the public actually want to read about. I was not aware of the unfortunate death of little Jade Austin and her brother; however, I can pinpoint to the hour when Victoria Beckham last had her breasts fondled by her husband.
Rebekah Vaughan
Sutton, Surrey

 Maybe I am more horrified by the death of Sarah Payne because she comes from my village, and her little sister goes to the same school as my son. But if it had been Jade Austin who lived closer to us than Sarah, it would have been the other way round.

If you are going to blame anyone for the picture that has been painted here, blame the media. They are what we rely on to get us the news. If the story, in their eyes, isn't "juicy" enough, it gets back-page coverage. If, like the Sarah Payne case, it looks as if it will sell papers, it will get on the front page. It's not the public who put it there.
Natalie Sasso
Hersham, Surrey brinn.boss@talk21.com

 The difference between the high level of interest in the disappearance of Sarah Payne and in children killed by their parents is precisely because it was a disappearance. We all hoped that Sarah would be alive. Now that the worst is known, the level of interest in bringing the killer to justice will surely be the same as for the murder of any other child, by parent or stranger.
Jack Treagus
Manchester

fields.headline: Inspecting the taxman
fields.trailText:
So 5.2m tax files disappear (July 20). Do we tell the Treasury it can have funding only if it does better, do we send in a squad to set things in order, do we bring in private contractors, or do we impose inspectors (Offchance?) on the chancellor. The next time members of the government sound off patronisingly about local authorities, doctors or teachers, perhaps they will first meditate on the proverb "Physician heal thyself".
Jeffrey Boss
Stroud, Glos

 Ken Macdonald (Letters, July 20) has got it wrong. As a Welshman I follow the old rule: 1) It's another triumph for Great Britain, or 2) England loses again.
Gareth Williams
Ystrad Mynach, Caerphilly

 So the Queen Mother's centenary pageant in Whitehall was disrupted by the closure of part of London's transport system (Republican bomb paralyses London, July 20). As I sat in my car for more than an hour and half, because half the streets in Victoria were shut down in the middle of the rush hour so she and her invited friends could travel to and from her birthday bash, I really felt sorry for the old dear. Honestly, some people are just too inconsiderate.
Robert Kelly
London

 Little public expense is spared in celebrating one woman's 100th birthday. Retired people receive 75p extra state pension per week. Modernising Britain or has the silly season arrived early?
Keith Popple
Southampton

 I went to Disneyland, Paris two weeks ago. I was really pleased to discover that, as I have Down's syndrome, I didn't have to queue for any rides. Disneyland gives priority to disabled people, which is really cool. It would be great if theme parks in Britain followed their example.
John-Paul Gower (aged 15)
Mold, Flintshire

Do we tell the Treasury it can have funding only if it does better, do we send in a squad to set things in order, do we bring in private contractors, or do we impose inspectors (Offchance?) on the chancellor. The next time members of the government sound off patronisingly about local authorities, doctors or teachers, perhaps they will first meditate on the proverb "Physician heal thyself". Jeffrey Boss Stroud, Glos  Ken Macdonald (Letters, July 20) has got it wrong. As a Welshman I follow the old rule: 1) It's another triumph for Great Britain, or 2) England loses again. Gareth Williams Ystrad Mynach, Caerphilly  So the Queen Mother's centenary pageant in Whitehall was disrupted by the closure of part of London's transport system (Republican bomb paralyses London, July 20). As I sat in my car for more than an hour and half, because half the streets in Victoria were shut down in the middle of the rush hour so she and her invited friends could travel to and from her birthday bash, I really felt sorry for the old dear. Honestly, some people are just too inconsiderate. Robert Kelly London  Little public expense is spared in celebrating one woman's 100th birthday. Retired people receive 75p extra state pension per week. Modernising Britain or has the silly season arrived early? Keith Popple Southampton  I went to Disneyland, Paris two weeks ago. I was really pleased to discover that, as I have Down's syndrome, I didn't have to queue for any rides. Disneyland gives priority to disabled people, which is really cool. It would be great if theme parks in Britain followed their example. John-Paul Gower (aged 15) Mold, Flintshire

fields.headline: Catholic who won't confess
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Westminster is being disingenuous in claiming that 20 years ago he did not understand the nature of paedophilia (Catholic leader appointed paedophile priest, July 20).
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Westminster is being disingenuous in claiming that 20 years ago he did not understand the nature of paedophilia (Catholic leader appointed paedophile priest, July 20).

The Roman Catholic church has, through the confessional and, more particularly through the seminaries, an extensive knowledge of the varieties of human sexuality.

The efficiency with which its authorities have moved potential sources of embarrassment from parish to parish, job to job and even country to country for very many more than 20 years was born of a shrewd understanding which belies the archbishop's plea of innocence.
David Pocock
Lewes, E Sussex

 After reading your article on Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, my first response was not to write a letter to the Guardian expressing my disgust. You helpfully included a website address for the Catholic church so I attempted to register my protest at this shocking mismanagement there. The website contained plenty of rhetoric from Murphy-O'Connor, but no opportunity for anyone to register their opinions on the subject.

This sums up for me, one of the many reasons why I am an ex-Catholic. The church is full of mechanisms for delivering dictates on behaviour, but scanty opportunities for any criticism of itself.
Beattie King
London b.king@mdx.ac.uk

fields.headline: Dave Pearce
fields.standfirst: Heavyweight whose misfortune was to fight in an era of giants
fields.trailText: The career of the 1980s British heavyweight boxing champion David "Bomber" Pearce, who has died aged 41, was cut short when brain scan irregularities led to his suspension by the British Boxing Board of Control. But the former Newport steelworker relentlessly campaigned for the return of his licence.
fields.body:
The career of the 1980s British heavyweight boxing champion David "Bomber" Pearce, who has died aged 41, was cut short when brain scan irregularities led to his suspension by the British Boxing Board of Control. But the former Newport steelworker relentlessly campaigned for the return of his licence.

Courageous and durable, with a fierce left hook, Pearce won 17 fights out of 21 but it was his misfortune to work in an era dominated by behemoths. Standing just six feet and tipping the scales at around 200lbs, he would have been better suited to the 190lb cruiserweight class, which was not established until the twilight of his career.

Pearce won the British championship - in September 1983 - when public interest in the mediocre domestic division was low. It took nine rounds for him to avenge an earlier defeat against the ponderous fellow Welshman Neville Meade at Cardiff that night, which undermined his ambition of challenging world champion Larry Holmes. But his record did include a knockout of the much-touted American prospect Larry McDonald.

Following victory over Meade, Pearce fought Lucien Rodriguez for the European title. The Frenchman survived a knockdown before scraping a narrow points decision.

The British champion's subsequent disclosure that he had spent the previous night sleeping on a bench at Heathrow's departure lounge came as something of a shock to his manager, Burt McCarthy, who had lent the fighter £200 for a hotel room. The pair parted acrimoniously and Pearce lost his licence soon afterwards. He had been on the breadline even during his brief reign as champion. He lived with his parents, and subsisted on cod his father - a former fairground booth fighter - brought home from fishing trips.

Pearce was one of seven brothers, six of whom fought professionally. He took up the sport at 10 and won a fistful of schoolboy and senior amateur titles prior to turning professional in his teens, first under Howard Winstone's old manager, Eddie Thomas. He had flattened his first opponent in less than a minute.

After rejecting offers to fight on the unlicenced circuit, Pearce returned to the ring after seven years in December 1990, against the American Purcell Davis in Michigan. Pearce was outweighed by around five stones, and the bout was stopped in the eighth round. He never fought again.

Plagued by epilepsy, Pearce lived alone. "It's not very nice," he observed of his financial plight. "I'm not a brickie, a carpenter or an electrician. I am a professional boxer - and a bloody good one."

He is survived by a son.

David Nigel Pearce, boxer, born May 8 1959; died May 20 2000

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • In a report about the banning of expeditions to Kanchenjunga by the authorities in Sikkim, page 17, July 13, we said the mountain was first climbed in 1953 by the Briton Charles Evans. In fact Charles Evans led the British/New Zealand team that made the first successful ascent on May 25, 1955 (not 1953). He did not reach the summit himself. In fact, neither (quite) did the two members of his team George Band and Joe Brown who made the ascent. Like N Hardie and HRA Streather who climbed it the following day, they stopped just short of the top in deference to the   wish of the Maharaja of Sikkim that it should not be trodden. Kanchenjunga (or Kangchenjunga) is 8586m high (28,169 feet), and not as we said in the piece (information from the Alpine Club).

fields.headline: Divers hunt for Titanic treasures
fields.trailText: The first manned dive of the Titanic sets off today to try to salvage some $300m (£200m) worth of diamonds and jewellery from inside the doomed liner.
fields.body:
The first manned dive of the Titanic sets off today to try to salvage some $300m (£200m) worth of diamonds and jewellery from inside the doomed liner.

Expedition leaders from the United States, accompanied by Russian and British vessels, hope to find a shipment of diamonds in the front cargo hold and to salvage passengers' personal jewellery which is thought to have been hurriedly collected by pursers as the ship sank in 1912. The bags should have been loaded on to lifeboats but were left on board.

RMS Titanic, the Florida-based firm which owns rights to salvage the site, said the prospects of finding the treasure were "like finding a needle in a haystack, not even a haystack". Any artifacts found will be preserved for display.

The expedition, equipped with two manned submarines, also aims to lift the anchor.

webTitle: Long road back into the black

fields.headline: Long road back into the black
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Why is debt relief so slow? How can it be speeded up?
fields.body:
Why is debt relief so slow?

 Poor countries must prepare detailed plans for the IMF and World Bank explaining how they will spend the money, and this is taking much longer than expected

 The IMF and the bank are using the plans to demand extra reforms - for example, in Honduras the IMF demanded that it include plans to privatise its electricity sector

 Some of the countries on the list are in conflict and the G8 are reluctant to give more money to poor countries spending resources on arms rather than health or education

 The G8 have failed to stump up all the cash they promised last year to pay the World Bank and IMF bills

How can it be speeded up?

 Drop the requirement for countries to prepare detailed anti-poverty plans before they get their loans cancelled, and give debt relief to countries who agree to put the money in a ring-fenced anti-poverty fund

 Review all debt-burdened countries - including countries such as Nigeria which are not even on the list to receive writeoffs - to find out where the hold-ups lie

 Reverse the burden of proof: if it wants to stop debt cancellation, the IMF should be required to prove that a country will waste the money, rather than the country having to prove it will spend it wisely

fields.headline: Italy arrests Chinese traffickers
fields.trailText: The Italian police said yesterday that they had smashed a human trafficking ring after infiltrating a network of three gangs responsible for smuggling 5,000 Chinese nationals into the country this year.
fields.byline: Rory Carroll  in Rome and Jon Henley  in Paris
fields.body:
The Italian police said yesterday that they had smashed a human trafficking ring after infiltrating a network of three gangs responsible for smuggling 5,000 Chinese nationals into the country this year.

Forty people were arrested in an undercover operation, and another 20 are on the run. The scale and audacity of the trafficking, which brought in more than £40m, suggested that the 58 Chinese corpses discovered in Dover last month had not interrupted supply or demand, the police said.

Italy has the most porous borders in Europe. As if to illustrate the size of the problem, a further 400 would-be immigrants, mostly Kurds, arrived yesterday on a rusty freighter which steamed into the port of Reggio di Calabria.

The concern of the Italian police was echoed yesterday at a meeting of ministers in Paris, where the French interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, described the question of migration as "one of the major issues of the 21st century for Europe".

Saying he expected the European Union to absorb up to 50m immigrants in the next 50 years, Mr Chevènement told the conference that Russian, Turkish and Albanian mafias now controlled global human trafficking networks.

He announced plans to treble the £1,000 fine France imposes on transport companies for every illegal immigrant found travelling in a lorry, plane or boat. But the Australian immigration minister, Philip Ruddock, said that far stronger measures were needed, citing Australia's maximum 20-year prison term for immigrant smugglers.

Police fear that the 20 smugglers who escaped yesterday fled to the relative safety of Croatia through bordering Slovenia. The 40 people arrested were mostly Chinese but included Croats, Slovenes and Italians.

The year-long operation was launched after 50 Chinese immigrants and asylum seekers were rescued from sweatshops where they were forced to work to pay for their trip. They claimed that the traffickers threatened, beat and tortured those who could not pay the £8,000-10,000 fee, sometimes relaying their screams down the telephone to relatives at home.

Most of the arrests took place on Tuesday in Trieste, Rome, Bologna, Udine and Verona, but were announced only yesterday, hours after an unrelated national sweep and deportation of 90 Nigerian prostitutes.

The immigrants, mostly young men, were flown from Beijing to Moscow, Kiev or Budapest, and then taken to Italy by truck through Slovenia and Croatia. Twenty-six Chinese nationals were recently found hiding in a tanker near the Croatian capital Zagreb.

Rival gangs based in Trieste use land routes through Yugoslavia and Bosnia, or cross the Adriatic from Albania in semi-inflatable dinghies.

The Italian police say a key figures in Balkan smuggling and a boss of the network smashed this week is a 43-year-old Croat. A former mechanic, he is said to have started smuggling contraband into Italy 15 years ago.

Wanted in Italy and hounded from Slovenia, he has returned to Croatia to run his empire. The man's lawyer said he was not involved and had not been convicted of any crime.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pakistan issues nuclear warning
fields.body:
Pakistan issues nuclear warning

Pakistan will consider using nuclear weapons first if attacked by conventional forces, its deputy foreign minister said yesterday.

"There is no way Pakistan can hold out any assurance that it will not use any nuclear weapons if its existence is threatened," Inam ul Haque said on a visit to Germany.
Reuters, Berlin

Uganda cult took 780 lives

The final death toll in the doomsday cult massacre and mass suicide in Uganda in March was 780, the police said yesterday.

Hundreds of members of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments were burned alive in a church in Kanungu, western Uganda.

The police believe that cult leaders killed another 400 followers after their prediction that the world would end at the beginning of 2000 failed to come true.
Reuters, Kampala

German tourist was kidnapped

The German foreign ministry confirmed yesterday that a 48-year-old tourist from the central state of Hesse has been abducted by an armed group in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir.

No one has claimed responsibility for the kidnapping.
Reuters, Berlin

Low-calorie diet for fat tortoises

Researchers at Zurich zoo have put their young Galapagos tortoises on a diet because they weigh 10 times as much as their relatives in the wild.

They are being fed low-calorie, high-fibre food. The biggest is a male called Jumbo, who weighs 213kg (33 stones).
AP, Zurich

Sex is back in MPs' lives

An internet porn filter has been removed from Socialist party computers in the Dutch parliament after an MP complained that it interfered with her research.

The filter program, which blocked emails and web pages containing words like 'sex', prevented her seeing a foreign study of drug policy.
AP, The Hague

King's pay-as-you-thrill novel

The horror writer Stephen King is to serialise a new novel on his website and rely on honest readers to send him $1 (67p) an installment.

Part one of The Plant - described as "sort of funny and at the same time pretty gruesome" - appears on Monday. King got the idea when a reader mailed him $2.50 guilt money for having read one of his books free on an unauthorised website.
AP, Portland

webTitle: Rough justice comes late for Teddy Roosevelt

fields.headline: Rough justice comes late for Teddy Roosevelt
fields.standfirst: Army finally approves bravery medal for Cuba battles
fields.trailText: More than a hundred years after leading his legendary regiment of "Rough Riders" into the decisive battle of the war he did more than almost anyone to start, President Theodore Roosevelt may at last receive the bravery award he craved.
fields.body:
More than a hundred years after leading his legendary regiment of "Rough Riders" into the decisive battle of the war he did more than almost anyone to start, President Theodore Roosevelt may at last receive the bravery award he craved.

Pentagon chiefs have endorsed a congressional recommendation to President Bill Clinton that Roosevelt should be posthumously awarded the Medal of Honour, America's highest award for bravery, for his heroism under fire in Cuba during the Spanish-American war of 1898.

The recommendation now only awaits Mr Clinton's signature to become the medal's most belated award in American military history.

It will be yet another striking sign of the re-emergence of "TR" as among the US presidents most admired by today's politicians.

His actions in the war made Roosevelt, who resigned as assistant navy secretary to fight in Cuba, into the most famous American of his time.

They helped to propel him towards the White House, which he entered in 1901 after the assassination of President William McKinley as the youngest president in US history. But his failure to win the Medal of Honour rankled with him until his death in January 1919.

"I am entitled to the Medal of Honour and I want it," wrote Roosevelt, never a shrinking violet, shortly after he returned from the war a national hero.

Twenty-two other American soldiers, including two of Roosevelt's Rough Riders, received the medal for their bravery in the attacks on Spanish forces on Kettle Hill and the San Juan Heights, the decisive action of the war.

Yet, for reasons which have never been fully explained, Roosevelt never received the award he coveted for his action on what he called "the great day of my life".

Speculation that he would receive the medal began almost as soon as the dust of battle had settled, but the army failed to endorse the idea.

"I don't ask this as a favour, I ask it as a right," Roosevelt wrote later to his friend Senator Henry Cabot Lodge. "I feel rather ugly on this Medal of Honour business, and the president and war department may as well understand it. If they want fighting, they shall have it."

Attempts to give Roosevelt the medal were revived by Republicans in 1998, the centenary year of the Spanish-American war.

Mr Clinton ducked the proposal, referring it to the army and a group of independent scholars for their recommendation. Even then, many observers suspected that tradition-bound officers would not want to reverse the judgment of their predecessors. Now, after 14 months of research, the vote has gone in Roosevelt's favour.

Mr Clinton is all but certain to sign the recommendation, not least because he is a great fan of Roosevelt, and keeps a bust of him in the Oval Office.

"I would rather have led that charge than served three terms in the US Senate," Roosevelt once said.

"I feel rather ugly on this Medal of Honour business, and the president and war department may as well understand it. If they want fighting, they shall have it." Attempts to give Roosevelt the medal were revived by Republicans in 1998, the centenary year of the Spanish-American war. Mr Clinton ducked the proposal, referring it to the army and a group of independent scholars for their recommendation. Even then, many observers suspected that tradition-bound officers would not want to reverse the judgment of their predecessors. Now, after 14 months of research, the vote has gone in Roosevelt's favour. Mr Clinton is all but certain to sign the recommendation, not least because he is a great fan of Roosevelt, and keeps a bust of him in the Oval Office. "I would rather have led that charge than served three terms in the US Senate," Roosevelt once said.

webTitle: Technology firms are tightwads of top pay league

fields.headline: Technology firms are tightwads of top pay league
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: New economy companies are the stingiest in the FTSE 100 when it comes to paying top executives, according to a study by remuneration consultants.
fields.body:
New economy companies are the stingiest in the FTSE 100 when it comes to paying top executives, according to a study by remuneration consultants.

The Monks Partnership - which advises many blue chip firms on executive pay - has found that the average FTSE 100 chief executive earned £643,000 last year, an increase of some 10.2%.

The biggest earner was Charles Brady, executive chairman of fund management firm Amvescap, who took home £3.8m in salary and bonuses.

However, Britain's fast growing hi-tech companies are reluctant to offer bulging pay packets. Software services companies in the FTSE 100 paid top executives an average of just £423,000, while telecoms firms offered £431,000.

David Atkins, a consultant at the Monks Partnership, said: "Pay at these companies does seem to be towards the bottom end." One of the reasons was that many hi-tech firms are still run by entrepreneurial people rather than professional corporate managers.

"Typically, some of the executive directors may well have been the founding fathers of the organisations. They're probably wealthy from share ownership in their own right."

The worst paid boss in the FTSE 100 was Fran Rooney, chief executive of high flying Irish internet security specialist Baltimore Technologies. Mr Rooney received £190,000, despite running a company with a market capitalisation of £2.6bn. He recently claimed he was not motivated by money, saying he was "driven by pride and the desire to do things well". However, his stake in the business is worth more than £80m.

Internet service provider Freeserve was similarly parsimonious - its chief executive, John Pluthero, is on a salary of £200,000.

The best paid bosses were in financial, leisure, mining and drugs companies. After adding in the profits from exercising share options, Granada's chairman, Gerry Robinson, banked the most money during the year, making a total of £6.28m.

A spokesman for the media group said: "Gerry Robinson is the architect of Granada's success. His pay reflects this."

The study also calls into question the performance criteria attached to bonus payments, by revealing that nearly all bosses get close to the maximum possible payout.
