webTitle: West's fine words leave debts piled high

fields.headline: West's fine words leave debts piled high
fields.standfirst:
Last year's G8 deal has done little to help poorest countries
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Toronto, London, Naples, Lyon and Cologne. The list of places where leaders from the Group of Eight have met since 1988 to solve the problem of third-world debt sounds like a veritable Cook's tour, but the fine meals eaten and the air miles chalked up have resulted in very little for the countries still locked in the chains of debt.
fields.body:
Toronto, London, Naples, Lyon and Cologne. The list of places where leaders from the Group of Eight have met since 1988 to solve the problem of third-world debt sounds like a veritable Cook's tour, but the fine meals eaten and the air miles chalked up have resulted in very little for the countries still locked in the chains of debt.

As the G8 gathers for its annual summit, this time on the Japanese island of Okinawa, the $100bn (£67bn) debt deal agreed in Cologne last year is starting to look rather shabby.

The G8 promised that 25 countries would begin the debt relief process by the end of 2000, but with five months to go, only nine have qualified. Only $10bn of the $100bn has been delivered, and this had been agreed under pre-existing debt-cutting agreements anyway.

So what went wrong? To some extent the G8 were victims of their own hype. What they portrayed as a historic deal was, as others pointed out, really just a slightly more generous version of the existing international debt relief programme.

It was never going to end third world debt, merely massage it down to levels where the countries were judged to be sustainable again according to the criteria of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). In fact, the programme aims to make poor countries solvent again so they can continuing repaying their debts to the west.

Sustainability is based on a country's ability to service its debts through export earnings, not on how poor it is. As Oxfam has calculated, even once they are through the Cologne debt process, many countries still spend more on debt relief than on health and education combined.

To take an example, Tanzania has had its debt interest payments reduced by just under 20% over the next three years, so it will be paying the west an average of $146m (£98m) in 2001-3. The government spends $85m a year on basic education - the budget for teaching materials is just $1 a year per pupil. Meanwhile 2.2m children are not in school and Tanzania is one of the few countries in the world where illiteracy is rising.

The Cologne debt deal was never going to end such horrendous poverty, but even by its own limited criteria it has so far been a failure. Unfortunately for the debtors, despite the promise that the G8 would speed up the progress of debt relief, the new deal looks just as prone to delays as previous agreements.

There are several reasons for these delays, and not all can be blamed on the G8. Several of the debtor countries are in the middle of military coups or civil wars, and the new government in Senegal has asked for a pause while it settles in.

But coups and wars notwithstanding, the G8 must bear much of the blame.

The big idea from Cologne was to link debt relief with poverty reduction, which in theory sounds sensible. But in practice it has imposed huge burdens on countries where government machinery is already stretched to the limit.

Most already have to meet strict eco nomic rules to qualify for assistance from the IMF and the World Bank. Now, in addition, to qualify for full debt relief, these countries have to produce a detailed poverty reduction strategy paper explaining to the west how the money will be spent. Although a draft plan is sufficient to get the process started, the drafts are proving to be large and complex documents which take a long time to prepare.

The requirement to consult widely before producing these plans, and the need for speedy debt relief, are mutually exclusive. Most poor countries already have their macro-economic policies dictated by the IMF, and many have been tempted to ask staff from the Washington financial institutions to write an anti-poverty plan which they know will satisfy the boards of the IMF and the bank.

The IMF is slowing down debt relief in several counties to force them to implement unpopular aspects of the fund's macro-economic reform programmes.

A further reason for the delay is problems with funding. While the G8 leaders were happy to promise enormous sums in Cologne for a special trust fund to help cover the amount needed to write off the debts owed the World Bank and IMF, they have been much less enthusiastic about writing out the cheques.

The worst offender is the US, which promised $600m but has yet to deliver, because Congress rebuffed President Clinton's request for the money. The EU and Japan are using the US failure as an excuse to delay their own contributions.

So what should the G8 do to break the log-jam? They could simplify the process, for a start, by removing the thousands of conditions attached to debt relief.

The World Bank's own research shows that governments do not stick to reform programmes imposed by donors. It is only when countries decide for themselves that they are ready to bear the pain which accompanies economic reform - and have the political support to carry it through - that change happens.

So does that mean we should give the money back without asking how it will be spent? There is a halfway house between loading countries down with thousands of conditions and giving the money with no strings attached.

Oxfam has suggested that any country prepared to put the savings from debt relief into a fund ringfenced for spending on poverty-reducing areas such as education, health and employment generation should have the money immediately.

The poverty reduction strategies should not be abandoned, but they should be removed from the debt relief process to avoid the rush which is leading to countries taking off-the-peg plans from Washington. Tackling poverty is a much bigger task than simply solving the debt problem: the plans need to be carefully worked out.

The real danger the international community faces is that people have begun to believe the hype. After hearing world leaders repeatedly declare that they have solved the debt crisis, many believe the loans burden is no longer a problem for poor countries.

In fact an enormous amount remains to be done, and even if the debt crisis were solved, the more difficult task of tackling poverty would remain.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Making History/Jazz Legends
fields.body:
Sue Cook opens another season of Making History (3.0pm, Radio 4), helping listeners research their own background or other historical connections they have stumbled on. First comes a request from a family which thinks it may be related to Lawrence of Arabia. Given Lawrence's habit of embroidering almost every aspect of his colourful life, it's not an easy search. The one sure thing the team can cling to is the Dorset spot where Lawrence was killed while riding his Brough motorcycle.

Charlie Parker died in 1955, aged 35, but his reputation endures as one of the seminal Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3), a status that will last well into the future. He was, of course, one of the key figures who set the music on an entirely new path through the bop revolution. Julian Joseph revives some of the vast repertoire Parker left behind, and British saxophonist Peter King assesses the enduring impact of Parker's performances.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee highlights the government's folly on law and order

fields.headline: The cost of cowardice
fields.standfirst:
Polly Toynbee highlights the government's folly on law and order

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government's folly on law and order.
fields.body:
Never get in a pissing contest with a skunk was one of Eisenhower's few bons mots. Pick your own ground to fight on, never your enemy's. So the government should look across the floor of the House at the assorted skunks, reptiles and vipers on the benches opposite and mark out its own chosen battlefield, avoiding theirs. How odd they spend so much time doing precisely the opposite.

Labour will always win on health and education. Labour will win on public transport. They will win on taking children out of poverty, reversing urban blight and decay, creating the better life. Most of all, they win for general competence. With a bit more imagination, in their next manifesto they could win with other feel-good issues - free bus fares for all under 21s, free sports and leisure facilities, universal community nurseries or a general right to work a four-day week. To use that infamous memo-speak, Labour's "brand" should be a spirit of optimism and progress - a sense that anything really is possible in this extraordinarily lucky golden age.

Instead cowardly, fearful and backward-looking, they slope off into dark enemy territory for a war they will never win. Law and order is Conservative home ground, always was, always will be. Even if Labour brought back the cat, the rack, the treadmill and transportation, law and order would still be a Tory issue. The awful visage of Widdecombe and Howard would outflank them on the right every time.

Jack Straw suspects William Hague will call for the rope in his election manifesto. He also points with pride to Labour's scores as the party with the best law and order policy - but that is a mirage, just a reflection of Labour's overall competence rating. No one who genuinely puts punishment at the top of their agenda will vote for Labour to be toughest. All that happens is that Labour is pulled further and further rightwards in an ideological tug of war, wasting its energy, squandering its own "brand".

Worse, it has seriously bad consequences in the real world. This week 4,000 more police were promised by 2003. Ministers hardly bothered to disguise the entirely political motive for lifting the falling police numbers to the highest level ever. The swelling "More bobbies on the beat" cry had become politically irresistible. But each "bobby" costs £46,000 to run and the home secretary himself admitted there is no correlation between more manpower and best results.

As for "on the beat", the Police Foundation records that a plod patrolling all day, every day will catch a burglar once every 15 years. An audit commission survey found a large number of the police never spoke with a member of the public in the course of a day's duty. When there was a sudden and dramatic decline in police as they were pulled off the streets in great battalions for the miners strike, researchers afterwards found no change in crime rates.

Measuring what the police do is fraught with perversity - from the perverse incentive for a policeman to do very little so he has least chance of getting into trouble to the perverse behaviour of a public more inclined to report crimes and swell the figures when there are more police around to report them to. Drug busts are the most statistically satisfying, which may explain the huge number of drug possession arrests: it is a crime found and detected in one swoop, a 100% clear-up rate every time. Meanwhile researchers looking at what the police do all day find under-trained frontline managers deploying their troops guided only by lofty exhortation from above and gut instinct or old habits from below.

Jack Straw is afraid to take on the bombastic political fire-power of the Police Federation. Time and again home secretaries have been advised that creating a cheaper second tier of street patrollers, community constables with good radios, can do what caretakers on rough estates do to reassure the population at half the price. But as with doctors, nurses and every profession, the union fights any dilution of their status and all home secretaries shudder when the Police Federation bellows.

Worse by far is the promise of 2,660 more prison cells to be built to add to the highest prison population ever, now at above 65,000. Is that as well as the 4,000 extra yobs the prime minister recently promised to double-up in cells built for one? Each prisoner costs an average £25,500 a year. A phenomenal £667m extra has been ear-marked - almost as much as the dome bill. The more cells are built and the louder the government talks up prison, the more the judges hurry to fill them. Mandatory sentencing for burglars will lead to locking up thousands more. There is also more money for drug programmes, education and treatment in prison and in the community - but the Home Office can give no figures to compare money spent on punishment and money spent on treatment. It will again be grossly disproportionate.

Meanwhile, we wait to hear Jack Straw declaiming to the Sun the triumph of one programme about which there has been soundbite silence so far. At any one time, 2,000 prisoners, mostly on shorter sentences, have been let out on electronic tags for the last weeks of their sentence; 60% of short-term prisoners reoffend, a high proportion within their first weeks of release. So far only 5% of those on tags have broken their agreed curfews and only a remarkable 1.9% have committed offences while tagged. It is too early to say yet if that good effect lasts longer - but Nacro, which runs many resettlement programmes for offenders, suggests that about half the prison population could be out on tags at less than half the price of prison; all the money saved could go on better treatments. Tags calm down erratic lives, help people get some structure into their day, making it more likely they will attend probation, treatment and training schemes.

Jack Straw complains no one ever reports his praise for community treatment or for the many schemes now working well in youth justice, treating young criminals at an earlier stage. It is not headline-grabbing stuff. But he and Tony Blair have shown little appetite for going out to change the voters' insatiable appetite for punishment. Sun readers have not been regaled with true facts about what really reduces crime and reoffending. Talking about crime off the record, both Straw and Blair speak with an odd mixture of hard-nosed political expediency and sententious home-spun moralising, peppered with genuine knowledge of the research on what works, all in the same breath.

They can no longer distinguish between these three - toughness and causes swirling about with crowd-pleasing. There is still no sign that they feel any duty to lead public opinion, only to swim with the tide wherever it takes them. Bad news rarely makes unnerved politicians better, but might the depth of cynicism revealed in the leaked memos make this pair set out in the autumn on a new course on law and order? Or will it be kneejerk business as usual?

webTitle: How can I resume my relationship with the son I left behind?

fields.headline: How can I resume my relationship with the son I left behind?
fields.trailText: I am 50 and until last November had not seen my son, now 27, since he was two. My ex-wife and I are both remarried. I grew up as a child of ill-suited parents and did not want my son to have the same problems, so I decided to step back from his life. He now lives in the US.
fields.body:
I am 50 and until last November had not seen my son, now 27, since he was two. My ex-wife and I are both remarried. I grew up as a child of ill-suited parents and did not want my son to have the same problems, so I decided to step back from his life. He now lives in the US.

He is my only child and my only living relative. Four years ago I decided to try to contact him. But when my ex-wife tried to persuade him to see me, he said I had never done anything for him, and that he had a perfectly good stepfather in England. Over the next two years I wrote letters, but got no reply. Then, on a business trip to the US, I called him at work. We met for lunch, which ended, I thought, promisingly.

On my next visit, we arranged a meeting but he backed out, saying he "didn't want to start a relationship with someone he didn't know from Adam". My parents died in their mid-50s, and I don't feel I can let time take its course. The situation, unfortunately, hasn't the same urgency for him. How can I convince him that I'm worth an effort on his part?
Name and address withheld

Don't be so selfish

I am not convinced that your decision to remove yourself from your son's life was unselfish. It seems more likely to me that you could not face repeating the pattern of your parents' marriage. Avoiding your pain took priority over your child. Faced now with your own mortality, you are once again placing your needs above those of your son. The circumstances in which you find yourself are entirely of your own making. Your son says that he has a perfectly good stepfather, in other words someone who was prepared to take responsibility for him and do their best to love and raise him. Now that the job is done, you want to enjoy the end product. Parenthood is a duty and not a right. It's time for you to grow up.
S Squires,

Stay out of his life

Five years ago I was approached by a relation to resume a relationship with a man who had "walked out" of the family 20 years previously. We had had no contact in this time. When we met it was a painful experience, partly because of this man's insistence that he had left for my benefit, that we must make up for lost time because he was my father. I have no deep feeling for him. I was fine before he came along.

You have no right to mess up this man's life. He's done all right without you. Or is that what hurts? He's moved on, and you're living in the past. Sorry to sound so hard, but you can't make anyone like you - especially your own children.
D Coussins, Wimbledon, London

Family comes first

My parents were divorced when I was four, and I went to South Africa with my mother and younger brother. I am now 35. Both my parents remarried, and I have a wonderful relationship with my stepfather.

My father has lived in America for most of my life, and is 60 years old. Our attempts at contact were fragmented, compounded by his lack of interest in our upbringing. Our first opportunity at reconciliation came when I was 25, when I spent three weeks in America with my dad and his new wife. The holiday was fraught with anger and a strong feeling of abandonment - "How could you have left us and never made contact with us?" It took me the next 10 years to understand that he was trying to tell me he was sorry.

Forgiveness is probably the hardest thing to do. But life is short, and I want to give our relationship another go. We have resumed contact now and are working on being friends. He is aware that he's missed out on some of the important events in our lives - the best that we can do is try and retrieve that lost time. We're all the family we've got.
Name and address withheld

Self-pity is no motive

My ex-husband used a similar argument to convince himself that he should have no future links with our young children. Two of them make occasional contact with him; one makes a big effort to keep in touch; the youngest refuses to associate with him, using the same rationale as your son. Like you when your child was two, they are all adults now. They have to make their own decisions and live with them. So must you.

Consciousness of your own mortality has made you maudlin for a blood tie that you chose to ignore when life held more promise for you. The older you get, the more likely you are to experience such self-pity, so toughen up! Check out Shakespeare's sonnet number 30, which weeps with misery over past losses and griefs, yet ends: "But if the while I think on thee, dear friend,/All losses are restored, and sorrows end."

You're not a widower (or you'd have mentioned it) and you have friends, presumably. If they are no help, maybe on your next US business trips you could find yourself a nice shrink.
Name and address withheld

A recipe for disaster

It seems from the tenor of your letter that you are considering only your own interests. Your son is not responsible for what you did in the past, and you can hardly expect him to welcome a relationship with you simply because you have now decided that you would like one with him. Having made contact, the only thing to do is to leave it to him to make the next move - if there is one. As an adoptive parent I have witnessed a similar situation with my child. The dismal experience we all suffered makes me sure that happiness is not to be found in forcing yourself on someone who, for whatever reason, does not want you in their life.

If you love him, leave him

I read your letter last Friday after making a decision to cut off all contact with my natural father. I was adopted at birth and enjoyed a loving upbringing with my adopted family - that is, until five years ago, when my natural parents traced me.

It took three years for me to establish a workable relationship with my birth mother, but now I feel it is impossible to move forward with my father and I have decided never to see him again. My situation was thus: my father blamed my mother for the adoption and her rejection of marriage and sought in me a kindred spirit. He has never accepted my adoption and has made deliberate efforts to undermine my relationshp with my adopted family.

You made a difficult decision no doubt based on the desire to want the best for your son in the long term. These appear to be the actions of a good and loving parent, however heartbreaking the consequences.

What strikes me is that you still have an understanding of your son's place in another family. As a good parent, you are compelled to protect your child from anything that could undermine that family. Unfortunately, this is what your relationship threatens to do. The effort your son has already made to meet you was quite enough for you to expect. It is an act of superhuman sacrifice to walk away, but it could be the best course of action; in doing this you may not have a relationship with your son, but you will always have his respect.
S Lusby, London

Next week

I have been with my husband for 23 years and we have three teenage children. Ten years ago I wanted to break up as I was very unhappy - as I still am. My husband would not agree to it. I did not want a damaging confrontation and we decided to stay together for the family, with plans to part company when they grew up.

He now has a relationshp with a woman with children of her own and who is known (and liked) by me and by our children. I have no problem with this. The difficulty is that he hates having to tell lies when he visits her and plans to tell our children about her soon. I cannot see the point in inflicting pain when our family circumstances will not change for some time. He is determined to pursue this course, though I have tried to persuade him otherwise. It looks to me as if he wants to save his conscience at a high cost to our children.

I would welcome ideas about how I can help the children handle their responses when the time comes. This man has always been a good father and I believe that the children need loving relationships with both of us. Am I wrong about the deceit aspect? Might it be that his honesty is the best path?

fields.headline: CDnow falls to Bertelsmann
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: CDnow, the online music retailer which was once valued at as much as $1bn (£660m), was swallowed yesterday by German media group Bertelsmann for $117m.
fields.body:
CDnow, the online music retailer which was once valued at as much as $1bn (£660m), was swallowed yesterday by German media group Bertelsmann for $117m.

The company, founded by twins Jason and Matthew Olim, was put up for sale after becoming cash-strapped, with only enough funds to operate until September.

Yesterday's bid of $3 for each CDnow share marked the collapse of the dot.com, which sells CDs, DVDs, videos, T-shirts and music downloads online to about 4m customers.

Bertelsmann has agreed to give CDnow $42m as part of the deal to pay back loans and also sustain the day to day business until the deal is completed. Klaus Eierhoff, director of Bertelsmann multimedia, said: "CDnow is a pioneer in its field and an excellent fit with our online and offline music assets."

Earlier this year, Bertelsmann struck an agreement with America Online to expand its distribution of media content and e-commerce across AOL's network.

CDnow's board has approved the deal and the Olim brothers have agreed to sell their 5.8m shares, representing almost 18% of the stock.

Before the deal was announced the stock was at $2.875 from a year high of $22.675. The sale reflects the financial difficulty of CDnow as the offer contains just a small premium for shareholders. CDnow will continue to operate under its brand name and become a subsidiary of Bertelsmann's e-commerce division.

Jason Olim, chief executive of CDnow, said: "We believe our combination with Bertelsmann is the best outcome for our shareholders, employees and customers.

"CDnow will continue to provide music fans with a digital connection to the world of music through music products, information, entertainment and community."

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.standfirst: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.trailText: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Café 21 35 The Broadway, Darras Hall, Ponteland, Northumberland. Tel: 01661 820357

Hurrah for the fixed-price menu. It is the cheapskate's best friend. Terry Leybourne's Café 21, settled into the north-west outskirts of Newcastle-upon-Tyne proper, is unusual in that it does both set lunches and set dinners (£10.50-£12.50). For this, you'll get two or three courses masterminded by one of the country's finest and most sensible chefs. He doesn't cook them, just sets the tone for boldly flavoured, hale and hearty, mostly Francophile food, with the odd spotted-dick-and-custard dish thrown in. The style is laid back - blackboard menu, bistro bustle, bright lighting, wooden chairs, prints and garçon aprons on keen waiters and waitresses. Wine list as competitively priced as the food. Popular for obvious reasons.

Tilleys 104 Westgate Road, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, Tyne and Wear. Tel: 0191-232 0692

There can't be many places where your hot roast beef sandwich with gravy comes in a quarter stottie (see On the menu below). But then there aren't many places like Tilleys, throbbing with students and thespians from the theatre village nearby. This is one of the few bars anywhere that is more famous for its cheeseboard than for its beer (though that's top-quality Jennings, Cumberland and Cocker Hoop). The bread is from a local bakery. The portions are gargantuan and the prices derisory (£3 for soup, indisputably homemade, plus cheese or pté, or £4 with a sandwich). "To the uninitiated, our menu may appear rather limited, but we believe in quality not quantity." A motto more places might follow.

fields.headline: On the menu: stottie
fields.standfirst: Cheat's kitchen
fields.trailText: Cheat's kitchen
fields.body:
Or stotty. Or even stottie cake.

I'm hottie for a stottie. Where can I find one?

In the north-east of England, where they are a lonely outpost of our country's great baking tradition.

How would I recognise one?

Roundish, about 200mm across and about 30mm thick. White in places. Brown in others. With a hole in the middle.

And what do I do with when I've got one?

Slice it across the middle, and stuff it with whatever you like just as in a sandwich. Or if you wish to emulate a local tradition in the north-east, spread the stottie slices with pease pudding.

Cheat's kitchen

Insalata sopressa

1 can beans (borlotti, flageolet, anything you like)

extra virgin olive oil

contents of fridge and larder

1. Drain and rinse the can of beans.Then drench them in olive oil.

2. Search your fridge and larder. Add some or all of the following, chopped: onion (preferably spring), tomatoes, red peppers, celery, fresh herbs, stoned olives, canned fish, or crispy bacon bits.

3. Serve with chunks of bread (if you have any).

June Pegg, Tring, Hertfordshire

If you have a tip for Cheat's kitchen, send it to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

webTitle: Bit Valley earns Japan e-street cred

fields.headline: Bit Valley earns Japan e-street cred
fields.standfirst:
News Analysis The staid salaryman is giving way to dot.com daring
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: It used to be the home of boutiques, bistros and night clubs and now it is the haunt of internet consultancies and web design agencies, too. The Shibuya district of Tokyo, renamed by its denizens Bit Valley, will loom large when Japan asserts its new economy credentials this weekend by putting information technology at the top of the agenda for the G8 summit in Okinawa.
fields.body:
It used to be the home of boutiques, bistros and night clubs and now it is the haunt of internet consultancies and web design agencies, too. The Shibuya district of Tokyo, renamed by its denizens Bit Valley, will loom large when Japan asserts its new economy credentials this weekend by putting information technology at the top of the agenda for the G8 summit in Okinawa.

It is a gamble by the host nation. World leaders have yet to discuss the internet in detail and many of them have only recently learned to distinguish between a mouse and a joystick.

Japan's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, may feel particularly uncomfortable providing leadership on this issue. He sent his first email only last month and produced guffaws when he announced plans to establish an IC - rather than IT - taskforce to boost Japan's internet competitiveness.

Aside from the blunders of their gaffe-prone leader, Japanese politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen have good reason to feel that the internet has the potential to lift the world's second biggest economy out of a 10-year rut.

Bit Valley's name is a tribute to California's Silicon Valley and although it has yet to produce a homegrown Bill Gates it is nurturing a new generation of entrepreneurs who are very different from the conformist and drone-like salarymen often associated with Japanese corporate culture.

Take Hirohiko Sasaki, the 30-year-old senior vice president of NetYear, one of Japan's leading internet business incubators. As is clear from his purple open-neck shirt and long, unparted hair, he is no salaryman. He has less job security and - far from the image of the dot.com millionaire - a lower income than many of his peers. But it is the risk and the potential for striking it rich that excite him.

"I'm fortunate that I didn't join a big company. We're in a dynamic market with the sort of opportunities that only come once in a hundred years. We have a chance to change Japan. That is fun."

NetYear is growing fast. Established in 1997, it now has 50 staff and, after securing $20m of new capital in May, the company moved to a plush new office suite overlooking Shibuya's main street.

Despite the image of wealth, Mr Sasaki says NetYear's employees earn less than their peers in other industries. "We recruit the best and people take a pay cut to join us because they share our vision," he explains.

It has not been an easy six months for NetYear. The internet bubble has burst as explosively in Japan as anywhere in the world, driving investors out of the new economy in droves.

But Mr Sasaki and other "believers" remain confident that things are moving their way. This Christmas, they predict a surge in e-commerce present-buying as new technology widens up the web.

Despite its reputation as a technological powerhouse, Japan has been slow to embrace the internet. As of April, only 29m Japanese people were online, less than a quarter of the population - a far lower penetration than in the United States or Britain.

Development has been retarded by the language barrier, unfamiliarity with PCs and the influence of domestic telecommunication operator NTT, which levies interconnection charges that are three to four times higher than in Europe. The latter may change after the US on Wednesday forced open Japan's telecoms market to foreign competition.

Thanks to a host of smart new domestically produced devices, the web is finally starting to weave its magic, drawing 110,000 new consumers each day.

More than two-thirds of these novices access the internet from mobile communication devices rather than personal computers. By far the most popular is the i-mode phone, which keeps its 8m users online 24-hours a day and only charges them for the data they transmit or download.

The phenomenal success of i-mode has made the operator, NTT DoCoMo, into Japan's biggest company in terms of stock market valuation. DoCoMo is now moving into international markets, with a 2 trillion yen (£12bn) warchest for buying stakes in foreign companies.

Sony, the Japanese electronics and media group, is also opening up new internet territory. Its PlayStation2 video game console, which has been a huge hit since its launch in Japan this March, is designed to offer a broadband link to the internet that will allow users to download films and music. PS2 will arrive on British shelves this autumn.

According to analysts, this is just the start of the Japanese invasion of the internet business. fields.headline: $53bn tag for VoiceStream
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: One of the few independent wireless phone companies remaining in the United States appeared to be at the centre of a $53bn bid battle last night.
fields.body:
One of the few independent wireless phone companies remaining in the United States appeared to be at the centre of a $53bn bid battle last night.

Deutsche Telekom refused to confirm whether it was to bid for VoiceStream, which provides digital wireless services to nearly 2.5m customers in 19 of the top 25 US cities.

Analysts said Deutsche Telekom's bid was an expensive but necessary one, given the interest shown in the US company by rivals such as France Telecom and Japan's Nippon Telegraph and Telephone. Previous reports said the deal would not top $35bn.

Speculation yesterday was that Deutsche Telekom was planning a bid at $205.60 a share, with a mixture of 3.2 of its own shares plus $30 cash for each VoiceStream share.

Shares in Deutsche Telekom fell €3.35 to €57.05, those in VoiceStream were up 6% at noon in the New York markets to almost $155.

Analysts immediately expressed concern at the size of the reported bid, which would value VoiceStream at almost $20,000 a customer.

France Telecom set a record by bidding £27bn for Orange this year, which valued the UK mobile customers at €6,741 (£4,200) each.

"They [Deutsche Telekom and VoiceStream] definitely have been in discussions," said SG Securities analyst Sean Johnstone. "But the price is getting quite high."

Deutsche Telekom is hampered by Hutchison Wham poa's ownership of 23% of VoiceStream - a stake it considers a strategic investment.

DT may also face American regulatory resistance because it is 59% owned by the German government.

US laws do not permit any acquisition of an American company by a firm that is more than 25%-owned by a foreign government. However, regulators are able to waive that restriction if it is in the public interest. Both Deutsche Telekom and VocieStream are said to be in final talks, al though agreement has not yet been achieved.

Deutsche Telekom has been touted as a potential acquirer of many companies recently amid frenzied speculation about its strategy. It has been nominated as a possible buyer of Sprint Corporation, Cable & Wireless and Qwest Communications, with which it held takeover talks earlier this year.

In March it withdrew a $117bn offer to buy both Qwest and US West amid questions about whether such a deal would jeopardise the existing merger agreement between those two companies.

DT also has the embarrassing history of aborted takeover talks with Telecom Italia.

The German group is capable of financing a deal in the order of €100bn and is under pressure to make an acquisitions as telecoms companies consolidate and jockey to dominate the converging mobile and internet sectors.

There have been many suitors suggested for VoiceStream including Japanese telephony group NTT DoCoMo.

fields.headline: Flight of the fulmars
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
Northumberland

A wet walk along our lovely seashore, extremely bleak on that particular afternoon, was enlivened by an abundance of fulmars and gulls. Most people would be unable to distinguish a fulmar from a gull, yet these birds are representatives of different families. The fulmar is a petrel, and like all members of this clan it has a pronounced tube on the surface of its bill. This horny excrescence encases the bird's nostrils.

A gull beats its wings regularly, but fulmars glide and bank on outstretched wings. As a pelagic bird it spends much of its time at sea like the gannet, the albatross and its lesser petrel cousins. However, like other species, the fulmar must come ashore to nest. On the water, fulmars are buoyant, but on land they shuffle about with the aid of their wings as if their feet were largely useless appendages except as paddles when they are seaborne.

Watching pre-nuptial displays at Dunstanburgh and Cresswell, I must have got too close in my enthusiasm and several fulmars spat at me. This is a peculiar habit, ejecting a nauseating liquid at anyone approaching too near courtship or the nest. The bird spits through its double-barrelled tubular nostrils or through its open beak. So deeply ingrained is the habit that even chicks, still damp from the eggs, have been observed engaging in this reflex action.

The majority of fulmars nest on cliffs and rocky edifices overlooking the sea, but there are inland nidification sites. An ornithological conundrum arises - how do these nestlings, once full-feathered, reach the sea which is their natural habitat? Sea-cliff birds just flutter and tumble on to the water, but for an inland-reared chick it must be more of an adventure to reach the ocean. Fulmars have india-rubber legs and once crash-landed a young bird would hardly be able to take to the air again.

One ornithologist told me the parent birds assess upward thermal currents and when a fledgling is full-feathered they are propelled from the nest in a natural glide which will take them over the sea which, in some cases, may be a mile away.

webTitle: Uganda losing its lustre as star pupil

fields.headline: Uganda losing its lustre as star pupil
fields.trailText: Uganda has always been a favourite pupil of the west when it comes to economic reform.
fields.body:
Uganda has always been a favourite pupil of the west when it comes to economic reform.

After 14 years on International Monetary Fund programmes, it was one of the first countries to qualify for the original debt-relief package which creditors and the financial institutions put together in 1996.

The country was also the inspiration for the idea of linking debt relief to poverty reduction: it set up a "ring-fenced" fund for the money it saved from debt write-offs and agreed to spend the proceeds on alleviating poverty.

But while it was the creditors' darling in the early days, hope that it would be the first country to graduate from the west's revamped debt-relief programme earlier this year - which would also have made it the first country to have its debts written off - has faded.

The first hitch came when Kampala decided to spend $30m (£20m) on a corporate jet just as its case for debt relief was being considered by the World Bank and the IMF.

More seriously, Kampala's intervention in the war ravaging the neighbouring Democratic Republic of Congo alarmed donors. When the Ugandan and Rwandan armies turned on each other in early June, just as Uganda's case was coming before Paris Club of creditor states, the US led the charge to put its debt relief on hold.

The decision outraged Jubilee 2000, the coalition of non-governmental organisations and churches which has led the debt campaign.

The campaigners say it showed that debt relief was being used by the west for political objectives rather than to reduce poverty, which was why the process needed an independent arbitrator.

webTitle: The militarised rivals who upstage the rest of the world

fields.headline: The militarised rivals who upstage the rest of the world
fields.standfirst:
The Middle East continues to exert its strange power

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Middle East continues to exert its strange power.
fields.body:
The Japanese, complaining that even before the Okinawa summit began "it feels like we're being swept aside" because Bill Clinton lingered for a day at Camp David, are only the latest sufferers from the Middle East's capacity to upstage events, peoples, and governments. Decade after decade, the Middle East has relentlessly stolen a disproportionate amount of the world's attention, resources, diplomacy, and psychic energy. The combined population of the five countries whose territories constitute the central zone of Arab-Israeli conflict is, as it happens, somewhat less than that of Japan. It is amazing that a region which contains only a small fraction of the world's people (if, on the margins, a great deal of its oil), should continue to occupy such a central position in everybody's calculations.

It is typical, for instance, that the Israelis think the last country which should be called upon to pay the costs of a settlement, should there be one, is Israel itself. No, that task belongs to the United States and the European countries, who, along with the Arab oil states, are also called upon to finance the Palestinian Authority and the Palestinian state, when we have it. Every step toward agreement in the Middle East in recent years has been accompanied by the chink of coins. Nowhere else would there be such an assumption that regional peace is so desirable that it should be subsidised to this degree. The American Congress may now be questioning it, but if so it is almost for the first time. The readiness to pay for peace as well as war in the Middle East is an index of a broad engagement which cannot be explained simply by the presence of oil. Nor does a mere cumulation of the different ways in which the region is significant, religious, political, and strategic, quite explain the matter. The Middle East has had an almost theatrical importance in world affairs, seeming to dramatise, in an endless shifting of scenes, every issue of importance in the past half century, from underdevelopment to imperialism, from secularism to fundamentalism.

There was a time when many in the west identified with what they saw as Israel's heroic progress. Amos Elon, in the introduction to a new collection of his shrewd and perceptive dispatches, speaks of the "near mythic quality" of the six day war both for Israelis and many outsiders. Israel embodied a degree of national solidarity, a capacity for boldness, and an efficiency, especially a military efficiency, that some in western countries found very attractive. As they fumbled their way to the end of empire, or found themselves stuck, like the US, in new conflicts that were not going their way, Israel's super-sharp military style seemed, if unfortunately not a model they could duplicate, then definitely something to be admired. This pro-Israeli tendency merged with an earlier, much broader and less militaristic tradition of support for Israel that attracted people on the left, such as James Cameron, as well as from the rest of the political spectrum.

The opposite tendency, which identified with the Arabs and with the Palestinians as they more and more strongly emerged as a visible nation, was always uppermost in the non-western world. There, in the eastern bloc, and on the left in the west it was projected as part of a global struggle for "liberation", a concept harder to define in retrospect than it was to applaud at the time. But the emotionally satisfying links this idea could forge between politics in different regions are described by Graham Usher, whose hard but fair reports from Palestine and Israel have recently been published in book form. Teaching in the East End in the early 80s to classes full of black and brown Britons and of recent refugees, he found that "Palestine was the emblem of their own dispossession... the PLO's quest for a homeland chimed with their own aspirations of liberation, independence, and return." It was "the prism that threw into relief the context, bitterness and violence of all the other causes espoused by my Kurdish, Iranian, Sri Lankan, and Chilean students."

The point of change in western opinion probably came at about that time, with the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982. From then on, support for Israel was increasingly accompanied by criticism, including criticism from within the diaspora. Anxieties about "terrorism", similarly, were increasingly qualified by an understanding that it was another way of making war which was not necessarily more vicious than more conventional methods, even if it should not escape condemnation for that reason alone. Twenty years later, with the Israelis and Palestinians both worn down by events, it can be said that the heroic age in the Middle East is definitely over.

Yet the end of idealisation does not mean, unfortunately, that common sense prevails. This is not only because new kinds of religious extremism have appeared on both sides but because the attempt to reach a final settlement throws both Israelis and Palestinians back on their history, a history which appears to both peoples to make certain demands.

The attempt at finality also casts a long shadow over future politics on both sides. The PLO was founded to represent the Palestinians expelled from Israel, although in time the needs of those who stayed put in Gaza and the West Bank have come to assume greater importance. But how, in final negotiations, could the foundation issues of the return of the refugees and the control of Jerusalem be compromised? To say that the Palestinians need some returns and some of Jerusalem does not answer: the question is how many and how much. The Israelis are fighting on the same historical ground. For them the psychological question is the difference between their weakness in 1947 and their strength in 1967, which accounts in part for their obduracy on exactly the same issues of Jerusalem and the right of return. The symbolic clash is more important than the substantive issues, critical though these are.

Whether or not the effort succeeds at this point, will the Middle East continue to exercise its strange power over the world? The larger region, as Fred Halliday points out in the conclusion to an enlightening collection of his essays, has lost some of its positive attractions but retains many of its negative aspects. It is economically weak to a startling degree in spite of oil, authoritarian with only limited exceptions, culturally repressed, and marked by a militarised and likely soon to be nuclearised rivalry which is by no means confined to the Arab-Israeli divide. The solidarity its people now needs from outsiders, he suggests, is a solidarity of rights that targets both external manipulation and local oppression, whatever the agents. There is, in other words, a liberation yet to come.

 Dispatches from Palestine, by Graham Usher (Pluto); A Blood-Dimmed Tide, by Amos Elon (Allen Lane); Nation and Religion in the Middle East by Fred Halliday (Saqi Book).

webTitle: Barristers open to prosecution for negligence after law lords end immunity

fields.headline: Barristers open to prosecution for negligence after law lords end immunity
fields.trailText: A 200-year-old immunity which protected barristers from being sued over the way they handled cases in court was swept away yesterday in a ruling by seven law lords.
fields.body:
A 200-year-old immunity which protected barristers from being sued over the way they handled cases in court was swept away yesterday in a ruling by seven law lords.

The law lords held that the immunity, which barred actions for negligence no matter how badly a barrister performed in court, no longer applied. This overturned judgments of their own court in 1967 and 1980.

The issue was seen as so important that a special court of seven judges rather than the usual five heard three test cases. The judges decided unanimously that the immunity should go in civil cases.

A minority of three would have kept it for criminal cases.

Until yesterday, barristers could be sued for negligence in advice or paperwork, but not over anything done in court or "intimately connected" with court proceedings. The rule applied to all court advocates, including solicitors conducting cases in court.

The three test cases involved negligence claims against solicitors by three dissatisfied clients, who can now go ahead with their actions. But the outcome has much greater significance for barristers, since advocacy is their core activity.

The Bar Council regarded the issue as so important that it briefed two leading QCs to put the case for keeping the immunity. They argued that it was for parliament, not the judges, to decide if it should be abolished.

But Lord Steyn said: "My view is that it would be an abdication of our responsibilities, with the unfortunate consequence of plunging both branches of the legal profession in England into a state of uncertainty over a prolonged period. That would be a disservice to the public interest."

Lord Hoffmann said: "The judges created the immunity and the judges should say that the grounds for maintaining it no longer exist."

Jonathan Hirst QC, chairman of the bar, said: "The vital thing for the future conduct of justice is that advocates remain free to assert their client's case without fear or favour. I have confidence that the judiciary and the courts will continue to ensure that this is the case. In the meantime the bar will be considering the implications of the ruling."

The reasons cited for the immunity in the past included the undesirability of re-litigating cases that had already been decided, the fact that the lawyer owed a duty to the court as well as the client, and the "cab rank" rule, which obliges a barrister to take on any client.

But the law lords were influenced by experience in Canada and South Africa, where lawyers have no immunity from lawsuits over their court work.

A case pending at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg is widely expected to hold that immunity breaches article six of the European convention, the right to a fair hearing for civil claims. The convention will become part of UK law from October, when the Human Rights Act comes into force.

The law lords held that the immunity, which barred actions for negligence no matter how badly a barrister performed in court, no longer applied. This overturned judgments of their own court in 1967 and 1980. The issue was seen as so important that a special court of seven judges rather than the usual five heard three test cases. The judges decided unanimously that the immunity should go in civil cases. A minority of three would have kept it for criminal cases. Until yesterday, barristers could be sued for negligence in advice or paperwork, but not over anything done in court or "intimately connected" with court proceedings. The rule applied to all court advocates, including solicitors conducting cases in court. The three test cases involved negligence claims against solicitors by three dissatisfied clients, who can now go ahead with their actions. But the outcome has much greater significance for barristers, since advocacy is their core activity. The Bar Council regarded the issue as so important that it briefed two leading QCs to put the case for keeping the immunity. They argued that it was for parliament, not the judges, to decide if it should be abolished. fields.headline: Selling out to Mondeo Man
fields.standfirst:
John Prescott's great giveaway has set the scene for transport hell

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott's great giveaway has set the scene for transport hell.
fields.body:
No one can doubt that John Prescott is serious about restoring our crumbling transport infrastructure: £60bn for railways is enough to fund a railway renaissance. The plan is drawn up in the expectation that there will be a huge scale modernisation; 6,000 new trains, new stations, the clearing of railway bottlenecks to increase capacity for freight and passenger journeys. There is also real willingness to use the powers of the Strategic Rail Authority and the franchising process to improve services and control fares. Prescott deserves credit for this.

But there is a worrying emphasis on glossy, new transport projects. Much though double-decker trains, new rolling stock and even new lines are needed, they won't substantially affect car use and will mainly benefit commuters.

Eurostar's new line swallowed swaths of the transport budget and the Kent countryside. The reduced journey mainly benefits businessmen. These sorts of projects often turn into bottomless pits, gobbling up general transport budgets. Now Prescott is prioritising an urgent upgrade of the West Coast line. Typically, Virgin, the main beneficiary, has recently abandoned cheaper, flexible off-peak tickets.

Big projects and modernisation are all very well, but the vast bulk of journeys are not commuter journeys from city to city, but shorter, more complex, journeys by ordinary people. They travel across a town's outskirts, to and from shops, to schools and hospitals. Good bus routes, good connections, convenience and cheap fares make all the difference here.

Again the 10-year plan sounds good, allocating £59bn to local authorities to create coherent, environmentally-friendly plans. But £31bn of that is for local road maintenance and it also has to fund incredibly expensive new light railway schemes.

Local small-scale initiatives are the 10-year plan's poor relations. This is such a missed opportunity. Getting it right with public transport is not just about congestion-busting, but wider environmental issues. Good public transport can reverse the dominance of the car, which has destroyed the possibility of children playing in the streets or of elderly people moving safely. That is why charities such as Help the Aged, the WI, Playlink and the RNIB were campaigning with environmentalists around the 10-year plan with the Safe Streets Coalition. They favoured investment in bus and cycle lanes, speed reduction, home zones, and safe routes to school. These even make sense economically. An estimated £2.5bn would have provided safe routes to every school, far cheaper than road building, and with considerable savings in terms of children's long-term health and in accident reduction. Prescott acknowledges their value, but provides no dedicated funding.

So who has the government been listening to on transport? The answer is a litmus test for the soul of New Labour and tragically appears to be the motoring organisations and Mondeo Man. They have pitched the whole discussion in terms of "congestion-busting" rather than using transport strategy to enhance the quality of life. Only this can account for the truly horrendous scale of investment in road building.

Sixty billion has been allocated to road maintenance and building. Prescott says it will fund 100 new bypasses, and 360 miles of motorway widening. Even the Tories were only talking of 30 to 40 bypasses when forced to abandon their road building programme.

This new money goes beyond the Tories wildest dreams. It will mean reawakening controversial schemes such as the Salisbury and Hereford bypasses and the south coast "motorway by stealth". This will not just damage numerous wildlife habitats, but involve environmental damage on a devastating scale.

What on earth are they up to? All research concludes there can never be enough congestion-free roads for people to drive where and when they like. Expansion creates more traffic and simply shifts congestion points. This scale of environmental damage would be intolerable.

Does Prescott think road protesters melted away with the Tories? Or that people will see bypasses as the friendly face of road building? It was the bypass at Newbury that finished off Tory road plans. Prescott's plans mean a Newbury in every county, a recipe for civil war.

webTitle: BBC job cuts are not enough, says Smith

fields.headline: BBC job cuts are not enough, says Smith
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Plans for swingeing job cuts at the BBC, announced by director general Greg Dyke last week, did not go far enough, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans for swingeing job cuts at the BBC, announced by director general Greg Dyke last week, did not go far enough, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, said yesterday.

Mr Smith said that the 1,100 job losses to yield £750m were still a long way short of the kind of savings he was looking for over the next six years in return for agreeing to an inflation-busting increase in the licence fee.

In an interview in the New Statesman magazine, Mr Smith said: "Under Greg Dyke the BBC has begun to get its house in order. Some of the measures that Greg has announced will produce substantial efficiency savings, but he hasn't got near the £1bn of savings I am looking for."

Mr Smith appointed consultants Pannell Kerr Forster last November to review the corporation's finances and he said they would continue to scrutinise the BBC's staffing levels.

"They had a quick look for us during the Davies inquiry on the licence fee and they saw the scope for further savings," he added. "They came back to me and said: 'We've looked at this and we believe they can go an awful lot further'."

The job cuts already identified have largely been among administrative and management staff.

Mr Smith also set himself on collision course with the BBC over recent proposals to turn the corporation's four television channels into genre-based stations.

"I would be very concerned," he said. "It would alter fundamentally the crucial public service remit of the BBC."

Mr Smith's concerns were echoed by the former BBC World Service head John Tusa. In the same magazine he warned that genre-based channels would "ghettoise" arts programming.

fields.headline: BBC 'prima donnas' frustrated FO staff
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: BBC journalists represented "a larger collection of prima donnas than has ever graced Covent Garden", a senior Foreign Office diplomat noted in an internal document released yesterday at the Public Record Office.
fields.body:
BBC journalists represented "a larger collection of prima donnas than has ever graced Covent Garden", a senior Foreign Office diplomat noted in an internal document released yesterday at the Public Record Office.

The broadside came from Sir James Johnston as the FO's "news and guidance" department agonised over how best to complain to the corporation's journalists 30 years ago. Television in particular attracted "ambitious and often self-opinionated individuals out to make personal reputations for themselves", it said.

The FO also lamented that BBC journalists were subject "to no restraint equivalent to the Official Secrets Act".

It came to the conclusion that complaining all the time to top BBC executives and issuing instructions would be counterproductive. BBC staff were described as "not being amenable to regular direction".

Rather, FO officials should have "close and friendly contacts at the editorial, ie producer" level.

That, noted Johnston, would be the most effective means of "influencing the content, emphasis, and balance of BBC programmes directed at the home audience".

Other official papers released yesterday show how the US was extremely reluctant after the second world war to share nuclear secrets with Britain.

By 1957 the FO was driven to propose "full-scale integration in the fields of nuclear weapons [and] ballistic weapons".

FO officials also advised the government that it should "support the Americans in their endeavours to prevent the establishment of a fourth atomic power" - a reference to France.

fields.headline: Air comfort for broader passengers
fields.trailText: Researchers are to design a new generation of economy seats to accommodate the increasing girth of air travellers, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Researchers are to design a new generation of economy seats to accommodate the increasing girth of air travellers, it was announced yesterday.

Dean Southall, chief consultant at ICE Ergonomics in Loughborough, Leicestershire, which is carrying out the research for Europe's joint aviation authority, said yesterday that statisticians were analysing new data on passengers' leg length, stature and hip width to ensure safety - and a modest degree of comfort - for economy passengers.

A spokesman for the CAA said these and other seat design regulations were under review because more people were being crammed on an increasing number of long-haul flights than ever before.

New seats would also have to take account of taller and heavier passengers, he said.

Mr Southall said: "There is evidence that in the final decades of the last century we were getting taller and also wider.

"But in Europe and America the increase in height, caused by a change in diet, has now slowed down."

The affects of prolonged flights on health will also be considered following evidence last year of a link between long-haul flights and passengers developing blood clots.

fields.headline: Much harping over the investiture
fields.standfirst:
Public records: Papers reveal wrangles, musical and otherwise, over Prince of Wales ceremony

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The official preparations for the royal investiture of Prince Charles as Prince of Wales in 1969 was riven by behind-the-scenes disputes over who should be invited to the ceremony, where the prince might live in Wales, and whether there should be a new "order of Arthur", according to confidential Whitehall documents released yesterday.
fields.body:
The official preparations for the royal investiture of Prince Charles as Prince of Wales in 1969 was riven by behind-the-scenes disputes over who should be invited to the ceremony, where the prince might live in Wales, and whether there should be a new "order of Arthur", according to confidential Whitehall documents released yesterday.

But public record office papers show that many of the arguments paled into insignificance compared with the battle that took place between Buckingham Palace, Downing Street and Welsh ministers over a plan to appoint a royal harpist to the Prince of Wales to mark the occasion.

The row, during which Buckingham Palace condemned the idea as "somewhat archaic" and warned it would leave the monarchy open to a "certain amount of ridicule" is all the more interesting because Prince Charles has just appointed Catrin Finch, aged 20, as his official harpist.

The suggestion was first made in March 1968 by the ancient bardic Society of Cymmrodorian who proposed either a "harpist-in-ordinary to the sovereign" or a "harper to the Prince of Wales" be created to mark the occasion. It suggested that a distinguished young harpist Osian Ellis, "the acknowledged master of the instrument" and tutor of the harp at the Royal Academy, should be appointed to the job.

It was an idea which was warmly taken up by George Thomas, the Welsh Office minister, "mainly for sentimental reasons", who, as the three inch thick file of Whitehall papers shows, was prepared to press the case despite strong opposition from Buckingham Palace, Downing Street and even the Welsh Office. He was backed by the Bards of Wales.

D Morgan, a senior Welsh Office civil servant, left Downing Street in no doubt of the strength of feeling: "While there is a certain quaint appeal in the idea of reviving a royal Welsh harpist ... I suggest this is not a suitable symbol of the image which we, and possibly the royal family themselves, would want to perpetuate.

"Wales as a land of harpists and bards, stovepipe hats and similar paraphernalia is long gone, but this conception unfortunately persists abroad, and even in England, partly because of outdated souvenirs and symbols," Mr Morgan told Downing Street.

"As a result, many people do not think of Wales as a country where modern technologically-based or sophisticated entertainment can be found," he said, adding that he doubted whether a majority of Welsh people would respond favourably to such an "artificial and anachronistic" appointment.

"Even harpists in Wales - and there are, of course, few - might look upon themselves as performers of modern composition rather than individual bards playing traditional airs."

The office of Harold Wilson, the prime minister, wrote back after consulting Buckingham Palace: "The lord chamberlain feels that such an appointment might cause a certain amount of ridicule ..." George Thomas only relented when he was told there would be "a lot of trouble" with the investiture music sub-committee, who had already booked two harpists to play at the ceremony.

The row was not the only thorny question Whitehall faced over the investiture. When it was suggested Prince Charles might have an official residence in the principality, three different bids were immediately received on behalf of north, mid and south Wales. Buckingham Palace courtiers thought it better to postpone a decision.

There was also a move to create a new Welsh order, to be known as the Order of St David or Arthur, which would be made up of 24 "worthy Welshmen", but this was vetoed by the palace.

There were also efforts to familiarise Prince Charles with Wales and its history. But an attempt to help him learn Welsh by getting hold of the tapes of a television programme, Croeso Christine, was hampered when the television authorities had to admit they had wiped 22 of the 24 episodes.

And a series of lunches to meet "leading Welsh personalities" at Lancaster House in London got off to a poor start when 10 men were invited, including Harry Secombe and rugby player Cliff Jones, but "no lady guests" were present.

Post with strings attached

The post of court harpist goes back hundreds of years but little is known about those who have done the job, according to the Whitehall papers.

Robert Ap Hew served James 1 in the post in the 17th century and John Thomas of Bridgend was the last man to be appointed harpist in ordinary - to Queen Victoria in 1872 until his death in 1913.

Edward Jones, "a native of Llanderfel, Merionethshire" was the last appointed harpist to the Prince of Wales in about 1796. When the prince became King George IV in 1820, Mr Jones called him self "Bardd y Brenin" (bard to the king).

Catrin Finch, 20, from Llanon, near Aberystwyth, was appointed official harpist to Prince Charles this year after she played at his 50th birthday party in 1998.

fields.headline: Get real, boys
fields.standfirst:
The planet's in crisis all around them, but the political lobby journalists just want to trade tittle-tattle
Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: I have an uncle - an accountant - who tells me that one of the main pleasures of his life has been to read his newspaper and argue about politics. But he is now increasingly bored by his newspaper and cannot find anyone who is interested in talking about politics.
fields.body:
I have an uncle - an accountant - who tells me that one of the main pleasures of his life has been to read his newspaper and argue about politics. But he is now increasingly bored by his newspaper and cannot find anyone who is interested in talking about politics.

There is no doubt that the culture of politics is changing. Ideology has weakened. Fewer people attend political meetings. There is less passion and political activism around traditional politics. At the same time, our political news is increasingly dominated by trivia. Political journalists - the lobby - spend their time listening to gossip about who irritates whom.

My own conclusion is that political correspondents have become the gossip columnists of Westminster - not really interested in political, historical or economic change, but terribly well informed about tittle-tattle.

One in five of the 6bn people with whom we share the planet live in abject poverty. Half live on less than $2 a day. Such poverty exists at a time of unprecedented availability of capital, engineering skills and knowledge. This poverty alongside growing plenty in a globalising era must be the biggest moral challenge facing our generation.

And for those who are unconcerned about morality, it is also a challenge to our self-interest. First, the world's population has grown dramatically - from 1.6bn in 1900, to 3bn in 1960, to 6bn now. Given its age profile, it will inevitably reach 10bn, probably by 2050. This is a massive change in human civilisation and an increasing strain on the resources of the planet that has developed over a mere 100 years.

Second, post-cold war, the overwhelming majority of conflicts are taking place within developing countries. There are more refugees in the world than ever before. As Bosnia, Kosovo, Sierra Leone and East Timor show, the challenge to our armed forces and to the United Nations has been transformed.

Third, there are new diseases spreading across the world, including drug resistant malaria and TB. HIV/ Aids is the most spectacular. It is not confined to Africa - my department also has programmes in China, India and Bangladesh. HIV is spreading fast, along with drug use, in Russia. There is no cure. Anti-retroviral drugs prolong life but are very expensive and highly toxic. Scientists suggest that we should have a vaccine within 10 years. But this is by no means certain.

Fourth, strains on the environment are increasingly clear. Global warming will cause increasing turbulence and natural disasters that will endanger human life, because growing populations are living in more marginal areas. Rising sea levels will destroy islands and low-lying territory. Deserts are spreading, deforestation continues and seas are overfished. It is the poor of the world who are most affected: the 1.2bn people living in abject poverty. For the planet to have a sustainable future, poor people need sustainable livelihoods.

And 80% of the world's population live in developing countries. Business is increasingly clear that it should not restrict its ambitions to the 20% of us that live in OECD countries. Capital is accumulating as populations age and pension funds grow. These funds need outlets. The best rates of return come in emerging markets. But it isn't clear which countries will emerge, and rapid, volatile capital flows can endanger international financial stability.

Major historical change is taking place. Globalisation may only be an acceleration of forces that were at work up to the outbreak of the first world war. But since the end of the cold war, the growth and acceleration of the movement of capital, the growth of trade and the new information technologies are bringing about major change.

The role of the nation state is changing. We are struggling to create new multilateral institutions, such as the World Trade Organisation, and to strengthen controls over financial flows. Sovereignty increasingly has to be pooled in order to be exercised. Massive demonstrations broke out in Seattle and Washington and are expected later in the year in Prague at the annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The United States is in protectionist mood. The last time that happened was the 1930s.

They are interested in bigger things - who is whispering unattributable poison down the telephone against whom. Or perhaps, more importantly, which politician can be entrapped into saying something from which Number 10 might wish to distance itself at one of those very important lobby briefings that political journalists attend so assiduously.

fields.headline: Murder appeal 50 years on after
fields.trailText: A former RAF serviceman yesterday won the chance to overturn his conviction for the murder of a judge's daughter almost 50 years ago.
fields.body:
A former RAF serviceman yesterday won the chance to overturn his conviction for the murder of a judge's daughter almost 50 years ago.

The criminal cases review commission yesterday ordered the court of appeal in Belfast to reconsider Iain Hay Gordon's conviction for the murder of Patricia Curran, a 19-year-old student, at her home in Whiteabbey, north of Belfast, in 1952.

Now 68, Hay Gordon was found guilty but insane - a conviction no longer used - when he was 21.

He served seven years in a mental hospital before he was released with a new identity on the condition that he never discussed his conviction.

The case is notorious in Northern Ireland's history. Newly discovered evidence implicates Patricia's father, Sir Lancelot Curran, a high court judge and former unionist MP, in a cover-up.

Mr Gordon, who lives in Glasgow, said: "It is a big step forward. I feel a different person today."

The appeal will focus on the non-disclosure of evidence to Mr Gordon's defence team; the unreliability of his confession and the summing up of the judge, lord chief justice John McDermott, a friend of the victim's father. It is expected to take place in the autumn.

Ms Curran's body was found with 37 stab wounds. Her death was a sensation in what was then a largely crime free society. The RUC came under pressure to find her killer. Officers turned to Scotland Yard for help, and soon afterwards Mr Gordon, who was based at a nearby Edenmore base, confessed. Mr Gordon says he did so because detectives threatened to tell his mother about a recent homosexual encounter.

webTitle: Briton faces trial after boat deaths

fields.headline: Briton faces trial after boat deaths
fields.trailText: A Briton who survived a holiday boating accident on Lake Garda in which three people died is facing charges of multiple manslaughter in Italy.
fields.body:
A Briton who survived a holiday boating accident on Lake Garda in which three people died is facing charges of multiple manslaughter in Italy.

John Lilley, 44, from Aberdeen, was in charge of the pleasure boat when it overturned during a sudden storm in August 1998. Mr Lilley, his children, aged 12 and 14, and Katherine Harris, from Bedfordshire, survived by clinging to the upturned vessel for 15 hours. But Mrs Harris's husband and two sons, aged 13 and six, died.

After an eight month investigation, Mr Lilley, 44, had been accused of "shipwreck, negligence, causing disaster and multiple manslaughter", according to a spokesman at the British consulate general in Milan. He was accused of continuing to sail the boat in spite of storm conditions and of failing to ensure his passengers wore lifejackets. Six policemen and the boat's owners are also due before a hearing in Milan in September. The police have been charged with multiple manslaughter for failing to get a rescue operation underway in sufficient time. There was no attempt to scramble helicopters.

fields.headline: Diplomat's daughter held in India
fields.trailText: The 19-year-old daughter of a British diplomat in Delhi has been arrested after being caught with the son of the American naval attache trying to conceal 380 grams of cannabis resin in a slipper.
fields.body:
The 19-year-old daughter of a British diplomat in Delhi has been arrested after being caught with the son of the American naval attache trying to conceal 380 grams of cannabis resin in a slipper.

Kate Elizabeth Reid, whose father, Peter Reid, is a first secretary at the British high commission, was picked up by police on Wednesday with a friend, Andy Grussendorf, 19. He had been due to leave India yesterday.

Police said Mr Grussendorf asked a shoe shop owner to make a cavity in a thick-soled slipper. The owner tipped off the police, who were waiting when Mr Grussendorf returned to collect the shoe. Ms Reid, who had been across the road in a guest house, then intervened. "She said: 'The drugs are mine'," a police source said. She said the drugs were for their personal consumption.

The teenagers were taken to a police station, where Ms Reid apparently told detectives: "I am the daughter of a British diplomat and my friend is the son of an American diplomat." Mr Grussendorf, whose father, Captain Mark Grussendorf, had just finished his posting, produced an identity card.

The police were advised that the pair were covered by diplomatic immunity and could not be prosecuted.

Ms Reid was collected from the station by the British deputy high commissioner, Tom Macan. Two American embassy officials also took away Mr Grussendorf, who was visiting his parents during a summer vacation from a college in the US.

Under Indian law anyone convicted of possessing 380 grams of cannabis receives an automatic minimum jail sentence of 10 years. Defendants are ineligible for bail and spend months, often years, waiting for trial.
