webTitle: Watchdog orders ITV to move news at 11

fields.headline: Watchdog orders ITV to move news at 11
fields.trailText: The long running row over ITV's decision to axe News at Ten moved toward endgame last night when regulators said they would invoke legal powers to bring forward the nightly 11pm bulletin.
fields.body:
The long running row over ITV's decision to axe News at Ten moved toward endgame last night when regulators said they would invoke legal powers to bring forward the nightly 11pm bulletin.

The Independent Television Commission will publish a legally binding directive early next week outlining its demands. The regulator is concerned over a slump in ratings for ITV's news programmes since News at Ten was scrapped over a year ago.

In the past few days ITV chiefs failed in a last minute plea for more time to improve the viewing figures, which have fallen by 1.3m over the past year for the combined 6.30pm and 11pm programmes - a decline of just under 14%. ITV has refused to give ground.

The clash looks likely to head for court if, as expected, the broadcaster seeks a judicial review to establish whether it is within the regulator's ambit to force a rescheduling.

A brief statement from the ITC said ITV had "failed to satisfy" a list of demands set out after a meeting between the two sides at the end of last month. The directive will not however call for the reinstatement of News at Ten and is likely to leave room for further negotiation with ITV over a new time slot for the main nightly bulletin. The ITC is understood to see 10.30pm as a happy compromise.

ITV responded by saying it was "considering its position in the light of the ITC's statement".

News at Ten was aired for the last time in March last year to an outcry from MPs, including Gerald Kaufman and Tony Blair.

ITV argued that in an increasingly tough market it needed more flexibility in its evening schedule to show films and dramas without a break. The broadcaster is coming under increasing pressure from advertisers and hoped to arrest a decline in prime time audiences.

An insider said ITV now had nothing to lose by taking the issue to court in what would be an unprecedented battle to establish the powers of the regulator.

A month ago ITV hoped to resolve the dispute by promising to invest an extra £21m in programming during the run-up to the 11pm news, which gets better ratings if the preceding show is popular. ITV also said it would reintroduce News at Ten during election time.

The proposal was rejected and yesterday's statement from the ITC was a formal endorsement of its tough stance. "ITV must comply with what we said last month to come up with a more suitable time for the nightly news," an ITC spokesman said.

The ITC is understood to have felt that a single figure percentage decline in audiences would have been acceptable.

The BBC has hinted it may make capital from the absence of News at Ten by moving its own nightly bulletin back from 9pm to 10pm. Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC chairman, told the Commons culture, media and sports select committee last week that he would consider doing so if he thought audiences would rise.

webTitle: Strike vote by lecturers at college staff

fields.headline: Strike vote by lecturers at college staff
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lecturers at Sheffield College, one of Britain's biggest further education colleges, are to ballot for strike action next week over plans to cut up to 186 jobs in response to a report on a managerial and financial crisis at the college.
fields.body:
Lecturers at Sheffield College, one of Britain's biggest further education colleges, are to ballot for strike action next week over plans to cut up to 186 jobs in response to a report on a managerial and financial crisis at the college.

"It cannot make sense to make lecturers redundant when we need to get more people into the college," said Paul Mackney, general secretary of the National Association of Teachers in Further and Higher Education.

The 32,000 student college employs 1,241 full time staff.

In December, the further education funding council ordered an investigation into the college's failure to meet its educational targets or manage its £45m budget. Sir George Sweeney, who transformed the fortunes of Knowsley College, Liverpool, was drafted in to co-author the review and act as principal. He recommended restructuring the college and cutting staff.

webTitle: SA mine victims may sue in Britain

fields.headline: SA mine victims may sue in Britain
fields.trailText: A British company that mined asbestos in South Africa for nearly 90 years faces compensation claims of millions of pounds for causing disease to more than 3,000 black employees, after a ruling in the House of Lords yesterday.
fields.body:
A British company that mined asbestos in South Africa for nearly 90 years faces compensation claims of millions of pounds for causing disease to more than 3,000 black employees, after a ruling in the House of Lords yesterday.

Five law lords, led by Lord Bingham, yesterday unanimously decided that the workers and others living near the mines and mills may claim for personal injury or death against Cape plc of Uxbridge in the English courts.

The decision could have far-reaching consequences for British multinational companies operating in countries which do not provide state funding for legal representation in complicated cases.

Richard Meeran, principal lawyer to the claimants, who include relatives of 360 workers who died, said: "We urge Cape and its shareholders, including Equitable Life and Norwich Union, to negotiate a rapid settlement."

Cape, which has fought for three years to have the case heard in South Africa, said it would issue a statement after the directors had digested the judgment.

The law lords, reversing a court of appeal decision staying the action in England, held that claimants would be denied justice if forced to sue in South Africa. There was no convincing evidence legal aid would be available, no South African attorneys with expertise in the personal injury field had the means or would undertake the risk of working on a "no win, no fee" basis, and there were no procedures in South Africa for handling group actions, Lord Bingham said.

Cape left South Africa in 1979 and now concentrates on construction materials. Last year it made a pre-tax profit of £9.1m. It began mining blue asbestos in the Northern Cape in 1893, moving into Northern Transvaal in 1925.

In Britain hundreds of workers at Cape's factory in Barking - closed in 1968 - were given £30m compensation for asbestosis. Asbestos-related diseases can take 20 years to develop. The dangers were recognised and legislated for in the 1930s.

Although the South African government has tried to clean up the sites, the communities are still plagued by dust.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • When the Guardian reported two days ago that Caroline Thomson has been dramatically promoted from deputy MD of the World Service to BBC public policy chief (she will "lead the fight against the abolition of the board of governors"), there was no room to mention her spouse. Caroline is married to my old friend Roger Liddle, a major player in the policy arena himself, as he was heard bragging recently at a BBC dinner party, as head of Europe policy at Number 10. If Roger has half as much influence with Mr Tony as he suggests, I'm convinced that he and Caroline will take every precaution to ensure minimal crossover in their working lives. Of course they will. Anyway, well done Caroline on the promotion. First John Birt becoming an adviser on crime, now this, next week Bobby Mandelson taking over as host of One Man And His Dog... you just can't get enough of these BBC-New Labour link-ups, can you? I know I can't.

Caroline is married to my old friend Roger Liddle, a major player in the policy arena himself, as he was heard bragging recently at a BBC dinner party, as head of Europe policy at Number 10. If Roger has half as much influence with Mr Tony as he suggests, I'm convinced that he and Caroline will take every precaution to ensure minimal crossover in their working lives. Of course they will. Anyway, well done Caroline on the promotion. First John Birt becoming an adviser on crime, now this, next week Bobby Mandelson taking over as host of One Man And His Dog... you just can't get enough of these BBC-New Labour link-ups, can you? I know I can't.

 Meanwhile, three years on from so famously declaring "we were elected as New Labour, we will govern as New Labour", Mr T has apparently decided on a major alteration to the "brand". My colleague Claire Wallerstein rings Downing Street to check out the strong rumour that the party's name is changing . . . "Mm?" says the press officer, quizzically... to Snickers? Is that right? Will it be the Snickers party? The length of silence suggests an attack of Weltschmerz, and this is confirmed by the ensuing sigh. "I don't think I'm going to get into a discussion about this," says the youth eventually, and with that is gone.

 While Diary pundit Steptoe mulls over the odds on the new Speaker, a brief look at the succession to Betty Boothroyd's West Bromwich seat. While his heart may say yes, journalist Sin Simon (the elegance of whose prose very nearly disguises his Olympian sycophancy to Mr T) is thought unlikely to run, since this would cost him his big new salary as News of the World political columnist. So High Command wants to parachute in Matthew Taylor, worthy if not electrifying director of the Institute of Public Policy Research. At the first sign of any anti-control freak backlash, however, Millbank will make a tactical withdrawal and leave the seat to whoever the local party prefers.

 In a piece headlined "How I danced for Britain", Times religion correspondent Ruth Gledhill reports that she and her partner (her husband Andrew, we trust) were one of six couples selected to represent the 30s by ballroom dancing at Wednesday's marvellous pageant for the Queen Mother's 100th. "As the massed military bands played on," writes Ruth, "... my legs suddenly threatened to give way." Oh God, surely not... but, phew, no, those shaky pins recovered, and dancing to Noël Coward's Dance Little Lady "seemed to go all too quickly... It truly was an honour, an overwhelming one." Well said. You can find more on these lines, and more, at www.ruthgledhill.com.

 Thanks to Ian Bond, who faxes a photocopied invoice. "I have just returned from holiday in Italy, and attach the bill from a restaurant we found in Treviso," writes Ian. "I have no idea whether Tony Blair plans to holiday in Italy again this year [actually, he does, Ian. He's borrowing the usual Tuscan villa; the one where he had the adjoining beach closed off to the public], but if he does then this must be the place for him." If the PM is interested in Ian's suggestion, he can make a booking at the Trattoria Toni del Spin on 0039 0422 453829.

 A very warm hats off to Saddam Hussein's 21-year-old niece Fatima. According to Deutsche Welle, the German World Service equivalent, she has won the Miss Iraq beauty contest. A trim 15 stone, Fatima follows in a proud family tradition. Miss Teen Iraq, Mrs Iraq and, indeed, Miss Islamic Role Model are all Saddam's relatives too.

According to Deutsche Welle, the German World Service equivalent, she has won the Miss Iraq beauty contest. A trim 15 stone, Fatima follows in a proud family tradition. Miss Teen Iraq, Mrs Iraq and, indeed, Miss Islamic Role Model are all Saddam's relatives too.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Queen Mother gets 6m viewers
ITV's live coverage of the Queen Mother's birthday pageant was watched by an average 6.1m viewers between 5pm and 7pm on Wednesday. This represented 43% of all people watching TV, the network's highest share of viewers at that time of day since 1993.

ITV's live coverage of the Queen Mother's birthday pageant was watched by an average 6.1m viewers between 5pm and 7pm on Wednesday. This represented 43% of all people watching TV, the network's highest share of viewers at that time of day since 1993.

Hillsborough majority ruling
The jury in the Leeds crown court trial of two police officers accused of manslaughter during the Hillsborough football disaster in 1989 was told yesterday it could return a majority verdict.

Surgery recalls women patients
Eighty-three women patients have been recalled by Menston medical centre, in Ilkley, West Yorkshire, after it was discovered that equipment used for internal examinations had not been properly sterilised. The women have been offered screening for viral and bacterial infections such as HIV, hepatitis and thrush.

Spice Girls face £400,000 bill
A high court judge yesterday ordered the Spice Girls to pay Italian motor scooter manufacturer Aprilia £45,550 plus 60% of its legal costs, in a final ruling on damages and costs following the pop group's lost claim against the company, which could leave them facing a £400,000 bill.

Man held over triple murder
Police hunting the husband of a woman found murdered with her two young children arrested a man in Cumbria yesterday. The bodies of Claire Austin, 31, and her children Keiran, eight, and Jade, seven, were found in their Northampton home on Monday.

fields.headline: Fundi Konde
fields.standfirst: A legend of East African music
fields.trailText: During the postwar, pre-independence era, Kenya had a significant music industry and a plethora of performers whose songs were heard throughout Africa on radio and record. One of the early stars was Fundi Konde, who has died aged 75.
fields.body:
During the postwar, pre-independence era, Kenya had a significant music industry and a plethora of performers whose songs were heard throughout Africa on radio and record. As well as various indigenous tongues, the inter-ethnic Swahili language was a vehicle for singer-composers from across East Africa, and Nairobi became a regional centre for record companies. One of the early stars was Fundi Konde, who has died aged 75.

Konde was the first guitarist in East Africa to use an electric pick-up. He developed his guitar technique with a South African-made acoustic instrument and a tuition manual by Bert Weedon and pursued a successful career - as singer, musician and recording engineer - for more than 50 years. Many of his songs became standards and are still played by Swahili dance bands throughout East Africa.

As a child growing up in Waa, near Mombasa, Konde enjoyed the traditional nomba dance rhythms. At Catholic school he learned to read music and took up flute and clarinet to play hymns, European waltzes and foxtrots. After leaving school in 1940 he worked for the department of health, while developing his guitar skills in an informal band, playing at weddings and parties.

The most popular styles were blues, calypso and Cuban son (rumba), to which Konde introduced Swahili lyrics and local sengenya rhythms. The band graduated to playing dances where palm wine fuelled participants' enthusiasm and, when music conflicted with Konde's job, he was fired.

In 1944 he joined the King's African Rifles entertainment unit. Posted to India to entertain African, Asian and European troops, they recorded 10 songs at Calcutta's Dum Dum studio.

In 1946 Konde joined the film and music producer Peter Colmore's African Band, contributing several hits and also appearing in Colmore's film Nyimbo za Kisasa (Today's Songs).

By the early 50s, Konde was one of the most popular artistes in the region and regularly played in Tanganyika, Uganda and the Belgian Congo. During Kenya's Mau Mau emergency, he moved to Kampala in Uganda, but in 1954 returned to Nairobi to work at the African Broadcasting Service.

He moved on to HMV records as A&R man and studio engineer, recording with hundreds of musicians and releasing 30 records of his own. Among these were the hits Jambo Sigara, Kipenzi Wanui-Ua, Mama Sowera and Olivia Leo, in which Konde's deep, relaxed voice combined with sweet harmonies, simple melodies and his understated guitar to create universally popular songs.

At the Hi-Fidelity and Jambo record labels, he engineered and played on Fadhili William's massive hit version of Malaika, one of the standards of African music, internationally popularised by Miriam Makeba.

In 1963 Konde retired, to work his farm outside Malindi, but six years later he returned to Hi-Fidelity. In those days, one person would often arrange a song, tune instruments, set up sound levels, run the tape and accompany the musicians while they played, and Konde had the experience to do that effortlessly.

In 1991 he produced an album for the Nairobi pop band the Mushrooms, the success of which revived Konde's name. A year later he met Scottish music writer Ronnie Graham, then African director of Help Age International, who was setting up Shikamoo Jazz, a band of veteran musicians in Dar Es Salaam. Konde did not formally join Shikamoo but he frequently guested and shared his experience with them. Konde's records had long been unavailable and Graham made a compilation of Konde's hits which was released in 1994 for the RetroAfric label under the title Retrospective.

In 1995 Konde linked up with Shikamoo Jazz and the Zanzibari taarab queen Bi Kidude for the East African Legends tour of Britain, which included a Womad festival appearance. On their return home Konde was engaged as a special guest of Shikamoo. As a Kenyan he was liable to pay for an expensive business visa to work in Tanzania, but Graham was able to arrange for a much less costly and no less appropriate missionary visa. The authorities knew who Konde was and it is significant that they accepted his music-charity work in that category.

He is survived by two wives, Zena and Sophia, and daughter Nimuna.

Fundi Konde, musician, born August 24, 1924; died June 29, 2000

fields.headline: Escape from the helter-swelter
fields.trailText: Escape from the helter-swelter
fields.body:
"All day the heat had been barely supportable..." The first eight words of Evelyn Waugh's Los Angeles black comedy The Loved One seemed all too familiar today, so I put it straight back on the shelf. I'll re-read it when the winter sets in and I need some heat coming off the page.

Right now that's just about the last thing I want. I need cold, give me tundra, give me blizzards. I need Fargo. I need Scott of the Antarctic. I need my pin-sharp Cinemascope copy of Ice Station Zebra.

I can easily understand why Howard Hughes watched ISZ over and over in his antiseptic Las Vegas penthouse, wearing Kleenex-box slippers and clicking his banana-length Freddy Krueger fingernails on the sterilised arms of his sterilised chair. Because he was nuts? No, because he lived in the desert.

And why do I dream of avalanches, hypothermia and the soothing sound of chattering teeth? Because all day the heat has been barely supportable...

It's official. Summer's here and the time is right for slumping in our seats. All weekend the radio issued its barometer-busting temperature predictions and its dude-inflected surfcasts as citizens of California lay around in their undies, stunned, poleaxed, and rendered strangely listless and lizard-like by the warmth and humidity.

This is the time of year when the ground dries up and drives all manner of insects and beasties into your house for food and water. A friend of mine woke up on his couch one morning to find that overnight an army of ants had laid siege to the breast pocket of the shirt he'd fallen asleep in. An unbroken line of them was marching back and forth down the side of the sofa, and stretched 20ft across the hardwood floor to a tiny crack in his window.

Waking up, he found his chest was a seething blur, and on closer examination he found that the ants were feasting on a piece of chicken that had fallen out of a taco he'd eaten the night before.

Last summer, I had all manner of thirsty critters coming in through the catflap to drink out of my cat's food and water bowls. First there was the possum, a foot-long rodent with a pink pointy head. It looked at me blankly as I vainly implored it to bugger off. He left in his own good time, and on a full stomach, if you please.

Then there was the skunk, which would be one of my favourite cuddly animals were it not for the fabled stench. Roused from my bed in the wee small hours, and thinking that my cat was hissing at a burglar, I tiptoed naked into the kitchen brandishing a baseball bat, and flicked on the lights just as the skunk raised its tail.

That spray can ruin your whole week even if you're fully dressed, so I flung myself sideways into the bathroom and slammed the door. I nearly broke my neck but I came up smelling of roses. I thought the cat was a goner, but the skunk was freaked by the slamming door and legged it into the night.

Relief from the heat can be sought in people's pools or at the beach, although the Beach Boys' Endless Summer ideal of sand and surf-bunnies has clouded over somewhat in recent years. There are gang rumbles on the dunes these days, and occasional shootings on the Venice Broadwalk. The Hyperion sewage plant south of Santa Monica sometimes malfunctions and vomits meningitis-bearing sludge into the surf, causing swimming to be banned.

The beach is now totally off limits after dark. When I first visited LA nearly 20 years ago, I slept on Zuma beach for 10 days without a problem. If I tried that now I'd be spotted by one of the police gunships that patrol the shore, and issue tickets for trespassing.

Mainly the heat just makes you lazy and sleepy. The oddest things strike you as perfectly normal, like the fully-laden hearse I saw using a Burger King drive-thru this afternoon. Actually that makes perfect sense: Forest Lawn cemetery is only a few blocks away, ringed by retirement homes, casket-builders, geriatric hospitals, flower shops, temp agencies for terminal nursing staff, funeral parlours and headstone designers - Glendale is a veritable city of the dead or soon-to-be-dead.

Then there was the 90-minute live-as-it-happened freeway pursuit that preoccupied me in the middle of the day. Whenever he came anywhere near my neighbourhood, I could hear the roar of eight police choppers and five news-copters that tracked his progress and transmitted it to my telly.

I was too lazy and flattened by the heat to go and look out the window. I was too lazy to change channels until it was over. When I did I heard the worrying and painful-sounding headline: "Gore Catches Bush in Polls!"

Gosh. I hope he's all better in time for the Democratic convention here next month, which I think falls in the same week as another summer highlight: my annual pilgrimage up to Cielo Drive, the site of the 1969 Charles Manson-Sharon Tate murders. You should have been there last year for the 30-year anniversary. My, what a gathering of the freaks that was.

And X-Men, another gathering of the freaks, albeit a rather poorly-reviewed one, was the big box-office winner this weekend, taking in an almost unprecedented $57m. I suspect that along with the millions who came primarily for the air-conditioning, every geek in America also turned out, either mindlessly cheering at the special effects or mindlessly tut-tutting as they found out that their favourite X-Man hadn't made the cut.

My personal fave was Halle Berry as Storm. To hell with the other characters' special powers, like nuclear halitosis and Midwich Cuckoos-style beams of blinding light; Storm, like Sean Connery in that rotten Avengers remake, can change the weather. Perhaps she could come over to my house and make it rain in my back garden for an hour every afternoon until Labor Day.

webTitle: How Fatty Arbuckle fell for me

fields.headline: How Fatty fell for me
fields.standfirst: When Addie Sheldon met and married Roscoe 'Fatty' Arbuckle he was a scandal-ridden Hollywood outcast. As she turns 95, she tells Austin M Mewse that her husband died a happy man
fields.trailText: When Addie Sheldon met and married Roscoe 'Fatty' Arbuckle he was a scandal-ridden Hollywood outcast. As she turns 95, she tells Austin M Mewse that her husband died a happy man
fields.body:
Just as the movies were beginning to talk, Addie Sheldon met the comedian Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle on the set of a film he was directing for Educational Pictures called Up a Tree in 1931, in which she was to star. She started work in the 1920s, known as Addie McPhail, in Gower Street, a line of low-budget studios dubbed Poverty Row.

It was a momentous meeting: "I had feelings for Roscoe," says Addie, who's just turned 95. "We worked together for several months at the studio before we even had lunch together. Even then, it was at the studio commissary, so the rest of the cast and the director were there too, so you might say that love came slowly for me. For Roscoe it was completely different - he had seen two of my movies, Midnight Daddies [1929] and Three Sisters [1930], and had immediately fallen in love with me. I believe at the time he was dating the heiress Dorothy Wallace. It was a short-lived affair. He had been married twice before."

Arbuckle had spent 10 years adrift since he became involved in the first scandal to shake Hollywood when a wild party in San Francisco ended in a starlet called Virginia Rappe meeting a gruesome death. There are many versions of what happened, but widespread rumours alleged that Arbuckle had forced himself on her and accidentally suffocated her while having sex.

He denied the charges and claimed he had no part in the affair. But it was too late: his name was anathema to every women's group and church organisation in America. In her 1980 autobiography, Swanson on Swanson, Gloria Swanson wrote: "The newspapers had proved in less than a week that the public got a much greater thrill out of watching stars fall than out of watching them shine. One day Fatty Arbuckle had been their most beloved comedian next to Chaplin; the next day they were screaming for his head."

Although he was cleared by a jury, the public had decided Arbuckle was guilty. After the court case, he disappeared. "Roscoe was in the wilderness for 10 years," Addie recalls. "The stock market crash of October 1929 hit him hard. He sold his nightclub and attempted a comeback as a film director under the pseudonym of William Goodrich. That is when we met. He rarely spoke about the scandal to me. I know he didn't want me to feel any sympathy for him. I didn't. Roscoe neither needed it nor wanted it."

In Kevin Brownlow's book The Parade's Gone By, actress Louise Brooks recalled meeting Arbuckle: "I was working at Educational Pictures in May 1931. He made no attempt to direct the picture. He sat in his chair like a man dead. It was such an amazing thing for me to come in to make this broken-down picture [Windy Riley Goes to Hollywood] and to find my director was the great Roscoe Arbuckle. Oh, I thought he was magnificent in films. He was a wonderful dancer, a wonderful ballroom dancer, in his heyday. It was like floating in the arms of a huge doughnut - really delightful."

Addie saw Arbuckle as a jolly, big-hearted man. She had seen him in comedies with Mabel Normand when her mother took her to the movies as a young girl. "I never gave the whole affair a thought," she said. "He hated people calling him Fatty. That was a character. After the scandal broke, I don't think he minded what people called him as long as they called."

Addie McPhail was born in White Plains, Kentucky, on July 15, 1905. Her father was in the insurance business. He moved his family around America almost every two years. "We settled in many small towns. In 1911, daddy took us to Chicago, Illinois."

Addie loved the movies. In November 1925, the family was uprooted again, this time to Hollywood. "I had already decided that I wanted to be an actress, so I thought this move was fate." Addie began working less than two weeks after her arrival in Hollywood. "I came to Hollywood by the Santa Fe train. It was a very clean town in 1925.

"I signed a contract for the Stern Brothers comedies. When I wasn't working for them, they allowed me to go off and work as an extra doing bits for other studios in order for me to become acquainted with the profession. I was a stranger in Hollywood so it was only my appearance that opened doors, although they never opened very wide. Maybe I was never the actress I wanted to be." Addie felt her career would consist largely of having custard pies thrown in her face: "The rough and tumble of comedy was hard, it eventually cooled my ardour for acting."

For Arbuckle, on the other hand, the tide began to turn in September 1931, when Motion Picture magazine ran an article under the heading: Doesn't Fatty Arbuckle Deserve a Break? Director James Cruze was quoted as saying he was willing to direct the comedian in a movie and not take a cent of salary. Other movie people rallied to his side, including Buster Keaton, Marion Davies and Laurel and Hardy. The public joined the stars in support. It seemed that a new generation was about to forgive the man.

By this time, Addie was engaged to Arbuckle and was working with him on a vaudeville tour. "Roscoe was warmly received, even in Montreal and Quebec, and met with only a little opposition. He wanted to prove to himself that he had been missed."

In February, 1932, a call came through from Jack Warner offering him the chance to perform in front of the camera again under his real name. "Roscoe felt he had been given his life back. It was the call he had been waiting 11 years for. The Hays office was still wary of public opinion, and wanted to wait and see if they would forgive him before allowing Warner Bros to thrust him back into the limelight." Two months later, in Erie, Pennsylvania, the couple woke up the justice of the peace and were married.

The two celebrated their first wedding anniversary together in a New York restaurant. "Roscoe told Rivkin [his agent] that it was the happiest day of his life. We left the restaurant some time after midnight, Roscoe had a headache. Back at the hotel, Roscoe was laughing about something that had been said earlier that evening. He was really belly laughing, even when he got into bed. I went to the bathroom, I was calling out to him, on the way out I was still talking. Still he did not answer me. He was very peaceful. Looked as if he had fallen asleep. Then I realised, he was dead!"

Roscoe Arbuckle died at 2.15am on June 29, 1933. He was 46. Hollywood mourned his death. The actor and humorist Will Rogers said at the time: "Those who demanded their pound of flesh finally received their satisfaction. Roscoe 'Fatty' Arbuckle accommodated them by dying from a broken heart."

"What really surprised people was the fact that Roscoe never held any malice," Addie recalls. "All he wanted to do was to make people laugh. His sudden death left me feeling devastated for a long while." During the 30s, Addie attempted her own comeback, but it did not last. After only a handful of films, her last being Northwest Passage in 1940, with Spencer Tracy and Ruth Hussey, Addie retired. "It was over for me. I don't believe I ever did anything spectacular enough in pictures or on stage to be remembered for it. I was like a small ship passing through a rough sea."

Today, Addie lives not 20 miles from Hollywood in a modest apartment block. Until recently, she worked as a volunteer nurse at the Motion Picture and Television country house and hospital in Woodland Hills, California. "I was extremely happy in my 17 years of volunteer service. Some of the patients I knew from my time in Hollywood, or they knew Roscoe. When I reminded Norma Shearer, Caryl Lincoln, Viola Dana, Stepin Fetchit and others who I was, they would always smile and say something good about Roscoe."

While Arbuckle's fall is well-known, the happy ending to his life is not. "I believe Roscoe died happy," Addie concludes. "He was with a girl who loved him and Hollywood had forgiven him and welcomed him back."

For Roscoe it was completely different - he had seen two of my movies, Midnight Daddies [1929] and Three Sisters [1930], and had immediately fallen in love with me. I believe at the time he was dating the heiress Dorothy Wallace. It was a short-lived affair. He had been married twice before." Arbuckle had spent 10 years adrift since he became involved in the first scandal to shake Hollywood when a wild party in San Francisco ended in a starlet called Virginia Rappe meeting a gruesome death. There are many versions of what happened, but widespread rumours alleged that Arbuckle had forced himself on her and accidentally suffocated her while having sex. He denied the charges and claimed he had no part in the affair. But it was too late: his name was anathema to every women's group and church organisation in America. In her 1980 autobiography, Swanson on Swanson, Gloria Swanson wrote: "The newspapers had proved in less than a week that the public got a much greater thrill out of watching stars fall than out of watching them shine. One day Fatty Arbuckle had been their most beloved comedian next to Chaplin; the next day they were screaming for his head." Although he was cleared by a jury, the public had decided Arbuckle was guilty. After the court case, he disappeared. "Roscoe was in the wilderness for 10 years," Addie recalls. "The stock market crash of October 1929 hit him hard. He sold his nightclub and attempted a comeback as a film director under the pseudonym of William Goodrich. That is when we met. He rarely spoke about the scandal to me. I know he didn't want me to feel any sympathy for him. I didn't. Roscoe neither needed it nor wanted it." In Kevin Brownlow's book The Parade's Gone By, actress Louise Brooks recalled meeting Arbuckle: "I was working at Educational Pictures in May 1931. He made no attempt to direct the picture. He sat in his chair like a man dead. It was such an amazing thing for me to come in to make this broken-down picture [Windy Riley Goes to Hollywood] and to find my director was the great Roscoe Arbuckle. Oh, I thought he was magnificent in films. He was a wonderful dancer, a wonderful ballroom dancer, in his heyday. It was like floating in the arms of a huge doughnut - really delightful." Addie saw Arbuckle as a jolly, big-hearted man. She had seen him in comedies with Mabel Normand when her mother took her to the movies as a young girl. "I never gave the whole affair a thought," she said. "He hated people calling him Fatty. That was a character. After the scandal broke, I don't think he minded what people called him as long as they called." Addie McPhail was born in White Plains, Kentucky, on July 15, 1905. Her father was in the insurance business. He moved his family around America almost every two years. "We settled in many small towns. In 1911, daddy took us to Chicago, Illinois." Addie loved the movies. In November 1925, the family was uprooted again, this time to Hollywood. "I had already decided that I wanted to be an actress, so I thought this move was fate." Addie began working less than two weeks after her arrival in Hollywood. "I came to Hollywood by the Santa Fe train. It was a very clean town in 1925. "I signed a contract for the Stern Brothers comedies. When I wasn't working for them, they allowed me to go off and work as an extra doing bits for other studios in order for me to become acquainted with the profession. I was a stranger in Hollywood so it was only my appearance that opened doors, although they never opened very wide. Maybe I was never the actress I wanted to be." Addie felt her career would consist largely of having custard pies thrown in her face: "The rough and tumble of comedy was hard, it eventually cooled my ardour for acting." For Arbuckle, on the other hand, the tide began to turn in September 1931, when Motion Picture magazine ran an article under the heading: Doesn't Fatty Arbuckle Deserve a Break? Director James Cruze was quoted as saying he was willing to direct the comedian in a movie and not take a cent of salary. Other movie people rallied to his side, including Buster Keaton, Marion Davies and Laurel and Hardy. The public joined the stars in support. It seemed that a new generation was about to forgive the man. By this time, Addie was engaged to Arbuckle and was working with him on a vaudeville tour. "Roscoe was warmly received, even in Montreal and Quebec, and met with only a little opposition. He wanted to prove to himself that he had been missed." In February, 1932, a call came through from Jack Warner offering him the chance to perform in front of the camera again under his real name. "Roscoe felt he had been given his life back. It was the call he had been waiting 11 years for. The Hays office was still wary of public opinion, and wanted to wait and see if they would forgive him before allowing Warner Bros to thrust him back into the limelight." Two months later, in Erie, Pennsylvania, the couple woke up the justice of the peace and were married. The two celebrated their first wedding anniversary together in a New York restaurant. "Roscoe told Rivkin [his agent] that it was the happiest day of his life. We left the restaurant some time after midnight, Roscoe had a headache. Back at the hotel, Roscoe was laughing about something that had been said earlier that evening. He was really belly laughing, even when he got into bed. I went to the bathroom, I was calling out to him, on the way out I was still talking. Still he did not answer me. He was very peaceful. Looked as if he had fallen asleep. Then I realised, he was dead!" Roscoe Arbuckle died at 2.15am on June 29, 1933. He was 46. Hollywood mourned his death. The actor and humorist Will Rogers said at the time: "Those who demanded their pound of flesh finally received their satisfaction. Roscoe 'Fatty' Arbuckle accommodated them by dying from a broken heart." "What really surprised people was the fact that Roscoe never held any malice," Addie recalls. "All he wanted to do was to make people laugh. His sudden death left me feeling devastated for a long while." During the 30s, Addie attempted her own comeback, but it did not last. After only a handful of films, her last being Northwest Passage in 1940, with Spencer Tracy and Ruth Hussey, Addie retired. "It was over for me. I don't believe I ever did anything spectacular enough in pictures or on stage to be remembered for it. I was like a small ship passing through a rough sea." Today, Addie lives not 20 miles from Hollywood in a modest apartment block. Until recently, she worked as a volunteer nurse at the Motion Picture and Television country house and hospital in Woodland Hills, California. "I was extremely happy in my 17 years of volunteer service. Some of the patients I knew from my time in Hollywood, or they knew Roscoe. When I reminded Norma Shearer, Caryl Lincoln, Viola Dana, Stepin Fetchit and others who I was, they would always smile and say something good about Roscoe." While Arbuckle's fall is well-known, the happy ending to his life is not. "I believe Roscoe died happy," Addie concludes. "He was with a girl who loved him and Hollywood had forgiven him and welcomed him back."

fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: Limbo | Sleepy Hollow | Angela's Ashes
fields.trailText: Limbo | Sleepy Hollow | Angela's Ashes
fields.body:
Limbo
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
*****

A film of two halves from the estimable John Sayles, who was writer, editor and director, and unusually, is the only name on the front of the sleeve. The first half introduces a set of believable characters with messy lives and lets you gradually work out the connections and relationships between them.

Sayles's strengths are all here: working individuals with real-life problems, talking like real people. Sayles's dialogue often reminds you how artificial and plot-driven most big-screen debate is. The focus eventually narrows down to three main characters - David Strathairn (a Sayles regular all the way back to his debut) as a defensive ex-fisherman gradually getting involved with Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio's brittle singer and her resentful daughter, Vanessa Martinez. Everything looks set for a gritty relationship drama but the arrival of Strathairn's half-brother (Casey Siemaszko) sets the film on a different course: tense and gripping to the end.

Siemaszko is rather too obviously a man you wouldn't trust to tell you the time of day, but the three principals are excellent and Martinez, who had a small role in Sayles's hit Lone Star, increasingly steals the show as the fevered Noelle. Mastrantonio and Strathairn pull off a believably awkward relationship, and the former also sings her own songs creditably in a vaguely Emmylou Harris mode and has a very fine speech explaining why she is a singer.

The plot works its way towards an unusual final scene Sayles describes as "the only ending that was right for the film". I know this because he has a typically lucid and unpretentious commentary on the whole movie on the DVD which would make an excellent "how to do it" guide for any budding film-maker. Limbo is set in Alaska which, filmed by Haskell Wexler, looks as rugged as Kris Kristofferson, another Lone Star star, who has a small but crucial role here.

Sleepy Hollow
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Fox Pathé Cert 15
****

Tim Burton is the director, a virtual guarantee of a great-looking film, and his Gothic imagination is let rip to good effect once more. His blood-soaked take on Washington Irving takes the story firmly into his own world complete with Christopher Lee and three Gs of grotesque gothery, (Gambon, Griffiths and Gough).

This is Hammer crossed with Monty Python's Black Knight sketch. Johnny Depp is the constable out of his depth when he is sent to investigate mysterious goings-on, in a role not unlike his accountant in Dead Man. He is provided with weird and wonderful detecting equipment but is no match for the headless horseman, who prefers everyone to end at the neck. When the horseman does have a head it's Christopher Walken's and even scarier. The plot is convoluted, but with Christina Ricci and Miranda Richardson on hand along with a Frankenstein-style windmill and lots of spectacular effects, it's fun to let it wash over you. Heads you win. The DVD includes interviews with Burton and cast members.

Angela's Ashes
Rental
Universal Cert 15
**

The film starts with a quote: "Worse than the ordinary miserable childhood is the miserable Irish childhood and worse yet is the miserable Irish Catholic childhood." It goes on to prove the point with lashings of rain, poverty, desperation, fleas, cold, premature death, and more rain.

Angela's Ashes has every hardship cliché in the book and makes it hard to see why Frank McCourt's Pulitzer prize-winning novel was so successful. Alan Parker assembles a fine cast, with Robert Carlyle, Emily Watson and three talented Frankies at different ages, but the poverty is ladled on with what, ironically, looks like great expense; and it's hard not to compare this long, laboured wallow in gloom with the freshness and surprising insights Lynne Ramsay brought to the same set-up (feckless drunk father and suffering family) in Ratcatcher recently, for a fraction of the cost.

fields.headline: Charlie Creed-Miles
fields.trailText: Charlie Creed-Miles
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw? Star Wars - a ride from start to finish.

What's your favourite film? American Beauty. It's exemplary and emotionally nourishing.

When was the last time you walked out? I would have during Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, but I was with the cast and crew. The whole thing was distasteful.

When did you last hide under your seat? During the first 20 minutes of Saving Private Ryan. I thought I was heading for a panic attack and would need an oxygen mask.

When was the last time you cried? Kes - the plight of the child and when his bird is killed by his brother. I'm also ashamed to say I shed a few tears at the end of The English Patient. Emotionally it worked.

What was the cinema's most erotic moment? Sharon Stone in Basic Instinct. The crossing legs scene - phwoarr. She has such power over the men in the room and men in the audience.

What's your favourite snatch of dialogue? "I don't think it's nice, you laughin'. You see, my mule don't like people laughin'. He gets the crazy idea you're laughin' at him. Now if you apologise, like I know you're going to, I might convince him that you really didn't mean it." Joe (Clint Eastwood) in A Fistful of Dollars.

Which actor would you like to be? It has to be between Jack Nicholson and Kevin Spacey. They are both ultimately watchable, charismatic and effortless performers.

Which actress? Annette Bening, she's superb in everything.

You play the lead in Essex Boys, would you agree Essex is the lead character? It plays an important part, it's all about Essex, so that's an understatement. The film captures its aura, the broad spectrum and mixture of new towns and wide-open spaces. Essex is the land of opportunity for its history and a visually stunning, fascinating place.

Are you ever mistaken for a teenager? It's marvellous to hear that I could be. A friend of mine saw Essex Boys and he told me at last I'd come of age and looked like a man.

 Charlie Creed-Miles stars in Essex Boys, on general release.

fields.headline: How to be a Euro-villain
fields.standfirst: Have you got what it takes to be a Hollywood bad guy? If you're British, says US writer Justine Elias, you're already halfway there
fields.trailText: Have you got what it takes to be a Hollywood bad guy? If you're British, says US writer Justine Elias, you're already halfway there
fields.body:
Dear British person: could you could be the next Euro- villain? Are you a crown subject? Have you performed leading roles with an internationally recognised theatre company? If you answered yes to both questions, you are hereby eligible to portray a villain in a major Hollywood film. In accordance with the laws of the European Union, the British villain will now be known as the Euro-villain - but we all know, deep down, that he's British to the core. Adhere to the following guidelines and you'll be well on your way.

Choose your character

Type A: Sneering, disdainful, urbane villain who wants to regain his degenerate aristocratic family's squandered fortune while grinding everyone else down into the dirt. (Examples: James Mason, Alan Rickman, Dirk Bogarde, Paul Scofield, Ralph Fiennes in Schindler's List, Jason Isaacs in The Patriot.)

Type B: Sneering, resentful working-class villain who rages against those who made his father a snivelling failure, his mother a whore, and generally kept him down in the dirt all his life. (Examples: Steven Berkoff, Tim Roth, Gary Oldman, Robert Carlyle, currently Vinnie Jones in Gone in 60 Seconds.)

Now select your fashion statement

1 A brilliantly tailored suit.
2 Military uniform.
3 Leather and haute couture, rock-star style.
4 Leather, S&M-style neo-Nazi garb.
5 Modern, stylish, with vague suggestion of bisexuality.

Now hone your physical appearance. (Note: pale complexion, cut-glass cheekbones and thin lips are mandatory equipment for the Euro-villain.)

1 A body that's long, lean, and mean.
2 A body that's scrawny, scrappy, and undernourished.
3 Very white, very sharp teeth.
4 Bad teeth (it hardly matters, since you rarely smile, except in thin-lipped disgust).
5 Bare chest with nipple ring.
6 Bare chest with scary tattoos.
7 Long hair (unwashed).
8 Long hair (silky, clean, conditioned).
9 Traditional skinhead.
10 Satanic little beard.
11 Pencil-thin moustache.
12 Prominent but not unattractive facial scar.

You may now choose your Euro-villain minions and henchmen

1 Two large steroid freaks (Are they brothers? Lovers? Robots? You decide!).
2 Silent black man with spectacles and a gun.
3 Viking goddess with vaguely lesbian aura and a gun.
4 Faceless Red Army drones.
5 The Third Reich.
6 The Green Dragoons.
7 A brutal, unappreciated lieutenant who'll eventually turn against you because you slighted him once too often.

Now choose your Euro-villain sex partner

1 European slut.
2 Eurasian slut.
3 Russian slut.
4 Cyberpunk slut.
5 Cute boy, nationality unspecified.
6 Your sister.
7 Your mother.
8 A magnificent horse, which you groom and console after your first run-in with the hero ("There, there, my lovely girl - you're nice and clean now, aren't you, Vanessa?").

When you're not killing, thieving and fucking, what do you like to play with?

1 A pair of enormous hounds representing a nation that Americans find intimidating (German shepherd, doberman, Rhodesian ridgeback, Chow, Russian wolfhound, great Dane, French poodle) - which the hero will later shoot in self-defence or tempt away with treats.
2 Valuable art objects and fine home furnishings, which the hero will later smash to bits.
3 Your own long, silky, manageable hair, which you - at your toilette - like to see falling around your shoulders, so that you can gaze fondly at your reflection in the mirror as though it were some really hot chick looking back at you.

Now choose your Euro-villain weapon

1 Something small and silver with a clip.
2 Something big and black with a clip.
3 Silver-headed cane.
4 Scimitar.
5 Nuclear warhead.
6 Futuristic laser weapon.
7 Infernal armageddon device.
8 Unrelieved sarcasm.
9 The ability to leer at anything, at any time, even with your eyes closed.

Next, tell us what turns you on

1 Power, money.
2 More money.
3 More money than you could possibly imagine, you fool!
4 Violence.
5 Sex.
6 Violent sex.
7 Watching things go boom!
8 Bringing colonists with pitchforks to their knees.
9 Bringing the fascist US of A to its knees.
10 The possibility of a knighthood.
11 The mere fact that you, the Euro-villain, are just plain mean like a snake.

When you come face to face with the hero, get ready to say something clever

1 "So... we meet at last."
2 "You'll never get out of here alive."
3 "No one kills him but me."
4 "Foolish Americans, always believing that your ridiculous idealism will triumph over a superior culture!"
5 "Was that your son I killed? Stupid boy - just like his father."
6 (Indicating pile of corpses) "Friends of yours?"
7 "You and I are just alike, you know."
8 "I have waited for this moment as a bridegroom awaits his bride."
9 "Goodbye, Mr Bond."

Finally, it' s time for you to die like the cowardly Euro-villain dog that you are. You will be

1 Strangled or hanged.
2 Shot at close range, but not before you've gone a few rounds with the hero.
3 Shot from across the room, just as you're about to rape the hero's girlfriend.
4 Thrown from the roof of a tall building.
5 Shot, and as you stagger backwards into a vat of deadly acid, you realise, just for a moment, that you aren't going to be pretty any more.
6 Doused with gasoline and set on fire by the hero, who says something unkind just before he tosses the match.
7 Run through with a sword, leaving you just enough time to say something snotty and unkind before you expire.
8 Shot, then stabbed, hanged, run through with a sword, set on fire and then you fall off a tall building, screaming all the way down - until you are impaled, horribly, on some giant spike that just happens to be there.
9 Blown up by your own infernal armageddon device.

For your efforts, you will be rewarded with the following: fantastic reviews, which rave about how you stole the movie from under the nose of the boring US movie star; hundreds of Hollywood offers to play characters like the one you just played; the enduring enmity of British journalists, who will chastise you for disgracing your country; a brief, scandalous affair with the US actress who plays the hero's simpering girlfriend; an Academy award nomination for best supporting actor; the possibility of a knighthood, somewhere down the line. It may take a while to make your mark, Euro-villain, so keep practising that sneer. But in the meantime, nobody can say you haven' t got style.

 The Patriot is on general release. Gone in 60 Seconds is out on August 4.

 Film Unlimited Brit bashing quiz.

It may take a while to make your mark, Euro-villain, so keep practising that sneer. But in the meantime, nobody can say you haven' t got style.  The Patriot is on general release. Gone in 60 Seconds is out on August 4.  Film Unlimited Brit bashing quiz.

webTitle: Cut and thrust Currys challenges Wal-Mart superstore

fields.headline: Cut and thrust Currys challenges Wal-Mart superstore
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Currys yesterday became the first retail chain to issue a direct challenge to Wal-Mart, the American group attempting to woo British shoppers with rock-bottom prices.
fields.body:
Currys yesterday became the first retail chain to issue a direct challenge to Wal-Mart, the American group attempting to woo British shoppers with rock-bottom prices.

In a move that could herald a full scale price war, Currys said it would undercut Wal-Mart by at least £10 in its stores around Bristol, where Wal-Mart opens its first British outlet on Monday.

Currys' price guarantee covers any electrical goods priced by Wal-Mart at more than £200; it is calculated to lessen the impact of Wal-Mart's entry into the British market.

The US chain has come up with a list of ploys to attract shoppers, including a "brolly patrol" to shelter customers from the rain, greeters to welcome shoppers on arrival and Bristol Rovers footballers to act as shopping bag packers.

Wal-Mart's move comes a year after it took over Asda. Its Bristol store (above), to be called Asda Wal-Mart Supercentre, will be the first of three warehouse-style outlets stocking goods ranging from food to bikes and gardening equipment.

Many prices will be 30% to 40% cheaper than rivals'. Among the offers will be Ray-Ban sunglasses for £29.99, widescreen televisions for £349 and five litres of paint for £4.97.

webTitle: Taking art to the people:  National Gallery plans shopping mall exhibition

fields.headline: Taking art to the people:  National Gallery plans shopping mall exhibition
fields.trailText: The National Gallery is preparing to embrace mall culture, taking an exhibition of works from its collection matched with drawings by artist, author and poet Quentin Blake to the Bluewater shopping centre in Kent.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The National Gallery is preparing to embrace mall culture, taking an exhibition of works from its collection matched with drawings by artist, author and poet Quentin Blake to the Bluewater shopping centre in Kent.

Bluewater, which has quotations from Shakespeare and Milton built into the aisles, was an obvious first choice, but the gallery director, Neil MacGregor, said they were ready to continue the experiment. "We will go on if we are asked - we are poised to go from mall to mall."

Quentin Blake, renowned for his collaboration with the late Roald Dahl, is currently the first children's laureate.

For the exhibition, Tell Me a Story, he has chosen 26 pictures which should lure visitors, particularly children, to explore the stories in the paint. They include works by Jack Yeats and Paula Rego, Uccello's Saint George and the Dragon, and one of the most haunting and mysterious paintings in the collection, Piero di Cosimo's A Satyr Mourning over a Dead Nymph - which features a distinctly Quentin Blakeish dismal hound.

The exhibition will be seen first at the National Gallery next spring, and then, using prints, photographs and pieces written by young visitors, at Bluewater - the gallery says the originals could not be displayed safely in a shopping centre.

The National Gallery, which launched its annual review yesterday, is on a roll, with 5m visitors last year, and 2.5m up to June this year.

The runaway success was its millennium exhibition of religious art, Seeing Salvation, which attracted 300,000 people.
